column2: DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -A defenseman, Ron Stackhouse, tallied for Detroit with just 2:36 remaining tonight, gaining a 3-3 tie for the Wings with the Vancouver Canucks. Marcel Dionne, Detroit's leading scorer with 34 points, was not in uniform and the team announced he had been suspended indefinitely for not appearing for the game.

May I refer to your news story of Nov. 18: "Steady streams of opium and hashish flow over the unpatrolled and porous borders" of Afghanistan, "aided by a largely indifferent Government and many of its officials and employes."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Robert Schwarz Strauss, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, comes out of the classic tradition of bright, likable small-town boys who made it big because they could not bear to look back. "
CAVE CITY, Ark. -- Joseph Harry Weston, 61 years old, is a one-man terrorist band. His weapon is a weekly newspaper, and he runs it on the creed that all the outrage he can muster is fit to print.

Is it possible, in a few words, to explain why the John Brownlee Opera Theater production of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" at the Manhattan School of Music Saturday night was the most completely satisfying this reviewer has ever experienced here or abroad?

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- As the Soviet Union has moved toward improved relations with the West this year, its secret police have mounted a determined campaign of repression against the domestic dissident movement that has left some dissenters feeling weaker, more vulnerable and more on the defensive than at any other time since the mid-nineteen-sixties.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened its 61st annual appeal yesterday with $331,146.03 already donated by estates, trust funds and 204 mail contributors.
The prospect of higher interest rates confronts the nation's money markets this week.

TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- Immobilized on the left by Governor Cahill's liberal Republican record and inspired by what they perceive as a conservative swing in New Jersey, a number of potential Democratic candidates for Governor have begun a race to the right for their party's nomination in the June Democratic gubernatorial primary election.

Three New Jersey divisions of the ITT Continental Baking Company resumed operations yesterday following the settlement of a month-old strike. But their products were not expected to reach retail stores until tomorrow.
Encouraged by the City Council's Democratic leaders, Angelo J. Arculeo, Brooklyn Republican, expects to regain next month the Council minority leadership post he previously held for seven years.

Margot Johnson has arrow-straight brows, a strong profile and center-parted dark hair. People are always asking her if she has American Indian blood, particularly when she wears her beaded braid ornaments to parties. Actually, her ancestry is Icelandic, but when she was growing up in North Dakota, she invariably found herself cast as the Indian in her playmates' games.

Two New Jersey youths were shot and slightly wounded after a fist fight with a group of Staten Island youths Saturday night in the Huguenot section of Staten Island, the police of the Tottenville station reported.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 11 -Premier Kakuei Tanaka's Liberal-Democratic party has been returned to power with a solid, although unspectacular, victory in nationwide elections.

A survey of American business leaders, released here yesterday, disclosed that four out of five top executives would be opposed to a decision of the Securities and Exchange Commission that companies be required to tell investors how much money they expected to earn.

VENICE, Italy, Dec. 19 -Thieves broke into the cathedral of Castelfranco Veneto, northwest of here, last night and stole Giorgione's painting "The Madonna With SS. Liberalis and Francis." The disappearance of the celebrated work -- one of the few attributed with certainty to Giorgione and believed to date from 1504 -- caused consternation throughout Italy.

The performance of Handel's "Messiah" by the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra at Philharmonic Hall yesterday afternoon went at that splendid work in an essentially Victorian way, with chorus of more than 200 voices, but it steered clear of the worst excesses of the hearty roast-beef style.

According to recently reported "disclosures" by Ladislas Farago in The London Daily Express and reprinted in United States newspapers, it appears that history may again be subverted to the cause of sensationalism. I refer to Farago's claim that Martin Bormann arranged for transshipment from Germany to Argentina of a treasure for his personal account which amounted to $200 million.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two Soviet grandmasters, Tigran Petrosian and Anatoly Karpov, whisked through draws with their opponents today and settled for a three-way tie for first place with Hungary's driving Lajor Portisch in the final standings of the Church's Fried Chicken international chess tournament.
CAMDEN, Dec. 10 -- If Newark carries out its declared intention to ask the new session of the New Jersey Legislature for financial help to avert bankruptcy, it will not be alone.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A new kind of trade legislation, including a system of safeguards for industries and workers damaged by steeply rising imports, has strong backing within the Administration.
BONN, Dec. 10 -- Fried, Krupp, Gmbh, the vast and renowned West German concern based in Essen, is apparently having financial and leadership troubles again, for the second time in six years.

For the first time, New York State agencies plan to hold a public discussion on the question of reducing highway noise -- including noise on highways already in existence. What prompted the Departments of Environmental Conservation and of Transportation jointly to call this conference was the protest of Westchester and Putnam County residents against the intolerable screeching and rumbling of trucks on a ten-mile stretch of Route Interstate 684 between Armonk and Katonah.

Union democracy is a stranger throughout the ranks of organized labor, not just in the United Mine Workers union as your editorial of Nov. 30 states. Dictatorial control is so pervasive that what few changes take place are usually the result of a "palace revolt" among incumbent leaders.

William E. Hickey is a 32year-old executive vice president of a small manufacturing company in Bloomfield, Conn. Every morning he awakes at 6:30, props himself up on his bed and spends 20 minutes letting his mind dwell on a meaningless sound known as a "mantra."

Your Nov. 16 editorial "Subs and SALT" suggests that the coming strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) should strive for an agreement permitting each side to deploy a specified number of nuclear submarines in certain waters, thus providing a cheaper and more dependable nuclear deterrent than exists at present.

The coast-to-coast Shubert empire, for decades the most powerful force in the nation's legitimate theater, is trying to fight its way out of a crisis that may greatly alter show business along Broadway and throughout the country.

The United States Government, applying some of the hoopla of a patent medicine peddler, is auctioning some 2.3 million old-time silver dollars, and some coin dealers contend the public is being duped.
CAMDEN, Dec. 10 -- If Newark carries out its declared intention to ask the new session of the New Jersey Legislature for financial help to avert bankruptcy, it will not be alone.
Following is a list of bus services available to Nassau and Suffolk County commuters to subway stops in Queens:...
" It was like watching an old uncle succumb, inevitable but shocking and sad when the end comes," said John E. O'Toole, president of Foote, Cone Belding, commenting on the demise of Life magazine.

Maurice H. Nadjari, the special prosecutor appointed to investigate corruption in the criminal-justice system, has begun an investigation of a lawyer who said he was close to State Supreme Court judges he indicated were corrupt, according to a source close to the inquiry.

Encouraged by City Council leaders, Angelo J. Arculeo, the Brooklyn Republican, expects next month to regain the Council minority leadership post he previously held for seven years. The Republican minority on the Council, at three members, is barely large enough to have a conversation, let alone a political fight.
BURLINGTON CITY, N.J., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A man who was discharged from the Army in 1955 after eight years of service enlisted in the New Jersey National Guard today along with his son.

The use of attractive policewomen to encourage overtures by male "patrons" may be the stuff that titillates viewers of television cop-operas. Applied to the streets of New York, however, the practice is an abuse of police power and, if not an outright violation of the statutes, then at least clearly an affront to the spirit of the laws.

Dr. Kenneth Clark's "about face" on decentralization (news story Nov. 30) represents an unfair impatience and a familiar but regrettable lack of staying power. The centralized bureaucracies have had many decades to prove that their inefficiency is impregnable against all attempted improvements -- with inevitable rapidly increasing costs.

State Controller Arthur Levitt charged the City's Board of Education yesterday with a variety of legal violations, including conflict of interest, while paying $1.2-million in three years to a computer company processing certain payrolls.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 7 -- Despite daily assertions by the Communists that the Saigon Government is planning a campaign of mass arrests and assassination of political prisoners, a series of interviews with sources in close touch with the national police as well as with Vietnamese opposition political figures has disclosed no evidence to support the charges.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A new kind of trade legislation, including a system of safeguards for industries and workers damaged by steeply rising imports, has strong backing within the Administration.

PICOS, Brazil -- The women who do their laundry in the Guaribas River as it flows through this important market town have just learned that the innocent snails in the riverbed can carry dangerous parasites.

NEWARK, Dec. 10 -- Lieut. Edward Lee Kerr, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's choice to be this city's first black Police Director, showed up at the West District station house at 7 A.M. today in the chilly rain to work his eight-hour shift.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Enemy attacks across South Vietnam declined sharply, the Saigon command reported yesterday.

Tim Boxer, a show-business photographer, recalled being accosted by a prostitute who solicited him a few doors away from his own apartment in a corridor of the luxury apartment building where he lives.

The troubles that have disfigured Ireland lately have been recorded and reported, but now, according to the Architectural League of New York, they will be the subject of an exhibition called "The Troubles: An Artist's Document of Ulster."

WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Dec. 10 -- The giant Volkswagen Company, once the prototype of West Germany's economic strength, is still sailing troubled waters but its new captain, Rudolf Leiding, is convinced that dramatic improvement will come by 1974 at the latest.

William E. Hickey is a 32year-old executive vice president of a small manufacturing company in Bloomfield, Conn. Every morning he awakes at 6:30, props himself up on his bed and spends 20 minutes letting his mind dwell on a meaningless sound known as a "mantra."

A staff report to the state's Public Service Commission warns that "nuclear energy is not the answer to all our problems" and urges the development of nonatomic sources of electrical energy to meet the present shortage.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- Western diplomats said tonight that a confidential Soviet document reported that Chinese intruders killed five Soviet soldiers last month. This was the first report of a clash along the ChineseSoviet border since 1969.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- When Father Jacques Marquette, the Jesuit missionary and explorer, came to these shores to preach among the Indians in the winter and spring of 1675, the area's first bootlegger, Pierre (The Mole) Moreau, already had a thriving business.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 (AP) -Rick Barry, who scored all 36 of his points in the last three quarters, hit two foul shots in the closing minute to give the Golden State Warriors a 103100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight in a National Basketball Association contest.

Vanderbilt, unranked and forgotten in the preseason polls, and Jan van Breda Kolff have gained early national college basketball prominence. The Commodores have won five straight games, including two on the road against Louisville and Kansas.

Andrew Wyke (Laurence Olivier), the rich, snobbish author of mystery fiction that has apparently outsold both S.S. Van Dine and Agatha Christie, strides about the study of his magnificent 16th-century English country house, sounding an inexhaustible supply of rolled r's and s's so sibilant they could cut tunnels through fog.

Harvey B. Scribner, chancellor of the city school system, said last night that he would not permit minority-group pupils from the Tilden Houses project in Brooklyn to be excluded eventually from junior high schools in Canarsie and in East Flatbush, as the local board for that Brooklyn district has proposed.
Peter McDuffe, who knows what being a "fifth wheel' is like, finally got his chance last night to play for the Rangers.

Albert Maltz, the screenwriter convicted in the 1950's for refusing to say before a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, has offered to turn over his "considerable royalties" in the Soviet Union to Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the banned Russian novelist who is reportedly in financial difficulties.

There was a time, according to Paul Bitetzakis, when you could "drop a nail" off the roof above his Acropolis restaurant at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 47th Street, "and it would never hit the sidewalk."

Carl Dorian is a young apprentice electrician. Quiet and recently married, he feels his life has no great drama in it. In trade school he did well enough to know his craft but was not outstanding. Outside of school he made friends with a group whose members still see each other and still all live in the Charlestown district of Boston where they grew up.

BATON ROUGE, Dec. 10 -- Members of a biracial commission investigating the deaths of two Southern University students said today they disputed the official version of the incident that occurred last month on the school's campus.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 10 -- Former President Harry S. Truman was taken off the critical list today after a five-day bout with lung congestion, but a weakened heart kept him in serious condition.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 11 -Premier Kakuei Tanaka's Liberal-Democratic party has been returned to power with a solid, although unspectacular, victory in nationwide elections.
The head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he saw "very little hope for service in the immediate future" on the struck Long Island Rail Road.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -The Atlanta Falcons had a clear shot at the Western Division title of the National Football Conference today. But they missed it in a wave of mistakes that gave the San Francisco 49ers a 20-0 victory and first place with one week to go.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- At what we hope is the brink of success for Henry Kissinger in his long search for peace in Vietnam, it is fascinating to look back at the paper in which he roughed out his approach to the negotiations. That was his article of January, 1969, in Foreign Affairs.

In a major shake-up of his agency, the city's Housing and Development Administrator announced yesterday the resignations of five top officials, the dismissal of another, the promotion of four executives and the appointment of four others, including a new chief investigator with a mandate to "root out corruption."

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- Mrs. Margaret Court took only 50 minutes to crush Evonne Goolagong, 6-3, 6-2, in the final of the West Australian tennis championship today. The top prize was $720.

Ann Kandel, a Queens school librarian in gray pants and a red turtleneck, looked up yesterday at the great bronze chandeliers and the carved, tarnished -gold ceiling of the New York Public Library's main reading room.

WASHINGTON -- In a pleasant white frame house in Bethesda, Md., a handful of senior citizens gathers every day around the living room fireplace to play games, work at crafts, nibble on snacks. Or just to wander around.
The United Nations faces another critical test of credibility today when the Sixth (Legal) Committee is expected to vote on proposals for curbing international terrorism.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -President Nixon conferred for 75 minutes today with Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., key aide to Henry A. Kissinger at the secret Paris talks with the North Vietnamese. But the White House continued to provide no information on how close the two sides had come to concluding an Indochina settlement.
The head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he saw "very little hope for service in the immediate future" on the struck Long Island Rail Road.

OTTAWA, Dec. 10 (UPI) -After 23 seconds of a sudden death overtime, Wayne Carlton scored to give the Ottawa Nationals a 7-6 victory over the Quebec Nordiques in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Forecasting that "a whole new energy frontier lies before us," former Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel has proposed that the United States invest $684.7million in a 10-year research and development program on geothermal energy.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- A rocket found in a Belfast street by a patrol blew up inside an army post today, killing a sergeant and wounding two soldiers, one of them seriously, a military spokesman said.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- To the blare of trumpets, eight Americans, two Britons and a West German author received 1972 Nobel Prizes today from Crown Prince Carl Gustaf of Sweden.

The unemployment rate has finally moved down from the 5.5 per cent plateau where it had stood frozen for a half year. The substantial reduction in joblessness recorded in November renews hope that those on the idle list will not remain shutouts in the nation's economic boom.

With his legs unable to summon the "instant movement" that had characterized his earlier tennis tournament victories, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales bowed to top-seeded Charles Pasarell yesterday in the final of the $75,000 Clean Air Classic, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened its 61st annual appeal yesterday with $331,146.03 already donated by estates, trust funds and 204 mail contributors.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 10 -- The New York Jets regained part of their running attack today with the unexpected return of Cliff McClain. But the surprise was diluted by predictions that a muddy field would await them tomorrow night when they played the Oakland Raiders in the Oakland Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -President Nixon conferred for 75 minutes today with Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., key aide to Henry A. Kissinger at the secret Paris talks with the North Vietnamese. But the White House continued to provide no information on how close the two sides had come to concluding an Indochina settlement.

The City Finance Administrator, Richard Lewisohn, said yesterday he had established a special task force to ensure that the city was receiving its full share of taxes from "adult" bookstores, peep-show theaters, "masage" parlors and hotels in the midtown area used by prostitutes.

BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Jim Lorentz and Rick Martin scored in the third period tonight, carrying the Buffalo Sabres to a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. The triumph gave Dave Dryden, the Sabres' goalie, his first N.H.L. victory over his younger brother, Ken, who was in the nets for Montreal.

The author Ladislas Farago said in an interview yesterday that statements by an Argentine, Juan Jose Velasco, casting doubt on his recent report that Martin Bormann had been found alive were false "in their entirety."
CAVE CITY, Ark. -- Joseph Harry Weston, 61 years old, is a one-man terrorist band. His weapon is a weekly newspaper, and he runs it on the creed that all the outrage he can muster is fit to print.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 10 -- A short time ago, most Australians would have thought that having an ambassador from Peking in Canberra next year was as unlikely as seeing an uncensored version of "Portnoy's Complaint" on the country's sanitized movie screens.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 10 -Gen. Phoune Sipraseuth, leader of the Pathet Lao delegation negotiating a peace settlement with the Vientiane Government, returned here tonight after an absence of eight days.
HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- Apollo 17 rocketed into an orbit of the moon today and was set for the sixth landing of men on the earth's desolate satellite world.

MANILA, Dec. 10 -- A new effort began here this weekend to settle without further bloodshed the problem of dissidence among the three million Filipino Moslems of western Mindanao and the Sulu archipelago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- This city, ruled from its beginnings by an interlocking alliance of businessmen, politicians and hoodlums so intricate that their roles shade into one another, once again is facing the possibility of a wave of reform.

FAIRFAX, S. C., Dec. 10 -The 1970 shotgun slaying of an 18-year-old black youth has attracted new interest here after reports that it may have been a random ambush in retaliation for the wounding of a white man.
August Heckscher, the Parks Commissioner, gave details yesterday of two large-scale and costly attacks by vandals on Manhattan park sites.

By winning yesterday, the Miami Dolphins tied the 1934 Chicago Bears' record of 13 consecutive victories from the start of the season. However, the Bears actually won 17 consecutive regular-season games, counting their last four regular games in 1933, the year they defeated the New York Giants, 23-21, in the league title game. They lost to New York, 30-13, in the 1934 title game.
For doll collectors, doll makers, doll menders and doll curators, make believe and reality merge in the flutter of fake lashes, the pursing of painted lips.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 10 -- When last year's annual meeting of Litton Industries adjourned there was at least one stockholder who had not been given a promised chance to be heard.

It is the old story about the landlord knocking and the impecunious tenant who is about to be sent out into the cold, and it may even include the kindly rescuer arriving in the nick of time with the rent.

Toward the end of a two-week strike in 1967 against the Columbia Broadcasting System and the other major networks, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFTRA) called on other unions in broadcasting to lend the performers' union active support by honoring AFTRA picket lines.

The bodies of a young man and a young woman who had died of asphyxiation during the night were found at 8:30 yesterday morning in the Verrazanno parking field beneath the Verrazano Bridge, alongside the Belt Parkway in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

POTOMAC, Md., Dec. 10 -- E. Howard Hunt, whose wife, Dorothy, was killed in the United Air Lines crash near Midway Airport in Chicago on Friday, said tonight that the $10,000 in cash found in her purse was intended for a business investment in the Chicago area.
Two National Football League division titles were still unsettled after yesterday's action and will be decided next weekend when the regular season comes to an end.

The Philadelphia 76ers, last in their league but warmly regarded by compassionate men, were a match for the Knicks for 14 minutes last night, but then ran out of luck and wound up losing to the New Yorkers, 120-109, at Madison Square Garden before -- surprisingly -a capacity crowd of 19,694.

HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- The area of tomorrow's moon landing is a museum selected to offer a maximum number of revealing exhibits including what scientists hope will prove to be the oldest rocks ever brought into a laboratory.

MANILA, Dec. 10 (UPI) -The Philippine Government today officially identified the man who attacked President Ferdinand E. Marcos's wife, Imelda, as a "shy" geodetic engineer who apparently was out to kill President Marcos.

PERUGIA, Italy, Dec. 10 -Italy is in the throes of a crisis and needs drastic reforms to do away with parasitism and unjust privilege, but social reforms are impossible unless Italians work harder or more efficiently.
Computers are being put to work in an effort to make a dent in the $6.5-billion it costs the American transportation industry a year for its paper work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -President Nixon has filled his second-term Cabinet, barring confirmation battles, and public interest in the "new" Nixon Administration has diminished, but there are still significant decisions to be made about people and positions below the Cabinet level.
A clincher may be added to Anthony Lewis' Nov. 27 column criticizing Daniel Bell's thesis supporting meritocracy.

MIDDLE ISLAND, L.I., Dec. 10 -- Ann Snyder, one of the leading junior riders of the country three years ago, returned to the show ring today and rode Happy to the regular working hunter championship at the Middle Island horse show.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Ken Hodge scored three goals and Don Marcotte got two as the Boston Bruins skated to an 8-4 victory over California tonight. The victory extended their National Hockey League unbeaten string to 12 games.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 10 -- Members of a biracial commission investigating the deaths of two Southern University students said today they dispute the official version of the incident that occurred last month on the school's campus.

Robert Strauss, the newly elected Democratic national chairman, reported yesterday that he had assurances of his acceptability to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, while New York State's party chairman predicted that Mr. Strauss would "bring people together."

PENNSAUKEN, N.J., Dec. 10 -- A schipperke, the descendant of a breed long popular as a barge dog on the canals in Belgium, barged to the front at the 40th annual fixture of the Camden County Kennel Club in Ivystone Inn tonight.
Three contemporary strains of Jazz were woven together in a concert Saturday evening at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street.

The Miami Dolphins, created only seven years ago as an expansion team in an expansion league, tied a 38-year-old National Football League record yesterday by making their won-lost record 13-0 with a 23-13 victory over the New York Giants at Yankee Stadium.

An admirable and unusual aspect of the current repertory of Israel's Batsheva Dance Company is its inclusion of works by both unknown company members and internationally recognized choreographers. Yet it would be a shame for Batsheva to become the dumping ground for the second-rate efforts of those with international reputations.

In a major shake-up of his agency, the city's Housing and Development Administrator announced yesterday the resignations of five top officials, the dismissal of another, the promotion of four executives and the appointment of four others, including a new chief investigator with a mandate to "root out corruption."
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10 -Yale University announced today a recruitment policy that will eventually achieve a three-to-two ratio of men to women in its undergraduate college.
HOUSTON, Dec. 10 -- Apollo 17 rocketed into an orbit of the moon today and was set for the sixth landing of men on the earth's desolate satellite world.

The coast-to-coast Shubert empire, for decades the most powerful force in the nation's legitimate theater, is trying to fight its way out of a crisis that may greatly alter show business along Broadway and throughout the country.

By beating Clarkstown, 4-1, last week and losing, 4-0, to the German-Hungarians yesterday, the New York Ukrainians have proved themselves the most inconsistent team in the GermanAmerican Soccer League.

Regular partners who take the trouble to discuss their bidding procedures have a good chance of avoiding the many ambiguities that can arise in standard methods. Consider, for example, the plight of the player who raises his strange partner from one of a suit to two, and then hears a bid of three in the same suit.
Your Dec. 4 editorial on America's self-disenfranchised voters partially answers the question of who these dropouts from the democratic process are.
Prince Stanislas Radzwill confirmed last night reports that he and his wife, Lee, sister of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, are ending their marriage of 14 years.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (UPI) -The Ford Motor Company's chairman, Henry Ford 2d, warned over the weekend that continued reliance on a profitmargin ceiling to control prices in 1973 could hold back sustained long-term growth of the nation's economy.
VIENNA, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -An outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease brought tourist travel on land to a virtual standstill in Eastern Europe today after some Communist countries sealed their borders.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Dec. 10 -- Al LoBalbo listens to the critics' complaints: "The F.D.U. offense is as exciting as watching grass grow, like watching paint dry."

Atlanta, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Phil Roberto scored twice tonight, once in the final minute, in leading the St. Louis Blues to a 5-4 triumph over the Atlanta Flames. Roberto's second goal came after the Flames had pulled the goalie with 1:28 remaining and sent in a sixth forward in an attempt to overcome a 4-3 deficit. Atlanta scored after his goal.

No message is more important to those in the service away from home than one that says they are missed, loved and not forgotten. This year the United Service Or ganizations are celebrating their 31st anniversary, and they continue to provide a touch of home to members of the armed forces in distant lands.

For most American families the most meaningful measuring rod of success or failure in the battle against inflation is what happens to the price of food at the check-out counter. On that basis, consumers are likely to take a more apprehensive view than does the Administration of last month's 1.4 per cent rise in the index of wholesale food prices.

In working up a program of music by Alexander Scriabin, Vladimir Ashkenazy decided to give a cross section of the composer's work, and to give it chronologically. This was a good idea. There has been a major Scriabin renaissance in the last few years, but most attention has been focussed on the problematic, mystical late works. The earlier works, with their pronounced influence of Chopin, are by and large neglected.

HARTFORD, Dec. 10 -- With other states, other stock exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the big brokerage houses watching nervously from the wings, Connecticut's bid for a seat on the PBW Stock Exchange in Philadelphia is due to be acted on this week.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Louisiana's Attorney General, William Guste, acknowledged today that some members of the biracial commission investigating the deaths of two Southern University students had concluded that both were killed by a single shotgun blast, but he denied reports that identification of the person who fired the fatal shot was near.

It may have been mere coincidence that Harry Chapin was celebrating his 30th birthday, but that fact of life made his first major concert appearance at Alice Tully Hall, Sunday evening, even more of a good-humored celebration.
Bombs went off yesterday in New York, Miami and Montreal at the offices of companies engaged in shipping goods to Cuba.
The American Medical Association, already a minipublishing empire, is preparing to bring forth still another magazine in April.
Two years ago, Mrs. Rosamond Campion found a lump the size of an olive pit in her left breast. She entered a Manhattan hospital for a biopsy, and the lump was diagnosed as being cancerous.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 11 -- Seventeen more people were detained last night in connection with a police investigation of what was termed a pro-Syrian espionage and sabotage ring.
If you have a child in school and the child's friend is using drugs, what do you do? If you are a divorced mother who goes out on dates, how much do you tell young sons and daughters?
Some of Wall Street's glamour stocks boomed ahead yesterday, while popular averages continued last week's habit of posting record highs.
The New York Mercantile Exchange, where futures in Maine potatoes, platinum, United States silver coins, imported boneless beef and palladium are traded, celebrated its 100th anniversary yesterday.

TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- Officials of the Port of New York and New Jersey Authority told a Senate hearing today that the $650-million mass transit improvements pending in the Legislature would be self-supporting and they urged that final approval be given to the proposals.

ABOARD THE S.S. STATENDAM, in the Caribbean Sea -- In the ship's theater, Norman Mailer was hypothesizing the existence of what he called the thanatosphere, a home for the souls of the dead out beyond the biosphere, and wondering whether space exploration might not be upsetting its delicate vibrations.
William Styron, whon won a Pulitzer Prize for his novel about the 1831 slave uprising in Virginia, "The Confessions of Nat Turner," has written his first play, "In the Clap Shack."
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 11 -The New York Jets' last chance to back into the playoffs as the wild-card disappeared tonight when they were defeated by the Oakland Raiders, 24-16.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Agence France-Presse -- Talks concerning a five-year international agreement on coffee export quotas collapsed when the International Coffee Council failed to reach a compromise between producer and consumer countries here tonight after 13 days of prolonged negotiations.
A $15 check from Melvin J. Hahn of 1036 Park Avenue was among the 50 contributions recorded yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

The City Commission on Human Rights warned yesterday that a "dangerous pattern" of arson and vandalism against blacks and Puerto Ricans had developed in several white neighborhoods of the city. The commission charged that in some instances the Police Department had been inadequate in its efforts to prevent and investigate the violence.
It is always amusing to read letters such as the one by Mrs. Harriet S. Hart which appeared Dec. 1 on the unfairness of forced busing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -Senator Robert J. Dole announced today that he was resigning as Republican National Chairman and that George Bush, United States representative to the United Nations, had been chosen to replace him.
The Price Paper Corporation, a subsidiary of the Price Company, Ltd., of Quebec, said yesterday that it planned to increase its newsprint prices by $5 a ton, effective Feb. 1.

The music that the New Lost City Ramblers have been playing and singing for the last 14 years is usually described as "old-time country music." But the way Mike Seeger, John Cohen and Tracy Schwarz present their songs, they manage to turn almost everything they offer into good-time music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the Government's claim that the General Dynamics Corporation's acquisition of United Electric Coal Companies illegally lessened competition.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 11 -- Jerry Molloy doesn't like to speak at dinners and other social functions, but he does it anyway. As Hoboken's ambassador at large, he wants to get a message across.
Commuters left without their regular means of transportation by the Long Island Rail Road strike began another week of improvised travel arrangements yesterday as again no negotiations were held.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -Fraternal organizations may discriminate in choosing their members but not in deciding whether to serve food and drink to guests, under a Supreme Court action today.
Major commercial banks in New York City have quietly raised their lending rates on home mortgages to 7 1/4 per cent from 7 per cent.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -Thomas Gangemi Jr., who ran second behind Dr. Paul T. Jordan in the race for Mayor a little over a year ago, said today he would make another bid for the office in the elections scheduled for next May.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman rested quietly without pain today, but doctors said that his condition "still is serious and will continue to be so for an indefinite period."

Policemen who rushed to a Bronx bank after an anonymous caller demanded all its money and told a clerk that dynamite had been planted inside discovered yesterday that the "explosives" were pieces of broom handles taped together.
When Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger entered the White House together in January, 1969, only one of them was professedly a "Disraeli conservative." It wasn't Mr. Nixon.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 11 -Communist forces mounted heavy attacks on Laotian Government positions near the forward base supporting operations on the Plaine des Jarres over the weekend in what may be the start of a new drive to overrun the base.

A woman in Rye, N.Y., is considering charging District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County with malfeasance for agreeing not to prosecute two men who allegedly robbed her home and then returned some of the stolen items along with $600,000 worth of missing art works.

For the first time in the family history of President and Mrs. Nixon, neither of their daughters, Tricia and Julie, will be with them at Christmas. The White House said that Tricia and Edward F. Cox, her husband, and Julie and Lieut. David Eisenhower, her husband, would spend the holiday as a foursome in Athens.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Doctors at Christ Hospital pressed satisfaction that a lesion removed from the right lung of Johnny Bench today was not malignant and said the Cincinnati Reds' star catcher should have no trouble returning to his baseball career.

The Hobeau Farm, with two successive victories in the feature race at Aqueduct last week, extended its good works by taking the main event at the Big A yesterday. Allen Jerkens, who trains for Hobeau, sent Vertee into the $9,500 allowance race of one mile against six rivals, and Vertee sped to a 9 1/2-length victory.

Two publishing companies named Macmillan have averted a threatened identity crisis. Macmillan, Ltd., of London yesterday dropped its legal action to bar Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., from changing its name to Macmillan, Inc., on Jan. 1.

Firemen rescued six persons, including two small children, from a burning apartment building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn early yesterday and revived the children, who had stopped breathing, with mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, fire officials said.

HOUSTON, Dec. 11 -- The first of three traverses across the lunar surface on the Apollo 17 mission was designed to make the most of the limited time available after installation of the various observing instruments to be left on the moon.

NEWARK, Dec. l1 -- Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman refused today to consider further restrictions on picketing at the embattled Kawaida Towers construction site until the contractor makes "a goodfaith attempt" to bring in men and equipment.

About 50 members of a black self-help organization took over the midtown offices of the State Health Department yesterday and, after ousting virtually the entire staff, vowed to remain until the state agreed to pay $800,000 in disputed Medicaid payments to Interfaith Hospital in Queens.

MANILA, Dec. 11 -- A Government spokesman said today that further questioning of persons detained under martial law regulations had disclosed information about many more attempts on the life of President Ferdinand E. Marcos than had previously been reported.
PARIS, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -The French Army began today to clear up mountains of garbage that have been rising in the streets of Paris since the city's garbage workers went on strike five days ago.

By a majority of more than five to one, the voters of the Irish Republic have built a modest first section of a framework in which the reunification of Ireland might one day become possible. They have repealed a section of their 1937 Constitution that conferred a "special position" on the Roman Catholic Church, to which 95 per cent of the citizens of the Republic belong.

Moliere's "Don Juan" is comparatively little known in the English-speaking theater, which is both surprising and a pity. Perhaps its potential popularity has been damaged by the Mozart opera, but whatever the reason this is not among Moliere's most familiar plays.

The Duke Power Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 3 million common shares for sale through Merrill Lynch and the First Boston Corporation. The company's stock closed at 23 3/8, up 1/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mark Van Doren, the poet and critic and retired Columbia professor, died Sunday night two days after undergoing surgery for circulatory problems at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn. He was 78 years old.
Governor Rockefeller agreed yesterday to meet soon with opponents of the state's abortion law who have repeatedly attacked him in the last month at his Town Hall meetings across the state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Retail sales in November remained close to the record October level, the Commerce Department reported today.

HOUSTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -The United States has spent more than $26.657-billion on the manned space program in the last 15 years and plans to spend about $8.85-billion in the next five years, a National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -President Nixon disclosed today his decision to continue wage and price controls in 1973, possibly in modified form.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Shooting of the third film in the "Shaft" series, "Shaft in Africa," is to begin here today. The two stars, Vanetta McGee and Richard Round-tree, were received by Emperor Haile Selassie in a palace audience Saturday.
Timothy Hunt, president of Paper Handlers Local No. 1, said yesterday that his union was notifying the city's four major daily newspapers that it was terminating its contract with them.
The New York Raiders have become almost unbeatable on the Madison Square Garden ice. Last night they made the Chicago Cougars an 8-3 victim in winning their ninth home game in the last 11.

From its sugar-frosted turrets and candied spires down to its nut-framed doorways and chocolate cooky foundations, Tjasa Sprague's fantasy town is definitely the most traditional creation in Design Research, that bastion of modernity at 53 East 57th Street.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 11 -What is left of the civil rights establishment of the nineteensixties gathered here today to celebrate the opening of former President Johnson's rights papers and to urge President Nixon to assume in his second term the leadership of a renewed movement for minority rights.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- India and Pakistan today completed demarcation of a new truce line in divided Kashmir, paving the way for a withdrawal of troops elsewhere along their frontiers.

Helge Brilioth's song recital at Hunter College Sunday night, his first in this country, had its ups and downs. But taken altogether, the tenor's easy stage manner, communicative warmth and unaffectedly direct interpretations gave a great deal of pleasure.
Your Nov. 24 editorial concerning the management of the Lincoln Center Parking Garage was prompted by a callous disregard for the people they are there to serve.

At least a dozen commodities set new life-of-contract highs yesterday in futures trading.
A $15 check from Melvin J. Hahn of 1036 Park Avenue was among the 50 contributions recorded yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

If being nobody special is not awarded much prestige in this society, however, it is a condition which all the nobodies have learned to share.

Two solo concerts and a company dance performance turned up in likely and unlikely nooks and crannies of the East and West Village during the weekend. Albert Reid showed his friendly, spritely company at the newly refurbished, Exchange Theater on Sunday at Westbeth.

RECIFE, Brazil, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Twenty-one students, including five women, who had been held in jail for eight months on charges of subversion were freed today after the defense asserted that both they and witnesses had been tortured by the police.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, Dec. 13 (UPI) -Gunmen fired 25 bullets into a policeman as he stepped out of a Belfast hotel early today, killing him in the latest wave of killings in Northern Ireland, the British Army said.
PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- The current phase of the Vietnam peace negotiations is coming to an end here with one difficult unresolved question.
Your editorial of Nov. 22 describing the Indian occupation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs bore little resemblance to descriptions of that incident as reported in various newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Government accused the Xerox Corporation today of illegally monopolizing the $1.7-billion market for office copying machines.

BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- When a man phoned the internal revenue office in West Berlin's Charlottenburg borough about a tax problem the other day, the operator told him the entire staff was away for the day.
A problem for bridge experts is how to put the idle to work. An idle bid is one that cannot profitably be employed in a natural sense, and may with advantage be given a specialized meaning.

Sounding what is likely to be the death knell for a proposed fusion candidate for Mayor, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that a multiparty coalition behind a candidate would be "virtually impossible" next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Richard M. Earle, president of the National Coordinating Council on Drug Education, said today that the majority of currently available films on drug abuse "are doing more harm than good."

SOUTH DEVON, England -- I want kids to sit up and pay attention before we start. I'm a bit formal about this. And they were sitting around all over the place not paying much attention, so I said: "Right, sit up, face the front." They got around to it and were sitting up facing the front, except for this one boy that was obviously different to the rest.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 12 (AP) -- An official of the International Rescue Committee says that more than 2,000 Bengalis are in jail in Pakistan without charge and have "none of the normal rights of prisoners." His report describes growing distress and deepening despondency in a community forbidden to leave for Bangladesh.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday in Washington ordered Butcher Sherrerd, a Philadelphia brokerage firm, to suspend solicitation of retail sales for 10 business days, beginning Jan. 8, 1973.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The wife of a New York City police captain was found dead last night in the garage of her home here, apparently the victim of accidental carbon monoxide poisoning.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Funding for the Villanova University student newspaper was canceled yesterday by the school's president, after the paper printed an editorial critical of a high university official.

The back-to-nature movement has hit the florists this Christmas. Gone is most of the glitter and tinsel, the sequins and gold braid. In their place -- on trees, wreaths, centerpieces and incidental decorations -- are fruits, berries, nuts, pine cones, tree bark, roots, herbs, sea shells and flowers. Many of these are frankly fake, but the natural effect is there. Even the papier mache angels have been treated to look like wood.
TRENTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The State Division of Consumer Affairs announced today that a Burlington auto dealer had been fined $350 for misrepresenting the year of a used car sold to a Willingboro man.

HOUSTON, Dec. 12 -- While two astronauts are carrying out the final moon walks of the Apollo program, their colleague, Comdr. Ronald E. Evans, is probing the moon from orbit with a radio sounding system that, it is believed, can penetrate three-quarters of a mile or more into the lunar interior.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 -- It was Daniel Ellsberg's belief that the long delay in his trial had caused the jury to become prejudiced against him. Today he tested his theory in the courthouse corridor.

In hectic trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday a record 11,261 world sugar contracts changed hands, making it the busiest day on the exchange since December 15, 1971, when 11,110 contracts traded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Civil Service Commission study shows that 5.7 per cent of the Defense Department's work force is made up of retired military personnel who collect pensions as well as regular pay -- something retired civilians are not allowed to do.

UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 12 -- The Islanders started Phase Two of their first year on ice by erupting, in their fashion, for their highest goal total in three weeks with a 4-4 tie against the St. Louis Blues tonight.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 12 -- The attitude of the Cambodian Government toward the Indochina cease-fire now being negotiated seems to have changed from one of wishfulness and plaintive optimism to more realism and worry.

You have finally published a letter defending the poor misunderstood dope pusher as the least culpable in a tragic chain of events leading to death through overuse of narcotics. Michael R. Putnam (letter Dec. 1) is to be congratulated as the man who has crystallized the Alice-in-Wonderland logic so popular among apologists for the drug culture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Government auditors ended today a year-long investigation into heroin smuggling by concluding that traffic in the drug was too big to stop at United States borders.

There's no business like show business, they say. Take, for example, the performance at the Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto Monday night of a revival of the 1919 musical comedy "Irene," starring Debbie Reynolds.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- The State of New York was $11,300 poorer today and $97-million richer thanks to Federal revenue sharing and a Chaplinesque rush by air and land to obtain the signature of Governor Rockefeller on the back of a check.

Eight new eligible players headed by Warren Spahn, Whitey Ford and Robin Roberts appear on the Hall of Fame ballots placed in the mail yesterday to members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

The defense lawyer for Auguste Joseph Ricord painted a picture of him yesterday as a sickly man interested only in his motel and restaurant business in Latin America instead of the international heroin trafficker portrayed by the Government.

NEWARK, Dec. 12 -- A group of black Newark residents who pitted themselves against the Newark police and won $1,250 in punitive damages from an all-white jury went back to court today to ask for more. Charging that their apartments were illegally ransacked by the police in searches for bank robbers who were not there, they are seeking a new trial for compensatory damages.

ANCHORAGE, Dec. 12 -- A special six-member jury ruled today that Representative Nicholas J. Begich, Democrat of Alaska, and two other men who disappeared with him on a flight from here Oct. 16 were "presumed dead."

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 12 -- Pathet Lao negotiators today offered a new draft for a peace agreement in Laos that, a Communist spokesman asserted, could end the war immediately if accepted by the Vientiane Government.

LIVINGSTON, Ala., Dec. 12 -- Gov. Geoge C. Wallace pressed a lever on a speaker's platform here today and detonated a 100-pound dynamite blast at Gainesville, Ala., breaking ground for the long-delayed Tennessee Tombigbee Wateways.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Leaders of organized labor indicated today that they were amenable to President Nixon's decision to extend wage and price controls but only if some changes were made.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that beginning March 1 neither policemen nor complainants would be required to appear in court at the arraignment of defendants. The move, the authority for which was given the Police Department in 1970, would be a fundamental change in the way cases are processed in New York City.

The photograph of Prof. Samuel L. Popkin, handcuffed (your front page of Nov. 22) has brought again most vividly to my mind what I and many others have repeatedly felt. Perhaps the law of the country made it impossible to dismiss the charges against Professor Popkin.

The loss of a playoff position and their division title as a consequence of the defeat by the Green Bay Packers was a bitter blow to the Minnesota Vikings, although there had been plenty of hints earlier that this was not to be their season.

NEWARK, Dec. 12 -- Despite maintaining his own private practice and holding numerous other medical positions, Dr. Sam D'Ambola has found enough spare time to coach Essex Catholic High School to eight consecutive New Jersey State scholastic fencing championships.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 12 -- The Suffolk County Attorney, the deputy presiding officer of the County Legislature, his brother, who is a real-estate broker, and the former Supervisor of the Town of Southampton have been indicted on charges of official misconduct and grand larceny in connection with the county's purchase of waterfront land.
The Monsanto Company said yesterday that the Price Commission had permitted the company to restate its base period profit margins beginning Jan. 1.

THURMONT, Md. -- Among the displays in a corridor showcase in a Thurmont restaurant are what appear to be three pitted billiard balls on a skewer and a faintly yellowed bellpush. They are identified as a fishing float and bedroom buzzer used by President Franklin D. Roosevelt at Camp David.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- An apparent winning basket by Chicago's Chet Walker in the closing second of overtime was disallowed tonight by the referees, Mark Mano and Paul Mihalik, allowing the Los Angeles Lakers to edge the Bulls, 106-105, in a National Basketball Association game.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 -- It was Daniel Ellsberg's belief that the long delay in his trial had caused the jury to become prejudiced against him. Today he tested his theory in the courthouse corridor.

HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -The strains of Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries," radioed from earth, woke Capt. Eugene A. Cernan and Harrison H. Schmitt, the astronauts, on the moon today. The Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston said that the music was appropriate because Mr. Schmitt used to rouse his roommates at the California Institute of Technology each morning when he played it on his record player.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The New York Stock Exchange spelled out today a number of dangers that it sees in any plan permitting or requiring corporations to publish internal forecasts of sales and earnings.
CAIRO, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Egypt's War Minister, Gen. Ahmed Ismail, warned today that the lack of unified Arab military action would enable Israel to perpetuate her occupation of Arab lands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The White House confirmed today that a two-man investigative team, known jokingly as the White House plumbers, worked during 1971 at trying to plug news leaks concerning "national security affairs" and had a private telephone.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Former President Juan D. Peron was reportedly offered last night a nomination for the Argentine presidency by a coalition of his Justicialist party and smaller allied groups.

LISBON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The outline of an opposition party in the 1973 parliamentary elections emerged over the weekend as leaders of the group, called the Democratic Opposition, met to plan its congress for sometime next spring.

Julie Harris, pale, gaunt and gallant, received a standing ovation at the ANTA Theater last night. She was starring, indeed largely supporting, a new play by James Prideaux called "The Last of Mrs. Lincoln."

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 12 -- Foreign Minister Shridath S. Ramphal of Guyana announced in Parliament today that his nation -- as well as Barbados, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago -- had established diplomatic relations with Cuba.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A Los Angeles psychologist was arrested here yesterday on, a warrant from Philadelphia charging him with performing illegal abortions and practicing medicine without a license.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, in a sudden and emotional return from retirement, reverted to his old role as mediator today as he quelled a dispute between divided civil rights leaders.

Private contractors do work for the City of Albany that "clearly could be performed by city personnel," a witness testified at a public hearing of the State Commission Investigation. "In fact," said Albert Sohn, an accountant for the commission, "private contractors build tennis courts, pave roads, install traffic lights and do just about everything except provide police and fire protection."

KEARNY, N. J., Dec. 12 -- The world's biggest, most complex and largely automated bulk mail facility, which opened June 1 and is weathering its first Christmas mailing season by processing double its daily capacity, had its hectic routine disturbed today by a series of planned confrontations between postal workers union officials and postal authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- While the Lindsay administration went to court today to try to block the Nixon Administration from cutting back on funds for waste-treatment plants, the Rockefeller administration took a more direct approach to the problem.
PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- The current phase of the Vietnam peace negotiations is coming to an end here with one difficult unresolved question.
Contemplating a bond market that had become quite soggy of late, underwriters raised yields yesterday in an attempt to uncover demand for some key new issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A Senate subcommittee is planning hearings when Congress meets in January to look into the Grumman Aerospace Corporation's refusal to proceed on its contract to build fighter planes for the Navy.

Two long-term professional playing careers have apparently come to an end. Hoyt Wilhelm, the knuckleball pitcher who, over 21 years, made more major league appearances than any other pitcher, has switched to managing.

Round-up time has come in the city's parks for packs of stray dogs, most of them lean, hungry, unlicensed or abandoned and many just lost.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu's call for a Christmas truce and an exchange of prisoners left many South Vietnamese and American officials here today with the impression that Mr. Thieu was once more trying to forestall a cease-fire accord he dislikes by offering new terms of his own.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 12 -- A Jordanian Government decision to impose a 12 per cent tax on all imports from the Israeli-occupied West Bank has stirred a dispute between Amman and West Bank businessmen.
BUTTE, Mont., Dec. 12 -- A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Federal funds could not be used to build a road into the center of the Big Sky resort.

An accord covering desk officers employed by 15 steamship companies based on the East and Gulf Coasts was announced yesterday by Capt. Thomas F. O'Callaghan, president of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Henry Kissinger has been living during the critical last days of the Vietnam peace talks in the old Rothschild house, now the American Embassy, at No. 41 Rue du Faubourg St. Honore, down this glittering street from where President Pompidou of France resides in the Elysee Palace.

Alvin L. ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A Federal court jury today found Martin J. McNally guilty of air piracy in the hijacking of an American Airlines 727 jetliner in which $500,000 was demanded, paid and later recovered in an Indian farm field.

J., and the bodyguards he wore, one on each arm, were bunnies of provocative design, complete with long ears, cottontails and other accoutrements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Government agency that insures United States corporate investments in less-developed countries announced today an unusual settlement of a problem arising from the nationalization by Bolivia in 1971 of a United States-owned lead and zinc property.
Thirty stink bombs were set off at last night's performance of the Moscow Circus at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum, the police said, but the show was not disrupted.
Scoring 33 points off 31 Atlanta turnovers, the New York Knicks walloped the Hawks, 114-93, at Madison Square Garden last night and hastened to Atlanta to play the Hawks again tonight.

The airline hostess who tells the departing passenger, "It was nice to have you aboard, sir," may be, behind her smile, a closet feminist on the verge of adding: "And you acted like a male chauvinist pig."

KEARNY, Dec. 12 -- The world's biggest, most complex bulk mail facility, which is weathering its first Christmas season by processing double its rated daily capacity, had its hectic routine disturbed today by a series of planned confrontations between postal workers, union officials and postal authorities.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Ground action in South Vietnam was reported at a low level yesterday, and infiltrating North Vietnamese troops who had come under strong attack northwest of Saigon were said to be fleeing back to Cambodia.

HOUSTON, Wednesday, Dec 13 -- The Apollo 17 astronauts completed their second exploration of the lunar surface early today after gathering ancient rocks at the foot of a mountain and discovering some orange soil, the biggest scientific surprise thus far in the mission.
Stock prices turned lower on profit taking yesterday as Monday's surge of glamour issues suddenly played out.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Nixon Administration refused any public comment today on President Nguyen Van Thieu's speech setting forth Saigon's objections to the Paris peace talks and his own proposals for ending the Vietnam war.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A Superior Court judge ordered a North Bergen cemetery today to restore at its own expense gravestones and monuments it had knocked down or buried.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market took a beating yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by about 2-1.

A Russian street-sweeper, an ardent believer in Communism, tells an interviewer he does not personally "matter as much as a party member"; German office workers are reported often to feel "humiliated" by their clothes; American construction workers tell a team of researchers they feel they have to give their sons cars in order to be respected as fathers.

The Health Services Administration cited 23 more food-processing establishments yesterday for failure, without valid reason, to correct violations of the city's Health Code found on two subsequent visits by health inspectors.
TRENTON, Dec. 12 -- The State Senate's minority leader, J. Edward Crabiel, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Hungry but happy, 65 Haitian refugees drifted ashore today after sailing to Cuba and the Bahamas in a three-week journey aboard a leaking 56-foot sailboat.

Francis J. Dunleavy, an executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, is expected to be named president of the big conglomerate at an early date, according to reliable industry sources.
The conviction of Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and two codefendants was upheld here yesterday in a case involving illegal payments from employers to union representatives in Harlem.

Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival production of "Much Ado About Nothing" will be presented in three hours of prime evening time over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Feb. 2, with the International Business Machines Corporation the sole sponsor.

Remember the Jerry Grant hassle in the Indianapolis 500 last May? Grant finished second, but race stewards bumped him to 12th because he had illegally refueled from the storage tank of his teammmate, Bobby Unser.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Neutron beams will be used at the Naval Research Laboratory in an experimental program to treat cancer patients, researchers announced today.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that his union would seek to form a coalition of citizens' groups to press for restoration of money lost to school budget cuts.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Private contractors do work for the City of Albany that "clearly could be performed by city personnel," an accountant for the State Commission of Investigation testified today.

PARIS -- Jack Lynch, the spry, athletic Taoiseach or Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, has confounded those critics who called him too weak and easy-going by now giving Dublin the most vibrant display of political leadership it has seen in years.

A secondary offering of 247,300 beneficial shares of First Mortgage Investors at 27 3/8 was offered and completed yesterday by underwriters managed by Goldman Sachs, Blyth Eastman Dillon and Paine Webber. First Mortgage Investors closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 27 3/8, down 1/8.
MANILA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The president of the Philippine National Press Club has filed a petition to stop a referendum Jan. 15 on the proposed constitution for the Philippines.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 12 -- A prediction that Australia would eventually become a republic and no longer acknowledge Queen Elizabeth II as sovereign was made here today by the newly appointed Australian envoy to Britain.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday in Washington ordered Butcher Sherrerd, a Philadelphia brokerage firm, to suspend solicitation of retail sales for 10 business days, beginning Jan. 8, 1973.
Concert-hall performances of Rossini's "Petite Messe Solennelle" in its original form are hard to come by. The scoring is too unusual -- harmonium and two pianos. Thus orchestras keep away from it.

Sounding what is likely to be the death knell for a proposed fusion candidate for Mayor, Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that a multiparty coalition behind a candidate would be "virtually impossible" next year.

The Metropolitan Opera is introducing an exceptional number of new conductors this season. The latest is Roberto Benzi, who made his debut here leading the season's first performance of "Faust" Monday night.

SILVER SPRING, Md., Dec. 13 -- The insurgent reform faction in the United Mine Workers held a narrow lead tonight over the slate of the incumbent president, W. A. Boyle. The Labor Department is continuing its around-the-clock tally of ballots in the Government-supervised coal union election.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 13 -- India announced today that she had begun withdrawing troops from the occupied areas in Pakistan.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels roared to a 42-20 first-quarter lead and withstood a late rally by the Carolina Cougars to post a 119-112 victory tonight. The Colonels converted 78 per cent of their field-goal attempts in the first quarter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Two important measures of the nation's balance of international payments moved in opposite directions in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 13 -- President Park Chung Hoe tonight lifted the martial law regulations that he imposed 57 days ago to allow him to amend the Constitution and to clear the way for him to stay in power indefinitely.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Cargill, Inc., Minneapolis grain company, announced today formation of a subsidiary, Cargill Investor Services, Inc., a commodity futures brokerage company with worldwide headquarters in Chicago and operations in many markets.
A bill requiring all future New York City employes who reside in the suburbs to pay the full city resident income tax was passed unanimously yesterday by the City Council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Government gave the states a three-month extension today before it puts into effect its plans to withhold nearly $700-million in matching welfare funds.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Henry A. Kissinger flew home tonight, ending an arduous round of Vietnam cease-fire talks without having solved the central problem -- political control of South Vietnam.
