Toronto has elected a mayor whose whole emphasis in municipal politics is the development of a city in which people continue to have a "sense of roots, a sense of place." David Crombie, the successful candidate, is the champion of "controlled growth" and of neighborhood identity against those whose guiding stars have been the bulldozer and the high-rise.

Organizers of bridge tournaments might well follow the example of chess tournaments and award a prize for the best-played hand. Provided the subjective problems of judging can be overcome, such a prize would provide good material for the journalists and good reading for the bridge public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Justice Department announced today that it had settled its antitrust suit against a former subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System, but not against C.B.S. itself or the other two major television networks.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Nineteen seamen were reported missing tonight after a Panama-registered merchant marine vessel cracked in half in heavy Atlantic seas, the United States Coast Guard reported.

In nearly two years of hard work, George Bush had become a widely respected and uncommonly well-liked United States representative to the United Nations. He was not invariably successful because some Administration policies he had to defend were strongly opposed by a majority of U.N. members; but his effectiveness increased steadily and his efforts unquestionably cut United States losses in the Security Council and the General Assembly.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- Besides Phil Sellers, Ron Williams and Mike Dabney, all freshmen and starters at Rutgers, the Scarlet Knights have discovered that another freshman, Mike Palko, can play alongside Gene Armstead, the senior center. Palko proved his worth against Lehigh, and Rutgers will play him more Saturday against Temple.

Amid rumors that the Philadelphia Blazers were desperately attempting to trade Derek Sanderson and his $500,000-ayear contract, Sanderson's lawyer said from Boston yesterday that "if the deal made sense or could help the situation we would give it every consideration."

The United States Shoe Corporation, a retailer and producer of shoes with about 45 per cent of its output going to independent retailers, realized larger gains in earnings than in sales for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to results reported yesterday.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The New York Raiders took over second place in the World Hockey Association's East Division tonight with a 4-3 victory over the Ottawa Nationals.
HOUSTON, Dec. 14 -- Apollo 17's moon explorers blasted off from the surface and rejoined their orbiting command ship tonight in the Apollo project's last departure from that desolate, cratered world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A group of Federal, state and local government officials rejected today President Nixon's idea that the Federal Government provide the financial aid that would permit local governments to reduce property taxes.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 14 -- The State Board of Education adopted a resolution today accepting science textbooks for the state's three million elementary school pupils but calling for modifications to eliminate what board members believe is "scientific dogmatism" on the teaching of evolution.

As its music director for the last few years, Henry Lewis has built the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra into a first-rate ensemble. Since its base is Newark, he likes to bring it across the river to Carnegie Hall with some regularity.

An increased program "to upgrade employe discipline and productivity" among the city's welfare employes has led in the last two months to disciplinary actions against 344 workers, including 71 who were discharged.

It was 20 degrees above zero at Bromley Mountain's base late yesterday afternoon, and Karl Pfeiffer, the Vermont resort's ski school director, reported by telephone: "I spent part of the afternoon on my hands and knees praying."

David and Sandra Scheraga of Stamford, Conn., sent The New York Times's Neediest Cases Fund $52 yesterday along with a note hailing 1972 as a "year of good fortune" marking their second wedding anniversary and the birth of their daughter.

PARIS, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The skyrocketing inflation of nearly 10 per cent in Western Europe should slow within three to six months, a report by the Organization of Economic Co-operation and Development said today.

BOSTON -- To the many absurd and prevalent apprehensions about the state of civil liberties in the United States (whatever happened to the one about Spiro Agnew studying how to annul the Presidential election in 1972?) we can now add another: searching air travelers may be a violation of the Fourth Amendment guarantee against "unreasonable searches and seizures."
A broad spectrum of interest rates crept higher yesterday, the last session of 1972 in which a large number of major new financings will come to market.
In a crackdown on peep shows along West 42d Street yesterday, the police arrested eight owners or operators of shows that were still in operation half an hour after shutdowns had been ordered.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- An overflow crowd of 1,250 friends and well-wishers held a testimonial dinner here tonight for the Senate majority leader, Earl W. Brydges, who is retiring from politics after serving 24 consecutive years as a Senator.
Fifty-seven pounds of heroin -- with an estimated street value of $10-million to $12-million -- has been stolen from the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

Tuqui II contributed a classic distance performance in winning the main event on the Aqueduct program yesterday. Coming from last place in the field of six in the 1 1/8-mile contest, Tuqui made up ground in the stretch to register a halflength triumph over Harry Gordon's Projective.
Louise Nevelson offered a four and half ton bouquet to the City of New York yesterday in appreciation of a halfcentury of artistic hospitality and inspiration.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey opened a United States customs inspection area at Newark Airport today as the first step of a three-phase program to convert the airport into a full fledged international flight facility by 1976.
Fifty-seven pounds of heroin -- with an estimated street value of $10-million to $12-million -- has been stolen from the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

President Nixon is employing a quite misleading phrase when he states that "throwing money at social problems does not solve them." It takes little study to determine that if one raises Old Age Assistance payments from $100 to $200 a month the problem of elderly poverty is alleviated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- An electric-powered vehicle, resembling an enclosed golf cart, was delivered to the Federal Government today for testing and possible future use.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 14 -The Michigan Legislature voted today to raise the state gasoline tax by 2 cents a gallon and to permit the diversion of one-half cent of the increase -or $21-million a year -- for public transit.
BELFAST, Dec. 14 -- An American sailor was taken hostage at gunpoint in Londonderry last night by three men who tried to rob the United States Navy's communications center there.
Louise Nevelson offered a four-and-a-half-ton bouquet to the City of New York in appreciation of a half-century of artistic hospitality and inspiration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A group of Federal, state and local government officials rejected today President Nixon's idea that the Federal Government provide the financial aid that would permit local governments to reduce property taxes.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 14 -- A state-appointed commission investigating the killing of two black Southern University students here last month said today that both were killed by a single shotgun blast "from an area where sheriff's deputies were deployed."

About 30 people, most of them nurses and doctors from Metropolitan Hospital picketed Gracie Mansion yesterday to protest the quality of care patients were receiving and the dismissal of a registered nurse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The State Department said today that the United States would give sympathetic consideration to any request to remain in the country made by Dr. Valery N. Chalidze, a prominent Soviet dissident, who was informed yesterday while in New York on a speaking tour that his citizenship had been revoked.
An antipoverty worker who had told the police that someone was trying to kill him was found shot to death in his office yesterday.

BOSTON -- One day in the spring of 1958 Robert Frost, in his eighty-fourth year, left his grey Victorian house on Brewster Street in Cambridge and went down to Washington. At Back Bay station in Boston his secretary, Kay Morrison, saw him aboard The Senator, which would bring him into the capital at supper time.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- The Assembly approved today a bill calling for an additional $40million in state aid to education. Approval followed the failure, by one vote, of a Democratic move to hold the measure for amendent.

The San Francisco ,49ers call clinch the eighth and last postseason playoff berth by defeating or tying the Minnesota Vikings tomorrow. If they do that, then the wagering point line will shift sharply for Sunday's games involving the 49ers' competitors, the Lions and Falcons.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- A tough campaign measure that would require candidates in local and state elections to report all contributions and expenses exceeding $100 was overwhelmingly approved in the State Senate tonight.
For the last 10 days and nights, gypsy men and women have been encamped in a board room at St. Vincent's Hospital, keeping a vigil for Mary Mitchell, a 70-year-old woman they consider their queen.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- All four delegations to the regular formal Vietnam negotiations publicly recorded their explanations today of why almost a month of private talks had failed to result in agreement.
PONTIAC, Ill., Dec. 14 (AP) -- One inmate was killed tonight and six were injured in a gang fight in the dining room of Pontiac State Prison.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Enemy gunners fired rockets at Bienhoa air base and an outlying village 15 miles northeast of Saigon in a predawn attack today.

The local activities of the Irish Republican Army (in one or another of its forms) again being given prominence in the news media should give cause for considerable heart-searching. The fund-raising for terrorist groups is of national concern.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Mel Daniels and George McGinnis scored 29 points apiece tonight for the Indiana Pacers in a 111-104 American Basketball Association victory over the San Diego Conquistadors.

Eugene Berman, a celebrated neoromantic painter who created a series of elaborate, dreamlike stage settings for ballet and opera, died at his home in Rome yesterday of internal hemorrhages. He was 73 years old.

Hundreds of people came to City Hall from all five boroughs yesterday to plead with the City Planning Commission for money to save parks, build libraries, expand cultural facilities and, in general, make life in the city more congenial.
TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- A bill described by its sponsors as the strongest in the country in protection of news sources won final legislative approval this evening.

PARIS -- Maurice Schumann, present tenant of the Quai d'Orsay, by nature an optimist, is also one of the most energetic of France's Foreign Ministers. He seems to see this country as a kind of swing-man, initiating ideas or diplomatic contacts between disputing parties around the world.

Surely no cause could be worthier than that of mentally retarded children. But full enjoyment of a benefit rock concert staged by John Lennon and Yoko Ono last August at Madison Square Garden -- and presented as an hour TV program tonight -will require at least one tin ear and the conviction that Mr. and Mrs. Lennon can do -- or sing -- no wrong.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, quietly finishing the few remaining days of a long Congressional career, became 75 years old today but declined to celebrate the anniversary.
YONKERS, Dec. 14 -- Wanna buy a horse?

The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band opened Wednesday night at Max's Kansas City, plays through tomorrow and is, to put it baldly, well worth hearing. Not that their music constitutes some immemorial contribution to the art -- although their ebullient blending of country, bluegrass, cajun, rock and who knows what else does have both esthetic and sociological significance.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Dec. 14 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Government of this Island nation off the southeastern coast of Africa declared a state of siege in and near the port city of Tamatave today after two days of rioting over educational reforms.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The major Western countries, reflecting conflicting approaches, are quietly letting this year pass without creating any more Special Drawing Rights, the "paper gold" designed to serve as the linchpin of a future monetary system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -Three medical experts openly despaired at a Senate hearing today that the public would ever believe the truth about obesity: It is food that makes one fat, not pills that make one thin.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (UPI) Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that he had acted to remove Harold Gibbons as head of the union's 13-state Central Conference because "Gibbons has not measured up to the work."

The Reserve Oil Gas Company and Western Crude Oil, Inc., of Denver jointly announced yesterday that directors of both companies had agreed in principle to a merger of Western Crude Oil into Reserve Oil through an exchange of stock valued at about $26million.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -- The Government revealed today that it had a second wiretap involving a member of the defense team in the Pentagon papers case, and a Federal judge set Tuesday morning for a hearing on the matter.

Although snowbelt states prohibit the chasing of wild animals by snowmobile operators, the practice still continues to varying degrees in some areas, as acknowledged by the Colorado Wildlife Division's recent announcement that it might have to tighten its restrictions against the abuse.

On Dec. 5 this year, the day honoring the Constitution of the Soviet Union, Valery N. Chalidze wrote an article on The Times Op-Ed Page describing unconstitutional repressions bearing down on his Soviet colleagues in dissent. "Will the movement in defense of human rights live on, or will the participants in this movement be imprisoned, exiled, intimidated, broken?" he asked.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14--Juan Domingo Peron left Argentina today and turned down any chance to become President again. He rejected a nomination that he was in any case ineligible to accept under the rules laid down by the military Government.

DENVER, Dec. 14 (AP) -Julius Keye set an American Basketball Association record last night with 12 blocked shots. The last one was the most crucial as the Denver Rockets posted a 103-99 victory over the Virginia Squires.

A. L. Rowse, the tart Elizabethan scholar, whose assertive and offbeat life of Shakespeare made for a lively and argumentative literary season back in 1964, has with this volume completed his magisterial survey of the Elizabethan age: its structure, its spirit, its achievement, its influence.
MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- Some of the Soviet Union's leading legislative and law-enforcement officials declined today to comment on Dr. Chalidze's case.
TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- A bill described by its sponsors as the strongest in the country in protection of news sources won final legislative approval this evening.

Steve Tannen has been injured so often this season one might get the idea he's related to Joe Blfstk, the friend of Lil' Abner who walks around with a black cloud hovering over his head and creates calamity wherever he goes.

HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -A 30-foot-high lunar sounder antenna aboard the Apollo 17 command ship America, has been found to be in working order, ending fears that it would have to be blown off the craft.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- City Council President Louis M. Turco today called Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's nomination of Police Lieut. Edward L. Kerr to be the city's first black police director "another Eagleton affair."
The money market tightened this week, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

Directors of the Mead Corporation, a producer of paper and other allied products, approved yesterday a $14-million reserve to cover the cost of phasing out marginal operations to be charged against 1972 earnings.
WARSAW, Dec. 14 -- An outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Eastern Europe is creating widespread travel disruption and mounting economic losses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -Total business inventories, until recently a sluggish element in the expanding economy, rose substantially in October for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.
GARY, Ind., Dec. 14 (AP) -- An experimental program in which a Palo Alto, Calif., company operated a Gary elementary school has been discontinued because it was not working, school officials said.

Don't, please don't be put off by the colossal length of John Gardner's fourth novel, "The Sunlight Dialogues," for it is not at all what fictions of its length (nearly 700 large pages) so often turn out to be -- that is, either realism of such minute detail that the author's interest in his story long outlasts the reader's, or experimentation of such mind-numbing self-indulgence that few readers' interests are aroused in the first place.
TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- The Senate today gave final legislative approval to two bills permitting the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend $650-million on masstransit improvements.

Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso yesterday said that he would ask the State Legislature to prevent New York City from imposing the full city resident income tax on all future city employes who reside in the suburbs. A bill requiring full taxation was passed unanimously by the City Council on Wednesday.

Press reports and Washington rumors continue to fuel speculation that the Foreign Service and the Department of State will be "vitalized." However worthy this objective, it will not be easy to achieve.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -William Farr, the Los Angeles journalist jailed two weeks ago for refusing to reveal his news sources, is being held here in isolation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Enemy gunners fired rockets at Bienhoa air base and an outlying village 15 miles northeast of Saigon in a predawn attack today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14 -- Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today that the Government would reform the white-administered aboriginal educational system in a move to save the vanishing culture of the native Australian people.
The Tennessee Valley Authority awarded yesterday to the General Electric Company what is believed to be the largest nuclear order ever in terms of generating capacity.

Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said yesterday that his agency would use, "if necessary," new authority granted by Congress to prevent foreign airlines from offering "eneconomic" fares during a threatened trans-Atlantic airline price war.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday met a "surgeon," who in his light green cottons looked as though he was fresh from the operating room; a "telephone lineman" with tools bulging from his kit, and assorted "hippies."

DALLAS, Dec. 14 (AP) -James Silas, a rookie, hit a pro high of 29 points tonight and Rich Jones, a forward, scored 9 key fourth-quarter points to lead the Dallas Chaparrals to a 121-113 victory of the Kentucky Colonels.
TOKYO, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -A Government spokesman today denied a report in The New York Times that suggested that China might give military aid to Japan if Japan was attacked by the Soviet Union.
The first full DKG, Inc., campaign for the Dollar Savings Bank will break on Monday and it will mark the Bronx-based institution's debut on TV.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The world's largest machine for scientific experiments, a $250million atom smasher that accelerates atomic particles around a four-mile ring, has generated a proton beam with twice as much energy as the original design called for, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, in the opening round of negotiations yesterday, asked for a 25 per cent wage increase in a new three - year contract covering 60,000 dressmakers in an eightstate area.

The first men to visit the moon, Neil A. Armstrong and Edwin E. Aldrin Jr., landed there on July 20, 1969. Yesterday, less than three and a half years later, Eugene A. Cernan and Harrison H. Schmitt rocketed off the moon.

About five years ago the players of the Evenings for New Music programs headed by Lukas Foss would stride grimly on stage and engage some complicated serial music. Times have changed. Now Evenings for New Music make dulcet sounds and are all but romantic in nature. One of two things therefore suggests itself: (a) Mr. Foss has undergone a major conversion, or (b) academic serialism is a thing of the past.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Gordon L. Calvert was joining its staff as vice president and general counsel, based in Washington. Mr. Calvert is 51 years old and has been executive vice president and general counsel of the Securities Industry Association.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- The Republican and Democratic leaders of the Assembly, in separate auguries concerning the 1973 Legislature, said today that they hoped to provide some relief for heavily taxed homeowners.

PARTICIPANTS -- The Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, electrical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperating employes, as well as some supervisors.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A palace spokesman said today that a military tribunal had convicted three Jordanians, among them a royal guard commander, of having plotted to overthrow King Hussein. The spokesman did not announce the sentences.

Harry Davidoff, secretarytreasurer of a Teamsters Union local of ground-service employes at Kennedy International Airport, was convicted last night by a Federal court jury in Brooklyn on 21 of 23 counts of violating the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -President Nixon announced today that he was giving his Domestic Council expanded authority and appointing a new executive director to free John D. Ehrlichman, his chief domestic affairs adviser, to take on "additional responsibilities" for the President.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- The New York Rangers could hardly have chosen a less auspicious time for their first appearance of the season in Boston Garden. They ran into the pent-up fury of the Boston Brains, who bombarded them with four goals in the second period, a total of 55 shots on goal and a final score of 4-2 tonight.

In some ways, this is just another pretty good Mahattan Spanish restaurant. They know how to lard a roast with ham (boliche mechado). It does not have the luscious tenderness and flavor of homecooked versions of this dish that have been lengthily marinated in lime juice, but this pot roast is still quite good value.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 14 -- Edmond Leburton, the Frenchspeaking co-president of the Belgian Socialist party, accepted a mandate from King Baudouin today to form a government.

Martha Graham is an artist much and sensibly concerned with past events. She sees the past as a mirror to the soul; she contemplates and reflects. One of the very first -- possibly even the first -- of her "time-past works," is the nowadays little-known "Herodiade."
The Knicks, who will play the Bulls tonight in Chicago, announced yesterday that they were sending Tom Riker, a rookie forward, to the Allentown Jets of the Eastern League.
BONN, Dec. 14 -- Willy Brandt was inaugurated today for a second term as Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany after his election in the Bundestag.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -The White House formally dissociated itself today from the cease-fire proposal made two days ago by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam and said it would support only the plan that Henry A. Kissinger has been negotiating with the North Vietnamese in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The Government ordered 12 automobile makers today to back up more than 100 advertisements ranging from General Motors' statement that steel beams in its Vega are "comparable to highway guardrails" to Volkswagen's contention that it gets superior gas mileage.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Sir Michael Swann, principal of Edinburgh University and a highly regarded biologist, was named chairman of the governors of the British Broadcasting Corporation today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Complaints about sex discrimination have exceeded complaints about racial discrimination, the director of the state's Division on Civil Rights said today.

The exhibition exchange between the Metropolitan Museum and the Louvre is, according to Douglas Dillon, president of the Metropolitan, "the most important loan agreement ever made between two of the world's leading museums."

While you touched upon extremely valid issues such as pay increases and tenure in your editorial "Unionized University," you failed to raise what seems to me to be the most obvious question: If the Board of Higher Education (B.H.E.) and the union both owe their existence to the needs of the students ,whom they serve, why don't students have a voice in the contract which will shape educational policy for years to come?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration today revived a two-year-old proposal guaranteeing refunds to customers who buy dangerous toys or other banned hazardous substances.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- New England's governors unanimously ordered today an immediate freeze on the hiring of new personnel for the controversial New England Regional Commission and called for an evaluation of the federally funded development agency with a view toward reducing its size and programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Nixon is planning to name John A. Scali, a former journalist now serving the President as a special consultant on foreign policy, as United States representative to the United Nations, White House personnel said today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Tennessee escaped the clutches of a press defense late in the game and defeated Syra cuse, 87-83, in the Volunteer tournament tonight. Missouri took advantage of a seldom-called lane violation to beat Holy Cross, 68-65.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15 -- Former President Harry S. Truman, already hospitalized in "very serious" condition because of lung congestion and a weak heart, was threatened tonight by kidney failure and inability to absorb nourishment as his condition further deteriorated.

HARTFORD, Dec. 15 (AP) -The Connecticut Real Estate Commission refused yesterday to allow a Philadelphia company to advertise or sell in Connecticut home sites in Israel known as "Sabra-Carmel Hills."

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Burlington Magazine, an esteemed monthly dealing with the history and criticism of art, describes as "sinister" the policy of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in selling some of its paintings and using the proceeds to buy others.

STORMVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Inmates at Green Haven State Correctional Facility remained locked in their cells today as correction officials tried to finish their search for weapons after finding a "significant number" in the last two days.
SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 15 -- South Koreans voted today to elect 2,359 delegates to the National Conference for Unification, which will choose a new president.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Federal Grand Jury is conducting an antitrust investigation into at least six major sugar companies, industry spokesmen said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Administration officials said today that the United States and Chile would begin high-level talks here next Wednesday aimed at finding solutions to the increasing problems between them.

The new director of Women Marines is Col. Margaret A. Brewer, who has spent 20 of her 42 years with the corps. She will be the seventh director of the Women Marines, succeeding Col. Jeanette I. Sustad, who is retiring.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- If every citizen decided to preempt his share of the national parks at the same time, he would be standing on about one-tenth of an acre, within a pebble's toss of the next person.
Following are the highlights of the revised Apollo 17 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern standard.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Dave Cowens scored 31 points and played inspiring defense to lead the Boston Celtics to a 102-98 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight in the National Basketball Association. Cowens pulled down 19 rebounds and harassed Wilt Chamberlain as the Celtics won their seventh in a row and ran the N.B.A.'s best won-lost record to 24-3.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 16 -- American B-52 bombers stepped up their raids on North Vietnam to a record of 16 missions during the 24hour period ended at noon yesterday, United States military spokesmen reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Price Commission granted pre-Christmas price increases today to the Mattel Company, a leading toy manufacturer; the Bulova Watch Company, and George A. Hormel Co. meat packers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Henry A. Kissinger met with President Nixon today for the fourth time in two days and conferred individually with other high Administration officials on the outlook for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

In its Nov. 11 editorial "The Abortion Front," The Times once again aligns itself with those pledged to retain the 1970 New York State Abortion Law. While The Times seeks to find some consolation in the results of the November election, it seems, rather, that the net effect both in New York State and nationwide was to indicate a strong trend away from abortion as a solution to social problems.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The General Assembly today approved the establishment of an ambitious international program for safeguarding the human environment.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 15 -- Former President Harry S. Truman, already hospitalized in "very serious" condition because of lung congestion and a weak heart, was threatened tonight by kidney failure and inability to absorb nourishment as his condition further deteriorated.
Food Fair Stores, which had a loss in the last quarter of fiscal 1972 had a net income in the initial quarter of fiscal 1973, Myer B. Marcus, chairman, reported yesterday. The quarter ended Nov. 18.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Antoine Riboud started off selling bottles and ended up in control of the company that makes them. Then he went on to make the stuff that goes inside.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended trading in two Wyo ming-based firms because of the dissemination of what it described as false information concerning a possibe skin-cancer cure.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The officers of 15 local building trades unions have joined with members of the Chicago Contractors Association to train minority workers in construction skills and get them admitted to construction unions.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market ended mixed yesterday in active trading.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Three newsmen have filed a Superior Court suit contending that Los Angeles County is spending public funds illegally to keep William Farr, a reporter, in jail.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 15 -Four former Cabinet ministers who controlled the Moroccan economy were sentenced to prison terms ranging from 4 to 12 years today when convicted of accepting bribes from European and American companies who were awarded multimillion dollar contracts in Morocco.

Unionism is a stronghold of the one-party system of government. Challengers of the entrenched leadership can expect vilification as selfish adventurers, agents of the employers and wreckers of the union's hard-won gains. Nowhere has this despotic tradition been more ingrained than in the United Mine Workers, once the most powerful of unions, now a scandal-racked skeleton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15--President Nixon is planning to name John A. Scali, a former journalist now serving the President as a special consultant on foreign policy, as United States representative to the United Nations, White House personnel said today.

What was on Johnny Bench's mind yesterday, 96 hours after lung surgery? "I'll have to find a nurse," said the Cincinnati Reds' bachelor slugger. "A couple of friends are nurses -- and they said they'd stay with me."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission imposed penalties today on the brokerage firm of Weis, Voisin Co. of New York, because of alleged frauds in connection with the sale of stock in the Dumont Corporation.

The head of the city's Housing and Development Administration told a City Council committee yesterday that its proposed bill to dismantle the agency would make housing problems here worse instead of solving them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The San Francisco 49ers shoot for their third straight National Football Conference West title, while the disappointed Minnesota Vikings play for pride tomorrow when the clubs meet in the final regular-season game of the 1972 season.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The Metropolitan Museum of New York and the Louvre announced today a program of cooperation to make the treasures of two of the world's great museums available for joint exhibition.

YONKERS, Dec. 15 -- Part I of the two-day Old Glory Sale attracted 750 horsemen and horsewomen, who spent $433,600 for 140 standardbreds at Yonkers Raceway today. The average of $3,097 set a record for a single day's Old Glory winter sale.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 15 -The chairman of the Parks Committee of the Suffolk County Legislature, R. Thomas Strong, suspended himself as chairman of that committee today after being asked to do so by Michael J. Grant, the Legislature's presiding officer.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- City Court Judge Charles Roskoski voluntarily suspended himself from the bench yesterday pending results of an investigation into his involvement in an incident at a Newburgh diner early Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- In Philadelphia, Steve Carlton is called "the franchise." The left-handed pitcher, with a 27-10 won-lost record, accounted for nearly half of the Phillies' victories in 1972.

The New York Rangers, somewhat the worse for wear after being cuffed around Boston Garden by the Bruins Thursday night, will play the Minnesota North Stars tonight at Bloomington (WOR-TV, Channel 9, 9 o'clock).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Severe restrictions on the use of methadone were made public today by the Food and Drug Administration in an effort to exert better control over this widely used substitute for heroin.

Carol Wincenc, Juilliard-trained and currently principal flutist of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, came back to New York on Thursday night to make her debut here in Carnegie Recital Hall as a solo artist, sponsored by the Concert Artists Guild.
The American Stock Exchange adopted yesterday stiffer listing standards for applicant companies engaged in the operation of race tracks and gambling casinos.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 15 -- A policeman and a part-time soldier were shot to death in Northern Ireland today, bringing to four the number of persons killed by terrorists during the last 24 hours.

TRENTON, Dec. 15--Conspicuously displayed sanitary inspection notices--white for pass, yellow for maybe, pink for an at least temporary closing--made their initial appearance today at restaurants as New Jersey began to implement the country's toughest statewide health code for retail food establishments.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 15 -- The Commonwealth Arbitration Commission, which sets basic wage rates for Australia, ruled today that women must be paid equally with men turning out the same work.

Officials of the two major Federal agencies involved in seizing and storing contraband drugs said yesterday that they knew of no disappearances of heroin comparable to those reported by the New York Police Department this week.
Twenty-four more pounds of heroin impounded during the celebrated "French Connection" case of a decade ago has been stolen from the Police Department's cluttered property-storage room in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The Intelsat agreement on the management of the orbital telecommunications system will be brought into force in 60 days, the State Department said today.

Edward R. Egan, the "French Connection" detective who was dismissed because he allegedly mishandled drugs seized as evidence, charged yesterday that "slipshod procedures" in the property clerk's office of the Police Department might have been behind the theft of $10-million worth of heroin from a police office vault.

Auguste Joseph Ricord was convicted in Federal District Court here yesterday of conspiring to smuggle narcotics, culminating a two-year effort by the Government to sever the so-called "Latin-American connection" in international heroin trafficking.

MAHOPAC, N.Y., Dec. 15, (AP) -- The Mahopac School Board voted 6 to 3 last night to reinstate a teacher who was dismissed 20 months ago because, she said, she had added a peace poster to a school Christmas display.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Dec. 15 (AP)--Six students at a campus dance sponsored by the Stevens Institute of Technology Chinese Students Association were shot and wounded late tonight when four young men were denied admission into the affair.
SILVER SPRING, Md., Dec. 15 -- Rank-and-file insurgents in the United Mine Workers Union won a decisive victory today in the long struggle to oust the union's president, W. A. Boyle.

When the potential dummy has bid two suits, the second of them is often the one for the defense to lead. A convincing illustration of this occurred in a recent Von Zedtwitz Knockout Team match in New York.

A very important event took place for the young Puerto Rican-born dancer Manuel Alum at the new and very agreeable Exchange Theater on Bank Street on Thursday night. His new troupe, the Manuel Alum Dance Company, made its highly successful debut.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Jean Paul Getty, probably the world's richest man, celebrated his 80th birthday until early this morning with 200 guests, a phone call from President Nixon, an exchange of cheek kisses with women spanning three generations, and a promise never to marry again.
Four major baking companies were fined a total of $175,000 in Federal Court here yesterday for fixing bread prices in the New York region.
Reports of Larry Grantham's retirement always seem to surface at this time of year.

One of Russia's better-kept cultural secrets over the last 25 years, Mikhail Alexandrovich made his American debut Thursday night in Town Hall. Although an immensely popular singer in the Soviet Union (he has received the Stalin Prize, and more than 20 million of his records have been sold), the tenor, who is Jewish, was never allowed an exit visa until last year.

It is a long jump from the Texas Panhandle to Madison Square Garden. Perhaps, suggested Coach Dennis Walling yesterday, that is one reason why his West Texas State basketball team has never won in the big arena.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- Italian newsmen are protesting a court order banning a Sicilian writer-editor from practicing the journalistic profession for a year following a conviction on a libel charge.

The special Wyoming County grand jury investigating last year's inmate rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility returned its first indictments yesterday. But it will be impossible, until Monday, to know who or how many were indicted, and on what charges, because all 37 indictments were sealed.

A mail room and clerical employe at Governor Rockefeller's office at 22 West 55th Street has pleaded guilty to petit larceny in connection with a charge that he had completed travel vouchers worth at least $250, using fictitious names, for his own use.
Reports of Larry Grantham's retirement always seem to surface at this time of year.

The Giants have good reason to be pleased with several decisions they made this year -- the acquisition of Jack Gregory and Norm Snead, for example, and the drafting of Larry Jacobson and John Mendenhall. But they also have to be pleased with a decision they didn't make last year.

It is a long jump from the Texas Panhandle to Madison Square Garden. Perhaps, suggested Coach Dennis Walling yesterday, that is one reason why his West Texas State basketball team has never won in the big arena.

Your Dec. 6 editorial "Unionized University" equates faculty unionism, along with "automatic promotion and instant tenure," with an "adoption of the public school staffing model," teachers being "interchangeable."
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The Chicago Bulls outplayed the New York Knicks in the fourth quarter of a fast-moving defensive battle tonight and scored a 90-86 victory before 11,329 at the Chicago Stadium.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Still banned in Italy, Bernardo Bertolucci's audacious film, "Last Tango in Paris," with Marlon Brando and Marie Schneider, had its premiere here today. All the notices were raves, but the critics differed in their classification of the film's qualities.

MIAMI, Dec. 15 (AP)--Cuba and Chile issued a joint communique today denouncing "imperialist maneuvers" that they said were designed to punish economically those countries that do not share North American social and ideological policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Treasury announced today that it was considering the sale of a long-term bond issue early in January.

American Montessori Society officials accused toy and game manufacturers of deceptively labeling toys and games "Montossori" even though these products have no connection with the worldwide educational system.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Bryan Campbell and Michel Plante rapped in two goals each tonight and carried the Philadelphia Blazers to a 6-4 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.
The business of evaluating mutual fund holdings is almost as demanding as owning stocks directly.

ANCHORAGE, Dec. 15 (AP) -In what has been called a "historic" first involving "untold millions" in oil resources, Alaska has been given title to submerged lands in Cook Inlet in a dispute with the Federal Government.

Pierre Boulez and the New York Philharmonic are scheduled to record Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra on Monday, and if Thursday night's subscription performance can be taken as a fair indication, the disk could be a prize-winner.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The United States Attorney Douglas Gonzales said today several of the six deputies suspected by the F.B.I. in the killings of two Southern University students Nov. 16 had refused to take lie-detector tests.
Twenty-four more pounds of heroin impounded during the celebrated "French Connection" case of a decade ago has been stolen from the Police Department's cluttered property-storage room in Manhattan.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Kansas City-Omaha Kings charged back from a 15-point deficit to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 140-132, in overtime tonight. Dave Bing of the Pistons sent the game into overtime when he took an in-bounds pass and fired from 30 feet, the ball banking off the glass and into the hoop with 2 seconds left.

Works by an unusual group of artists -- inmates at a maximum-security prison -- will go on view Feb. 2 at the National Collection of Fine Arts of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. The display, entitled "From Within," will continue through March 25 and then travel to museums in New York and other cities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Federal Power Commission staff has recommended for the first time that a major interstate natural gas pipeline stop charging big customers lower average prices thna are paid by small customers.

HOUSTON, Dec. 15 -- Apollo 17 circled the moon today, surveying its surface with cameras and remote-sensing instruments and preparing for the rocket blast tomorrow that should start the astronauts on their return journey to earth.

The police suspended their week-old drive against street venders of hot dogs yesterday after a mayoral aide described the order for seizure of the pushcarts and the arrest and day-long detention of the venders as "too sweeping."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial production, now beginning to increase rapidly, rose a further 1.1 per cent in November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -With another round in the Paris negotiations ended and with Henry A. Kissinger back in Washington briefing officials, many important questions remain unanswered publicly, and uncertainty and confusion continue to surround tile talks. Following are some or the questions and an attempt to define the situation that now exists:

Until J. Stewart Johnson stepped into the living room of a prominent French family in Lyon, he was convinced that traveling 3,800 miles to buy an Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann room for the Brooklyn Museum was anything but a wild goose chase.
Newark officials are trying to duplicate records stolen from City Hall on about 170 buildings demolished under the Public Employment Program.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Bob Dandridge scored 18 points, leading a balanced attack that carried the Milwaukee Bucks to a 98-82 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight. The Bucks are 10-0 against Cleveland since the Cavs entered the league three years ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The Chicago Bulls outplayed the New York Knicks in the fourth quarter of a fast-moving defensive battle tonight and scored a 90-86 victory before 11,329 at the Chicago Stadium.

DALLAS, Dec. 15 (AP) -Southern Methodist University hired Dave Smith of Oklahoma State today as head football coach. Smith was an assistant coach for eight years at S.M.U. until he went to Winnipeg of the Canadian Football League in 1970, where he was offensive coordinator.
BONN, Dec. 15 -- Willy Brandt started his second term as Chancellor today with a vow that he would be "as down to earth as possible," and indicated that he expected to concentrate on domestic policy.
Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., announced yesterday it had entered into preliminary negotiations with Missouri Beef Packers, Inc., on the possibility of combining the two companies.

The nation's longest major stakes race on the flat, the Display Handicap, will serve as the feature attraction on the program at Aqueduct today. If there is any kind of acceptable weather, which is rather unlikely, a crowd of 35,000 may attend, for the card is the final one of the New York thoroughbred racing season.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- A second case in which a family became ill after eating Deerfield Fordhook frozen lima beans was reported today by state health officials.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Carolina Cougars bolted to a 21-point lead in the second quarter tonight and trounced the Virginia Squires, 113-97, in an American Basketball Association game.
WEIRTON, W. Va., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Twenty-one men were killed today in an explosion and fire at the Weirton Steel Division's new coke plant on Brown Island in the Ohio River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A 14-year-old boy invented a simple way to show his father's age on a birthday cake. He managed to do it with one candle displaying three colors. John Henry Kumm, now 17 and a high school senior in Severna Park, Md., will he be granted Patent 3,706,523 next week for the one-candle device, which is called Resistage.

John Reardon, who stepped in for an indisposed Cesare Siepi Thursday night to sing his first Don Giovanni at the Metropolitan Opera, did a commendable job -- especially considering the circumstances. He had never performed the part in Italian before, had not sung it at all since the mid-sixties (he can't remember exactly when) and had had, to put it charitably, minimal rehearsal.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- "It is the traditional refuge for the little guy when he is scared," the trader said as the feverish demand for Napoleons, the dime-sized gold coins resting under so many mattresses in France, lifted the price to a new high again today.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Dec. 14 -- On orders from the presiding judge, a bulletproof shield has been installed in the Marin County Courthouse where several trials involving convicts from San Quentin Prison are to take place.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- The first major Eastern indoor track and field meet of the season will be held at Princeton University's Jadwin Gym tomorrow when about 775 athletes from 37 colleges and universities compete in the second Princeton Relays.

OXFORD, England, Dec. 15 -- Dressed in jeans and duffel coats, carrying cardboard suitcases -- the proletarian look has not been replaced -- the young men and women of Oxford University jammed the platform this morning waiting for trains to take them home for the Christmas break.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Wes Unseld's controversial layup with 19 seconds left and his clinching free throws with a second remaining gave the Baltimore Bullets a 94-91 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.
ENGLEWOOD, Dec. 15 -- "Good morning, we've come to make an inspection," said John Ferraiola, spreading out copies of Chapter 12 of the State Sanitary Code.
HONG KONG, Saturday, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- The Vietcong charged today that the United States was trying to prolong the Vietnam war and warned it was ready to fight on until victory.

It is too early to write off Juan Peron as a political force in Argentina; but his 28-day visit to his homeland -- the first in seventeen years -- has dramatically cut down the myth, leaving only the man and the politician. Many of his followers are disillusioned and the divisions in their disparate ranks are again surfacing.

HARTFORD, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal panel was asked today to withhold a ruling on the tax-exempt status of Elks Club and Moose lodges in Connecticut until the United States Supreme Court decides the constitutionality of the tax exemptions.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Six weeks after Judith Silver Shapiro won her fight for an exit visa from the Soviet Union for her husband, Gavriel, the Shapiros are apparently planning a divorce, Jewish Agency officials said today.

When Marlene Dietrich lights up the television screen on Jan. 13, looking all peaches and creamy and sparkling in a $30,000 Jean Louis dress, she will sing "I Wish You Love," the title of the Columbia Broadcasting System special.

The Sierra Pacific Power Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed offering of 500,000 common shares. The offering through underwriters managed by Stone Webster and Dean Witter, is expected next month. The company's stock was clown 1/4 at 15 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Major Gen. Jewell C. Maxwell, who retired from the Air Force on Nov. 1 after more than 30 years of service, joined the Boeing Company as a vice president on Nov. 30. According to the aerospace company, he is "on special assignment reviewing technical and management program performance."

Rising prices of fuel oil may force a number of ship operators to resort to nuclear ship propulsion by early 1975, according to James J. Henry, a naval architect who is president of the J. J. Henry Company, Inc., here.
MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Bob Griese, the Miami Dolphins quarterback said today he was resigned to backing up Earl Morrall through the championship playoff games.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- A disease that has caused the slaughter of more than a thousand head of livestock in England's Midlands in the last week was identified today as swine vesicular disease and not foot-and-mouth disease, as had been suspected.
Negotiators for the Columbia Broadcasting System and its striking technicians union yesterday recessed mediation talks in Washington, but will resume them Monday at 1 P.M.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller gave short shrift today to a hope espoused by Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea that a revenue surplus at the end of the state fiscal year might be used to alleviate the tax burden on homeowners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Henry A. Kissinger met with President Nixon today for the fourth time in two days and conferred individually with other high Administration officials on the outlook for a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war.

This weekend's big production on television is a ballet. "The Sleeping Beauty," featuring Tchaikovsky's music and Rudolf Nureyev as guest artist with the National Ballet of Canada, will be presented by the Public Broadcasting Service tomorrow at 7 P.M.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -Juan Peron's party today renominated the 77-year-old leader for president of Argentina, only 23 hours after Mr. Peron had declined the candidacy and left Argentina.

The career of the American painter Sam Francis is something of a historical oddity. Now 49 years old, he has been for many years one of the most celebrated abstract painters on the world scene, yet he is one of the very few American artists of his generation whose reputation and influence owe little or nothing to New York.

HOUSTON, Saturday, Dec. 16--Apollo 17 circled the moon today, surveying its surface with cameras and remote-sensing instruments and preparing for the rocket blast tonight that should start the astronauts on their return journey to earth.

John Gardner, author of "The Sunlight Dialogues," a novel much in the news just now, says that his book "is also an attempt to bring back the illustrated novel," and he hopes to counteract objections made by Henry James in a famous letter to his publisher.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- A spokesman for striking pressmen at The New Haven Register and The Journal-Courier said yesterday that the newspaper had stopped paying medical and life insurance premiums for the workers.

The Times editorial "Unionized University'' (Dec. 6) misrepresents the issues in the negotiations between the Professional Staff Congress and the Board of Higher Education (B.H.E.). The board would abolish the City University salary system by which annual increments are earned for service and experience, and substitute a pork barrel by which individuals must negotiate alone for increases beyond a fixed range.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- The hijacker of a Quebecair passenger liner was ordered to undergo a mental examination today when he appeared in court a day after surrendering to police at the international airport here.
TAMATAVE, Madagascar, Dec. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- Refugees continued to stream out of this port city today in the wake of three days of tribal rioting, looting and arson.

Alan Watts has always been something more than a popular interpreter of Eastern religious thought to the West. He has also been an exemplar, a participant, a function, so to speak, of his teachings. He is not a man, say, like Arthur Waley, essentially a technician, bringing over the thoughts of one language into another.

BUFFALO, Dec. 15 (UPI) -Two of four men, including the reputed Rochester gambling boss, Frank J. Valenti, were found guilty last night on various counts of conspiracy and extortion in connection with extorting money from a suburban Buffalo contractor.
So-called hometown plans to integrate the construction industry should be replaced by a single statewide program, an advisory committee to the United States Civil Rights Commission said yesterday.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 15 -"We try to keep Dan [Issel] and Artie [Gilmore] in there as long as we can. If they can establish the inside game, then we feel we can control the outcome."

Representatives of virtually every major local organization on the West Side will attend a communitywide meeting Monday night "to see what joint action can be taken to force the city to improve conditions" for tenants of single-room-occupancy buildings.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- There is wonderful irony in the belief, now being expressed on all sides, that the United States can have peace in Vietnam if only it acts despite the objections of Nguyen Van Thieu. For American independence of Saigon has always been a prerequisite of any negotiated settlement.

A negligence award of $2,175,000, one of the highest ever recorded in New York State, was granted yesterday by a six-man jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to a man who was paralyzed from his waist down by a power line of the Long Island Lighting Company.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Le Duc Tho flew to Moscow today on his way home to Hanoi to report on his 15 negotiating sessions with Henry A. Kissinger.

The head of New York City's Housing and Development Administration told a City Council committee hearing yesterday that a proposed bill to dismantle the superagency would worsen housing problems instead of helping, and would weaken current attempts to handle the housing situation.

During four years as director of the United States Information Agency Frank J. Shakespeare Jr. has irritated foreigners, demoralized old agency hands and embarrassed American diplomacy with his stridently propagandistic hardline approach to the presentation of American policy abroad.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Norman Wexler, award-winning playwright and screenwriter, has been accused of threatening President Nixon's life and jailed pending a Federal hearing.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) -Soviet and American engineers have made the first tests of a docking mechanism to be used in the joint space mission planned for the last half of 1975.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- The Environmental Protection Agency today ordered automobile manufacturers to stop installing devices aimed at turning off certain emission control equipment.
Why not a wine book for a gift this Christmas? There are some excellent ones around and because they are part textbook and part art book, they make great gifts.
MIAMI, Dec. 15 -- Under the microscope of a national TV audience, the Miami Dolphins will attempt tomorrow to become the first National Football League team to complete an unbeaten 14-game season.

MADISON TOWNSHIP, Dec. 15 -- Three days of public hearings this week on the proposed Toms River spur of the New Jersey Turnpike turned up opposition from residents of the affected area who fear more dirt, more noise, more traffic and more people.

With regard to Jeffery St. John's attack [Op-Ed Dec. 5] on "futurists," specifically the Meadows, Meadows, Randers and Behrens study (The Limits to Growth), I must take exception with his claim that they are unscientific and "intellectually dishonest." This is not true.

The death of a 74-year-old physician who was found bound and gagged in his West Side quarters Thursday evening was listed as a homicide due to strangulation, the Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

The special Wyoming County grand jury investigating last year's inmate rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility returned its first indictments yesterday. But it will be impossible, until Monday, to know who or how many were indicted, and on what charges, because all 37 indictments were sealed.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Britain will not fix a new parity for the floating pound before she enters the European Economic Community next month, Anthony Barber, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today.

With understatement, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has characterized as "a scandal in the department" the theft of heroin -- which yesterday was revealed to total 81 pounds -- from a Police Headquarters annex on Broome Street. Not only is the loss of that quantity of drugs unprecedented for any American law-enforcement agency, but the crime is conceded to have all the earmarks of an inside job.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- Have you ever flicked on your television and sat down to watch the news of the miseries of the world only to have your children grumble: "News? Aw, do we have to watch that stuff again?"

SOONER than expected -- but not surprisingly -- President Nixon let it be known last week that he intends to seek Congressional extension of the economic-controls program beyond its scheduled expiration date next spring. Upon that announcement, typically, there was a mild round of applause in the business and economic world and some hooting in the ranks of labor.

Having seen "Bad Company" before reading Stephen Farber's article, "The Deserter as Hero," I was not a little appalled by his overreading of an essentially pointless film. To describe it, as he does, as "one of the great American stories of coming-of-age," is to accept the film's final, flip plunge into an implicitly permanent acting-out of adolescent fantasy as, somehow, a definition of maturity.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who has been Manhattan prosecutor for 30 years and has been endorsed eight times by the major parties, is facing a serious challenge if he seeks re-election to a ninth term next year.
A Japanese company is currently building a soy and teriyaki sauce plant in a former cornfield in southeastern Wisconsin, where, eventually, the work force will total 100.

VAL GARDENA, Italy, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Roland Collombin of Switzerland became the fastest Alpine ski racer in history today, downhill and took the lead in the World Cup standings with a downhill victory here.

LAUREL, Md., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Grover (Bud) Delp, the only trainer in Maryland racing history to saddle 100 or more winners in a single season, recorded his 103d victory of the season today at Laurel. He saddled Bold Place of the Bon Etage Farm, the winner of the second division of the $16,750 First Lady Handicap.

THEY may not come to overshadow the countries of Western Europe as established tourist destinations but a number of developing lands are making strong bids to attract more visitors. If the amount of money being spent is any criterion, and it has been in the past, then a look at some United Nations statistics should give an idea where tourists will be heading in the next few years.

The Nixon Administration is reportedly giving high-level consideration to adoption of a national policy encouraging construction of artificial islands 10 to 30 miles at sea to accommodate huge tankers that would help supply the nation's growing energy needs.

WESTWOOD -- The musicians had scarcely finished taking their bows at the recital presented by the Young Concert Artists of Bergen County when scores of youngsters swarmed on stage, each vying for a closer look at the sleek, ebony harpsichord.
LONDON -- British Government leaders are of two minds about the Smithsonian agreement.

TOKYO -- Premier Kakuel Tanaka of Japan was less than his usual bouncy self last Monday as he surveyed a large white signboard with the names of his party's candidates for the national Diet in Sunday's election. The red roses above the names of the Liberal Democratic winners were at least 10 fewer than he had expected. "We must reflect on this," he said.

JERSEY CITY -- When Sister Madeleine, president of Englewood Cliffs College in Englewood Cliffs, asked faculty members this fall to volunteer as instructors in New Jersey correctional institutions, Charles Vukovitch offered to teach a sculpture class. Mr. Vukovitch is chairman of the fine arts department at the college; the request for volunteers came from the New Jersey Department of Higher Education.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 16 -- After 18 months of direct military rule, Thailand will have a new 20-man cabinet and an appointed 299-member national assembly, Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn announced today.

ROSELLE -- Buying a tank of oil for an elderly couple, getting groceries for a family caught between jobs, installing a telephone for a heart patient whose welfare check is meager -- these are among the small emergencies that church people here hope to handle with their new Dollar-A-Month Emergency Fund.

For followers of traditional jazz, New York is a pretty barren town. And for those traditionalists who prefer the New Orleans-based music of King Oliver, the early Louis Armstrong small groups and Jelly Roll Morton rather than the Chicago style associated with Eddie Condon, it is even more so.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. -- The Divine Miss M., as she calls herself, has been described as a funky blend of Mae West, Edith Piaf, Lotte Lenya and Sophie Tucker. On her first cabaret date here, a sellout week at the Troubadour, she established a personality that shines with the grandes dames of the music halls.

New York officials in the Federal, state and city governments yesterday honored Harry S. Truman at services in City Hall Plaza as, in Mayor Lindsay's words, "a President who was both a leader and a lesson for all of us."

The 5,000-family development under construction on Welfare Island by the State Urban Development Corporation has been designated a "new community" by the Federal Government, thus giving the development priority in obtaining Federal grants earmarked for community facilities.

NEWARK, Dec. 28 -- The Bronze Shields, an organization Of black policemen, and 11 persons will file suit in Federal Court tomorrow charging that blacks and Hispanic men are discriminated against by the Newark Police Department.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 28 -- Harry S. Truman, 33d President of the United States, was buried today in the dark soil of his beloved Missouri.

The state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, yesterday subpoenaed the files and other investigative materials of the Knapp Commission.

A detective with 12 years in the police Department was indicted yesterday in what the District Attorney said was a case in which he had knowingly arrested four innocent men. The detective was immediately suspended.

In your news article (Dec. 8) documenting the "broadening" scope of the Rhodes Scholarship awards to include students "not perfectly wellrounded," you fail to mention the institution's continued refusal to consider women for the scholarships.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 28 -- The Israeli Cabinet convened an emergency session in Tel Aviv today shortly after the first reports were received of the Arab guerrilla take-over of the Israeli Embassy in Bangkok.

WASHINGTON -- Can we scientists meet in Washington and ignore the fact that our national Administration is launching from this city the most massive air attacks in history? It is launching those attacks against concentrated centers of civilian population, while blandly announcing lists of military targets that under these circumstances insult the intelligence of every thinking person.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A Federal judge has ordered a $1.5-million damage suit filed against Under Secretar of State-designate William J. Casey and others.

Valerian Stux Rybar's autobiography runs to 1,300 impressive red and brown leather volumes, each with its cover imprinted in gold, and they are stacked floor-to-ceiling in the mirrored hallway of his New York apartment. Everybody notices them. Some guests even grab for the racier titles -- such tomes as "Only Love One," "Only Love Two," "Elsa Maxwell Discovers Me" or "I Sell Myself."

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 28 -- At 1:30 this afternoon, walking slowly, carrying a cane but not using it for assistance and staring straight ahead, the 87-year-old widow of Harry S. Truman emerged from the side door of her two-story white frame house today to attend her husband's funeral.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Onny Parun of New Zealand upset Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union in five sets today in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Australian Open tennis championships at Kooyong. The scores were 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company yesterday announced plans to participate in a new banking venture in London involving Barclays Bank International and the Rumanian Bank for Foreign Trade.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- The official Soviet media are maintaining a drumfire of criticism against the heavy air assaults on North Vietnam. The theme is broken campaign promises to American voters over the war in Indochina.

A Queens man whose release in $500 bail in connection with the holdup-shooting of a patrolman and a restaurant patron stirred a controversy was indicted yesterday by a grand jury investigating the crimes.
The total output of goods and services in the American economy rose by a record $33-billion in the fourth quarter of 1972, Chase Econometric Associates said yesterday.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Mrs. Harry S. Truman, 87 years old, the widow of the former President, will receive an annual pension of $20,000 and Secret Service protection for the remainder of her life.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A House Armed Services subcommittee, warning that any increase in military retirement pay could lead to a tax increase, has unanimously urged rejection of a Senate-passed proposal that would provide raises of up to 40 per cent for retired officers and increases for retired enlisted men.

Team games scored by international match points, whether knockout matches or the Swiss variety, are common ground for two groups of players: those whose normal activity is the matchpoint pair game normal in duplicate clubs and those who prefer the rubber-bridge table.

The financial entanglements of the Commonwealth United Corporation have finally been settled with the new Seeburg Industries, Inc., acquiring the business and operations of the former Seeburg Corporation of Delaware subsidiary from Commonwealth United, it was announced yesterday.

The chief cashier of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel was killed by a shotgun blast in the chest in the fashionable midtown hotel yesterday by a man the police identified as an assistant cashier who was discharged last week.

W. Willard Wirtz, Secretary of Labor in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, has resigned as one of the four trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company. His resignation, effective next Sunday, was accepted by Judge John P. Fullam, who is overseeing the activities of the railroad.

To a small, gimlet-eyed army of talent scouts, agents, directors, and other theater wheels, the uptown shows of the Equity Library Theater are an ideal talent display, remote from the traditional, midtown grind of auditions and casting calls.

Treasury bond prices drifted lower in light trading yesterday, apparently reflecting no more than the usual post-Christmas apathy in the credit markets. The corporate market was closed in mourning for former President Truman as was much of the tax-exempt sector.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- A three-judge Federal panel here has ruled that a law suspending Federal scholarship funds for students convicted of serious crimes is invalid because it is vague and "overbroad."

Citibank cannot defend as a question of "esthetic judgment" (news story, Dec. 20) its pollution of Park Avenue with a garish anti-Christmas tree topped by a logotype parody of the Star of Bethlehem. It is simply committing commercial indecent exposure.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y. Dec. 28 (AP) -- Eighty-eight-yearold Alfred Curt von Wolfersdorf was released yesterday from Binghamton State Hospital after spending 21 years in mental institutions because of a murder he was not convicted of and he says he did not commit.

WASHINGTON -- If confusion has been the chronic state of the American public mind during most of the Vietnam conflict, there is little to suggest that its terminal phase will be a period of enlightened understanding. Since Oct. 26 when we first became aware of the sudden hope in the Paris negotiations, our understanding of the situation has become increasingly clouded by veiled or inadequate official statements supplemented by endless media speculations.

TRENTON, Dec. 28 -- Governor Cahill today signed two bills approving a $650-million mass-transportation construction program by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and he urged the New York Legislature to approve identical legislation quickly.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Troops patrolled this earthquake-battered city today with orders to shoot looters, gangs of whom have been prowling the ruins and hauling away items ranging from food to refrigerators and stoves.

DETROIT (UPI) -- When "Wamba," a series of five photographs depicting a sequence of a man pulling down his undershorts, went on exhibition at the Detroit Institute of Arts, patrons complained and the pictures were removed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 28 -- Acting on the last day before the expiration of his special decree powers, President Nguyen Van Thieu last night quietly signed a law that South Vietnamese political leaders say will eliminate virtually all political parties except Mr. Thieu's new Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Bowing to consumer pressure and a court order, the Department of Agriculture has announced plans for a second major round of reforms in the labeling and content of hot dogs.

TORONTO, Dec. 28 -- About 8,000 economists attending the annual conference of the Allied Social Science Research Council in Toronto this week are hearing considerably more about the cause of blacks, women and radical economists than about Nixon's economic policy or problems in traditional economic theory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -Dairy funds and other specialinterest groups donated thousands of dollars for the re-election of President Nixon in a blackout period when campaign contributions were not made public just before the Nov. 7 election.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 28 -- One of Hanoi's most animated and colorful streets, Kham Thien, is a mass of ruins and a scene of desolation and mourning today in the wake of the latest series of American air raids.
ATLANTA, Dec. 28 (UPI) -Baltimore rode a hot streak by Mike Riordan to a 112-111 victory over Atlanta tonight to maintain first place in the National Basketball Association's Central Division.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- American corporations spent $754-million more overseas in the third quarter of 1972 than foreign companies spent here, the Commerce Department said today.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 28 -- from a series of black tie-at-home gatherings in stately Princeton homes to the hubbub of Good Time Charley's dimly lighted Kingston public house, Jerseyans will welcome the New Year according to the dictates of taste and purse.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The National Bank of Washington is suing Walter T. Duncan for nonpayment of a $200,000 loan that he took out two days before donating an identical amount to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Nature does not always know best and science can form a good base for social value judgments, two eminent scientists said today in disputing two widespread current beliefs.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 -- Michigan's Supreme Court today warned the state Legislature that the distribution of money for public schools must be fairer than in the past.

CAMDEN, Dec. 29 -- The State of New Jersey and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico were accused today in a suit filed in Federal District Court here of deliberately failing to protect the rights of migrant farm laborers throughout the state.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- One symptom of the state of our civilization is the loss of confidence in reason. Mysticism and anti-intellectualism flourish. R. D. Laing, the Savonarola-psychiatrist, says our society is so terrible that schizophrenia: is an appropriate reaction.

In a short, pre-holiday trading session, soybean futures jumped the daily 10 cent-a-bushel limit yesterday in the case of the three nearby delivery months -- January, March and May -- on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Dec. 29 -- Thirteen men described by law enforcement officials as "top organized-crime figures," including a former examiner for the New York State Tax Commission, were arrested today in connection with two $3-million-a year bookmaking rings. The rings were also said to have served as the "layoff organizations" for the operations of the Carlo Gambino crime "family."
A Federal mediator, Alfred Della Corte, conferred yesterday with negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road in a new attempt to find a solution to the 30-day-old strike.
Milk distributors yesterday forecast a rise in the retail price of milk of about half a cent a quart as a result of a new Federal mandate.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 29 -- Demolition experts said today that it would take eight months to a year to clear away the wreckage from last week's devastating earthquake here.

Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg will continue to serve as President Nixon's man at the Court of St. James's. Nixon Administration officials said that Mr. Annenberg had submitted a pro forma resignation as Ambassador to Britain, but that the President had rejected it.
The Daily News has rejected an advertisement paid for and signed by 151 of its editorial employes that calls on President Nixon to make peace in Southeast Asia "without further deay."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Ron Low and Jacques Plante shared their second shutout of the season tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs skated to a 4-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which is manufacturing 100 weapon detectors for the Federal Aviation Administration, received a patent this week on a refinement that it plans to incorporate in future instruments. Patent 3,707,672, which was granted to Robert C. Miller, Walter J. Carr and George T. Mallick Jr., scitists at the company's research laboratories in Pittsburgh, covers what is called the pulsed field technique.

A break in a water main under 39th Street and the Avenue of the Americas shortly before noon yesterday flooded the pavement and disrupted subway service on the local tracks of the Sixth Avenue line of the IND for about 45 minutes.

The Queens man who was released in $500 cash bail last week in connection with a holdup-shooting in an East Side restaurant was arrested yesterday on a 19-count indictment charging him with robbery and the attempted murder of four policemen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 29 -- South Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Tran Van Lam, said tonight that he believed the United States bombing of North Vietnam would force Hanoi's leaders to "accept serious negotiations."
TORONTO, Dec. 29 -- Economists wrestled here with new definition for the marketing and legal use of heroin but agreed they did not have enough facts.

On the basis of Labor Department statistics, the health field has been an area of conspicuous success for the Nixon Administration's anti-inflation controls. The over-all rate of increase in the cost of medical care has been slowed materially since August 1971. The Canteen Corporation and Avis, Inc., filed registration statements yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission on behalf of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in compliance with the conglomerate's antitrust settlement with the Justice Department.

So, flying in the face of tradition, they advise that corks not be popped in greeting the New Year.
