DENVER, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Samuel I. Newhouse and the Herald Company of New York lost a court round today in the four-year-old legal battle for control of The Denver Post.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP) -- In a game between the National Hockey League's division cellar-dwellers, the California Golden Seals posted a 5-2 victory over the New York Islanders tonight.
NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- John L. Redden, the outgoing Newark Police Director, said today that the "tragedy" of the Kawaida Towers housing controversy was further racial polarization of this city.
DATIL, N. M. -- Ninety miles away at the Adobe Ranch, Tom Wagner, Catron County's livestock inspector, finished the day's work about dusk, then clambered into his car and headed here.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 29 -- Johnny Roche and Johnny Baum got hot in overtime tonight to spark the New York Nets to a 114-104 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors tonight. The Nets snapped a five-game losing streak.

November chain-store and catalogue-house sales rose by 12 per cent from the corresponding month of 1971, a survey of leading retail organizations showed yesterday. The gain was slightly below the 12.2 per cent increase in November, 1971.
Citing an "acute shortage of blood," the Greater New York Blood Program has appealed to doctors in the metropolitan area to postpone all but urgent surgery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Democratic reformers have mounted what could be a successful drive to make the Democratic whip, the party's No. 3 leadership post in the House, an elective job.

The indictments from Attica have been trickling down like a leaky faucet. There is a political and rancid stench about the entire process. These indictments could well be a rallying cry for environmentalists as well as civil libertarians.

BANGKOK, Dec. 29 -- Newspapers and Thai Government officials congratulated themselves today on their success in avoiding any misfortune in yesterday's seizure of the Israeli Embassy by four Arab terrorists. They awaited the return of two Thai Cabinet officials who escorted them to Cairo.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 -- Shortly before 2 A.M. today, Premier Golda Meir sat in her office in Tel Aviv talking by telephone with Rehavam Amir, the Israeli Ambassador in Bangkok.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Anxiety is increasing among European governments over the United States bombing of North Vietnam, and there were mounting protests today at official level.
Beginning Monday, a 10-cent Hershey chocolate bar will still be a 10-cent Hershey chocolate bar, but its size and weight will be smaller.

TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- Arthur H. West, president of the New Jersey Farm Bureau, today defended New Jersey's system of preferential tax treatment for farmers, which was called a costly failure earlier this week by an independent research organization.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Crusaders, with Paul Andrea scoring two goals, ran their winning streak to four games tonight with a 5-3 victory over the Quebec Nordiques. The victory gave the Crusaders a 3-point lead over third-place New York and moved them to within 2 points of Eastern Division-leading New England.

MADRID, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Ford Motor Company has applied for Spanish Government permission to set up a plant producing 240,000 vehicles a year on the Spanish east coast, an Industry Ministry spokesman said today.
New York City deserves all our thanks for bringing the President's pollution control rollback into court.
Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
SZCZECIN, Poland, Dec. 24 -- An unsteady Polish customer, full of holiday spirit, stood in the lobby of the Arcona Hotel here, arguing with a waitress and the manager over his bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A Federal judge invalidated today a Labor Department directive giving states six more months to develop job safety programs that meet Federal standards.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann indicated today that France was trying to get negotiations between the United States and North Vietnam going again.
HOUSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Behind the shooting of Lucius Allen, the Milwaukee Bucks rallied early in the third period to take a lead they never relinquished as they downed the Houston Rockets, 114-101,

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Treasury Department published for the first time today the population, income and tax data on which it based its Federal revenue-sharing allocations and announced that state, county and local governments had until Feb. 12 to challenge its figures.

The Christmas Eve surveillance of the Danish seaman's movements from a Brooklyn pier to a girlfriend's apartment where 18.7 pounds of heroin had allegedly been stored since April, has led to the arrest here of the Dane and the owner of a Philadelphia Chinese-American restaurant.

The Federal Reserve System closed its books on 1972 yesterday with the nation's money supply expanding at a rate substantially faster than most economists believe is appropriate to the current economic boom.

It is the paradox of the Presidency that outsiders see it as the nation's most powerful office while successive incumbents complain of frustration and a recurrent sense of powerlessness over departmental programs and bureaucracies. President Nixon's appointments and administrative rearrangements in the weeks since his re-election are in part a response to this chronic institutional problem of effective Presidential control within the executive branch.

The state's special anticorruption prosecutor and the city's special narcotics prosecutor, who had been wrangling for a week over jurisdiction in the Police Department narcotics-theft case, moved toward a tentative rapprochement yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A recluse who touched off anxiety throughout the San Francisco Bay area when he predicted that a big earthquake would occur on Jan. 4 said today that he was all wrong.

STANFORD, Calif. -- On Nov. 25 the United States and Cuba began negotiations on an antihijacking pact in Havana. Press coverage of the talks and their possible significance has been extensive but often superficial, leading to an uncritical enthusiasm for the anticipated pact and to wishful thinking and overly optimistic speculation on an easing of tensions between the U.S. and Cuba in the near future.
Signs of preparation for the New Year were all over town yesterday.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- The city's budget gap for next year -- the difference between projected spending and revenues -- has been whittled to about $10-million and will mean a real estate tax increase "of 80 to 85 points," Finance Director J. Anton Jungherr said today.

AUBURN -- The sixth-ranked college football team in the nation will play in its fifth Gator Bowl game today at Jacksonville, Fla., against 13th-ranked Colorado, with defense and a pair of deceptive running attacks the trademarks of both teams.
A new contract covering 9,300 paraprofessional classroom aides was tentatively agreed upon yesterday by the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers.

Robin Ficker, the Maryland lawyer who lost his lawsuit to abolish the National Football League's rule banning television coverage of home games, las a bid yesterday to go on television tomorrow during the Dallas-Washington game and challenge the N.F.L. on its policy.

A "pony express" relay of 20 horses will carry the mail for Herve Filion today and tonight at Monticello Raceway as harness racing's leading driver attempts to reach the single-season mark of 600 winners. The Canadian is set to drive in 10 races during the double-header's 2:30 matinee and 10 more tonight.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Eddie Johnston, supported by goals by Bobby Orr and Mike Walton, stifled the Minnesota North Stars, 2-0, tonight as the Boston Bruins climbed into first place in the National Hockey League's East Division.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The continued spreading of salt on Massachusetts highways at the present rate is dangerous to the environment and may also be economically wasteful, a report issued yesterday by a Special Commission on Salt Contamination of Water Supplies said.

Crawling underneath a subway car, a transit patrolman saved a mans life yesterday by applying improvised tourniquets to his legs after three subway cars had rolled over the victim's feet, the Transit Police reported.

HOUSTON, Dec 9 (UPI) -- Scientists studying the rocks brought back by the Apollo 17 astronauts said today that they were unable to determine whether the orange soil found on the lunar surface proved the existence of lunar volcanic activity.

TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- Governor Cahill today signed into law two bills designed to aid the state's ailing bus lines by subsidizing student fares, eliminating certain taxes and reducing registration fees.
Addressing 200 clergymen, social workers, psychiatrists and other members of the medical profession at Riverside Church recently, Florence Wald suddenly broke down and wept.

The Janus Chorale and the American Brass Quintet joined forces Wednesday evening for a delightful Christmas concert at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The program, mostly baroque, fell into two halves (although from a thematic standpoint the first half leaked over into the first two pieces after the intermission).
All that scrap wood, those old newspapers and cardboard boxes we throw out today may be back tomorrow in the guise of some very sophisticated furnishings, sporting fancy price tags.

The Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Consolidated Edison Company of New York an emergency increase in its electric, gas and steam rates that would increase the utility's annual revenue by $110-million.
The Times of Dec. 23 carried a story under the headline "State's $50,000 Stipend Cut Upsets 'Superteachers.'"
A sharp tongue drove two armed bandits out of the Enrico Caruso beauty salon at 110 East 55th Street yesterday morning.

Liam Clancy, one of the vigorously Irish Clancy Brothers, is on his own this week and next at Kenny's Castaways, 211 East 84th Street. Wearing a brown corduroy cap, a mustache and a gray turtleneck sweater and strumming a guitar, he has managed to get away from the visual image of the Clancy Brothers as an ensemble, with their clean visages and white fisherman's-knit sweaters.
With trading activity hitting a record pace for the year, prices rose ysterday on the American Stock Exchange.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 29 (AP) -- John Newcombe gained the semifinals of the $53,300 Australian open tennis championships, the only major title he has not won, with a 6-4, 7-6, 6-3 victory today over Bob Carmichael, an Australian living in France.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Democratic, reformers have mounted what could be a successful drive to make the Democratic whip, the party's No. 3 leadership post in the House, an elective job.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Big Bill Walton and University of California, Los Angeles, racehorse attack overwhelmed Drake in the second half tonight as the defending national champions posted their 52d straight triumph, an 85-72 victory in the opening round of the Sugar Bowl basketball tournament.

The Christmas Eve surveillance of a Danish seaman's movements from a Brooklyn pier to a girlfriend's apartment, where 18.7 pounds of heroin had allegedly been stored since April, has led to the arrest here of the Dane and the owner of a Philadelphia Chinese-American restaurant.
A study released by the City College of New York indicates that its black graduates are earning more money on average than their white counterparts.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Ruth Hadass, one of the hostages held by the Arab guerrillas in the Israeli Embassy, clutched a wine glass and danced today as she shouted in Hebrew, "I didn't know it was so good to be alive."

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 -- A labor contract negotiating committee of five physicians and a dentist was chosen by the professional staff of the Jersey City Medical Center here this evening to represent it in bargaining sessions expected to be conducted with the board managers of the 650-bed institution.

PEKING, Dec. 29 -- Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the Vietcong's Foreign Minister, told 10,000 Chinese here today that the United States was trying to split the Vietnamese people from China and other Communist countries.
The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled in Trenton yesterday that hidden "pitfalls" in insurance policies could not be used to deny consumers protection when they needed it.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- A special committee named by Senator Warren M. Anderson, the Binghamton Republican who is the new Senate majority leader, will recommend that the number of permanent Senate committees be reduced from 31 to 24.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- Penn State will have a big defensive problem when it faces Oklahoma's wishbone offense in the Sugar Bowl football game Sunday night. Although defense has been a large part of the Nittany Lion's success in recent years, Oklahoma presents a most difficult task, according to Coach Joe Paterno.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- How women achieved "liberation" in the ancient Etruscan World is not yet clear to scholars, but, as art and literature disclose, it was a woman's world as much as a man's, unlike Greece and other lands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States, irritated by a statement by Premier Olof Palme of Sweden comparing the bombing of North Vietnam toNazi massacres of World War II, has asked Stockholm not to send a new ambassador to Washington.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union today opened the first major electric power station in its West Siberian oil fields, which are viewed by Moscow's planners as an important future source of energy supplies.
Citing an "acute shortage of blood," the Greater New York Blood Program has appealed to doctors in the metropolitan area to postpone all but urgent surgery.
ATLANTA, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- With a freshman quarterback, Dave Buckey, at the controls, North Carolina State crushed West Virginia, 49-13, tonight in the Peach Bowl.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels, led by Dan Issel, routed the Dallas Chapparrals, 131-104, tonight in preparation for an American Basketball Association showdown with the Carolina Cougars tomorrow night.

Wade, director of the Offtrack Betting Division of the Connecticut Gaming Commission, said today the commission expected that when the offtrack betting program gets under way the amount wagered in a year would approach $100-million. LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Evening News of London reported today from Moscow that Mr. Brezhnev had postponed a planned visit to the United States next spring because of the delay in a Vietnam settlement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A former labor member of the Pay Board charged today that the wage-and-price controls program was a "hoax" and called on Congress to kill the program instead of extending it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- House investigators charged today that the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission was hampered by poor morale, lack of understanding of purpose and an unworkable structure and had failed to formulate a proper observance of the nation's 200th anniversary.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 -- Franco's Army serenaded the Miami Dolphins here today and handed out hundreds of "safe conduct" passes assuring the Dolphins of a safe return to Miami.

HARTFORD, Dec. 30 -- Connecticut's economy is improving, but only because defense expenditures are increasing, the state's new Council of Economic Advisers reported this week. Its report, the first to be issued by the council, is a review of the years since World War II.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- The University of California, Los Angeles, is just seven games short of the collegiate basketball record of 60 straight victories after defeating Illinois, 71-64, in the final of the Sugar Bowl tournament today.

ATLANTA, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The American Cyanamid Corporation has announced that new technological advances have enabled it to discontinue plans to dump millions of pounds of acid wastes into the Atlantic Ocean.

NEWARK -- St. Timothy's House is planning to celebrate its 10th birthday in January, thus marking the completion of a decade that its director terms unique in the treatment of New Jersey youth problems.

PETER HERMAN ADLER, age 73, made his Metropolitan Opera debut in September conducting a super-charged rendition of Verdi's "A Masked Ball." His stick - waving received raves from the critics and at least as many bravos from the audience as were showered on Martina Arroyo, Placido Domingo and Sherrill Milnes.

THE last day of the year is traditionally an occasion for celebration and merriment, and no doubt there is much to be grateful for in the art events of 1972. Artists still pursue their difficult calling with an undiminished persistence and courage, even though the odds against all but a very small number ever winning a reasonable recognition of their labors remain as high as ever.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- A new Cabinet was formed in the Yemen Arab Republic today under Abdullah al-Hagri, a member of the presidential council.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senate advocates of a Federal no-fault automobile insurance law have revised their bill to conform in many respects with a recently drafted model state law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird's decision to draft no men in February may mean that thousands of men who lost deferments late in 1972 will escape callup. They are vulnerable for the draft during the first three months of 1973.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- Robbers of Egyptian tombs, operating in the 15th and 16th centuries B.C., became unwilling suppliers of looted art objects to contemporary Minoan Crete, mainland Greece and other lands trading with Egypt, an archeologist maintained today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Nixon has offered to put a labor union representative at a high level in every Federal Government department, a well-informed White House official has disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, said today that the first order of business when peace talks resume in Paris "should be the establishment of an in-place ceasefire and agreement on exchange of prisoners, as the details of a total settlement are worked out."

The International Debutante Ball, held at the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom last night, might now be considered to have adult status. The event dates to 1954, making it the same age as most of the 66 debutantes presented under its auspices this year.
The Knapp Commission has expressed guarded optimism about the chances that the corruption it said infected the Police Department in 1971 can be considerably reduced.

A 19th-century three-story police precinct stationhouse in a high-crime area of the Crown Heights-Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn is becoming a home for a group of artists, poets and sculptors.

Without fanfare, the Bruckner bottleneck in the Bronx will become the completed Bruckner Interchange Tuesday at 10 A.M., when three southbound lanes of the Bruckner Expressway, each a half-mile long, will be opened to traffic. The $68-million project, built with 90 per cent Federal funds and 10 per cent state funds, will link the New England Thruway with the Bruckner Expressway and the Triborough Bridge.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Bobby Schmautz turned in his second four-goal game of the season tonight and led the Vancouver Canucks to a 5-2 National Hockey League victory over the New York Islanders.

HOUSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Condredge Holloway, a quarterback who passed up a $90,000 pro baseball contract to paly football, scored two touchdowns and passed for another in the first half to lead 11th-ranked Tennessee to a 24-17 victory over 10th-ranked Louisana State in the 14th annual Astor-Blue-bonnet Bowl tonight.

There are some countries, the study says, where citizens may lose civil and political liberties if the present trend of governmental regulation of individuals' lives continues.

The first pinch of SALT II is hardly enough to whet anyone's appetite. The only apparent achievement of the Soviet and American negotiators in a month of Geneva talks was the creation of a four-man consultative commission to supervise past and future strategic arms agreements, as foreseen in last May's agreements at the end of SALT I.
Mrs. Margaret Court routed Kerry Melville, 6-1, 6-0, today and advanced to the final of the $53,300 Australian open, a tennis title she has won 10 times.

The following dispatch was written for the Latin-American news agency LATIN by Carlos, Beriales, chief of the agency's4 Chilean bureau and himself a Uruguayan. LATIN is a cooperative news agency operated by 10 of Latin America's largest newspapers. @1972 by LATIN.
The unbeaten Miami Dolphins, with Bob Griese directing two second-half touchdown drives, defeated the Pittsburgh Steelers, 21-17, yesterday and won the American Football Conference championship.

Almost everybody but Woody Hayes and his Ohio State Buckeyes has conceded the National Collegiate football championship to the University of Southern California. Tomorrow the Buckeyes, 14-point underdogs, will try to topple the Trojans in the 59th Rose Bowl game.

If Barbara Gardner's "The New Dance" is a prophetic omen of what the year holds in store for dance, then stop the world, I want to get off. The work, given Saturday evening at Washington Square Methodist Church is a jumble, not a mix, of media and has the cohesion of scraps in a junk yard.
Shizuma Matsuo, chairman of the board of Japan Air Lines, died today at a hospital here. He was 69 years old and had been treated for a gall bladder disorder.

The First National Boston Corporation has acquired certain data-processing equipment and related leases from the Randolph Computer Corporation for $61-million, the parent company of the First National Bank of Boston announced last Saturday.

Every man or woman a choreographer was the keynote of a concert Saturday night by six members of the Murray Louis Dance Company. With all but Mr. Louis represented on this occasion, the group had a packed hall at the Louis-Nikolais Theater Lab (344 West 36th Street), with some people being turned away for lack of space.

Al McGuire; the Marquette basketball coach, is many thinks to many people, and is not one to waste words. His players either like or hate him, but respect him. The people of Milwaukee adore his coaching record.

Gov. Milton J. Shapp has dismissed state Police Commissioner Rocco Urella and forced Attorney General J. Shane Creamer to resign in the midst of a wiretap controversy. Mr. Shapp issued a formal statement today on Mr. Urella's dismissal.

Quadruplets-three boys and a girl-have been born here to the wife of an assistant United States attorney, and the children and mother were in satisfactory condition, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center reported yesterday.

Federal officials said today that the captain of the Eastern Airlines TriStar jet that crashed Friday night had a small brain tumor but was not at the controls when the plane went down in the Everglades with 178 persons aboard.

Worldwide observance last week of the 150th anniversary of the birth of Louis Pasteur constituted a deserved tribute to one of mankind's greatest benefactors. Millions owe their lives to just one of Pasteur's discoveries, the "pasteurization" that daily guards milk and milk products from becoming disease transmitters.

Hoping to bolster fledgling interscholastic athletic programs for women, New Jersey started an experiment last spring allowing girls to compete on boys' high school teams in noncontact sports for a one-year trial period.
The prestige of the Big Eight Conference will be on the line when Nebraska seeks its third consecutive Orange Bowl victory tonight against Notre Dame.

Herve Filion won three races today at Dover Downs and brought his 1972 record total to 604 victories. The 32-year-old Canadian had seven drives. In his other races he finished second twice, third and eighth.
The city's new noise code, the first comprehensive effort to reduce unwanted sound here, is running into strong opposition and, in some cases, open defiance, from the construction industry.

Stan Freeman, who wears a variety of musical hats, including, among others, that of accompanist to Marlene Dietrich, composer of Broadway musicals ("I Had a Ball" and "Lovely Ladies, Kind Gentlemen") and recording and concert pianist, has settled into Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, for a spell of playing jazz piano and singing.

The University, of Alabama, which has been to more bowl games than any other college football team, will make its 14th straight postseason appearance tomorrow against Texas in the Cotton Bowl. The kickoff is scheduled for 2 P.M. (ES.T.).

Despite mounting pressure to increase the number of black parole officers in corrections systems across the country, only minimal progress has been made by many state governments in the efforts to recruit blacks for the jobs.

Dr. Al Field of the Port Washington Yacht Club moved into the lead in the Penguin Class as Randy Bartholomew of Manhasse Bay retained his Interclub adge after the second round of the 42d annual Frostbite Regatta on Manhasset Bay today.

The people of Hanoi were able to get a full night's sleep last night for the first time since the United States bombing began two weeks ago. Fewer people in the streets wore helmets today, but as many as ever dug air-raid shelters, for the average Vietnamese does not seem to believe that the bombing is really over.

Harry P. Charlesworth, former vice president of Bell Laboratories and retired assistant chief engineer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Saturday in Montclair, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in North Caldwell, N.J.

A 50-year-old woman leaped from her burning thirdfloor apartment in East Harlem early yesterday and was rescued by a fireman who grabbed her when she hit the edge of an aerial ladder bucket being raised to the window ledge, fire officials said.

If there were an award for the best partnership of 1972 it would no doubt go to Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N.J. In the Summer Nationals, they successfully defended the Life Master Pair Championship title, a feat never previously achieved in the 43-year history of the

The Oyster Bay Rowing Association of Long Island captured the Elite eight-oared event of the annual New Year's Eve regatta of the New York Rowing Association yesterday on the Orchard Beach lagoon in the Bronx.
Mickey Redmond's 20th goal of the season earned the Detroit Red Wings a 4-4 tie with the Minnesota North Stars in the National Hockey League tonight. It was the Wings' third tie of the week.
Mrs. Ann Spencer Pratt, an artist, died yesterday in Canaan, Conn. She was 59 years old, lived at 130 East 67th Street and had a studio in Williasville, Mass.

Harris S. Bigelow, president of Profit Services, Inc., a sales management organization in New Canaan. and formerly a partner in the Sales Analysis Institute of New York, died yesterday at his home here. He was 80 years old.
The United States will begin the new year with a population of 210,194,312, the Census Bureau estimated today. The net gain in population during 1972 was 1.5 million, tile bureau said.

Clare Romano, an Englewood painter-printmaker whose works are included in the permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, was riding home one day when she was struck by the colors and forms she saw in the hard, pink, end-of-a-winter's-day light along North Woodland Avenue.

The steel industry is entering 1973 with Government controls apparently beginning to pinch. There is a fear that the industry, whose profits have been depressed for years, will be frozen into its unhappy past, as far as prices are concerned, by the Government's profit guidelines.

Fakhruddin Valibhai Valika, head of one of the richest families in Pakistan, died here yesterday at the age of 60.

RINK IN THE NEW If family elders opened the New Year with resolutions to seek to close the generation gap by spending more time with the children, a beginning of sorts could be made today at five outdoor and two indoor ice-skating rinks operated by the Parks Administration in the five boroughs of the city.
A seller's market through 1975. That was the prediction for the nation's paper industry as it finished a record year.

Governor Cahill called yesterday for "firmer leadership" in Newark to meet problems "such as crime, such as abandoned houses, such as dirty streets." "These things, I think, can be attended to," the New Jersey Governor declared.

A report released by Governor Cahill's office has shown that the early opening of completed portions of the east-west freeway in West Orange would result in safety problems and possible structural defects.

The police said yesterday that in a raid on The Zoo, an East Side discotheque catering mainly to teen-agers, they had found 12 small packets of heroin, 19 bags of marijuana, two hashish pipes, four pistols, a rifle, two knives, three blackjacks and three baseball bats.
Mickey Redmonid's 20th goal of the season earned the Detroit Red Wings a 4-4 tie with the Minnesota North Stars in the National Hockey League tonight. It was the Wings' third tie of the week.

Seeking to curb rising, food prices, the Nixon Administration plans efforts to increase food supplies and to stress price controlss on middlemen in the industry, Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today.

The nation's largest Indian tribe has set up an economic enterprise designed to insure that Indian artisans and workers receive more of the profits from the sale of their handicrafts. Most of the money now goes to white middlemen.

After a 10-year struggle, Britain joins Europe tomorrow with her officials jubilant and her public apprehensive. For Prime Minister Heath, who has long led the effort to enter the European Economic Community, or Common Market. it is a historic achievement and, as he said today, "a very moving moment."

The Department of the Interior has reversed itself on a plan that would have permitted the killing of the Eastern timber wolf, regarded as threatened with extinction.

Last night's game against the Philadelphia Blazers at Madison Square Garden was a little embarrassing for the New York Raiders. They had lost, 3 to 0, the day before to the New England Whalers, the top team in the Eastern Division of the World Hockey Association.

Tenants of 400,000 rent-controlled apartments in the city who have been paying a 15 per cent rent increase since last July 1 automatically-and without noticereceived a temporary decrease of half that amount beginning yesterday.

Few democratically elected heads of government in recent times have made so many major changes so rapidly as Gough Whitlam in Australia and Norman Kirk 'in New Zealand. Their simultaneous recognition of the People's Republic of China is only the latest in a series of whirlwind actions by the new Labor Prime Ministers to alter long-established policies at home and abroad.

A 4-year-old boy who had been badly beaten and whose infant brother was found beaten to death in a shallow grave, died yesterday at Cardinal Glennon Children's Hospital, the police said.

Australia will receive 24 F-1ll fighter-bombers from the United States this year, nearly a decade after they were ordered, but it may be a year more before the cost of the controversial plane to the Australian taxpayer is known.
Something enigmatic, with much sound and fury, has been going on in Yugoslavia since September, and it is hard to find any two people who can agree on a coherent, convincing explanation as yet.
Lieut. Gen. Henry D. Russell, one of three generals who investigated the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941, died yesterday at the age of 83.

Four Americans who returned from Hanoi Sunday night with hundreds of letters from American prisoners of war described yesterday as overwhelming the destruction they had seen in the city as a result of United States bombing raids.

Unions and management remained far apart yesterday in the Long Island Rail Road strike. There was no sign of any break in the 33-day-old impasse, the longest in the line's history.

Britain's entry into the European Common Market today was formally marked by a ceremony in Westminster Abbey and informally by absenteeism among tens of thousands of British workers.

Police detectives in the Bronx identified three bodies yesterday that had been found in two places the day before. In each case the police discounted earlier speculation that the murders were gangland executions.

An engaged couple were found shot dead today in a remote country lane near the border with Northern Ireland. A police spokesman said the couple, both Roman Catholics, were shot more than once through the head and left in a fitch about eight miles northwest of Londonderry.

A radical revamping of the state's courts-in which bail would be abolished, judges would be subject to strict discipline and courts would be run by administrative technicians rather than judges-was proposed yesterday by the Temporary Commission on the New York State Court System.
The announcement that the United States and North Vietnam would resume their private peace talks in Paris next Monday has prompted a cool reaction here among supporters of President Nguyen Van Thieu.

Alan Lowry, the Texas quarterback, bootlegged the ball 34 yards on a tip-toe run down the left sideline for a touchdown late in the fourth quarter today as the seventh-ranked Longhorns upset fourth-ranked Alabama, 1713, in the Cotton Bowl.

Earnings of the nation's largest banks should increase 10 per cent this year, M. A. Schapiro Co., Inc., a leading dealer in bank securities, said yesterday. In the December issue of its publication, the Bank Stock Quarterly, Schapiro said that this increase would be in contrast to an expected rise of 5.1 per cent in bank earnings in 1972 and only 3 per cent in 1971.

A study of the national forests by a Ralph Nader group has concluded that tentative Federal logging plans "will result in the destruction of millions of acres of potential wilderness and recreation areas."

DURHAM, N. C.--Dr. Martin Groder, the young director of the new Federal Center for Correctional Research at Camp Butner, near here, looks on the traditional American prison system as a sort of last-ditch "welfare system" for young, healthy males-men who are ineligible for most regular welfare programs but who don't have the skills or the opportunity to earn a living.
BRUSSELS-The newly expanded European Common Market has fielded a bigger, younger, politically more sensitive executive team for its "stretch" version.

Recorded flight information recovered in the wreckage of the jumbo jetliner that crashed on an approach to Miami International Airport last Friday night has given support to speculation that the aircraft crew may have unwittingly flown it into the ground, Federal investigators revealed today.
President Kenneth D. Kaunda has ordered the release from detention of former Vice President Simon M. Kapwepwe and 34 other members of the outlawed United Progressive party.
Bromwell Ault, who retired in 1971 as vice chairman of the Inmont Corporation, manufacturers of printing inks and related products, died Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Representatives of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson commuter railroad and the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen were scheduled to meet with Federal mediators at 11 A.M. in an attempt to avert a strike,scheduled for one minute after midnight tonight.

Having, over the years, offered what I assumed was terse, competent advice to correspondents on what equipment they should take with them on light tackle fishing ventures to Florida or the islands in the sun, I was unprepared for the indecision that beset me the last few days.
A Connecticut hitchhiker was held in lieu of $5,000 bail today on charges he attempted to rape a New Jersey coed when she and another student gave him a life.

In the 10 weeks that Daphne Liakos has been working in the showroom of the Hackensack Ford Agency, she has sold "11 or 12 cars" and run into her share of male chauvinist customers who think that selling cars is strictly a man's game.
The authorities searched tolay for 12 of 15 inmates who slipped away in a mass escape from the dilapidated Orleans Parish prison early Saturday. Three of the 15 were recap:ured Saturday night.

A satisfying type of contest that gets little attention in this country is the match between two clubs or two cities. Occasional exhibition matches are played on an intercity basis, but there is nothing to compare with the pre-World-War II series of matches between New York and Philadelphia - consistently won by the Philadelphians.

With the awarding of an $18-million contract tor completing Interstate Route 684, New York State has another opportunity to build at least part of a major highway with some regard for the land and the environment. BRUSSELS - Following are sketches of the men who make up the commission of the European Economic Community-the body that administers the operations of the European Common Market. With expansion of community to nine members on Jan. 1, the commission, itself has been expanded to 13 members-two apiece for the four larger countries, and one for each of other five members.
WOODBINE, Tex. - In this Cook County community of 500 population some 60 miles north of Fort Worth, women are the entire force of the volunteer fire department, some 25 strong.

Morgan Stanley Co., announced yesterday the admission of Lewis W. Bernard and Archibald Cox Jr., to the banking house as general partners. They were also elected managing directors of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.

American warplanes today continued their temporary halt in the bombing begun yesterday in North Vietnam below the 20th Parallel and in South Vietnam to observe a New Year's Day cease-fire, United States officials indicated.
Miss Karen Stephanie Rennert and Richard Anthony John May were married here this afternoon. The Rev. David Osborn performed the ceremony in the Central Unitarian Church.

Vincente K. Tibbs, former president of the City Council of Englewood, N.J., died on Sunday of complications following surgery at Englewood Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 516 Shepard Avenue in Englewood.

The Rev. Pierce Brennan, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent de Paul in Brooklyn and an Army chaplain in World War II and Korea, died Sunday after surgery in St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 58 years old and resided in the rectory at 167 North Sixth Street in Brooklyn.

No one, to my knowledge, has said a Federal tax -increase is clearly inevitable, but it has been asserted that an increase (in 1974, presumably) is "all but inevitable." The reasoning is that uncontrollable expenditures will increase so much faster than tax receipts that the budget will be hopelessly out of balance for years to come, with cumulating deficits so large as to be explosively inflationary.
A 70-year old retired doctor was bound, gagged and left in a storage shed for six hours with an automobile whose engine was running, the police said today.

In an old cinder block building in a black neighborhood out where Imperial Avenue crosses 30th Street, the Black Servicemen's Caucus quietly set up shop about a year ago.

One of the first news bulletins of the new year hit with a sickening jolt. In the emotionless language of radio bulletins, announcement was made early yesterday that a plane on a mercy mission to stricken Nicaragua went crashing into the Carribbean and that Robert Clemente, one of the Samaritans aboard the relief plane, presumably crashed to his death with it.
President Nixon pledged allegiance yesterday to the Washington Redskins in the Super Bowl game against the Miami Dolphins, his choice a year ago.

Rule, outspoken director of its procurement control operation, commendably urges Congress "to protect courageous civil servants who give honest testimony in response to its questions."

John Newcombe won his first Australian national singles title today by beating Onny Parun of New Zealand, 6-3, 6-7, 7-5, 6-1, in the final. "It's great to win the title at last," said the 29-year-old Australian, who has won three Wimbledon championships.

At least one shipment of nuclear materials sufficient to make an atomic bomb has been aboard a United States passenger jetliner hijacked to Cuba, according to an article in the January issue of The Washington Monthly magazine.

The Baltimore Bullets, scoreless for the first six minutes, 39 seconds, battled back for an 88-87 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. Mike Riordan's long jumper with 57 seconds left gave the Bullets the lead.

Southern California walloped Ohio State, 42-17, yesterday at Pasadena by scoring 35 points in the last two quarters. The rout clinched national college football championship honors for the Trojans. The leader of the U.S.C. offense was Sam Cunningham, who scored four touchdowns to break a Rose Bowl record.
More than 70 people were injured early today when 150 policemen battled an angry mob of thousands of New Year's revelers with nightsticks and tear gas along a half-mile stretch of resort beach.
Tsuneo Mori leader of a ring of apanese terrorists linked to he Palestine guerrilla movenent, hanged himself in jail today while awaiting trial on murder charges.

Tom Seaver sat by the Christmas tree yesterday in his home in Greenwich, Conn., and reflected on the life and times of Roberto Walker Clemente. He agreed that the key word in everything Clemente did for 38 years, nearby half of them in the big leagues, was "passion."

The postman never rings twice. But when Sylvia Hooks received a letter from Gladys Heldman about six weeks ago inviting her to play on the Virginia Slims women's tennis circuit, she didn't believe the man had rung at all. "I threw the letter down on the desk, thinking it was some sort of a joke," says Miss Hooks. "I'm not saying Gladys is selfish, but what does she need me for?"

The opening of the 93d Congress provides a fresh opportunity to attack the problem of the irresponsible distribution of power on Capitol Hill. Leadership has to have power to make the legislative process work, but that power has to be responsible and accountable. As matters now stand, the central leadership elected by the majority and minority parties has too little power and the committee chairmen chosen under the seniority system have too much.

From Los Angeles to New York City, much of the nation has been plagued by a shortage of blood for medical purposes through the holiday weekend. To the Editor: The Dec. 25 letter of David W. Peck, former Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, holding that "the elective system is unsuitable to the- selection of judges" misses the point. The fact is that where the elective system embraces a genuinely democratic nominative process a calibre of judges is produced equal to or higher than that yielded by any appointive system.

As the New York State Legislature convenes in Albany today, its members confront an extraordinary range of issues. European notables attending a banquet given tonight by Prime Minister Heath to mark his greatest triumph--Britain's entry into the European Economic Community--heard the community's top official warn that it "badly needed" an injection of democracy."
Technical experts from the United States and North Vietnam resumed their discussions oh a cease-fire today with a four-hour session and agreed to meet again tomorrow.
The Islanders tonight continued to suffer by comparison with the Atlanta Flames, who trounced them, 6-1, for the fourth straight time in the teams' first National Hockey League campaign.
The Baseball Writers Association of America will look into the possibility of inducting Roberto Clemente into the Hall of Fame, this year, Jack Lang, the group's secretary, said yesterday.

The shortage of whole blood available to 282 hospitals in the metropolitan area is expected to continue for at least two weeks, a spokesman for the Greater New York Blood Program said yesterday. Although the acute shortage over the holiday weekend was alleviated by the collection of 2,450 units from volunteers, normal requirements over the next several days will leave the reserve dangerously low, he said.

Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has been wearing an experimental electronic device designed to control pain impulses to his brain. The Governor started using the device, which he controls from a button on his wheelchair, during a recent vacation in Florida. It is said to alleviate the pain much of the time.

The Commerce Department announced today a continuation for the sixth year of its program of controls over dollar outflow abroad for financing direct corporate investment, with one important relaxation.

The first of 21 black sailors to be tried ashore in connection with racial fighting aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk was convicted of one charge today, but the major counts against him were thrown out.
The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, proposed, today that the county begin buying 3,000 acres of farmland to prevent housing development and to preserve it forever for agriculture.

Unbeaten Maryland, in a lethargic performance booed by the home fans, defeated Kent State, 76-58, tonight for its eighth victory. Len Elmore, from New York's Power Memorial Academy, tied a Maryland record by grabbing 24 rebounds. He scored 10 points.

Britain's official reserves of gold and foreign currency backing the troubled pound fell sharply in 1972, Government figures showed today. The reserves had increased substantially in 1971.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market began the new year in a bullish fashion yesterday as both lists made strong advances. The trading pace, however, slowed considerably.

A man accused of murder carries a bullet in his back. The state alleges that it was fired in selfdefense by a woman before she and her husband were killed. May the slug be removed for use as evidence against the defendant?

Legislative sources reported here this evening that Governor Cahill would not recommend any major new or increased taxes in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature this month.

The winners in the 1972 media awards competition of the New York State Bar Association were announced yesterday by former Associate Judge Francis Bergen of the State Court of Appeals, chairman of the awards committee.
Congressional opponents of the war in Vietnam threatened today to try to cut off appropriations for the war if the Nixon Administration did not quickly obtain a peace settlement.
Three race drivers in United States Auto Club competition-Mark Donohue, Roger McCluskey and Joe Leonard--earned more than $200,000 each in purses and other awards in the 1972 season.
A lawsuit was filed yesterday seeking to overturn a Federal law that permitted the Jewish ritual slaughter of animals. The suit was the first one filed this year in Federal Court here.

Israeli jets on a patrol flight today fought a brief air battle over Lebanon with Syrian jets that rose from nearby Syrian territory to intercept them. A military spokesman here said one Syrian MIG-21 was downed in the encounter.
The police shot and killed at least two persons today during a strike that paralyzed parts of Andhra Pradesh in southern India, where strikers are demanding a separate state.
Selective Service notified draft boards today to cancel induction orders for men who were left over from last year's draft pool and who have induction postponements due to expire this month or next.
Bob McAdoo, a rookie, scored 30 points tonight, leading the Buffalo Braves to a 114-110 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.
Motorists who have not received their new license plates by mail have been granted a 10-day grace period.

President Ferdinand E. Marcos today sought an end to dissidence among southern Moslems by at offering selective amnesty and economic benefits.

Chevrolet paced the American automobile industry in sales in 1971 and 1972, and will continue in the lead in 1973, F. James McDonald, Chevrolet general manager, said today. With car and truck sales topping the 3-million mark two years in a row-the only division of any car company to achieve the feat-Mr. McDonald predicted that Chevrolet sales this year will reach 3.6 million.

Whatever its impact on the negotiating position of the other side, it is now clear that President Nixon's 12-day aerial blitz against North Vietnam has had a backlash at home that cannot but affect the American bargaining stance. When Henry Kissinger returns to the Paris talks, he will have, in addition to Presidents Nixon and Thieu, an aroused Congress looking over his shoulder.

Advocates of a National Collegiate football championship playoff game have not got back to the line of scrimmage with their plans. But they gained considerable matrial for their argument last weekend as the bowl games proved nothing new.

The board of directors of baseball's Hall of Fame moved yesterday to clear the way for Roberto Clemente's immediate election, bypassing the usual five-year waiting period. Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced that the board had amended eligibility rules for the election and authorized the Baseball Writers Association of America to conduct a special election in the case of Clemente.

Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet representative, accused the United Nations public information staff today of "distortion, misrepresentation and outright deception" in its reporting of the work of the justconcluded session of the General Assembly.

The French Government's New Year gift to shoppers, a reduction in the national sales tax, has resulted in some modest cuts in retail. prices, more work for store employes, and a large measure of skepticism from housewives like Mrs. Colette Dupuis, who thinks "It's all a joke."
Walter Scott Shinn, a photographer of prominent personalities and families and a specialist in child photography, lied yesterday at his home, 446 East 20th Street. His age was 88.

Cesar Chavez, the farm worker leader, filed a $128-million damage suit today against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and California shippers and growers, alleging civil rights violations through "sham" contracts that excluded minority farm workers.

APPUHN--Professor William E.F., of 65 College Road, Monsey, N.Y. on January 3, 1973 In his 76th year. Beloved lather of Geraldine Dailey of Monsey, NY. and William E.F., Jr. of Brooklyn. He was a Professor of Mathematices at Stevens Institute of Technology, N.J., St. Francis College, Brooklyn and Long Island University, Brooklyn.

The leader of the Middlesex Assembly delegation urged the New Jersey Office of Fiscal Affairs today to recommend ways of curbing "widespread abuse of the state's farmland assessment laws which is costing homeowners millions of dollarss."

Three electric utilities announced yesterday expansion plans totaling more than $1.3billion and including both nuclear and conventional genrating systems. The Illinois Power Company said it planned to go ahead with an $800-million nuclear complex to be built near Clinton, Ill., about 35 miles north of Decatur on a 15,000-acre site.

A major disagreement emerged yesterday in Wall Street's hierarchy as to how the securities industry should work toward the creation of a new national system of stock exchanges.

Part of the collection of an influential New York' art dealer, the late Edith Gregor Halpert, will be auctioned March 14 and 15 at Sotheby Parke Bernet. Mrs. Halpert was for many years director of the Downtown Gallery, where she showed pioneer American modernists.

Officials of the Lefrak Organization, one of the largest building concerns in the country, confirmed yesterday that companies affiliated with it had made a series of $90 contributions to committees for the reelection of President Nixon but declined to give the total amount.

Gerald C. O'Brien, owner of G. C. O'Brien, Inc., nationally known contractors specializing in demolition work, was killed Monday evening in the crash of his twin-engine airplane at the airport in Memphis.
Gerard C. Smith, who for almost four years has headed the American delegation to talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic weapons, has resigned from Government service.

A founder and the first president of the Bermuda Kennel Club, Florence Lady Conyers of Pembroke plays a leading role in dog-show circles on the island.
Rolf Liebermann, the new manager of the Paris Opera, today announced an ambitious program for his first season.

The Nixon Administration's proposal that local television stations be held accountable for the content of network news they broadcast drew sharp criticism yesterday from Robert G. Fichenberg, chairman of the freedom of information committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
A retired Army warrant officer denied on the witness stand in Mercer County Court today that he had ever done construction or improvement work on the private property of Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell.
Supply routes and other targets in the southern part of North Vietnam were heavily attacked again yesterday by United States planes, among them B-52 heavy bombers.
Towards the end of fashion's era of hats, in the late nineteen-sixties, the two best milliners of all saw the handwriting on the wall. They began working up little jackets, skirts, shirtdresses.
Two-yearold Linda Lasher said no to Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut today, bringing a mirthful respite to an otherwise carefully rehearsed opening of the 1973 legislative session.

Mrs. Edna Cole Loranger, widow of Eli J. Loranger, who was vice president here of R. L. Polk Co., publishers of city directories, died Monday in the Echo Rest Home, Syosset, L. J. She was 83 years old.

If an individual can make out a personal balance sheet, the person can easily read a corporate balance sheet, whether it belongs to General Motors with its many billions of assets, or to a smaller company. And this is a good time to make out a personal balance sheet; just as many corporations are doing now.

The 93d Congress convened today amid pledges by the Senate Democratic leader to "bring about complete disinvolvement" from the Vietnam war and by the Democratic Speaker of the House to demonstrate independence from the Republican Administration.

Eighteen years ago this month Renata Tebaldi made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera in the role of Desdemona in "Otello." On Monday night the soprano returned to the role for the first time in many years, appearing in the Zeffirelli production that was new last season.
A Republican fund raiser who is a friend of President Nixon heads one of three companies trying to get the Federal broadcast license from television station WJXT in Jacksonville.

Ella Garrett, a singer who opened a two-week engagement on Tuesday at Reno Sweeney, 126 West 13th Street, is one of those fortunate performers who can project a warm, unpretentious, straightforward personality before an audience with the same naturalness and ease that one might in a personal encounter.

Responding to criticism that he had not publicly "interceded" with President Nixon to stop the bombing of North iVetnam, the Rev. Billy Graham said today that he hoped for a rapid and just peace in Southeast Asia.

Long-simmering student unrest flared into the open today as thousands of riot policemen used tear gas, bamboo staves and truncheons to keep rebellious university students from marching on downtown Cairo.
Rick Martin and Rene Robert each scored his 24th goal of the season tonight, helping the. Buffalo Sabres beat the New York Islanders, 4-1, in the National Hockey League.
The wave of conglomerate mergers in the late 1960's has produced one major harmful result, according to a study done for the Federal Trade Commission and made public today.
A new World open golf championship with a $500,000 purse and a first prize of $100,000 will be held Nov. 6 through 18 at Pinehurst, N. C. It will be the game's richest tournament.
A Federal prosecutor said today that a man accused of trying to hijack a plane last night at Friendship International Airport may have threatened in 1971 to kill President Nixon.

Three New Jersey residents aged 18 to 20 were given summonses by the state police for driving while under the influence of alcohol on Monday, the first day the state's new 18-year minimum drinking age was in effect. From 6 P.M. Friday to midnight Monday, the state police issued 103 drinking-driving summonses-three to the 18-to-20year-olds, 99 to other adults and one to a 17-year-old from Pennsylvania.

After a noisy floor fight, the City Council designated Angelo J. Arculeo, a Republican, as its new minority leader, replacing Eldon R. Clingan, who switched from the Liberal to the Democratic party last fall and resigned the leadership.

The Governor's call for the mandatory life imprisonment of drug sellers brought quick and angry denunciations yesterday from some of the quarters where such reactions were predictable-the Legal Aid Society, the New York Civil Liberties Union, the chairman of the McKay Commission on the Attica riots and Representative Bella S. Abzug.

The city's obscenity trial of "Deep Throat" ended yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court after the taking of more than 1,000 pages of expert testimony in 10 days for and against the popular hard-core pornographic film.

Long-simmering student unrest flared into the open today as thousands of riot policemen used tear gas, bamboo staves and truncheons to keep rebellious university students from marching on downtown Cairo.
Senate Democrats, hoping to exercise more control over key legislation in the new Congress, moved today to expand and liberalize slightly the membership of the Finance Committee.

Barely a fifth of the 132 members of the United Nations "enjoy what can genuinely be called freedom of information," the International Press Institute reported the other day. Although it listed the United States as one of the fortunate few, it also concluded that the Nixon Administration is "attempting to chip away at press freedom through the courts and by the threats of court action."

Anti-American statements by a member of Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's new Cabinet, coming on top of other disturbing developments in the normally tranquil relations between the United States and Australia, have irked the United States Embassy.
It should be easier for people watchers to distinguish the boys from the girls in 1973. The one with the short hair is likely to be female.
Stock prices soared to record levels yesterday, fed by the booming domestic economy and by hopes for the Vietnam peace talks. The Dow-Jones industrial average climbed 12.12 to finish at 1,043.80.

After a raucus floor fight, the City Council designated Angelo J. Arculeo, a Republican, as its new minority leader yesterday. The event marked the end of the three-year role of the Liberal party as the "dominant" minority.
Southern University reopened peacefully here today, seven weeks after the fatal shooting of two students prompted state officials to close the predominantly black school.
Governor Rockefeller's call for new Federal legislation to avert local transportation strikes in his State of the State message yesterday drew mixed reactions from some Congressional leaders.

The Lindsay administration said today that it had found elements of the Governor's State of the State message that "can be of substantial benefit to the city" -- particularly the proposed state assumption of welfare and court costs.
James H. Young, director of the Columbia-Community Athletic Field in Morningside Park, serving the university and the neighborhood residents, died yesterday in Cumberland Hospital, Brooklyn.
Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. are such different men that, but for the accident of their being in Vietnam at the same time, one might be surprised to find them co-defendants.
Quickly and decisively, Don Shula named Bob Griese yesterday as the Miami Dolphins' starting quarterback in the Super Bowl game.

Tampa was nice but Earle Bruce is not planning to stay around to win another cigar. The 41-year-old Bruce resigned yesterday as Tampa's head football coach, after only one year at the helm, to take the head coaching job at Iowa State.

The National Commission on Consumer Finance called today for extensive shifts in public policy to increase the availability of credit to consumers and to curb unfair or excessively harsh collection practices.

High Administration officials said today that the United States was entering the negotiations with North Vietnam next week without assurances that an early settlement of the Vietnam war would be achieved.

Consumer group spokesmen expressed pleasure yesterday over the decision reached by the Public Service Commission Tuesday denying a temporary $217-million rate increase for the New York Telephone Company. But John O'Sullivan, executive director of Grassroots Action, Inc., a consumer advocate group, warned that the telephone company might seek a "back-door increase" by seeking permission to charge for information calls.

A Red Army soldier, Serge Bochkov, won today's third jump of a four-jump ski tournament regarded as the sport's premier event in years when no Olympic medal or world championship is at stake.

The defense in the trial of Juan V. Corona rested today without calling a single witness on behalf of the 38-year-old Mexican national charged with the largest multiple murder in the nation's history.
The Soviet Union announced stiff penalties for airplane hijackers today, including the death penalty if the seizure of an aircraft causes casualties.

Clary Anderson is predictable. All the Montclair State football coach does is win, and then win some more. For 31 seasons, Anderson has not had a losing record and never had to revert to that old standby, "Wait 'til next year." This last season Anderson proved he was human after all and lost four of 10 games. Not even that had happened before.
IN MEMORIAM Ezra Pound died In Venice last November, leaving behind a wealth of highly acclaimed work by Pound, the poet, and a heap of controversy stirred by Pound, the person.
A Federal appeals court rejected today James R. Hoffa's appeal to overturn his 1964 conviction on jury tampering charges.
United States District Judge Barrington Parker refused today to stay his order barring the Labor Depatment from extending the deadline for states to get Federal approval of their job safety programs.
The American Broadcasting Company yesterday agreed to pay $25-million for exclusive United States television rights for the 1976 summer Olympics in Montreal.

CAMBRIDGE, England--Like our forefathers, we may feel that the world was spoiled before ever we Were born. We face systems of society not quite the same now as in feudal times, but such as have been defeating the human race for centuries.
Everett L. Hart, a television producer for Young Rubicam, Inc., New York advertising agency, died in Rome on Monday of complications following bronchial pneumonia.
A bus carrying a high-school swimming team home to Vestal, N. Y., from a meet in Towanda, Pa., overturned during freezing rain on Route 17 tonight.

A non-registered secondary offering of 25,000 common shares of Airwick Industries at $46.50 per share was completed yesterday by Blyth Eastman Dillon. The company's stock closed at 46%, down 5/8 on the American Stock Exchange.

The New Jersey Attorney General has asked a Federal appellate court to expedite the state's appeal of a lower-court ruling that would permit the Central Railroad of New Jersey to end passenger service after Jan. 21.

The official in charge of planning a deepwater port off New Jersey for the Army Corps of Engineers side today that he probably would recommend that the corps abandon the idea because of widespread public opposition.

As American and North Vietnamese representatives met for the second day today on the technical aspects of a cease-fire, North Vietnam said the United States had halted its mining as well as its bombing north of the 20th Parallel.

Winnebago Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of motor homes and a leading manufacturer of travel trailers and camper coaches, showed little change in its operating earnings in the third fiscal quarter from the levels a year ago, but an extraordinary charge halved the net for the 1972 period, according to yesterday's report.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest weekly report of changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.
About 100 physicians representing a wide variety of disciplines are attending a seminar on a acupuncture here this week.
The Greater New York Blood Program renewed its appeal yesterday for donors, saying there was less than one day's supply of whole blood available for the 282 hospitals in the metropolitan area.

In the modern, almost antiseptic Federal Building downtown here, thousands of miles from Vietnam, the final act of the Pentagon papers case began to unfold today with the start of jury selection in the, trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. They are accused of espionage.

The natives were restless in the early part of the season. They were grumbling because George Allen, their genius coach, persisted in starting Billy Kilmer at quarterback over their long-time pet, Sonny Jurgensen, Although the Redskin fans conceded that this had been proper enough during the previous year when Jurgy was injured, they vehemently insisted that Jurgy's return to health had robbed this concept of all validity.

It was a lock-'em-up-and-throw-away-the-key speech that Gov. Nelson Rockefeller delivered in Albany yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller proposed draconian remedies for the state's problems of drug addiction and the street crimes associated with it, including mandatory life sentences for those guilty of only first-time selling of small amounts of hashish to friends.

Two masked gunmen robbed a Long Island City branch of the Chemical Bank of $30,783 yesterday, but left most of the money in their wrecked getaway car after a collision with a panel truck two miles south on the Brooklyn waterfront.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it would fight in the courts any move by the Defense Department to abolish the right of servicemen who plead conscientious objection to seek honorable discharge.

Three Protestants were charged today with the murder of three Roman Catholics here. The defendants were the first to be brought to court in the series of religious killings that has terrorized Northern Ireland.

Graham Livingston, retired coordinator of production and sales for Lederle Laboratories, a pharmaceutical concern, died yesterday in the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center.

Four prison guards were held hostage for more than six hours today by a group of rebellious inmates, but they were released unharmed after the authorities agreed to meet three of the prisoners' demands.

When a small private plane disappeared in Alaska last October, it caused a double loss in the House of Representatives in Washington. Joseph Grutolla. whose release twice on $500 cash bail in connection with the shooting of a policeman stirred a public controversy, was arraigned in State Supreme Court yesterday and released on $25,000 bail.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill told the General Assembly today that he would ask it to deal urgently with a broad program of tax reform, in which he envisaged substantial reductions for both individuals and industries.

A group of New Jersey commuters is discovering that a private railroad car is really not much good without a railroad to haul it.

A young Russian defector, found dead in a rented mountain cabin, apparently shot himself to death accidentally with a gun he carried because threats had been made against his life, the authorities said yesterday.

Dr. Earl T. McBee, president and chairman of the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation here and head of the chemistry department at Purdue University from 1949 to 1967, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 66 years old.

Herve Filion drove 550 miles to get here in time for tonight's 1973 t harness racing opener at Yonkers Raceway, but Norman Dauplaise beat him to the punch by bringing home both ends of a $202.60 daily double.
The Social Security Administration announced today another raise in charges for the 22 million people aged 65 and older eligible for Medicare benefits, the third to go into effect this year.

The National Commission on Consumer Finance called today for extensive shifts in public policy to increase the availability of credit to consumers and to curb unfair or excessively harsh collection practices.
Mrs. Nancy Guggenheim Williams, an author, ballet teacher and copper heiress, died yesterday of an overdose of sleeping pills, the police reported today. She was 57 years old.

Occasional rain or showers are forecast today from central New England and the Metropolitan New York area through the Appalachians and Ohio Valley to the eastern Gulf Coast; freezing rain or snow is likely across northern New England. Warmer weather is expected in the lower lake region and the Southeast.

Americans don't like plain talk anymore. Nowadays they like fat talk. Show them a lean, plain word that cuts to the bone and watch them lard it with thick greasy syllables front and back until it wheezes and gasps for breath as it comes lumbering down upon some poor threadbare sentence like a sack of iron on a swayback horse.

Plans for the construction of a major housing development west of Times Square -- including two 45-story towers, a row of four-story apartment houses, a 1,000-car garage, five tennis courts, a swimming pool and other recreational and commercial facilities -- were approved unanimously yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
Jean-Claude Van Itallie is a young American playwright who made a distinct dent into world drama with his series of three playlets, "America Hurrah."

Fringe benefits for Representatives and Senators are worth a minimum of $8,500 and push their total income to at least $51,000, an Associated Press survey shows. The fringe benefits for members of Congress, who start a new session today, include such items as pensions, special tax considerations and liberal travel allowances.

The Navy bought $1.7 million worth of preferred stock of the near-bankrupt Gap Instrument Corporation late last month, hoping thereby to forestall the company's collapse in the middle of an unprofitable defense contract.

The breakthrough of bank credit cards into the department-store field took a major step forward with the announcement yesterday by Thalhimer Bros., Inc., a chain based in Richmond, Va., that it would honor Master Charge credit cards in all its 22 stores starting April 15. The chain also said it would add BankAmericard, another leading bank card, later.
A proposed constitution opens the possibility of treason trials for Pakistan's two previous rulers.

The higher price trend for key aluminum products initiated Tuesday by the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation spread to other major producers yesterday. The Aluminum Company of America announced that it had published higher list prices on some of its products and would continue to do so "as market conditions warrant."
Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav social critic, said today that he had been informed he must serve a one-month prison sentence for violation of a publication ban.

The collection of financial institutions known as the City of Londonpowerful, discreet and rarely known to enter a public controversy-has joined the campaign to get increased compensation for nearly 400 victims of thalidomide.

Mrs. Millicent Fenwick was sworn in today as the new director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs, thus becoming one of the highestranking women in state government.

Two top-level Lindsay administration officials accused the state yesterday of failing to consult the city on noisecontrol proposals that they said could "jeopardize the city's economy" and foment "corruption and graft."
Justice Raymond E. Peters of the California Supreme Court, who wrote hundreds of liberal opinions in 13 years on the court, died yesterday at his home of a stroke. He was 69 years old.

Superior Court Judge Irwin Kimmelman, conceding that living conditions at the Stella Wright public housing project were "bad, even deplorable," sentenced the two leaders of a tenants' rent strike today to 45 days' imprisonment on charges of civil contempt of court.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $25 yesterday "in loving memory of Catherine Wheeler Davis." Catherine died recently of an incurable heart defect at the age of 2.

Arthur E. Larkin Jr., the former president and chief operating officer of the General Foods Corporation who abruptly took, early retirement last April, has been named president of the Keebier Company.

The Lomita Gasoline Company, the largest producer of natural gas in Southern California, has been purchased by Petrolane, Inc., from the Standard Oil Company of California, Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

In a brilliant goaltending duel that wound up with Ed Giacomin becoming the Rangers' career shutout leader, the New Yorkers last night took advantage of their only two power-play opportunities and scored a 3-0 victory over the aggressive Los Angeles Kings.
