The Fairchild Camera Instrument Corporation announced yesterday at Mountain View, Calif., that it had received a $19-million contract to supply electronic circuitry to the Polaroid Corporation.

In one of his first moves as majority leader, Senator Warren M. Anderson today appointed Senators John J. Marchi and William T. Conklin, both of New York City, to important positions in the Senate power structure.

The 93d Congress convened today amid pledges by the Senate Democratic leader to "bring about complete disinvolvement" from the Vietnam war and by the Democratic Speaker of the House to demonstrate independence from the Republican Administration.

After their recent spectacular string of new historic highs, potato futures tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Speculators with large recent profits sold, and as the selling increased stop loss orders at lower prices became activated.

The New Jersey Attorney General has asked a Federal appellate court to expedite the state's appeal of a lower-court ruling that would permit the Central Railroad of New Jersey to end passenger service after Jan. 21.

Bond prices continued without a trend yesterday as Wall Street turned its attention to the first significant new financings since mid-December. Treasury securities, easier on Tuesday, achieved modest gains of up to l/8 point in advance of the auction today of $625million of 20-year bonds.
National Guard troops, with orders to shoot on sight, have killed 16 looters in the last five days in the ruins of this earthquake-devasted city, police officials said today.

Bipartisan opposition to the Nixon Administration's deep cuts in farm programs mounted in Congress today. Republican and Democratic members from farm states condemned the cuts that the White House ordered in an effort to hold Federal budget outlays to $250-billion for the current fiscal year.
Prices in the over-the-counter market and on the. American Stock Exchange continued to move higher yesterday although the advances were not as large as in the previous session. Trading was active.
Navy and Air Force officials displayed today a $7-million aircraft to be operated as the Atlanti Fleet's "flying command post" in the event of a national emergency. The EC135P,
The nation's manufacturing industries continued their steady but unspectacular inventory buildup in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill told the General Assembly today that he would ask it to deal urgently with a broad program of tax reform, in which he envisaged substantial reductions for both individuals and industries.
Judge Otto Kerner of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit'went on trial today in Federal District Court charged with bribery, perjury and income tax evasion.

Apparently concerned by the threat of an aroused United States Congress to cut off spending for the Vietnam war. President Nguyen Van Thieu is sending a delegation of five South Vietnamese senators to Washington, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4--Six Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders announced today that they would travel to Rome next week to seek the aid of Pope Paul VI in mobilizing world opinion against American war activities in Indochina.

The United States Olympic Committee selected Salt Lake City yesterday as the new American entry to bid for the 1976 Winter Olympics, despite an unresolved financial situation and possible problems of acceptance from many Utah residents.

A shareholder in the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company who reads the news release from the company's outside public relations counsel would probably feel reasonably good about the latest earnings result.
The three faces might have been stitched together in the laboratory of a mad scientist. They are a relief map of hockey, detailing the sites of battles and victories.

Last month's fire that destroyed the summit station of Sugarbush's 9,300-footlong gondola lift has made a happy philosopher of John King, the general manager of that popular central Vermont ski resort.

The New York Raiders and the Ottawa Nationals of the World Hockey Association may not play classic hockey, but they do help each other achieve big numbers. With Ron Ward accounting for five goals, the Raiders swamped the Nationals, 9-4, before a crowd of 4,927 at Madison Square Garden last night.
The Federal Reserve Board recommended today that Congress set a ceiling on the amount of money that can be collected from lending institutions in class-action suits.

Relatives and friends yesterday filed past the coffin of a 16-year-old boy whose body lay in a small mortuary in Harlem. The boy, Michael A. Marerro, was found dead in his bed in t a Bellevue Hospital ward on the morning of Dec. 26.
The minority Government promised the new Parliament today that it would give the highest priority to reducing unemployment, expanding the economy and attaining "reasonable price stability."

SAN FRANCISCO. Jan. 4--In two actions in Federal District Court, claiming massive damages and charging a conspiracy with employers, the United Farm Workers, led by Cesar Chavez, has thrown down the gauntlet to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Mrs. Esther Tane Baskin, nature writer, died in a nursing home today. She was 47 years old. Mrs. Baskin was the former wife of Leonard Baskin, professor of art and sculpture at Smith College, who illustrated some of her work.

Joseph W. McGovern, chancellor of the State Board of Regents, has told Governor Rockefeller that he has "grave concern" about the Governor's new proposal for an inspector general for elementary and secondary education in the executive department.
The new year's first major storm spread across the Central Plains to the upper Great Lakes yesterday. Another storm gathered strength in the Southwest.
North Vietnam said today that a preliminary survey showed that 1,318 persons were killed and 1,261 wounded by United States bombing raids on Hanoi last month.

A 28-year-old teacher of deaf children was found knifed to death in the efficiency apartment on West 72d Street to which she had moved because she was impressed by the comparative security of the building and the street.

Commissioner Walter Kennedy of the National Basketball Association disallowed a protest by the Chicago Bulls yesterday that time was still remaining when the periodending buzzer sounded in a 106-105 overtime loss to the Los Angeles Lakers last Dec. 12. The Bulls contended that a basket by Chet Walker should have been allowed since there was one second showing on the clock.

Despite a forecast drop in relief rolls and a Federal takeover of certain relief categories, the city's Human Resources Administration is asking for a record budget ot $2.634 billion for welfare, Medicaid and other programs for the fiscal year starting next July 1.
Ten of the country's largest retail chains reported yesterday that their December sales topped last year's by a wide margin as Christmas and post-Christmas business surged to record levels.

ABRAMSON--Fannie. The Samuel Tichner Society sorrowfully records the passing of the beloved wife of Brother, Samuel. Services 12:30 P.M. Friday, Jan. 5, at Forest Park Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76 Road. EDWARD M. RATOWSKY, President

Donald Drew Egbert, professor of architecture emeritus at Princeton and one of America's most distinguished scholars in the history of American art and architecture, died Wednesday at the Medical Center in Princeton. He was 70 years old.
Ron Williams scored 20 points and grabbed 16 rebounds to pace Long Island University to a 66-50 basketball victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University last night at the winner's Brooklyn court.

The Alert Bus Company, which has been carrying Long Island commuters to Shea Stadium on an emergency basis during the Long Island Rial Road strike, said today that it would apply to the State Public Service Commission for permission to establish a permanent commuter run from Long Island into Manhattan after the strike is over.
Australians took the first eight places in the second heat of the World 420 Championships sailed today at Seacliff. Anger Wangel won the heat, edging Peter Sieverwright.

A study undertaken for Action for Childrens Television (ACT) maintains that the networks could eliminate commercials from children's programs over a five-to-seven-year period without "cataclysmic" financial results.

The United States military command reported today that five Americans were killed in action in the Vietnam war last week. Thirteen were wounded and 24 listed as missing, captured or interned, the command said.

In a letter to Daniel M. Galbreath, president of the Pitts-. burgh Pirates, Richard P. Mellon, president of the Richard King Mellon Foundation, announced a grant of $100,000 yesterday in memory of Roberto Clemente.
The United States command reported yesterday that another B-52 the 16th since Dec. 18 - had been lost to North Vietnamese antiaircraft fire.

There are playwrights for their time and playwrights for every time-and only time itself can sort them out. Sean O'Casey, with his physician's finger on the pulse of Irish tragic Irony, spoke up for a 20th-century generation.

The truck division of the Hertz Corporation announced yesterday plans for a record purchase of new 1973 trucks valued at retail In excess of $45-million. The purchase will entail about 4,200 trucks of various sizes, models and makes and will be put in the company's rental fleet.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the four last numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.
Symbols of prestige and power surround the little stage where the Pentagon's official spokesman briefs the press on behalf of all the United States armed forces.
A key prosecution witness testified yesterday that he had met with Aniello Dellacroce three times to discuss selling stock that Dellacroce allegedly omitted from his Federal income taxes.
A Federal grand jury indicted 26 young men today for alleged violations of the Selective Service Act. Fifty others were expected to be charged in the next two weeks.
An 86-year-old South Ozone Park, Queens, woman was raped yesterday in her home by a youth who fled with $40 from the woman's purse, the police reported.
A smoky fire took the lives of a husband and wife, their youngest child and the husband's mother in their Queens Village home at 5 A.M. yesterday.
The 93d Congress is back in the capital spouting New Year's resolutions and promising, like a repentant drunk, to give up its feckless ways. In some respects it is a different Congress.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today warned developers and agents of condominium and similar real estate units that the offer and sale of such properties are subject to Federal securities laws when linked to rental or profit-sharing ar= rangements with purchasers.

Detectives in Brooklyn continued without success yesterday to search for a six-day-old boy and the woman who kidnapped him Wednesday after striking his mother with a hammer and saying she had been offered $1,000 for a baby.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn.--"I keep thinking I'm going to wake up; it's almost too good to be true: my goyishe dogs and my Franchot Tone house." The bearded man with the thoughtful face--always a little sad around the edges--gestured at his dream: a large white clapboard and stone house on a wooded road a few miles out of town, and two half-grown,

Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none). *** ??Victor's Cafe, 240 Columbus Avenue (at 71st Street), 877-7988.
Aieksanor Maitsev score four goals to lead the Soviet Union all-star team to a 9-4 victory over the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League in a penalty-ridden exhihition game tonight.
DUBLIN, Jan. 4 (AP)--Rita Mooney, a former actress and producer with the Abbey Theater, died Wednesday in a hospital here. She was 69 years old.
Legislative leaders of both parties today voiced initial favorable reaction to Governor Rockefeller's proposals for increased penalties for drug-pushers--including a mandatory life sentence

Prices on the American Stock Exchange were off sharply during much of yesterday's session but a late rally wiped out many losses. Nevertheless, prices closed slightly lower in moderate trading, with the Amex Index dipping to 26.63 off 0.01.

Some black New Yorkers gave mixed responses yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's call for "stern measures" to eliminate drug-related crime. Black people, statistics indicate, are the main victims of illegal drugs and crime.
Della Femina to Itta to Paccione. How's that for an an ethnic triple play?' That's the way yesterday went -two new campaigns and 'a new job.
While Bobby Short is taking his annual winter leave from the Cafe Carlyle, Marian McPartland has moved into the room for two months. For Miss McPartland, this represents quite a challenge.

Tickets matching only the last two numbers win five free 50-cent tickets for any single subsequent weekly drawing by showing the winning ticket to any licensed lottery vender.
Five Puerto Ricans charged in a Federal court suit here yesterday that the city discriminates against Puerto Ricans and other Hispanic residents in the hiring of sanitationmen.
George Drew, former Premier of Ontario and national leader of the Conservative party from 1948 to 1956, died in Wellesley Hospital today. He was 78 years old.
Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz brushed aside today bipartisan criticism that recent Nixon Administration cuts in longstanding and popular farm programs would harm rural areas.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday two key management changes in Europe and a related change in this country.

An extremely rare species of beaked whale that was rescued from the beach and placed in a private swimming pool has drawn scientists from several states and Canada here in an attempt to keep it alive and to determine just what type of whale it is.

The truck division of the Hertz Corporation announced yesterday plans for a record purchase of new 1973 trucks valued a?? retail In excess of $45-million. The purchase will entail about 4,200 trucks of various sizes, models and makes and will be put in the company's rental fleet.
There are undoubtedly some excellent players living in remote parts of the world, far from the mainstream of international competition.

If Jerry Quarry brings some of the rock groups he represented during his brief retirement from boxing with him into Madison Square Garden tonight, he might be assured of a sellout crowd for his 10-round heavyweight bout with Randy Neumann.

Traffic on a major interstate highway artery, Route 1-70, was detoured here today for the 24-hour cross-highway transit of two of the world's largest strip-mining machines, each with the deadweight of a small naval destroyer.

ALBANY, Jan. 4--Legislative leaders of both parties today voiced initial favorable reaction to Governor Rockefeller's proposals for increased penalties for drug-pushers--including a mandatory life sentence for convicted illegal drug-traffickers--but withheld full support until they had seen them in bill form and had had time to study them.

As official celebrations of Britain's entry into the Common Market continued, it seemed clear that public elation over the event was less than unanimous. Yesterday, a middle-aged woman swung her handbag in the direction of Prime Minister Heath as he opened an art exhibition related to the market entry.

A railroad-union leader warned in Trenton yesterday that his union would try to stop other commuter service in New Jersey if the Central Railroad of New Jersey abandoned its passenger commuter service in the state on Jan. 21.

The Middlesex County Board of Freeholders instructed the Board of Managers of Roosevelt Hospital in Menlo Park today to look into misconduct charges with political overtones raised by seven staff doctors against Dr. Man Wah Cheung, medical director and chief administrator of the hospital.
Gene Shalit, a movie and book reviewer, sports columnist, and publicity man, will join the panel of the National Broadcasting Company's "Today" show Jan. 15, replacing Joe Garagiola.
Veterans who hold World War I and World War II G.I. insurance will get a record dividend this year, Veterans Administrator Donald E. Johnson announced today.

The editor of the Los Angeles Times says the newspaper will not apologize to the Ohio State coach, Woody Hayes, for an incident in which the coach allegedly shoved a camera into the face of a Times photographer before the Rose Bowl game.

The Education Ministry announced today that French high school pupils would receive "information on reproduction" beginning next fall, the first time sex education has entered the official French curriculum.
Victor Desbien, his wife, Arlene, their 3-year-old son, Michael, and Mr. Desbien's mother, Pauline, were killed in a fire in their Queens Village home.

Apparently concerned by the threat of an aroused United States Congress to cut off spending for the Vietnam war, President Nguyen Van Thieu is sending a delegation of five South Vietnamese senators to Washington, it was disclosed today.

There are undoubtedly some excellent players living in remote parts of the world, far from the mainstream of international competition. Lack of strong partners and strong opponents automatically deprives them of the chance of reaching world class, but they can make their presence felt on occasion.

Congressional Democrats continued today to make speeches and approve resolutions against President Nixon's war policy, but leaders acknowledged that there was no prospect of immediate passage of legislation that would end the war.
Claude Chayet, France's new Delegate General to North Vietnam, arrived at his post yesterday and immediately toured parts of Hanoi destroyed in recent bombing raids, including Bach Mai Hospital.

PARIS--Current Egyptian student riots remind the world that numerous countries, regardless of ideology, share one basic problem: how to bridge the generation gap between youth and those who guide them. An 'old Latin-American saying applies on every inhabited continent: "In the minds of our grandfathers we are all radicals."
Albert A. Exendine, a member of the National Football Hall of Fame, died today after a long illness. He was 88 years old.
Simon Isaacson a retired builder who was president of Isaacson Steel Erectors, Inc., of Farmingdale, L. I., died Tuesday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 87 years old.

Egyptian university campuses were deserted today in the wake of clashes yesterday between students and riot policemen at Cairo University and of the Government's decision to suspend classes at all institutions of higher learning.

A Trans World Airlines 747 jet with 236 persons aboard on a flight from Madrid to New York was diverted to Ellsworth Air Force Base today because an extortionist said that he had put an altitude-sensitive bomb on the craft.

William F. Buckley Jr. said yesterday that he would seek private financial aid to keep his controversial "Firing Line" program on public television despite an apparent decision by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to drop the program May 1.

A 19-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday as one of three suspects in the fatal stabbing Wednesday night of an 18-year-old in a school gymnasium in Canarsie. The two other youthful suspects were still being sought.

The Western Union Corporation won Government approval today of its plan to build the first United States domestic satellite communications system to handle such services as its telegraph, Telex and private line services.

East Germany moved yesterday toward seeking diplomatic relations with the United States and American officials said that they were willing to discuss the matter. The issue was raised by the East German observer to the United Nations during a- courtesy call on the chief United States delegate, George Bush. [Page 1, Column 1.]
The Winchester Press, not yet four years old but with 100 published titles to, its credit, continues to offer works of special appeal to those interested in the outdoors and related' sports.

William F. Lawton, a retired National Guard warrant officer, testified today that he performed services on his own time and without charge for Maj. Gen, James F. Cantwell, while the General was chief of the New Jersey National Guard. He said he had done the work on the basis of a friendship that began in 1928 when both were enlisted men in the Army.

U. Alexis Johnson, the State Department's senior career officer, is expected to replace Gerard C. Smith as the head of the United States delegation to the talks with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic arms, well-placed Nixon Administration officials said today.

Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that he expected the Nixon Administration to ask Congress to reinstate the death penalty, which was in effect struck down by the United States Supreme Court last June 29.

One of the central issues-if not the central issuefacing the renewed peace talks Monday seems to be South Vietnam's demand, apparently backed by the United States, that any accord recognize and support the continuing existence of two Vietnams.
The Winchester Press, not yet four years old but with 100 published titles to its credit, continues to offer works of special appeal to those interested in the outdoors and related sports.

The Public Education Association called on the city's Board of Education yesterday to renew the contract of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, which expires on June 30, and "thus give him a clear mandate to continue the reform programs that he has so painstakingly initiated."

Senator Birch Bayh introduced today a bill to reduce inheritance taxes on farms handed down to relatives. The Indiana Democrat said the measure was necessary because high inheritance taxes force families to abandon the farms.
Wayne Harris, a jockey, suf fered cuts on his face and hand when he was spilled from hi mount in the backstretch during the third race today at Santa Anita.
Australia, often accused of racism in the selection of immigrants, has officially barred skin color as a factor for consideration in the admission of prospective settlers.

Officially, Prime Minister Jack Lynch has come to the United States to encourage more investment in the Republic of Ireland. He is believed, however, to intend to use his five days in this country to dissuade IrishAmericans from contributing funds ostensibly for relief in Northern Ireland but used to buy guns and ammunition for the Irish Republican Army Provisionals. Such a timely admonition from such a source cannot be sounded too loudly or too often.
The aluminum set-aside for the first quarter of 1973 will remain at the 125-millionpound level of the preceding three months, the Commerce Department said today.

A railroad union leader warned today that an attempt would be made to stop other commuter service in New Jersey if the Central Railroad of New Jersey abandoned its passenger commuter service in the state on Jan. 21.

Richard M. Clurman, the Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said at his swearing-in ceremony yesterday that his agency would "withdraw" all maintenance. men and services from public parks that are repeatedly vandalized where the community makes no move to stop it.

"It's Friday in New York and we're the Fitzgeralds" will be heard today for the last time as it introduces the daily radio broadcast that Ed and Pegeen Fitzgerald have done together here for the better part of 34 years.
The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation today reported their end-ofDecember car sales were running well ahead of last year's pace.

Relatives and friends yesterday filed past the coffin of a 16-year-old boy whose body lay in a small mortuary in Harlem. The boy, Michael A. Marerro, was found dead in his bed in a Bellevue Hospital ward on the morning of Dec. 26.

Christopher T. Chenery, a prominent horseman, breeder and corporate executive, died Wednesday at New Rochelle Hospital, after a long illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 1357 Park Lane in Pelham.

An inmates' strike at San Quentin prison fizzled yesterday as all but a dozen prisoners returned to their jobs. The walkout began Tuesday when 1,200 convicts out of the prison's 1,450-man work force stayed in their cells.

Only four days after a new state law made him a legal adult, an 18-year-old black youth was appointed today to the City Council as a temporary replacement for Councilman Vincent K. Tibbs, who died last Sunday.
The United states command reported yesterday that another B-52 -- the 16th since Dec. 18 -- had been lost to North Vietnamese antiaircraft fire.
Vice President Agnew, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon and Mr. and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson were among the national figures who paid tribute here today to Representative Hale Boggs.
Australia, often accused of racism in the selection of immigrants, has officially barred skin color as a factor for consideration in the admission of prospective settlers.

Edward A. Gibbs, assistant commissioner for Federal code enforcement of the city's Department of Rent and Housing Maintenance, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Monday in St. Martin, W.I., where he was on vacation.

China is vastly expanding her communications lines to the rest of the world this year with the aid of American communications technology. Three American companiesthe Communications Satellite Corporation, RCA Global Communications, Inc., and Western Union International-are play-ing a leading role in aiding the Chinese.

East Germany moved yesterday toward seeking diplomatic relations with the United States and American officials said that they were willing to discuss the matter. The issue was raised by the East German observer to the United Nations during a courtesy call on the chief United States delegate, George Bush. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Charles G. Dougherty, who retired as executive vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in 1971, died today at the age of 65. Mr. Dougherty, a lawyer, had been with the big insurance company for 39 years at his retirement.

The Metropolitan Opera Company, got up in its richest panoply and spread out on the stage like the hosts of Nebuchadnezzar, kept a blind date with hilarity yesterday. For nearly two hours it lent itself to the wiles of a conjurer, contortionist, mime and sleight-of-tongue artist named Danny Kaye. Never in his wildest nightmare had Walter Mitty dreamed anything like it.
The Champion Oil Company of Hamilton, Ohio, was awarded almost $3-million yesterday by a Federal Judge in an antitrust suit against the Atlantic Richfield Company of New York.

A retired United States Army Colonel, David H. Hackworth; the most decorated officer of the Vietnam war, said today that he was working as a waiter in a cafe in an Australian resort. And, he said, he likes it. "I'm here," he explained "because I like peace."

Congressional Democrats continued today to make speeches and approve resolutions against President Nixon's war policy, but leaders acknowledged that there was no prospect of immediate passage of legislation that would end the war.
James P. Sheehy, the City's Associate Deputy Commissioner of Health, who led the crackdown on dirty restaurants and stores, died at his office Wednesday night. He was 45 years old.

The Bell Howell Company sued the Eastman Kodak Company today, contending that Kodak's virtual monopoly of the film industry in this country gave it. an unfair advantage in the production and sales of camera equipment.
The granting of immunity to two alleged art thieves in exchange for return of $600,000 worth of art treasures stolen from the Caramoor Center for the Arts was upheld in State Supreme Court today.

Arnold Miller, the insurgent coal miner who won the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America in a bitterly contested election last month, announced today he was cutting his own salary and the salaries of other union officials and staff members.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers has expressed official concern to the Australian Government over the Australian maritime unions' boycott of American shipping in response to the American bombing of North Vietnam.

The Governor's Council certified today the results of the Nov. 7 referendum forcing retirement of judges at the age of 70. The action put 36 judges out of their jobs.
The United States Chamber of Commerce urged the Nixon Administration today to seek "farreaching" trade negotiating authority from Congress early in the new session.

Reflecting eleventh-hour improvement in market sentiment, the Treasury yesterday auctioned $625-million of 20-year bonds - the most distant maturity it has offered since 1965-at a rate of 6.795 per cent.
Jenneke Barton's song recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday promised rare satisfactions, built as it was around tastefully chosen groups by Mozart, Wolf, Respighi, Badings and Faure.

President Idi Amin announced today that 500 British concerns in this country would be taken over by Ugandans. He told the Acting British High Commissioner, Henry Brind, that 94 other Britishowned companies would be allowed to continue under British ownership.
A crowd of almost 300 children in Londonderry defied volleys of rubber bullets today and attacked six soldiers with stones and other missiles.
The Offtrack Betting Corporation presented the city with a check for $2.5-million yesterday as its part of the corporation's earnings for the month of December.

Donald Drew Egbert, professor of architecture emeritus at Princeton and one of America's most distinguished scholars in the history of American art and architecture, died Wednesday at the Medical Center in Princeton. He was 70 years old.

The Eastern Air Lines widebody jet that crashed in Miami a week ago made a rather steep final descent into the Everglades rather than the "gradual" descent first reported by Government investigators, Eastern sources said yesterday.

To the Editor: We write in response to your Dec. 14 editorial on Mr. Moynihan's appointment as Ambassador to India. In dwelling whimsically on Mr. Moynihan and India's impact on each other, you minimized Mr. Moynihan's competence for the position as well as the gravity of the issues dividing the two countries.
The City Commission on Human Rights yesterday extended its protection against discrimination to individuals with arrest and conviction records.

The Government sold $6.2-billion in savings bonds in 1972, the best one-year sales since 1948, the Treasury Department said today. At year-end, investors held $58.1-billion in E and H Bonds and Freedom Shares, $3.3-billion more than a year earlier. The Treasury called it the biggest annual growth in bond holdings in 27 years.

The Chicago Bulls rolled up a 16point lead in the first six minutes tonight and coasted to their fifth straight victory-a 111-97 decision over the Houston Rockets in a National Basketball Association game.

An extremely rare species of beaked whale that was rescued from the beach and placed in a private swimming pool has drawn scientists from several states and Canada here in an attempt to keep it alive and to determine just what type of whale it is.

The Interstate Commerce Commission suspended today part of the commercial operations of Allied Van Lines, the nation's largest movers, as a penalty for poor service. The commission said that it was also ready to move against six other major transport companies for similar violations.

Singing, "We will lay down our G swords and shields, down by the riverside," a religious conference wound up two days of activities today aimed at putting pressure on Congress to cut off funds for the war in Vietnam.
East Germany moved today toward seeking diplomatic relations with Washington, and United States officials said they were willing to discuss the matter.

The United States Olympic Committee selected Salt Lake City yesterday as the new American entry to bid for the 1976 Winter Olympics, despite an unresolved financial situation and possible problems of acceptance from many Utah residents.

Gary Sabourin scored an unassisted goal midway through the third period tonight to lift the St. Louis Blues to a 4-2 victory over Boston and snap the Bruins' National Hockey League winning streak at eight games.
A Superior Court judge ruled today that it was illegal to eject a person from a public meeting because he failed to place his hand over his heart during the Pledge of Allegiance.

Meatpackers bid up hog and cattle prices to record levels yesterday, fearful of temporarily short supplies. The snow and icestorms in the Midwest have prevented many animals from being moved from farms to market. This will mean higher prices in the supermarkets.

The Public Service Company of Colorado filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1.5 million shares of common stock to be sold through Merrill Lynch and the First Boston Corporation. The utility will use the proceeds to reduce outstanding commercial paper issued for construction The company's stock closed at 23 3/8, down 1/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa--A group of liberal lawyears, law professors and legal thinkers in South Africa have said their country's apartheid laws are undermining "the twin foundations of the common law, respect for the individual and equality before the law."
Three employes of the Massachusetts Bay Transit Authority led 400 commuters half a mile through a darkened tunnel to safety this morning after a fire broke out on an inbound rapidtransit train.

Officials of the Health and Hospitals Corporation have drawn up a $1,063,000,000 budget, which they say will be used to increase the number of nurses in New York's municipal hospitals, open new facilities, provide specialized training for ambulance drivers and increase hospital security.

The Army awarded the Western Electric Company a $136.8-million contract today for continued production and installation of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system at Grand Fork, N.D.

Julius Boros, Johnny Miller and the former Professional Golfers Association champion, Dave Stockton, shot four-underpar 67's at the 7,028-yard, par 71 Riviera Country Club Course today for the first-round lead in the $135,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.

An advisory committee drawn from the mutual fund industry proposed today that mutual funds no longer be required to make quarterly reports about the stocks they have bought and sold for the fund's investment portfolio.
Monetary expansion threatened to run at excessive rates this week, data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve System indicated.

Royal Daniel Jr., former managing editor of the old Pitts burgh Sun-Telegraph, city editor of The New York Daily Mirror and managing editor of The Boston Daily Advertiser, died Tuesday at the age of 77.

Dick Lloyd, the Rutgers basketball coach, told the New Jersey college basketball writers today, "I am more concerned about the turnovers we commit during a game than anything else right now. William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday urged the New York Stock Exchange to investigate the actions of two Big Board member firms in connection with the rapid rise in the price of Power Conversion, Inc., an over-the-counter stock.

The Vatican permitted foreign newsmen to inspect Michelangelo's restored Pieta today, and announced that next month the public would be able to see the masterpiece behind a triple-layer glass shield, two-thirds of an inch thick. at a distance of 25 feet.

Relatives of Roberto Clemente, the baseball star who was killed in a plane crash New Year's Eve, said today visitors to the Clemente home had stolen some of his trophies.

It appears that the two vacancies on the Securities and Exchange Commission will be filled soon. Certain names keep cropping up on Wall Street as probable nominees for seats on the five-member commission.

Conscientious objectors who satisfactorily complete two years of alternative service are entitled to the same educational benefits as military veterans, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

KANSAS CITY-Agriculture is the economic lifeblood of mid-America, and things on the farm are looking up for 1973. Fall rains and winter snows have thoroughly saturated the black earth that stretches all the way from the western slopes of the Appalachians into the Dakotas, Nebraska and Kansas. Demand for beef, pork and grain is steadily rising, particularly foreign demand.

Police detectives investigating last week's knife slaying of 28year-old Roseann Quinn in her West Side apartment said yesterday that they were searching for a witness who might be able to identify the killer.
President Nixon has announced the appointment of 13 women and three men to a new advisory committee on the economic role of women.

Prof. Alexander Eckstein, leader of a United States delegation that has just visited China to discuss Chinese-American cultural exchanges, said here today that prospects of a gradual expansion of exchanges "look very promising" although the delegation reached no agreement with the Chinese on concrete plans.

Beneath Atlantic Avenue, near the East River, are the dank remains of a shortlived transit glory. Here, in the eighteen-forties, Brooklyn proudly built the world's first subway. Its locomotives huffed and puffed barely 11 years before angry citizens hooted them off the scene.

Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that a $110million temporary rate increase for electric, gas and steam service would go into effect next Wednesday. A Con Edison spokesman said the increase, averaging 7.7 per cent, was being made in accordance with the Public Service Commission's order authorizing the increase.

Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd Elliott have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Elliott, to Arthur Geary Neal, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Leslie Neal of Ithaca, N. Y. The wedding will take place here April 18.

The 17th annual International Automobile Show, one of New York's harbingers of spring, will open Saturday, April 7, and run through Sunday, April 15, at the New York Coliseum. Over the last 16 years more than a half-million persons have attended the show at the Coliseum, Charles Snitow, show president, said yesterday.

HACKENSACK - Sixteenyear-old Mary G. was brought to Juvenile Court for running away from home and stealing from a neighbor. The judge gave her a suspended sentence and turned her over to a probation officer.

Campy Russell, the sophomore star, scored 23 points and led Michigan to a 68-62 basketball victory over Ohio State in a Big Ten opener today. It was Michigan's first triumph on the Buckeye court in 18 years.

The nation's airlines appear to be jetting into an era of fundamental changes for much of the industry-and the traveling public. But the airlines can't see yet just where the changes are taking them.

Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., the world's most experienced astronaut, announced today that he was retiring March 1 from the space agency and from the Navy to become an executive with a Houston corporation.

MONTAUK, L. I.-Montauk Manor, a lofty 200-room landmark hotel here on the East End of Long Island, will reopen as a hotel this summer for the first time since 1964, officials of Hilton Inns, Inc. and a contracting concern said last week.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., the motion picture producer which is diversifying into other leisure fields such as hotels, reported yesterday lower revenues and operating earnings in its first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 25.
Terry Warner was hospitalized with a back injury and Rudy Turcotte suffered a contusion of the left knee as a result of separate accidents today in the first race at Liberty Bell.
The Supreme Court, rejecting the protests of two competing railroads, approved today the merger of the Illinois Central and the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio railroads to form the Illinois Gulf Central.

Legislators arriving for their first working day were buttonholed today by hundreds of intense amateur lobbyists--parents and social workers from New York City who demanded that the state not increase day-care fees.

Philadelphia's public school teachers went on strike today for higher pay. Representatives of the school board spent the day in the courtroom of Judge D. Donald Jamieson of the Court of Common Pleas seeking an injunction to restore classes for the city's 285.000 students. But the Phila.
Subtract the baby from "Rosemary's Baby," transplant those strange, Manhattan cliff-dwellers to sunny California and you have "The Devil's Daughter," one of the better made-for-TV movies.

Random House has acquired Ballantine Books, publishers of mass-market paperbook originals and reprints, for approximately $6.4-million, payable in installments from Jan. 2, 1974, through Jan. 2, 1978.

In the aftermath of a case involving the Federal Communications Commission, 13 other Federal agencies have assured Congress that they do not secretly listen to their workers' phone calls and the commission says there will be no repetition of a 1970 eavesdropping episode disclosed by a Congressional committee.

An Internal Revenue Service claim for $7,009,165 in taxes due for last year was filed yesterday against Frank Matthews, the Staten Islander arrested in Las Vegas, Nev., last week in an investigation of alleged million-dollar trafficking in cocaine.

The New York film critics have opened the awards season by pronouncing "Cries and Whispers" the best film of 1972. It is a Bergman film from Sweden. Nobody outside Scandinavia has seen it except the New York film critics, and the prize need not detain us since, if your town is anything like Washington, the film will not arrive until the second Agnew Administration.

Lloyd O. Ireland, a certified public accountant and a founder last year of Sprague, Diggins Ireland, Inc., died Sunday in the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow. He was 45 years old and lived at 332 West Neck Road in Lloyd Harbor, L. I.
State correction officials reported that a new holiday furlough program for prison inmates was an "outstanding success," with all but 7 of 680 prisoners having returned to custody after visits home.

The police stormed a sniper stronghold on the roof of the Downtown Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge today. But they found only the body of a sniper who was shot to death last night and not the second gunman they had said they thought was holed up there.

Six firemen were injured, none seriously, and about 30, patients were temporarily moved to other buildings when I a steam line burst in two connected buildings of the Bellevue Hospital complex last night.
The Volkswagen Company announced today that although its total sales in the United States fell by 7 percent in 1972, sales of the "Beetle" rose almost 4 per cent to 345,000 cars.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, has lost a 14-month effort to win a divorce although he has been living with a second woman for more than three years and she has borne him two sons.
Euonymus closed strongly through the stretch at Bowie today to win the $10,000 allowance feature at 1 1-16 miles for fillies and mares.
The Federal Power Commission proposed today a system of rationing scarce natural gas supplies that would give first priority to homes and small commercial consumers.

Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that Gordon Rule had not been .dismissed as the Navy cost controller for his Senate testimony against a major shipbuilder but for "a series" of other unspecified statements.
An arctic cold wave that gripped much of the country held the metropolitan region in subfreezing temperatures yesterday and brought woe to commuters, many office workers and apartment dwellers.
Jose Rodriguez, a Bronx middleweight, slugged his way to a unanimous 10-round decision over Don Cobbs of St. Louis before a crowd of 1,451 at the Felt Forum last night.
A San Quentin convict who won an early release from prison 14 months ago because of a clerical error was arrested yesterday in connection with the slaying of a 50-year-old grandmother.

Israel and Syria fought extensive air and artillery battles today after Israeli planes struck at Syrian targets in what a military spokesman described as reprisal for guerrilla attacks on the Golan heights.
The General Electric Company has received $96-million in defense contracts, it was announced yesterday. Three awards were from the Navy: $49.1-million for ship propulsion equipment;

Athens today formally became the American Navy's largest home port in Europe. A navy-to-navy accord signed here will enable about 6,500 Navy men and their families to make Greece their home for the next five years.

Dr. Robert Vernon Steagall Jr., 28 years old, worked through the Christmas and New Year's weekends at Roanoke Memorial Hospital so that he and his wife of six months, Elizabeth, 25, could add a few days to a Southern vacation.
Visiting Europeans have always bought jewels here to take back home with them, but in the last few months they have been outdoing themselves. The Japanese and Mexicans have been loading up, too.

Cashing winners is usually a pedestrian business of no great interest, but occasionally the precise sequence in which the winners are cashed may require some thought. If you wish to test yourself, cover the East-West hands in the diagramed deal.
On the eve of his 60th birthday, President Nixon said the way to thwart advancing age was to avoid boredom, look to the future and--above all--to have young people around.
A tit-for-tat battle over the Vietnam war between waterfront unions in the United States and Australia has been making a mess of relations between the two countries. .

Woodstock College, the Jesuit seminary here that has been conducting an experiment in theological education, will close permanently--at least in its present form--on or before the end of the academic year.
The Health Department yesterday released the names of 11 food-processing establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

A New Jersey laboratory technician was arrested at La Guardia Airport yesterday and charged with attempted hijacking after he had allegedly tried to board an Eastern Airlines jet with two bottles containing cyanide gas.
Mrs. Mildred Murphy Nelson, the wife of Lindsey Nelson, the sportscaster, died Saturday on the island of Minorca, the United States Consulate reported today.
Albert T. Sommers, senior vice president and chief economist of The Conference Board, is bullish on America for 1973. One of the segments of the economy on which he is most bullish is retailing.

A freshman, Gene Chy led Florida to an upset victory over nationally ranked Vanderbilt, 80-72, tonight in a Southeastern Conference basketball game. Shy, a 6-foot-5-inch forward, scored 24 points, hitting on nine of 14 shots and six of nine free throws.

Rushing to the defense of "American tradition" and legions of play-money millionaires, the makers of Monopoly have fired off an indignantly worded protest to Atlantic City against a proposal to rename Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.

Governor Cahill's proposal for a mass transit agency has revived interest in plans to construct monorail or other mass transit systems along the rights of way of the New Jersey Turnpike or the Garden State Parkway.

Public discussion of the proposed new Philippine Constitution has ended as a result of an order by President Ferdinand E. Marcos yesterday, banning free debate on the charter and classifying the spreading of rumors as subversive.

The lecture read to the President's Congressional critics by Herbert G. Klein, the White House Director of Communications, spells out Mr. Nixon's determination not to brook interference with his conduct of either the war or the peace negotiations. In the process, political facts at home and military realities in Vietnam are to be bent to the President's will. If the truth stands in the way, the White House communicators blithely revise it.

The Super Bowl hullabaloo began in not-so-blase Los Angeles with a mob scene today that broke up the Washington Redskins' workout and their availability for 100 photographers and reporters at a photo-media session.

Detectives said yesterday that they had no clues so far to explain the case of a 40-year-old Salvadorian man, Ralph Fernandez, who was found shot to death in West 79th Street on Sunday just a few yards from the spot where his younger brother, Luis, was shot to death on Aug. 23.
Dispatches from Moscow said that Dr. Michael E. De Bakey had arrived there to operate on Mstislav Keldysh, president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
Panama retaliated against the World Boxing Council today for withdrawing recognition of Enrique Pinder as bantamweight champion--it withdrew recognition of the World Boxing Council.
The total amount of consumer credit outstanding rose by a record $2.1-billion in November, to a total of $153-billion, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The police considered and discarded everything from a frontal assault to helicopter landings and even the use of flame throwers in their 32-hour attempt to kill or capture the sniper or snipers in the Downtown Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge.
Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho resumed negotiations for a cease-fire here today. No substantive reports emerged from either side about how the talks had gone.

The Adirondack Park Agency ran into local opposition as it opened its first public hearing tonight on its controversial plan to control sharply development of the 3.7 million acres of private land in the vast Adirondack Park.

Evonne Goolagong, beaten yesterday in the final of the New South Wales tennis championship, won her first match in the New Zealand open championship today. The 21-year-old Aussie easily beat Lindsay Blatchford of Britain, 6-0, 6-3.

An individual's right to choose death by rejecting medical therapy and a patient's right to obtain a full explanation in clear, concise terms of his medical condition were affirmed in a 12-point "Bill of Rights" that the nation's leading hospital association issued yesterday.

Mrs. Ada Kogan Bildersee, a teacher and librarian in the public schools for 42 years until her retirement last September, died Sunday at New York Hospital. Her age was 61 and she lived at 205 West End Avenue.
A North Korean sports official said today that North and South Korea could possibly send a unified team to the next Olympic Games, scheduled for Montreal in 1976.
The Nassau Coliseum presented its fourth college basketball program tonight and once again pro scouts and the player agents had a field day and made up a large part of the announced crowd of 3,017.
" I just sat there on the hall floor, watching the incubators come out of the delivery room and go down to the nursery and come back to the delivery room and go down to the nursery, again and again.

Several of yesterday's TV soap operas were interrupted for what appeared to be a typical action-suspense melodrama, complete with policemen, terrorists, rifles and gunfire. The action, however, was live, direct from the Howard Johnson Motel in downtown New Orleans.

It was late last summer, and the Congdons were in the country, when a swarm of bees, clinging to a traffic sign at Fifth Avenue and 17th Street, appeared on their television screen. They looked at one another with instant foreboding.

The Rev. Dr. Fred J. Fiedler, who retired in 1959 as secretary of the Board of World Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, died Saturday in Jackson Heights, Queens, where he lived. His ago was 81.

President Zalman Shazar of Israel ended a five-day visit here yesterday with an appeal to Jews in the United States to help Israel absorb an influx of Soviet Jews. He left for home last night from Kennedy International Airport.
Buster Harvey's power-play goal with less than seven minutes to play tonight allowed the Minnesota North Stars to earn a 3-3 draw with the Montreal Canadiens in the National Hockey League.
Dave DeBusschere of the New York Knicks and Pete Maravich of the Atlanta Hawks will be 'in the National Basketball Association's All-Star game line-up for the first time at Chicago, Jan. 28.
From Chicago yesterday came dismaying news for most housewives-new record prices for live beef cattle in futures trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

" I was mentally ill," said 22-year-old Bryant Ramsey, a former narcotics addicts who is receiving treatment at Brooklyn's Harambee House. "I wouldn't even have felt guilty about stealing my mother's welfare check. How could I have felt anything about selling drugs?"

A man was shot to death today in the parking lot of the General Motors assembly plant here. According to the police, James Gwynn and Leonard Telesco Jr., both of White Plains, were involved in a car accident in a parking lot at the plant.

Two former officials of a major brokerage company pleaded guilty yesterday to participation in a stock scheme that allegedly cost investors $200-million in one of the largest fraud cases ever uncovered.

A top women's track and field coach charged yesterday that promoters of major indoor meets in the United States were discriminating against women athletes and contributing to the problems facing the sport for the 1976 Olympics.
The latest "moratorium" on the State Urban Development Corporation's plans in Westchester expires one week from today.

VISIONS OF CODY. By Jack Kerouac. Introduction by Allen Ginsberg. 398 pages., McGraw-Hill. $8.95. If Allen Ginsberg's introduction doesn't turn you off Jack Kerouac's "Visions of Cody"--now published for the first time in its entirety!--the book itself soon will. The introduction is one of the silliest pieces of writing I've ever seen.

Investors are familiar with those disclaimers that appear at the bottom of brokerage house recommendations. When they are read with care, it's a wonder the investor is willing to buy recommended stock at all.

Nourrhedine Boutagou won the men's 200-meter butterfly event tonight to give Algeria the first gold medal of the second all-Africa games. But the Egyptians, winners of all the gold medals in the first games held in 1965, ended the day with three gold, two silver and two bronze medals-all in swimming at the Olympic-sized pool.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association, assembling for the 67th annual convention that begins Thursday, indicated tonight that it probably would be unable to act on its expected investigation of the Southwestern Louisiana basketball team's alleged violations of the N.C.A.A. recruiting code.

Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho resumed negotiations in Paris yesterday for a Vietnam cease-fire. No substantive reports were given by either side about how the talks had gone. But there was no sign that either side had changed its position since talks between them broke down last month. Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Tho will meet again today. [Page 1, Column 8.]
On the eve of the submission to the Legislature of his narcotics-offense sentencing proposals, Governor Rockefeller today castigated judges who said last week that the plan would be unworkable.

George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, announced today that the Nixon Administration had halted virtually all new commitments to subsidize low-and middle-income housing construction.

Frederic C. Dumaine, president of the Amoskeag Company, announced today that Amoskeag had purchased $10.3-million of the $14.2-million in bonds held by four insurance companies in the bankrupt Boston Maine Railroad.
The lower house of Parliament today approved a bill sponsored by President Nguyen Van Thieu meant to help cut back the number of political parties.
British Overseas Airways Corporation today announced cuts in its round-trip fares across the Atlantic on regularly scheduled London-New York flights to a new low of $145.70 in the low season.

There was a great deal of vivacity at the Alvin Theater last night, but rather less life. The occasion was the opening of a new musical called "Tricks."

If more coaches followed Mike Curry's example, New Jersey's top high-school athletes would all be staying home and competing for Garden State colleges. The Trenton State wrestling coach has waged a war against out-of-state recruiters, emerging with victorious results. By loading up on local talent, Curry has forged one of the top mat teams on the East Coast. .

Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, asserting that a paramilitary concept of law enforcement prevails in to America, said today that the present system should be replaced by one using policemen as accepted as civil servants working for the people.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa --Two commissions appointed by Prime Minister John Vorster's Government have been studying universities and student organizations and are expected to report on them during the session of Parliament that begins early in February.

U.S.), Justice Douglas dissenting, and the Kansas City Southern Railroad (No. 72-581, Kansas City Southern v. U.S.)

Vietnam has become one man's war. Whether it is his crusade to prove that he, personally, cannot be "pushed around," or that our inevitable eventual departure is "honorable" does not matter. What matters, aside from the supreme consideration of the human losses and suffering caused, is that the President used the period of Congressional adjournment and preoccupation with the holiday season to intensify the war far above any previous level.

But the Egyptians. winners of all the gold medals in the first games held in 1965, ended the day with three gold, two silver and two bronze medals--all in swimming at the Olympic-sized pool.
On the eve of the submission to the Legislature of his narcotics-offense sentencing proposals, Governor Rockefeller today castigated judges who said last week that the plan would be unworkable.

The EI Chico Corporation said yesterday it had withdrawn a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last spring in connection with a proposed offering of 280,000 common shares.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday praised the 20th Century Fund, a property-owning tax-exempt foundation, for its sixth annual payment of $12,000 to the city for municipal services it received free of charge last year.
Playing a scrambling, catch-up kind of hockey, the New York Raiders twice rallied to tie the Quebec Nordiques last night at Madison Square Garden, only to lose in sudden-death overtime, 6-5.
Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told the House Armed Services Committee today that "from a military standpoint, the Vietnamization program has been completed."

The state police questioned survivors and sifted through ashes and charred ruins today looking for clues to what touched off the weekend fire that killed seven young resort workers in this Catskill Mountain hamlet.

American Negroes are under a state of siege launched by the "executive branch of the Federal Government,"' according to Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Senate Republicans voted today to take a step toward eliminating the absolute seniority rule for selecting party leaders on committees.
The New Hampshire lakefront estate where the author of the United States' open door policy in China spent his summers will be given to the Federal Government for a wildlife refuge.

A West Berlin forensic expert said today that he had established with near certainty that Martin Bormann, Hitler's aide, died in Berlin at the end of the war as Russian troops closed in on the former German capital.

Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst has agreed to meet with William J. Guste Jr., the Louisiana Attorney General, to discuss Mr. Guste's belief that there is a national terrorist group involved in the New Orleans gun battle.

Most stocks on the over-the counter market advanced yesterday while prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed. Brokers said both markets were hurt by stepped-up profit taking following the recent sharp gains of many issues.

The Dow-Jones industrial average edged into new high ground yesterday in a generally cautious and quiet session. After running I or 2 points behind for most of the day, the Dow tacked on a gain of 0.37 to finish at 1,047.86.

Israel and Syria fought extensive air and artillery battles today after Israeli planes struck at Syrian targets in what a military spokesman described as reprisal for guerrilla attacks on the Golan heights.
President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was quoted today as having said that he had given up all hope in United States efforts to bring about a peaceful settlement of the Middle East conflict.

Five members of a Long Island labor-management promotion fund were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to violate the Taft-Hartley Act by diverting employer contributions to such things as gifts of jewelry and a television-stereo set to union officials.

A "massive body of circumstantial evidence" proves beyond reasonable doubt that Juan V. Corona murdered all of the 25 men buried in makeshift graves near Yuba City in 1971, G. Dave Teja, the prosecutor, said today.
Negotiations to end the Long Island Rail Road strike broke up here last night with a spokesman saying there was "no progress" to report in the 41-day walkout.

Nelson Rockefeller's announcement that he will seek mandatory life sentences -- with no possibility of parole and no "plea bargaining"--for pushers of hard drugs. But for once, these arguments of right and wrong may be laid aside for the simple reason that the Governor's proposal is demonstrably unworkable, unless accompanied by unimaginable court and prison expansion.

This is a fact of international life which is very often misunderstood by sincere people who honestly want to see the bloodshed and the hostilities in Indochina brought to an end. to an end.

Deputy Major Edward K. Hamilton characterized as a "grossly irresponsible act" the withdrawal of Federal housing funds announced in Houston yesterday by George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
The bond market took the course of least resistance yesterday and declined as the first significant new corporate issue of the year met only a lukewarm response from investors.

A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry today rejected the proposal put for ward yesterday by 120 leading citizens that the Dutch Ambas sador in the United States be recalled as a protest against the American bombings in Vietnam.

A midtown diamond mer chant was beaten and robbed of more than $200,000 in unset gems yesterday by three men who forced their way into his office on the 15th floor at 62 West 47th Street after one of them posed as a mailman carrying a special delivery letter.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court has denied admission to the bar to a 47-year-old homosexual who 16 years ago was disbarred in Florida after his arrest on asodomy charge.
R. J. Reynolds Tobacco seems to be spending a lot of time these days trying to convince the critics of its Winchester advertising that Winchester is indeed a littlecigar.
Whether it was his intention or not, Governor Cahill's third annual message to the Legislature to day signaled the apparent start of the 1973 gubernatorial elec tion, according to many legislators.

Pete Maravich, priming for his first start in the National Basketball Association's All-Star game, led a surge in the last five minutes that gave the Atlanta Hawks a 120-114 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.
The rules committee of the Ameri can Football Coaches Association ironically came up with a 9-9 deadlock in voting today on a proposal for a college tiebreaking rule.

Gover nor Rockefeller will seek a $2-million to $3-million in crease in state aid in the coming year for financially troubled museums, orches tras, ballet and theater com panies and other cultural in stitutions, legislative sources said today.

James A. Farley, known to many fellow members of his party as Mr. Democrat, was elected an honorary life mem ber of the National Democratic Club at a dinner last night marking the last hurrah of theparty's ornate clubhouse.
Brazil has banned the sale of Picasso's erotic engravings in what appears to be a new waveof cultural puritanism.

In what might become a prec edent-setting case testing the power of tennis associations to ban players from sanctioned tournaments, Mrs, Gladys Held man filed a complaint yesterday against the United States Lawn Tennis Association, charging six counts of antitrust violationsand unfair competition.

The peripatetic David Am ram, who is conducting two free concerts a day for school children this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, with the Brooklyn Philharmonia and his own jazz quartet, found time to bring the jazz quartet to the Overseas Press Club late Monday afternoon to play a twilight jazz concert for theorganization's Jazz Club.

The Hunter College Concert Bureau, for 30 years a sponsor of some of New York's most illustrious concert offerings, is losing its autonomy and will function as an activity of ageneral arts program at Hunter.
Thailand expelled two Americans today after they served six months in jail for desecration of a Buddhastatue, the police said.
Domestic copper producers, as expected, announced yesterday increased prices.
Friday's deadline for a strike against the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company was postponed for 30 days today at the request of Assistant Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr.

Dr. Thomas S. Sexton, a senior vice president and a director of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at his office. He was 59 years old and lived in his Granby.

The number of deaths here attributed directly to narcotics use in 1972 rose only slightly over 1971. Specialists in addic tion treatment saw this as fur ther evidence that the city's heroin epidemic may be leveling off.

The Beatrice Foods Company announced yesterday its first venture into the wine industry by agreeing to acquire Brook side Enterprises, Inc., a wine producer with two wineries in southern California and one inSacramento.

A public dispute between two big-business neighbors on Park Avenue will come up in private before the Board of Estimate today - amid hints that the board will try to avoid an immediate decision.
Stock prices edged lower in cautious trading yesterday as volume continued its pullbackfrom recent lofty levels.

Ar thur G. Prangley, vice president and corporate counsel of the Amerace Esna Corporation, New York, died Friday in the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at67 New England Avenue here.

Samuel M. Fox, chairman of the Kaufman Carpet Corpora tion and former president of the General Realty and Util ities Corporation, died yester day in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 74 years old and livedat 501 East 79th Street.
The first discovery of evi dence that dinosaurs once lived in New York State was announced yesterday by a paleontologist of the StateGeological Survey.
England's amateur boxing team, which includes six Olym pians, had morning and after noon workouts yesterday in preparation for Monday night's competition against the UnitedStates national team.

A revival in demand for forest products, which accele rated last year with increasing strength of the economy, brought a sharp rise in earnings of the International Paper Com pany, according to yesterday's preliminary unaudited reportfor 1972.

A city official said last night that Governor Rockefeller's ad ministration had introduced unnecessary uncertainty into the financing of the special courts here that have been setup to handle narcotics cases.
Two brothers who own one of the largest resort hotels in the Catskills were convicted in Federal Court here yesterday of evading taxes on $1.4-million in income during a three-yearperiod.

The United Steelworkers of Amer ica announced today the names of nominees for international and district offices but ruled ineligible the first black man ever to seek one of the threeton offices in the union.

Pentagon officials said today that American pilots were being permitted to cross the 20th parallel in pursuit of North Vietnamese jets that attempt to attack United States B-52's and other bombers operating southof the 20th parallel.

Henry F. Schulte, author and former United Press Interna tional correspondent and editor, was appointed today dean of the Syracuse University S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications, effective Monday.

Judith Norell gave her third harpsichord recital in as many years at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night, and demon strated that she has become a finished, mature artist whom one would be glad to hear atany time.

The police said today that the rifle used to shoot hotel guests and policemen during a 12-hour sniping rampage on Sunday was the same weapon that killed a police cadet and wounded a patrolman here on New Year's Eve.

The Government today fined four airports $1,000 a day for failure to comply with its strict new program to combat hijack ings. It was the first punitive action taken under the program, which went into effect Friday.

Major airlines rationed their jet fuel at Kennedy International Airport yesterday because of what industry officials called a "very serious" shortage. "We're just about flat broke as far as fuel at Kennedy is concerned," said M. J. Strock, a fuel specialist for the Air Transport Association, Washington-headquarteredorganization of scheduled airlines.

This winter-holiday home coming was something special for Sandy Mayer, a 20-year old Stanford junior. A year ago he was the 30th-ranked tennis player in the country, hardly the talk of the sport. Now he ranks No. 11 and wears the crown of the national amateur grass champion. No Jerseyans have soared so high since Eddie Moylan and Dick Savitt in the nineteenfifties.

Lucille Lortel attracts ex cellent actors to participate in her annual Matinee Series at the Theater de Lys. This week's pair of one-act plays, the final presentation in this season's series, was no exception.
In the last year foreign corre spondents have faced growing censorship problems around the world, mostly through arrest or expulsion, the threat of expul sion or the denial of entryvisas.

That paradox stems from the certainty that the truce on the Penn Central will give the Administration a freshexcuse for refusing to face up to the need for a basic
Isidore Edelman, a program analyst with the Department of the Army, died Friday of cancer at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 58 years old and lived here.

The Securities and Exchange Com mission asked for comments today on two rules it is pro posing to cover the operations of the planned exchange in Chi cago where put and call optionson stocks would be traded.

More than 3,400 consumers who were allegedly cheated by a burglar-ilarm company will get either an immediate refund or a cancellation of their debt in a settlement announced yes terday by Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson, Justice Edward Thompson and United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.
A spokesman for. Consumers Union urged the Federal Com munications Commission today to ban commercials on chil dren's television programs or, if that is not feasible, to limittheir number sharply.

The probability of its hap pening was infinitesimal, but the number of new LP rec ords issued in 1972 was ex actly the same as that for 1971-5,196. So say the edi tors of the Schwann Record Tape Guide in their annual statistical roundup. There was, however, an increase of 1,874 over the previous year in the number of tape car tridges and cassettes released, bringing the total in thatcategory to 4,469.

George Allen went into the business of ranking football teams today and the coach of the Washington Redskins declared that Sunday's opponent in the Super Bowl, the Miami Dolphins, to be "the best pro football team we've ever faced, better than the 1966 Packers."
Rhodesia closed her fron tier with Zambia tonight and said that the Zambian Govern ment had ignored repeated re quests to stop guerrillas from using its territory as a basefor raids into Rhodesia.

A state commission said today that major employers in New York State discriminated against rehabilitated narcotics addicts in their hiring practices, and urged an amendment to the state's executive law that would ban such discrimination.
Eight women and four men were sworn in as jurors today for the trial of seven men charged with a conspiracy to spy on the Democrats in the primary election campaigns last year.

The Far West Financial Cor poration, a savings and loan holding company whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday write-offs of $698, 000-due to the "revaluation of certain assets at the end of 1972-which it said would re duce its 1972- net income by about $400,000, or 21 cents ashare.
Len Elmore scored 19 points and grabbed 17 rebounds as unbeaten Maryland thrashed Virginia, 93-74, in an Atlantic Coast Conferene basket ballgame tonight.

Mahler's vogue-so-called by those who fail to under stand his powerful grip on a growing public as well as on many of our most cultivated musicians-continues to thrive.

Now that the Swedish Government has talked itself into another diplomatic tangle with Wash ington, the question has been raised anew here why this neutral country expresses more hostility toward the United States 'role in Vietnam than any of America's other traditional friends.

The Kennecott Copper Cor poration announced yesterday that a district court in Ham burg, West Germany, had or dered a shipment of more than 3,500 tons of Chilean copper turned over to a court-appointed officer.
Dr. Joel. Schweig, a derma tologist in New York for 48 years until his retirement in October, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 yearsold.

The Gov ernment tonight ordered a special court-martial for 13 civilians charged with "con spiring to commit crimes," including the kidnapping of Henry J. Tasca, the UnitedStates Ambassador to Greece.
Jose Rodriguez, a Bronx middleweight, slugged his way to a unanimous 10-round deci sion over Don Cobbs of St. Louis before a crowd of 1,451iat the Felt Forum last night.
Ships began moving in Israel's an two Mediterranean ports today after dock workers called off a five-day slowdown that was crippling shipments of citrus,a major export item.

A Federal grand jury today charged John A. Kervick, New Jersey State Treasurer from 1958 until 1970, with having extorted $113,200 from a consulting en gineering concern that did bus iness with the Delaware RiverPort Authority,

City Controller Abraham L. Beame urged the Public Serv ice Commission yesterday not to grant a water-rate increase to the Utilities and Industries Corporation, which serves 20, 000 customers in Woodhaven,Queens.

Heishiro Ogawa, a longtime diplomat who currently heads the Foreign Ministry's For eign Service Training Insti tute, is most likely to be named Japan's first Ambassa dor to Communist China, the Kyodo news agency said today.
Dela ware's conservationist Gover nor, Russell W. Peterson, took a second major step today to preserve the coast of his statebefore leaving office.

Fried. man, Jonathan and Andrew Ames,' dear sister of David and Shirley Orenbach, loving daughter of Rose Orenbach. Services Wednesday 11:45 A.M., at "The Riverside," _76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

The police said today that the rifle used to shoot hotel guests and policemen during a 12-hour sniping rampage on Sunday was the same weapon that killed a police cadet and wounded a patrolman here onNew Year's Eve.

Henry A. Kis ;inger and Le Duc Tho held the secondd session today of their currentt round of private talks on a Vietnam cease-fire. They met for five and one half hours, including lunch, and gave no indication afterward ofwhat had happened.
The absolute seniority system for selecting the chairmen and rank ing minority members of Congressional committees movedcloser to extinction today.

The largest single month's decrease in the city's welfare rolls since May, 1966 -- a shrinkage in November of 8,883 persons-was announced yesterday, largely reflecting tightened controls by the Human Resources Administration.

The pros ecution said today that it would present evidence proving that Otto Kerner, former Illinois Governor, had awarded the owner of a horseracing asso ciation lucrative racing dates at tracks in the Chicago area in return for specially pricedstock in that association.

American bombing of Hanoi was re sumed on the evening of Dec. 18, and the next day it was announced that captured airmen from B-52 bombers shot down over the city would be seen at a "press conference" at the Interna tional Club. The promised occasionproved to be simply an exhibition.

Rafael Ferrer frostily ex uded an air of easy confi dence. The afternoon temper atures hovered in the mid twenties, and the ice house he was creating in the Whit ney Museum of American Art's outdoor garden lookedlike it would not melt.

Two athletes who spurned huge bonuses from the California Angels to continue playing college ball were expected to be among the top selections in baseball's an nual free-agent draft here today. Alan Bannister, an infielder who played at Arizona State, and Brad Van Pelt, an all-America defensive backand pitcher at Michigan State, were the pair,
Former Parks Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday that the city's new policy of withdrawing money and man power from parks repeatedly damaged by vandals was"utterly impractical."

The United Federation of Teachers yesterday condemned the report of the Fleischmann Commission as serving "no use ful function" and "paving the way for the destruction of the New York City public schoolsystem."
The staff of the British Overseas Air ways Corporation at London Airport will strike for one hour on Feb. 1 if the piped-in music in the long-distance terminal is not switched off by then.

Nate Archibald of the Kansas City Omaha Kings celebrated his achievement of leading the bal loting in the National Basket ball Association's all-star poll with 52 points tonight-his high for the season-but the New York Knicks shook a bad case of jitters to edge the Kingsin overtime, 116-115.
