Despite the acclaim that Sarah Vaughan has had for the last 30 years, particularly from her fellow jazz musi cians, she has never reached the broad audience that has responded to Billie Holiday or Ella Fitzgerald, who rank with her in the pantheon ofjazz singers.

A staff economist of the Federal Power Commission, arguing that there is little effective competition in the natural gas industry, has opposed the recommendation of an industry task force that Federal regula tion of natural gas wellheadprices be ended.

Bart Starr, the quarter back who led the Green Bay Packers to the heights of National Football League su premacy in the nineteen-six ties, announced yesterday he was leaving professional football to concentrate onbusiness and his family.

The cold fact-cold as the rink floor inside Madison Square Garden-is that an ice show is as much fun as you let it be. Last nights audience for the 33d edition of "Ice Capades" was warmly appre ciative of the mixture as be fore, spruced up in a new wardrobe with some new production specialties and a clutch of superbly skillful young skaters, some new tothe revue.

The average yield on four-month commitments for per cent Federal Housing Ad ministration-Veterans Adminis traction mortgages at yester day's auction was 7.689 per cent, up slightly from the aver age 7.685 per cent at the last such auction, Dec. 26, the Fed eral National Mortgage Association said today.

Thirteen months ago, The Colony closed its doors, ending a 50-year career as one of New York's most elegant restau rants, bringing tears to the eyes of Truman Capote and other regular patrons, and add ing one more casualty to a glit tering heap brought down by a combination of labor prob lems, high costs and a vanishing clientele.
Buster Harvey's power-play goal with less than seven minutes to play tonight allowed the Minnesota North Stars to earn a 3-3 draw with the Montreal Canadiens in the NationalHockey League.

Miss Ruth Phillips Benziger and Kurt David Steir were married last Thursday in Bristol, Vt. The Rev. Raymond Provost performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Ambrose Roman Catholic Church.

A group of reform-minded police offi cials and law enforcement scholars agreed today on the need for a uniform code of ethics for American policemen similar to the codes followed by the legal and medical professions..

Ray Dempsey, an assistant coach at Bowling Green, was named head football coach today at Youngstown State University, succeeding the late Dwight Beede.
Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's minority Government survived first voting test in the new Parliament today.

Interest rates on corporate bonds continued to climb yes terday as fresh worries about inflation and higher money rates swept through Wall Street. Specialists said there was particular concern about the soaring wholesale price in dex, which last month posted its biggest advance, 1.6 per cent, in more than 20 years.

An offering of 305,300 shares of Alexander's, Inc., common at $9 a share was made yesterday by Morgan Stanley and Oppenheimer Co. The company's stock closed at 9, down 1/4 on the NewYork Stock Exchange.

Mark James Robert Essex, the 23-year-old Negro identi fied by the New Orleans po lice as the sniper who was shot and killed atop the Downtown Howard John son's Motor Lodge there, was remembered here tonight as a quiet, average student who somehow developed a hatred for whites during a tour ofduty in the Navy.
The New Jersey Supreme Court heard four hours of arguments today on the landmark school-aid de cision that held that the state's system of financing public school education was unconstitutional.

President Anwarel Sadat of Egypt and Col. Muammar el-Quaddai, the Libyan leader, met for about two hours here today to discuss the tense mid dle Eastern situation, especially along the Syrian-Israeli truce line where a four-hour artilleryduel was fought yesterday.

Managua will be re built, with its commercial cen ter about six miles from where it was when an earthquake struck Dec. 23, the country's leader, Anastasio Somoza De- E bayle, said today. The Bank of Japan today raised the reserve deposit requirements for Japanese banks in an effort to cool off a strong inflationary trend. The measure, which takes effect Jan. 16, was adopted by the policy committee of the Bank of Japan, the nation'scentral bank, after approval by the Cabinet today.
The New York Newspaper Guild charged yesterday that Time Inc. had forced out em ployes of Time magazine to make room for favored em ployes from the company'sdefunct Life magazine.

Miruts Yifter, who won a silver medal for Ethiopia in the 10,000-meter run at the Olym pics last year, captured a gold medal at 10,000 meters today in the All-Africa Games. His time was 29 minutes 4.67 seconds, far behind his time at Munich.

In 1794 the Rutson family started a farm here in Dutchess County that pro duced almost everything that a Colonial family needed to survive. Today the farm is a model dairy operation, producing hay and corn to feed its purebred Holsteins, withmilk its cash crop.

Georges Goven of France produced the first upset of the New Zealand open tennis championships today with a 6-2, 7-6, 6-3 victory over Onny Parun, the top ranking New Zealand player and finalist in the recent Australian open.

Negotiations to end the Long Island Rail Road strike were suspended indefinitely yester day. A 90-minute bargaining ses sion at the International Hotel at Kennedy International Air port ended with negotiators for 12 striking unions and the rail road management adamant intheir positions.

The more so, since the same night the New York City Ballet at the State Theater recovered from its annual seizure of "The Nutcracker" and returned togeneral repertory.
Former State Representative Hudson Moyer has forced a fourth delay in his trial on charges of stealing postage stamps by hiring a state legislator to defend him.

The Los Angeles Kings ex tended their domination over the New York Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum tonight. Jump ing into the lead with a three goal splurge in the first period, the visitors registered a 3-2 triumph over the hapless localaggregation.

Top police officials from the state's six biggest cities gath ered at Police Headquarters here yesterday in preparation for an intensive lobbying effort for money from Albany for local law enforcement.
Morton Bartho White, a former executive of Radio Free Europe in New York and Munich and a former director of the Ameri can Council of NATO, died Sun day at his home here. He was43 years old.

Incendiary devices were ex ploded late last night at two midtown movie houses special izing in sex films. No injuries were reported, the police said, but some damage to the theaters occurred.

William Sheehan has been ap pointed senior vice president of A.B.C. News, it was announced yesterday by Elmer Lower, president of the American Broadcasting Company news division. Mr. Sheehan has been vice president and director of television news for the lastseven years.

The So viet Union announced today that it would set up a national environmental protection serv ice to monitor air and water pollution throughout the country.

Declines outpaced advances yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in overthe-counter trading.
John Norman, a fashion de signer and director of the fash ion information center of Butterick Fashion Marketing Company, died Sunday night at his home, 2 Sutton Place South.He was 55 years old.

Most live cattle and hog prices equaled Monday's rec ords or set new ones yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Ex change. The prices for pork bellies, from which bacon is produced, soared to new life of-contract highs and thehighest levels in six years.

A man who had been stopped for passing a red light in the Tremont section of the Bronx was shot and killed by three policemen last. night after he allegedly drew out a gun as they accompanied. him to a tenement where he said his driver's license and registra tion papers were, the police reported.

The Chicago Teachers Union an nounced tonight that the city's 21,000 public school teachers will go on strike tomorrow morning. School officials said Chicago schools would shutdown until further notice.

A staff study of the Senate Secu rities Committee reported today that because of opposition by the New York Stock Exchange and inaction by the Securities and Exchange Commission, there was no effective means of controlling operations ofmarket "specialists."
On a 5-4 vote the Supreme Court today broadened the au thority of the Commodity Ex change Commission to consider antitrust claims against mem bers of the nation's commodities exchanges.
Tired of fighting the psy chic, often affectations world of sprinting, Dennis Walker will switch to that great quarter-mile conditioner, the 600-yard run, for this indoorseason.

The State Attorney General's office argued today that New York's law exempting newsmen from giving forced testimony does not apply to a reporter whohas witnessed a crime.

Pete Maravich, priming for his first start in the National Basketball Association's All-Star game, led a surge in the last five minutes that gave the Atlanta Hawks a 120-114 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

HIGHER EDUCATION The City University's Graduate Center at 33 West 42d Street is 18 stories tall, scarcely an eye-catcher for the quick passer-by, but its interior is surprisingly and handsomely and modernly designed, for a building that first opened its doors in 1912. You enter through a block-through mall attractively laid out and oc casionally the site for a concert.

The fault with Governor Rockefeller's indiscriminate lock-'em-up-for-life response to the challenge posed by drug pushers and addicts lies not solely in its unwork ability. The bitter irony is that it would replace a currently effective program that holds some promise of success. Discouraging though it has often been, the state's expe rience with the drug problem, especially in recent months,does raise hope that addicts can in fact be rehabilitated.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a Virginia restaurant owner could not prevent her accountant from surrendering her income records to the In ternal Revenue Service by ar guing that the records mightincriminate her.

S. Elly Rosen, executive director of the Association of Jewish Antipoverty Workers in New York, said here today that he would recommend that his organization sponsor a program to move some of New York's poor elderly Jews to Israel.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn today issued its first financial report, showing total assets of about $60-million -- of which only $3-million was said to be readily available.
They laughed at Hans Thorner when he opened his Magic Mountain ski center late in 1960. "Even my friends kept burying me for the following five or six years," Thorner said today with a smile.
The New York City Ballet presented a new eveninglength version of George Balanchine's "Harlequinade" for the first time Tuesday night at the State Theater.

Alexander A. Cunningham, president of the Opel Company, a General Motors subsidiary in West Germany, said today that 1972 was "the most successful year in one hundred years or Opel history." Before building cars Opel produced bicycles, carriages and various household devices.

Faced by rioting inmates at the start of the October, 1970, disturbances in the Tombs, a number of correction officers retreated, according to Charles McElhone, an assistant deputy warden, despite his pleas to "back us up."
Mercer County Judge Samuel D. Lenox Jr. today granted a defense motion to dismiss one of three indictments against Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell.

Rey de la Torre has been giving recitals here since 1942, and if his hair has gotten somewhat gray his playing style has not changed nor has his interest in new music for the guitar. He appeared again here Tuesday night in Tully Hall, performing in the delicate, introspective manner that is distinctly his.
Business and civic groups met in Mineola, L. I., yesterday to press for Federal legislation that could help end the Long Island Rail Road strike.

The Governor's Commission on Tax Reform proposed broad changes today in Connecticut's tax structure, including a plan to take from the rich towns and give to the poor and another to inject new life into industries by lifting some of the burden of taxation from them.
HOLMES SITE There is much eyeball -rolling and high-order emoting in "The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes," the dramatized reading now unfolding Thursdays through Saturdays at the White Horse Inn,

Personnel directors for some of the city's largest private employers - among them New York Telephone, Consolidated Edison and Metropolitan Lifetold a hearing of the city's Human Rights Commission of plans and fears involved in the hiring of large numbers of rehabilitated drug addicts.
The 1967 edition of The ReEcho, the student yearbook of Emporia Senior High School, was just about the most prized piece of property in town today.

Governor Cahill signed legislation yesterday postponing for 60 days the requirement that New Jersey motorists carry auto-insurance identification cards. Ray J. Marini, the Motor Vehicle Division chief, said that during the 60-day moratorium inspectors would accept alternative insurance identification, such as a motorist's actual policy or a letter from an insurance agent.
Citing shortages of heating oil, Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, suggested today that it was time to end mandatory quotas on oil imports.

No wonder Elliot L. Richardson took refuge in discreet silence when members of Congress, at his Cabinet confirmation hearing, asked substantive questions about his policy views. By now, he knows that policy in this Administration is the absolute preserve of Richard M. Nixon and the janissaries around him in the White House.

Live beef cattle again set record highs in prices of futures contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The rising prices are bad news for housewives in terms of prospective higher beef prices.
C. Mercer Templeton, a former song and dance man on Broadway and in vaudeville, died Tuesday at Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Maplewood, N. J.
A fighter pilot's daughter with a B.S. in computer science and the Navy rank of lieutenant today became the first woman to be assigned to pilot training in the United States Navy.

An influential citizens group charged at a hearing here tonight that there were "dangerous loopholes" in the proposed plan to protect the vast Adirondack Park that could allow developers in through the back door.
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation questioned today the roommate of Mark Essex, the slain New Orleans sniper, but released him without charges.

The Yankees have so many new owners that Michael Burke, the general partner who will run the club, met most of them for the first time when the small army of executives and lawyers gathered for breakfast at the Carlyle Hotel yesterday.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., a one-time White House consultant who became a central figure in the Watergate affair, offered today to plead guilty to charges that he conspired to spy on the Democrats last year.
The Boston Celtics raced to a 37-18 first-quarter lead and then coasted to a 128-107 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.
Tom Nissalke was relieved of his duties as coach of the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association today and replaced by the assistant coach, Morris (Bucky) Buckwalter.

Mrs. Betty Belt Holtz, assistant education director of The Asia Society and a leading member of its Indonesia Council, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 141 East 89th Street.
The Administration announced today major new moves to spur increased production of meat and grains in the face of continued rising food prices.
Premier Golda Meir's office said today that she has not changed her plans to visit Paris this weekend despite criticism by President Pompidou.
A search of a house in this community near Elmira resulted yesterday in the seizure of more than 64 pounds of marijuana worth $32,000, the state police reported.
This city's 650 public schools were closed today as members of the Chicago Teachers Union struck for higher wages, smaller classes and a shorter school year.

The Navy's fifth highest ranking admiral described Gordon W. Rule today as a "loner" who would not work with the "team" and defended Mr. Rule's transfer to a minor job by describing the new post as important.
The Rhodesian Government's decision to close the border with Zambia has generated unexpectedly strong criticism by other political parties here.

A United States fighter-bomber was lost over North Vietnam yesterday as American planes flew their heaviest raids over that country's southern panhandle area since bombing was halted above the 20th Parallel on Dec. 30.

The Board of Education's effort to buy up the contract of School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has apparently run into a legal obstacle, heightening speculation that Dr. Scribher will remain in office until his contract expires on June 30.

Recently, a patient went to his physician for a check-up. The physician apparently diagnosed the patient's ailment as anemia and prescribed an iron compound. He also ordered extensive, expensive medical tests involving liver pathology.

Leo E. Schwarzstein, founder and president of the Yonkers Ferry, which operated between Yonkers and Alpine, N.J., from 1923 to 1956, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Doctors Hospital on Tuesday.

Although he is considered "small" at 6 feet 1 inch and weighs only 155 pounds, Nate (Tiny) Archibald could hardly be overlooked by the panel of writers and broadcasters who pick the National Basketball Association's All-Star squads.
Patrick J. Doran, the former County Engineer of Atlantic County, was sentenced today to five years in prison and

Citizens' assemblies newly organized throughout the Philippines by the Government began six days of meetings today to carry out a kind of national referendum on the martial-law administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
Government sources said today that Israeli raids in Syria on Monday killed more than 500 civilians, including many women and children. Air attacks killed the entire
At least 50 people were killed and 300 injured today when a tornado cut a 300-yard wide swath through the farming town of San Justo, the police reported.

The two American-owned residences in the Paris area where recent private Vietnam talks have been conducted were selected because members of the United States Embassy liked them and thought them big enough, their owners said today.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, said last night that Congress should move slowly and cautiously in any efforts to bring about freely competitive commission rates in Wall Street.

Thousands of Government employes, including clerks and secretaries in Prime Minister Heath's own Cabinet Office, stopped work today to hold meetings and rallies protesting pay losses they are suffering under Mr. Heath's 90-day wage and price freeze.

A ban on taxicab cruising in midtown and downtown Manhattan, as well as severe restrictions on parking in the busiest areas of the city, will be proposed today by state and city environmental authorities as the only ways to meet Federal air pollution standards here by the 1977 deadline.

In his Indianapolis speech and in a recent interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times, Clay T. Whitehead, director of the White House's Office of Telecommunications Policy, has limited himself to broad generalities on over-all broadcasting policy.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., a one-time White House consultant who became a central figure in the Watergate affair, offered today to plead guilty to charges that he conspired to spy on the Democrats last year.
A coalition whose membership ranges from mortgage bankers to welfare mothers laid plans today for a drive against the Nixon Administration's suspension of Federal housing subsidies.

Colt Industries, Inc., whose Crucible Steel Corporation business accounts for almost half of its total sales, last year had its best sales and earnings since 1969, reflecting mainly the improved performance of the steel division.
Howard R. Hughes, the mysterious billionaire recluse, won a stunning $180-million victory over the airline he once controlled, Trans World Airlines, in the Supreme Court today.

President Nixon's personal lawyer has been identified in court papers as a major solicitor of the dairy-farm campaign contributions that followed the Nixon Administration's decision to raise milk price supports.

Some peopie are saying Governor Rockefeller goes too far in wanting to lock up every drug dealer forever. Some say President Nixon's Justice Department shows too much love for the noose in asking Congress to bring back the death penalty, even for hijacking.

Melissa Singer and Karen Gumbs are lecturing on comic books this week. They have 11 students in their class of varying ages, and by the end of the week, the 13-year-old teachers will have devoted something more than three hours to explaining the history and background of one of their favorite pastimes.

Clashes last week between students and police in Cairo reflect the dangerously deepening frustrations of a society caught in an unbearable but apparently unalterable no-war, no-peace situation which leaves Israel's forces sitting on the Suez Canal in control of a large chunk of Egyptian territory. The students, less united today than they were a year ago, appear to have been subdued for the moment.

The New York Yankees identified their new owners yesterday and added a surprise: The syndicate was expanded this week to include Gabe Paul, who has been running the Cleveland Indians for the last dozen years.

" Namban Art," an exhibition opening to the public today at Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, boasts a number of firsts--first exhibition in the West of Namban art ("Art of the Southern Barbarians"),

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Council placed Centenary College of Shreveport, La., on indefinite probation today and declared ineligible for varsity competition five of Centenary's basketball players, including Robert Parish, a 7-foot freshman who was recruited by many colleges last year.

A wife can sometimes be a money-saving asset on business trips, according to two recent court decisions. A United States District Court and a United States Court of Appeals have upheld two husbands who deducted expenses of their wives on business trips in making out their income tax returns.

L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, continuing his reorganization of the bureau, has re-established a unit for maintaining an intelligence liaison with other key Government agencies.

A 50-pound bomb carried in a shopping bag exploded today in a downtown Belfast office building, blowing out the front of the structure and wrecking dozens of offices. There were no casualties, the police said.

Although he is considered "small" at 6 feet 1 inch and weighs only 155 pounds, Nate (Tiny) Archibald could hardly be overlooked by the panel of writers and broadcasters who pick the National Basketball Association's All-Star squads.
Booth Newspapers, Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed in principle with the Whitney Communications Corporation to acquire Parade Publications, Inc., publishers of Parade magazine.
Plans were announced today for a $1-billion residential, commercial and manufacturing development on 3,900 acres 34 miles west of Chicago's Loop.
The Board of Estimate agreed in executive session yesterday to postpone a hearing scheduled for today on an application to build a controversial bridge over East 51st Street.

Bobby Ancona, who has been using the street in front of his house as a practice track in recent weeks, surprised Dennis Walker and Tom Ulan in the 600-yard run last night at the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior championships.

Tonight at 9 o'clock the American Broadcasting Company is presenting a twohour news special called "Michelangelo Antonioni's 'China'." Produced for RAI, Italy's broadcasting network, it is less a probing documentary than a remarkable travelogue, in the best sense of that battered word.

The three main consumer issues facing the Legislature this year are registration of television repairmen and automobile repair shops, repeal of the prohibition on the advertisement of prescription drug prices and the licensing of debt-collection agencies, Peter M. Pryor, chairman of the State Consumer Protection Board, said today.

A 30-year-old B-52 pilot and crew commander is facing a possible court-martial on a charge of refusal to fly a combat mission over North Vietnam, the United States Strategic Air Command headquarters here said today.
Mark Essex was described today as a happy-go-lucky youth and "a darned good sailor" until two or three months before his discharge from the Navy two years ago for bad behavior.
Eugenia Soderberg, a Swedish novelist and journalist, died at her home here Tuesday night. She was 69 years old and lived with her husband, Dr. Hugo Perls, at 128 Central Park South.
Rich Jones and Bob Netolicky sparked the Dallas Chaparrals to a 124-111 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
A young pianist who plays Beethoven's "Diabelli" Variations as capably as Etsuko Tazaki did on Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall is, in one sense, not going anywhere: She is already there.

The First National Boston Corporation, the largest bank in New England and the parent company of the First National Bank of Boston, reported that operating earnings increased 4.3 per cent in 1972 to $42.1million, or $3.51 per share, from $40.4-million, or $3.37 per share the year before.
Annemarie Proell of Austria won her fourth World Cup downhill ski race of the season and second in two days today.

When Hoang Duc Nha first proposed to his wife, Tam, her family vehemently opposed the marriage. "He is only a poor engineer working in a Government office, he has no future," friends recall that her parents said at the time.

Spinach salad was served in the White House Blue Room Tuesday night during the dinner celebrating the 60th birthday of President Nixon, but the absence of iceberg lettuce from the menu did not mean, the White House said, that the Nixons had joined the lettuce boycott.

The almost incredible jump in wholesale food prices last month is a serious setback to the Administration's anti-inflation program. Even though special factors helped account for the December leap of 5.2 per cent in the food index, the sharp upward trend of wholesale food prices through all of the last quarter and the belatedness of Administration moves to expand 1973 food supplies indicate that this will be an expensive year at the supermarket.

President Nixon's personal lawyer has been identified in court papers as a major solicitor of the dairy-farm campaign contributions that followed the Nixon Administration's decision to raise milk price supports.
Lyn Lary, a Yankee shortstop who later played for the Red Sox, Senators, Browns, Indians, Dodgers and Cardinals in a 12-year major-league career, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack.
John Wayne Wilson, the suspect in the West Sidemurder last week of Roseann Quinn, was flown in from Indianapolis yesterday afternoon and charged with homicide.

Prices for meat, eggs and some vegetables in the city's supermarkets have jumped considerably in the last month as the result of rapidly rising wholesale prices. But the average shopper's attitude seems to be: "So what else is new?"
A 45-year-old diamond merchant was forced into a Lower East Side hallway yesterday afternoon and robbed of a pouch that he said contained $60,000 worth of unset gems, the police reported.
Don Shula, trying to keep one step ahead of the unusually heavy rain and George Allen's spies, switched the Miami Dolphins practice session today to a secret site, "somewhere in southern California."

Ron Brown scored 11 of his 13 points in the second half as Penn State rallied to beat Columbia, 61-52, tonight. Randy Meister and Keenan Preston led Penn State with 14 points each and Mark Hardaway topped Columbia's scorers with 13..
Representatives of peace groups have announced that they have obtained all the necessary permits for the planned March Against Death and for Peace in Vietnam scheduled for Inauguration Day, Jan. 20.

As the end of the 1972 fiscal year nears on Jan. 31, merchants from around the country expect a strong retailing year in 1973 that will be burdened by rapidly rising expenses that they cannot pass on because of price controls.

White House sources confirmed today that President Nixon would ask Congress for a simple extension of the Economic Stabilization Act as it now reads. The law is the basis for the current wage and price controls.
Paul Henderson scored a pair of goals, the 200th and 201st of his National Hockey League career, to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 victory tonight over the New York Islanders.
Henry A. Kissinger met for four hours with Le Duc Tho today on a Vietnam cease-fire, and technical experts working on secondary issues held an all-day session.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that 97 of the 110 policemen assigned to the precinct covering the Wall Street area would be transferred as a result of an investigation of an alleged shakedown of street peddlers.
The state radio and television network, one of Italy's most important centers of political power and patronage, is being rocked by disputes over who is in control.
JF Murphy Salt, a rock band that appeared for one night only at Max's Kansas City on Tuesday evening, makes tight, disciplined music.
The average player is often perplexed by the apparently erratic approach toward pawn-grabbing--especially in the opening--on the championship level.

City officials expressed grave concern yesterday over the possibility that neighborhood programs budgeted for $110million for the fiscal year beginning July 1 would have to be terminated because of the recently announced freeze in Federal subsidies.
James Henle, president of Vanguard Press from 1928 to 1952, died yesterday at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital. He was 81 years old.

The Appellate Division, in a 3-to-2 ruling, has upheld the Civil Service test which asked two women audiovisual staff members at Hunter College to lift a 25-pound barbell above their heads with one hand. The examiners justified the requirement on the grounds that the candidates' duties included handling 25-pound projectors.

About three-quarters of the first of three installments of the new biennial exhibition of American art at the Whitney Museum--successor to the Whitney annuals that have been held since 1932--opened to the public yesterday in the garden floor of the museum at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.
The State Department said today that while the recent exchange of proposals with Cuba for a treaty to deter hijacking had produced "some movement," unresolved differences remained.
The New York chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, tthe nanational journalism society, called on President Nixon yesterday to lift what it said were obstacles being placed in the way of freedom of the press.

The average daily handle at Monticello Raceway's fall-winter meeting fell by more than $64,000 a night, the State Tax Department announced today.
Lance Rentzel, the Los Angeles Ram wide receiver, was arrested today and booked for investigation of possession of marijuana for sale, a West Los Angeles police spokesman said.
The city was told yesterday by the Labor Department that at least 95 municipal employes hired under a Federally funded emergency employment program were ineligible and must be dismissed.

For almost two decades as Governors of New Jersey sped along the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway they have tried to figure out ways to tap the bulging profits of the authorities that run the two toll roads.
Miles W. Kirkpatrick, the Federal Trade Commission chairman who gave the agency a new consumer orientation and expanded antitrust policies, has resigned with almost four years remaining in his term.

The New York Public Library has established a Harry S. Truman Memorial Fund to acquire materials relating to the life and work of the former President, who died last month. The fund will initially have $5,000 earmarked from gifts to the library.
Anyone who wants to go into bankruptcy, no matter how poor, must pay the $50 in legal fees set by Federal law, the Supreme Court ruled today.

A lot has happened since 8-year-old Tom Donahue first ran as a third-grader at Brooklyn's Holy Name Grammar School. But something that happened that first year set the trend for the future. "I started to run because I wanted to be part of a team and I was too small for the other sports," remembers Tom. He is now 23 and running again with the North Jersey
Businesses expect to increase their spending on new plants and equipment 13 per cent in 1973, the Commerce Department reported today.
Annemarie Proell of Austria won her fourth World Cup downhill ski race of the season and second in two days today.

King Timahoe, Pasha and Vicky are probably the least publicized residents of the White House, but they are among the most popular, according to Traphes Bryant, kennelman at the White House from 1960 until he retired last March.

American Telephone, selling at its highest price since 1969, served as the star yesterday of a rather skittish stock market. Shares of the nation's most widely-held issue traded as high as 54 1/4 before closing at 54 1/8 with a gain of 1/2.

LONDON--I am surprised at how pleasant-no, not pleasant but poetic, evocative, mysterious and extraordinary-all the new buildings in Manhattan are. Out of scale to what was, they make their own smoky relationship to what is.

A woman tentatively identified as Estelle Baraz died yesterday in a fire at 53 West 11th Street that reportedly started when another tenant of the 15 apartment building looked under a bed with a lighted match.

A Federal prosecutor sought yesterday to use the recorded words of a confessed hijacker to convince a jury that the hijacker had "devised one of the biggest hoaxes society has ever seen" in leading psychiatrists to believe he was insane.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that 97 of the 110 policemen assigned to the precinct covering the Wall Street area would be transferred as a result of an investigation of an alleged shakedown of street peddlers.
The Thai Government has agreed to a United States request to keep American troops and aircraft in Thailand after a Vietnam cease-fire, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn. said today.

Charging there has been a clear evasion of the law, Senator Harry F. Byrd, Independent of Virginia, announced today a hearing by a Senate Armed Services subcommittee will be held next week to investigate 54-million that he said the Defense Department had made in loans to the Grumman Aerospace Corporation.

A broad cross-section of interest rates climbed another notch yesterday, reflecting continued nervousness about inflation and the steps that the nation's money managers might have to take to combat it.
Up, up and away the prices go. Eggs, traditionally a means to stretch the grocery budget, are now giving consumers one more reason to grumble about the toll of inflation.

LOME, Togo--This sweltering seaport capital of a West African sliver-state is not one of the fashion capitals of the world, but it seems no one has told Beverly Majors. She works like she thinks it is.

There have been six Super Bowl games and Mary Fleming has played in three of them, earning $37,500 in prize money. He will play in his fourth on Sunday when Fleming's team, the Miami Dolphins, opposes the Washington Redskins in the Los Angeles Coliseum.

The Seoul district prosecutor's office announced today that three former opposition members of the National Assembly had been arrested and indicted for trial on charges of taking bribes from businessmen.

Al Anderson, a singer and guitarist, illustrates some of the complexity of the recording business. Mr. Anderson who opened Tuesday evening at Gerdes Folk City, 130 West Third Street, is a fullfledged member of the group, NRBQ.

An American former nun, arrested in Bolivla for belonging to a subversive organization, has been held in jail for more than five weeks because she will not reveal the identities of other members of the clandestine group.
Prices on the over-the-counter market and on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday in stepped-up trading.
Congress and the White House may have to decide whether the lives of 5,000 Americans are worth Federal outlays of $1billion a year.

To the Editor: The Times recently reported the findings of a distinguished Study Group on the Caseload of the Supreme Court. Foremost among these is one calling for the establishment of a "national court of appeals," a seven-member tribunal drawn from the existing personnel of the United States Courts of Appeal, whose function it would be to screen all petitions for Supreme Court review and, on a limited basis, to decide certain types of cases.

Jimmy Jamieson and Tom Weiskopf, United States World Cup teammates, had to withdraw from the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today, hut a strong field remained for tomorrow's start of the 72-hole event.

GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West Indies--A soft wind came off the Caribbean, the stars of the Southern Cross were low on the horizon, and walking the long, white sand beach in front of the Royal Palms Hotel
A sniper on a Brooklyn street, who fired at a passing police patrol car in the Fort Greene section early yesterday, triggered a six-hour search of the streets, a nearby park and subway tunnels.
Senator Harold E. Hughes raised today the possibility of an attempt to hold up Senate confirmation of President Nixon's new Cabinet nominees "so we can stop the war."
Egypt held its strong lead in swimming competition at the second All-Africa Games today, breaking an African record to take the men's 800meter free-style relay in 8 minutes 30.7 seconds.
Because of an ailing right ankle, Joe Namath of the New York Jets will not play for the American Conference all-star team in the Pro Bowl game in Dallas Jan. 21.
To recapitulate: when we last saw him (in "The Abominable Dr. Phibes," released here in 1971), the abomininable Dr. Phibes was climbing into his well-appointed London tomb.

The Government has halted temporarily plans to distribute to public schools and colleges a controversial population film advocating legal abortion, the Administration's top population experts said today.

The oldest surviving member of George Allen's collection of elderly citizens on the Washington Redskins is Jack Pardee. The trail blazer for the famed Over the Hill Gang had been Sonny Jurgensen, aged 38. As if he were really an old crock, however, Sonny cracked up during the season and left it up to Pardee to use his seniority in leading the Skins in their inexorable advance toward Medicare and the Super Bowl.
Paul Henderson scored a pair of goals, the 200th and 201st of his National Hockey League career, to pace the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 4-2 victory tonight over the New York Islanders.
Richard and Margaret Gummere of 325 Riverside Drive sent $25 yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in "enormous" gratitude for the blessings accorded them and their family.

Directors of the H. J. Heinz Company today approved management proposals divesting the food processor of certain foreign operations, including all of its Mexican assets, and withdrawing from direct farming activities conducted by an Oregon subsidiary.
A stabile designed by Alexander Calder for the Archives of American Art will be presented to two members of the Archives national board of trustees and their wives for outstanding service.

William R. Ransom, who retired as a professor of mathematics at Tufts University in 1950 at the age of 75 after a halfcentury of teaching, died yesterday in the Winchester Hospital. He was 97 years old.
A new version of the Concorde, the French-British supersonic airliner featuring quieter, more powerful, smokefree engines, made its maiden flight today for an hour 45 minutes from Toulouse Airport.

In the summer of 1968, there were headlines in the financial press when two partners and an employee of one of the Big Eight accounting firms were found guilty in Federal Court here of conspiring to issue false financial statements and of mail fraud.

The New York Nets, with a patched backcourt, halted the Carolina Cougars' 11 -game winning streak, the longest of the American Basketball Association season, in a 105-93 upset tonight at the Nassau Coliseum.
Next season the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center will, for the first time, book a series of outside productions into the Vivian Beaumont instead of originating production within its own company.
The Duke Power Company offered three million shares at $23 each. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith Inc., and the First Boston Corporation managed the underwriting group.

Probus Management, Inc., a professional athletes' business agency accused of having failed to live up to the financial management contracts of 11 football players, was ordered today to open its books to the State Attorney General. Justice John C. Marbach of the State Supreme Court denied a motion by the White Plains firm to quash the request by Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz to examine the books.

Several United States and Canadian copper producers announced yesterday that they were following the lead taken Tuesday by the Phelps Dodge Corporation in increasing the price of copper by 2.5 cents a pound.
A lawyer for the bankrupt Penn Central Company said today that America's largest railroad may have to stopits trains at the end of February if it does not get some fresh cash.

It is widely believed that the mutual fund money managers are the men who are quick on the trigger in Wall Street. Whenever a big block of stock changes hands, the reporters and market observers scurry to the record books to check out the holdings of mutual funds in an attempt to nail down the seller.

The General Motors Corporation said today that antipollution equipment to meet tough Government rules for 1975 and 1976 would add $275 to a new-car price, the lowest estimate yet made in the automobile manufacturing industry.

Karlheinz Stockhausen, Germanically messianic, has received a mixed press in America. His music, always avant-garde, has grown steadily further out over the last 20 years, which offends the conservatives.
John Wayne Wilson, the suspect in the West Side murder last week of Roseann Quinn, was flown in from Indianapolis yesterday afternoon and charged with homicide.
Two diamond-studded golden crowns and other jewels valued at nearly $100,000 were reported stolen yesterday from an altar painting in a Roman Catholic church in Brooklyn.
The New York chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, tthe nanational journalism society, called on President Nixon yesterday to lift what it said were obstacles being placed in the way of freedom of the press.

An "unethical but not illegal" arrangement between many physicians and laborastories in which the doctors receive kickbacks for ordering unnecessary, expensive tests for patients has cost the city more than $4-million a year in Medicaid payments, an audit by the city's Health Department disclosed yesterday.
A previously unreported racial brawl aboard a Navy ship in Southeast Asia has resulted in charges against 10 marines, the Marine Corps has disclosed.

Governor Cahill today installed "the president of the second best Jesuit college in the United States" as a member of the Port of New York and New Jersey Authority. That is how Mr. Cahill referred to the new commissioner, the Rev. Victor R. Yapitelli.

A 44 - year - old widow and mother of four sons won $1million today in the New Jersey lottery. "I'm 44, but make it 29," Mrs. Frances E. Colon of Carteret said exuberantly when she was asked her age after the prize drawing at the War Memorial Building here.

The members of the Senate Armed Services Committee should not have been unduly surprised by Elliot Richardson's refusal to reveal his personal views on the recent carpet-bombing of Hanoi. The nominee for the post of Defense Secretary has already demonstrated his capacity as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to serve the President by unflinchingly abandoning opinions of his own.

A 71-year-old woman was killed in a fire in her Upper East Side apartment last night. The police identified the victim as Christine Bansa of 233 East 89th Street. The blaze, at about 9 P.M., was confined to her apartment.

The state commission on revising the City Charter turned its attention to Staten Island yesterday, taking a bus tour led by Borough President Robert T. Connor, who told the members his borough was still young enough to straighten out its problems.

Vincent J. Salierno, president of the Victory Optical Manufacturing Company, died of a heart attack last evening at St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 69 years old and lived in West Orange.

Howard R. Hughes, the mysterious billionaire recluse, won a stunning $180-million victory over the airline he once controlled, Trans World Airlines, in the Supreme Court today.

A plan to make school expenditures less dependent on local property taxes is a key elementand one of the most controversial-in the program unveiled here today by the Governor's Commission on Tax Reform.

Thousands of Government employes, including clerks and secretaries in Prime Minister Heath's own Cabinet Office, stopped work today to hold meetings and rallies protesting pay losses they are suffering under Mr. Heath's 90-day wage and price freeze.

Energy experts from around the world met here this week and generally agreed that one of the most promising new sources of relatively nonpolluting power is the natural heat of the earth's core-geothermal energy.

Apparently reversing a position it took a week ago, the Nixon Administration said today that it ddi not believe that a mandatory death sentence should be imposed for "cold-blooded, premeditated" crimes including plane hijackings.
The southern Laotian town of Saravane was abandoned by Government troops yesterday in the face of a crushing Communist artillery barrage, military sources here reported today.

A 30-year-old B-52 pilot and crew commander is facing a possible court-martial on a charge of refusal to fly a combat mission over North Vietnam, the United States Strategic Air Commandd headquarters here said today.

The trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey will meet Friday with Governor Cahill in a move that could pave the way for continuing the carrier's passenger service past its scheduled termination on Jan. 21.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers has telephoned John Lynch, the Irish Prime Minister, to express regret over demonstrations staged against him in New York, the State Department said today.

Not even our generous planning for exasperatingly normal delays had prepared us for a twenty-minute period during which four No. 104 buses, bound for the United Nations via 42d Street, but not a single No. 10 bound for downtown, stopped at 44th Street and Broadway. Giving up on public transportation, we hailed a cab and asked to be taken to Penn Station. "Is that near 34th Street?" asked the cabbie.
The New York Raiders, with a tough checking defense and two goals from Norm Ferguson, posted a 4-1 victory over the Philadelphia Blazers in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

The president of St. Peter's College in Jersey City heard himself described by Governor Cahill of New Jersey as "the president of the second-best Jesuit College in the United States" as he was sworn in yesterday as a member of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

TV Guide, with its 18 million circulation, one of the lowest cost-per-thousand advertising rates in publishing and a 15-cent cover price, is in for some competition from a little magazine with a similar format and a lower cost per thousand that will be given away free.

Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho held another private negotiating session in Paris yesterday amid indications that there had been no progress toward a Vietnamese peace settlement. For one thing, Soviet sources said Hanoi had not changed and would not change its opposition to a formal partition of Vietnam, a major United States demand.

Asserting that street crime has become their No. 1 problem, the Mayors of the state's six biggest cities announced yesterday that they were seeking $200-million from the state for local law enforcement.

Just what obligation do the nation's 13,933 commercial banks have to support the Federal Reserve System--not only with words, but with membership? Especially in the case of smaller banks, membership in the central bank often means a dollars-and-cents cost to bank shareholders.

A smoky, two-alarm fire destroyed a shoe store, a women's apparel shop and a stationery store on the street-level floor of a 32-story office building in Manhattan's financial district yesterday afternoon, injuring six persons.
Five public officials from Monmouth and Ocean Counties were indicted today on charges relating to bribery or illegal acceptance of money.

The famed team defense of the Knicks cooled off Pete Maravich and his hot-shooting Atlanta Hawk teammates in the second half tonight at the Omni and New York scored its eighth straight victory, a 122-107 decision which ended almost two years of New York frustration here.

FICTION Cut 'n' Run, by Frank Deford (Viking, $6.95). The effects of Sunday pro football on family and friends. East German Poetry: An Anthology, edited by Michael Hamburger, bilingual edition (Dutton $10; paperbound, $5.95).

A teen-aged youth charged with a mugging yesterday was said by the police to have kept a meticulous written list of some 30 prior assaults on elderly Bronx women, under the heading, "Official Holdup Record."
The B-52 pilot who balked at bombing North Vietnam after his 175th mission said today that he had refused because "the goals do not justify the mass destruction and killing."
The World Council of Churches announced today that it was sending $300,000 in medical supplies to the North Vietnamese Red Cross. The council also provides relief aid to South Vietnam.
City employes whose wives give birth may now obtain a five-day unpaid "paternity leave." Expectant mothers are already allowed six months' unpaid leave.
Two brothers and a sister, the eldest 5 years old, were killed yesterday afternoon in a fire that engulfed their secondstory bedroom in a tenement in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
J. C. Snead, a 30-year-old nephew of famed Sam Snead, shot a brilliant eight-under-par 62 today for the first-round lead in the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament.

Walter Zirpolo, former Mayor of Woodbridge, N. J., and Robert E. Jacks, former president of the Woodbridge Council, were sentenced in Middlesex County Court in New Brunswick to two to six years' imprisonment on briberyconspiracy charges. Judge John B. Molineux also fined Zirpolo $3,000 and Jacks $2,000.

Government officials said today that a pattern of strong support for the martial-law administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was emerging from the meetings of officially organized citizens' assemblies that began yesterday throughout the Philippines.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt arrived in Yugoslavia today for a day of talks with President Tito amid expectations of new endeavors by Cairo toward breaking the deadlock in the conflict with Israel.
Governor Cahill tonight rejected as "unacceptable" an Army Corps of Engineers proposal to construct a deep-water oil superport in coastal waters off New Jersey.
The Seattle Supersonics owner, Sam Schulman, said today he hoped he could avoid another "terrible blunder" like his choice of Tom Nissalke as head coach of his National Basketball Association team.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 133.4 from 131.9R last week.
The prosecution described in detail today the fatal stabbing and burning of a former New York City model who had been scheduled to be a key Government witness in a narcotics case in Manhattan.

The New Orleans Police Deapartment has evidence that there were at least two snipers and possibly three in the Downtown Howard Johnson Motor Lodge last Sunday and Monday, .and that the six people killed and 15 wounded by gunfire at the motel were shot from two different weapons-a .44-caliber semiautomatic rifle and a 'bolt action rifle.

Russell E. Train said today that President Nixon had told him he will remain as chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality. But there was some indication that the post will be downgraded in Mr. Nixon's governmental reorganization.
To the Editor: Few proposals are as unlikely to accomplish their stated objectives as Governor Rockefeller's plan to incarcerate for life those convicted of selling "hard" drugs.

The Justice Department today charged President Nixon's campaign finance committee with eight violations of Federal law in failing to record and report $31,300 that it had allegedly given to one of the defendants in the Watergate bugging trial.

Disclosure of the Administration's Phase 3 economic plan sent bond prices into retreat yesterday, more than offsetting in early attempt to rally. The weakening of the conrols mechanism was widely viewed as likely to lead to a faster pace of inflation and hus to higher interest rates,

Mike McCormack, an assistant coach for the Washington Redskins and one. of the top linemen in the National Football League's recent hisstory, is expected to be chosen as head coach f the Philadelphia . Eagles next week following the Super Bowl game.

L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the number of police officers killed on duty last year declined 11 per cent from 1971.

In the early stages of the Nixon Administration's Phase 2 attack on inflation, Dr. John T. Dunlop, the Harvard economist who was in charge of the Construction Industry Stabilization Committee, had frequent and open clashes with the members of the Pay Board.

A group of business executives were told here today that alcoholism in New Jersey was costing them $400-million to $500-million a year and that efforts to attack and reverse the disease had barely scratched the surface.

President Nixon ended mandatory wage and price controls today - except for those involving food, health care and construction - and replaced them with a system relying mainly on "voluntary cooperation." He also ended all Federal rent controls.

Marcus Duffield, for many years a writer and editor for The New York Herald Tribune, died in New Haven Hospital today. He was 69 years old and lived at 39 North Street.

While Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho continued their closed-door talks a few miles away, both Saigon and the Vietnamese Communist delegations reverted to stiff demands today at the weekly formal peace talks here.

Orders that have been issued for years without publicity by the Agriculture Department affecting local prices of fruits, vegetables, milk and some other products will be subject to clearance in the future by the Cost of Living Council, it was announced today.

When President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law in the Philippines last September he promised to curb insurgency and other lawlessness, to end corruption and to create a "new society" based on social justice. Although the President's seizure of arbitrary power outraged many freedom-loving Filipinos and though many questioned Mr. Marcos' qualifications for effecting the reforms he proclaimed, the military crackdown did win some grudging acceptance.

Advertising industry leaders, who have weathered frequent and heavy attacks from the newly aggressive and innovative Federal Trade Commission during the last two years, had nothing but kind words yesterday for Chairman Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who announced his resignation Wednesday.

Judge D. Donald Jamieson of Common Pleas Court ordered public school teachers today to end a strike that has paralyzed the city's school system, but union leaders vowed to disregard the judge's ruling.

The story of the Nixon Administration's deal with the milk lobby continues to unfold. In 1971, the White House reversed the Agriculture Department and ordered an increase in the Federal price support for milk. The milk producers thereupon contributed more than $400,000 to the Nixon campaign chest.

Ralph Nader, Bess Myerson, Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal and Erma Angevine never thought highly of Phases 1 or 2. But they, and some other consumer activists, expressed fear yesterday that, from their point of view, Phase 3 might be even worse.
Directors of the Loews Corporation again raised the quarterly dividend by the allowable amount, as proposed to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday preceding the board session.

Britain reported today her foreign-trade deficit widened in December, the final month before she joined the European Common Market, to [Pound]93-million ($218.6million) from [Pound]81-million ($190.4-million) in November.

Civil Service Commission examinations for city firemen discriminate against blacks and Puerto Ricans, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund charged yesterday in a suit in Federal District Court.

Gamble-Skogmo Inc. said yesterday its invitation for tenders of 500,000 shares of its own com-mon would not be extended. The tenders expired on Wednesday. Pravda's senior foreign affairs commentator, Yuri Zhukov, is a frequent and familiar visitor in the West. He is a veteran member of the Soviet Communist party whose loyalty and discretion have been proven over and over.

Dr. John D. Marshall Jr., associate clinical professor of psychiatry at the Yale University den School of Medicine, died here last night at his home of a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

Creation of a new Office of International Corporate Finance with responsibility for supervising security offerings by American companies to foreign investors as well as offerings by foreign issuers here was announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
There had been a "mob scene" that day just before the 1960 election, Joe O'Connor recalled, when John F. Kennedy stopped in at the National Democratic Club at 233 Madison Avenue, near 37th Street.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference, with 206 member colleges and universities, will challenge the right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to withdraw the N.C.A.A. from membership in the United States Olympic Committee.
President Nixon's education budget for the next fiscal year will propose the elimination or phasing out of many popular education programs, according to reports and documents reaching Capitol Hill.

The owners of the 24 major league baseball teams took a radical step yesterday to put more punch into the game. They voted to allow the American League to use a "designated pinch-hitter," who may bat for the pitcher without forcing him from the game.

President Nixon's decision to abolish mandatory controls over wages and prices in more than three-quarters of the economy threatens a reversion to the do-nothing formula for combating inflation that preceded his New Economic Policy of seventeen months ago.

Most speakers at a hearing that overflowed the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday urged Mayor Lindsay to veto a reapportionment bill that would increase the City Council membership to 43 from the present 37.

Controller Abraham D. Beame accused the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday of having too many executives and spending too much money for rent, food, parking, entertainment and telephone service.

Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court today denied an application for a temporary restraining order that would have prohibited abortions in New York City until a pending challenge to the legality of the 1970 New York state law is decided by the High Court.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference, with 206 member colleges and universities, will challenge the right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Council to withdraw the N.C.A.A. from membership in the United States Olympic Committee.
E. Howard Hunt Jr., a former White House consultant, pleaded guilty today to all six charges against him in connection with the break-in and alleged bugging of the Democratic national headquarters.
The Duval Corporation, the mining subsidiary fo the Penntoil Company, said yesterday that it will increase its suphur prices.
The Harvard Club, for 107 years a male preserve, voted yesterday to admit women as members.

The jury in the jet-hijacking trial of Garrett B. Trapnell adjourned shortly after 6 P.M. yesterday after failing to reach a verdict in seven hours of deliberation.

Walter Zirpolo, and former Mayor of Woodbridge, Robert E. Jacks, former president of the Woodbridge Council, were sentenced in Middlesex County Court here today to two to six years' imprisonment on briberyconspiracy charges.

President Nixon ended most mandatory wage and price controls yesterday and announced the beginning of a system of "voluntary cooperation" by labor and business to hold the line against inflation. Controls will remain in the food processing, health care and construction industries.

Ten leading American insurance companies, preparing for what is expected to be a major increase in trade with the Soviet Union, disclosed here yesterday that they had concluded an agreement with a Soviet-owned insurance company based in London.
Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that United StatesJapanese relations were his "most important foreign policy subject" and rejected calls for revising the two countries' security treaty.

The Securities and Exchange Commission approved by a 2-to-2 split decision today diversified investments by intrastate utility holding companies in non utility ventures but within narrower limits than in the Past.
A judge denied bail here today to a black man twice convicted of rape and barred from his courtroom the suspect's attorney, William M. Kunstler.
For millions of Monopoly players, those sentimental highrollers of play-money capitalism, today was a victory for tradition and the underdog for Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues.
The Ottawa Nationals received a quick opening-period goal from Rick Sentes and went on to defeat the New York Raiders, 4-1, in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

The detective said by law enforcement officials to be key figure" in the intricate web of police corruption allegedly set up by Hugh Mulligan, the gambler and reputed "fixer," pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to perjury and criminal contempt.

The new Nixon Cabinet is up before the Senate these days for confirmation, and more often than not it is a painful sight. For the new boys, reaching for the most prestigious jobs of their lives, face the most searching Questions about what they really believe, and somehow they have to try to be faithful to themselves, to the President who has nominated them and to his policies, which they may or may not approve.

The chairman of the Federal Power Commission, John N. Nassikas, said today that the United States should increase its energy supplies through expanded research, exploration on Federal lands and price and tax breaks for producers.

Despite the excitement and confusion about the lifting of acreage restrictions and the easing of price controls, live beef cattle quietly made new record highs yesterday in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

The famed team defense of the Knicks cooled off Pete Maravich and his hot-shooting Atlanta Hawk temmeates in the second half tonight at the Omni and New York scored its eighth straight victory, a 122-107 decision which ended almost two years of New York frustration here.

A 13-year-old boy who was released from the Indiana state school for boys 11 months ago has asked to be readmitted, saying he has been mistreated by his parents, who he says are involved in drug trafficking.

Casper W.Weinberger pledged today that as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare he would oppose busing for "artificial" racial balance in schools.

To adopt and publicize a position of neutrality can be a delicate matter for a bridgeplayer as well as for a nation-state. And unfortunately, one's partners and would-be allies do not always get the message.

President Nixon ended mandatory wage and price controls today - except for those involving food, health care and construction - and replaced them with a system relying mainly on "voluntary cooperation." He also ended all Federal rent controls. The actions were effective immediately.
Two rival goalies, Eddie Johnston of Boston and Gil Gilbert of Minnesota, turned in spectacular performances tonight as the Bruins and the North Stars battled to a 1-1 National Hockey League tie.

Joe Louis, a former heavyweight boxing champion, arrived here today and expressed encouragement for another Joe and hard words for Muhammad Ali. Louis says Ali is past his peak. Louis is here as guest of honor for the European title fight next Tuesday between Joe Bugner, the British titleholder, and Rudi Lubbers of the Netherlands.

Neal Shapiro of Glen Head, L. I., a member of the United States Equestrian Team, and Mrs. Nancy Bonham of Trabuco Canyon, Calif., were named horseman and horsewoman of the year yesterday by the American Horse 'Shows Association.

William C. Eisenhardt, president of the Queensboro Public Library since 1971, and a Queens civic leader, died Wednesday of a heart ailment at his home, 67 Biltmore Road in Massapequa, L.I. His age was 57.
In their dotage, the Washington Redskins might shout "Hip, hip, hoorav" on cue from Coach George Allen, but in reality they are professionals who look to the Super Bowl for the money involved.

Dr. Edgar A. Day, executive vice president of International Flavors Fragrances and a vice president of I.F.F., Inc., died Wednesday of a heart attack at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 44 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, preparing to begin two days of talks on European security and other issues with President Pompidou of France, declared today that "the Vietnam affair is drawing little by little to its conclusion."
Business executives generally applauded President Nixon's move to Phase 3 yesterday as a good step toward a less rigidly controlled economy. Some were surprised that it had come so soon.

With a predictable barrage of publicity fanfare, Jack Paar returned to television this week and, at least in the course of his first three 11:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. shows, ran into trouble, both in over-all content and in some important audience ratings.

Two long-time political foes, Governor Rockefeller and Alex Rose, the Liberal party leader, met privately on Wednesday to discuss the possibility of agreeing on a mayoral candidate, it was disclosed yesterday.

At long last, for the first time in the five games they have met this season, Pete Stemkowski and the New York Rangers beat the bustling Buffalo Sabres, a thirdyear expansion club. It was a hard-fought 4-2 victory tonight in Memorial Stadium, with Stemkowski scoring three goals the last into an empty net with one second left to play.
Jonnny Green sank two free throws with 10 seconds remaining tonight to help the Kansas City-Omaha Kings beat the Golden State Warriors, 109-108, in a National Basketball Association game.

When Bob Davis was a senior at Neptune (N.J.) High School he had a decision to make-play basketball, or football. He chose football. "I was actually a much better basketball player in high school than I was a football player," says Davis, now a resident of Wayside, N.J., and the backup quarterback to Joe Namath of the New York Jets.
Orange and Rockland Utiiities won approval from the Public Service Commission yesterday to overhead a 138-kilovolt power line about five miles through Rockland County.

The draft agreement released to the press by Hanoi on Oct. 26, 1972, was both the design of a cease-fire and an outline of principles to govern a subsequent peace settlement.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey took the first steps yesterday toward implementing its new masstransportation role as it adopted an $827-million budget for 1973.

Loving son of Molly Liebhaber, Services were held January 11, at Hellman Memorial Chapel. Shiva at home, 20 Francis Place, Monsey, NY. Donations In his memory to the Hebrew Community of Rockland County, Mansey, NY.

The Bureau of Mines has revised its procedure for imposing penalties for safety violations on the owners of coal mines because of "adverse comments" from the mine operators, a General Accounting Office report disclosed today.
A jury of 10 men and two women began deliberation at 11:40 A.M. today in the trial of Juan V. Corona, the 38-yearold Mexican national charged with the largest multiple murder in the nation's history.

The Harvard Club, for 107 years a male preserve, voted yesterday to admit women as members. The vote was not even close, although last May the old guard managed to eke out a narrow victory against women in a similar vote.

Even Karl Pfeiffer, the Austrian who Introduced it in 1965 at the nearby Killington resort, is astonished by the impact made by the graduated length method (G.L.M.) of skiing.

Charles Flanders, an illustrator and cartoonist who drew "The Lone Ranger" comic strip for 30 years for King Features, died Wednesday in Palma, Majorca. He was 65 years old and had lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

The way the Nets played basketball tonight, their opposition, the Virginia Squires, didn't need a coach. In fact, the Squires didn't have one for the second half. Al Bianchi was moaning in the locker room, losing a battle with the flu, as his Squires ripped apart the Nets with a 103-93 American Basketball Association decision.
Augustus W. Phelps, founder of Phelps. Fenn Co., 39 Broadway, New York, investment securities and a leader in municipal bonds, died yesterday at the White Plains Hosnital His age was 82.

Julius P. Molnar, executive vice president of Bell Telephone Laboratories and a director of Bell and of the Sandia CorporaIion, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 84 Countryside Drive.

Past musical scores for dance-"Swan Lake," for instancehave emerged to stand on their own, and Thursday night at Town Hall Meredith Monk, herself a dancer, offered her music for William Dunas's "Our Lady of Late" in concert. The result was an extraordinarily consoling, meditative experience.

Monmouth County will acquire an 11-acre tract on the Navesink Highlands southwest of Sandy Hook for development as a county park, Joseph C. Irwin, director of the county's Board of Freeholders, announced here today.
Boasting- a field of Olympic champions, a new track and a new site, the Knights of Columbus; track and field meet returns to the metropolitan area calendar tomorrow night.

The State Department has recommended to President Nixon that Graham A. Martin, the- departing Ambassador to Italy, be named Ambassador to South Vietnam to replace Ellsworth Bunker, who plans to -retire after almost six years ii Saigon, a department official said today.

A correction officer indicted on several charges growing out of the October, 1970, riot at the Tombs testified at his trial in State Supreme Court on the motives for a speech he made during the rebellion.
Elizabeth Mellon Sellers, daughter of the late Thomas Alexander Mellon Jr., died yesterday at West Penn Hospital. Her age was 69.
Gerald Slavis, vice president and national advertising man. ager of Esquire magazine, died Thursday evening of undeter. mined causes. He was 34 years old and lived at 460 East 79th Street.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel arrived here today for a two-day unofficial gathering of world Socialist leaders that the French Government has pledged it will officially ignore.
The State Board of Education decided today that social science textbooks - and not science texts-were the proper place for discussing in elementary schools the philosophy of man's origin.
The shape of a class of molecules that play an essential role in all life processes has been determined by a group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The Nixon Administration moved quickly today to reaffirm that the United States had rejected the use of nuclear weapons in the Vietnam war. The White House, the Defense Department and the State Department all issued statements reasserting the "no nuclear" policy to head off both foreign and domestic concern that might have been aroused by testimony yesterday by William P. Clements Jr,, President Nixon's nominee to be Deputy Secretary of Defense.

Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho conferred for six and a half hours yesterday in Paris, bringing to 27 the total number of hours they have spent in daily sessions since the private talks on a Vietnam cease-fire were resumed last Monday.

Rockingham Raceway reinstituted perfect and superfecta multiple wagering tonight. Ray Poirier, track publicity director, said a ban imposed Jan. 1 had resulted in a one-third drop in attendance and a decrease in the mutuel handle of about 50 per cent.
Roy Ruggles Johnson, former newspaperman who broke the story of Jim Thorpe's professionalism in 1913 in The Worcester Telegram, died yesterday at .Doctors Hospital here. He was 89 years old.

The Atlanta Flames, getting superb goal-tending from Dan Bouchard and a second-period goal from Larry Romanchych, moved into second place in the National Hockey League Western Division tonight with a 1-0 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

One day, a little more than 10 years ago, a ceramist named Harvey Littleton became fired up about glass. Although for decades craftsmen had been experimenting with just about every material that could be rendered into shape by human hands, glass had been almost completely neglected.

The Houston Lighting Power Company said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 1,500,000 common shares. The company said the offering is expected Feb. 6 and would be underwritten by a group managed by Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter. The company's stock closed unchanged at 501/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The "designated pinchhitter"-baseball's most radical innovation in three-quarters of a century--became the talk of the town yesterday, three months before his debut in the American League.
A 70-yearold widow died here today after she was shot near her home when British troops fired at a man believed to be a sniper belonging to the Irish Republican Army.

Horses will be joining the police forces of Rutgers, the State University, and New Brunswick. There will be sep arate mounted patrols but the horses will be housed to gether in stables on the Rutgers College of Agriculture and Environmental Science campus here.
The Soviet Union and the General Electric Company, one of America's industrial giants, signed a wide-ranging agreement here today for joint development of electric-power generating technology.

Secretary of Defense Melvin L. Laird has directed the Navy to concentrate on Texas as the prime site for the possible construction of Project Sanguine, a controversial billion-dollar communications system.
An agreement in principle for the acquisition of the Simplex Wire and Cable Company by the Okonite Company, a subsidiary of Omego-Alpha, Inc., was announced yesterday.

Roulette Records, a major jazz label in the nineteenfifties that went into a decline along with jazz in the sixties, has recently been delving into its vaults to bring back recordings made 10, 20, even 30 years ago by Count Basie, Art Tatum, Stan Getz, Charlie Parker and an impressive list of jazz stars.

More than a year ago, 518 men submitted applications to become New Jersey state troopers. On Sunday, the 41 who survived the written, physical and psychological tests will start the 14-week course at the State Police Academy here.

Good firm penal laws being the foundation of a sound polity, only the knavish or peevish would complain of the object presently sought by that great figure of the American colonies, Governor ROCKEFELLER.
