J. C. Snead carded a 67 today and stretched his lead to three strokes with a 129 total after 36 holes in the $150,000 Phoenix open golf tournament. The 31-year-old nephew of Sam Snead was 11 under par after two rounds over the friendly. 6,216-yard Arizona Country Club course.

The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, Cleveland, a leading producer of chemicals, oil, gas and minerals, reported yesterday increased earnings and sales for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 1972.
Dr. Oswald T. Allis, an Old Testament scholar and one of the founders of the Westminster Theological Seminary here in 1929, died today at his home in Wayne. He was 92 years old.

The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday castigated a Federal judge in Brooklyn, George Rosling, for conduct that it said seriouslyy prejudiced" a defendant at his trial on a narcotics charge. It reversed the conviction and ordered a new trial.

Peter J. Brennan, who is awaiting confirmation as Secretary of Labor, was praised by Governor Rockefeller last night as a great labor leader, a patriotic American and a man with "tremendous concern" about equal opportunity for all.

JERUSALEM--The Jerusalem Prize, Israel's international literary prize, has been awarded this year to Eugene Ionesco, the French playwright and philosopher. The $2,000 prize given biennially to an author "who has contributed to the freedom of the individual in society," will be presented to the 61-year-old writer at the opening of the sixth Jerusalem International Book Fair on April 25.

At his annual news conference two days before the Super Bowl, Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said today that George Allen, coach of the Washington Redskins, had been fined twice for breaking league rules since he became coach early in 1971, and was in line for a third assessment.

The leftist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens took control of all wheat sales today in a "profound political and social move" to strengthen planned rationing of at least 30 basic food items.
Theodore Norden Nelson, manager of purchasing for the GAF Corporation, died here Thursday. He was 64 years old and lived in Mountainside, N.J.

Traditional enemy staging areas northwest of Saigon were heavily bombed yesterday by United States B-52 bombers. The United States command said that 14 formations-each presumably consisting of three B-52's-were sent over targets between the old Michelin and Lai Khe rubber plantations, only 40 miles from the capital, in the 24 hours ended at 8 A.M.

Earl Monroe, who insists that his value to the Knicks involves more than scoring, did a lot of scoring and at the right times tonight to give the New Yorkers a breath-taking 104-103 triumph over the Houston Rockets at Hofheinz Pavilion.

Stanley Glaubach, graphic designer and artist, whose scultpured caricatures of politicians and other persons in the news were widely reproduced as illustrations in magazines and newspapers, died yesterday of a heart attack in his studio, 84 University Place. He was'48 years old and lived at 24 Oakdale Lane in Roslyn Heights, L.l.
The Soviet Union's latest unmanned mooncraft, Luna 21, went into orbit around the moon today in preparation for a series of maneuvers that may take it to the surface on Sunday.
Producers of television shows said today that the ban on network shows in the nation's 50 top markets during the first hour of prime viewing time

Stewart L. Udall, a former Secretary of the Interior, attacked "anything-to-win attitudes" of bigtime college athletics today before members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, including representatives of some colleges he singled out for special criticism.

Two charges that Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell "did willfully and knowingly obtain from the State of New Jersey a thing of value not lawfully and justly due him" were dropped by the court today as the trial of the retired head of the state's Defense Department approached the Mercer County trial jury's deliberations on a verdict.
Governor Cahill today authorized an additional $470,000 subsidy for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to keep passenger service for its 15,000 daily commuters running until March 23.
The Soviet Union and the General Electric Company, one of America's industrial giants, signed a wide-ranging agreement here today for joint development of electric-power generating technology.

Elizabeth Holtzman, the 31year-old Brooklyn Democrat who unseated Representative Emanuel Celler, the 84-yearold chairman of the House Judiciary Committee last year, will follow in Mr. Celler's footsteps on the Judiciary Committee.

John T. Dunlop, named i by President Nixon to be director of the Cost of Living Council, is an investor along with George Meany, president of the labor federation, and other labor figures in a Caribbean resort development.
The recently increased pace of inventory accumulation by business continued in November, the Commerce Department reported today.

The final report of the Knapp Commission investigating charges of police corruption in New York City found that the corruption which pervaded the law enforcement establishment here was repeatedly ignored by officials at high levels of public service.

BERKELEY, Calif. - Opposition to teaching evolution still lives, and powerful efforts are in progress to introduce the divine creation story into officially approved California science textbooks. These efforts were opposed at a hearing Nov. 9 by representatives of major religious faiths, including Christians, Jews and Buddhists.
The Citizens Budget Commission yesterday predicted a record 68-cent increase for each $100 of assessed valuation in the city's real estate tax for the 1973-74 fiscal year, which starts July 1.

When the American painter Abraham Walkowitz died in 1965 at the age of 84, he seemed to many observers of the art scene one of' those artists who, though once admired as pioneer exponents of the modern movement in this country, had not succeeded in producing notable oeuvres of their own.
The Federal Power Commission today reported that reserves of natural gas dropped 7.1 per cent in 1971, decreasing for the fourth straight year.
Governor Cahill today authorized an additional $470,000 subsidy for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to keep passenger service for its 15,000 daily commuters running until March 23.

Pioneer 10, the unmanned satellite bound for Jupiter, will be out of touch with its controllers here for three days next week because of massive radio interference from the sun, the Ames Research Center said today.
Bond prices slumped yesterday in continued response to the Administration's Phase 3 relaxation of economic controls, which have been widely interpreted as likely to produce higher rates of inflation.

A drug detection program that would call for intermediate school students in Harlem to submit to urinalysis to determine whether they are using drugs is being prepared with the aid of a White House agency.

A qualified source reported today that Greece had decided to give up direct United States military aid, which was set at about $15-million for 1973. However, there was no indication that Greece would also renounce the credits given under the United States Foreign Military Sales Act.
Joe Schmidt, a defensive superstar who never found coaching as easy as linebacking, resigned today as head coach of the Detroit Lions after six seasons of attempting to mold a champion team.

Cuba's new economic aid agreement with the Soviet Union indicates that Moscow has decided to become receiver in bankruptcy for the Cuban economy. Repayment of the several billion dollars Cuba owes the Soviet Union has been postponed until a 25-year period beginning in 1986, a formula that suggests the debt is really being written off as unrepayable.

Steve Smith, who failed to clear 16 feet at the Munich Olympics, set an American indoor record in the pole vault tonight with a leap of 17 feet 8 1/2 inches during the National Invitation track and field meet.

Palestinian uerrilla leaders ended six days of heated debate here today with the re-election of Yasir Arafat as their chairman, but with the dream of unified military and political action as remote as ever.
Millions of Italians deserted their jobs today in a general strike called by the nation's three major labor organizations to press for social reforms.
A spokesman for the Association of American Railroads said yesterday that train service could be curtailed soon if the nationwide fuel shortage is not eased.
A drug detection program that would require intermediate school students in Harlem to submit to urinalyses is being prepared with the aid of a White House agency.

A 50-year-old Queens College librarian whose car jumped a low stone wall in this rural Putnam County community last. night lay unnoticed in a ravine for 101/2 hours in subfreezing weather, the police reported.

Melville Harris, a New York lawyer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in New Rochelle Hospital today. He was 57 years old and lived at 312 Surrey Drive.

SAN FRANCISCO-If a nuclear reactor loses its coolant, the fuel can become a hot atomic puddle and melt out into the environment to produce a possible catastrophe involving perhaps a million deaths. The threat of such cataclysm-from failure of design or operation, from act of God or saboteur-is great enough that the Atomic Energy Commission requires a back-up emergency cooling system sound enough to prevent the disaster.

D'Avanzo, said it would force the unions to go through all Federal procedures and then have to start all over again with parallel state procedures.

Former Gov. James A. Rhodes announced today he will run for Governor again in 1974. The announcement makes Mr. Rhodes the early favorite to win the Republican nomination and take on Gov. John J. Gilligan, a Democrat, who has already announced plans to seek a second term.

The stock market soared on Thursday and then plunged on Friday to end a turbulent week as Wall Street sought to assess the new look in economic controls under Phase 3. This was the view Friday evening of analysts who had watched the markets fall sharply during the week's final trading session in continued negative reaction to Phase 3's reCredit nomic controls.

It is. therefore of more than idle interest that President Nixon seems to have patterned himself as a national leader upon that unlikely model, Charles deGaulle.

Meat markets would be restricted in making up names for grades of meat under a regulation proposed by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. Commissioner Bess Myerson said yesterday that she was proposing the regu lation to bar the use of private grade names in advertise ments unless the ads also give the official United States Department of Agriculture grade or a statement that themeat has not been officially graded.
Premier Gol da Meir of Israel will meet with Pope Paul VI tomorrow in the first visit to the head of the Ro man Catholic Church by ahead of the Israeli Government.

Op position to an oil superport off New Jersey or Delaware by Governors Cahill and Russell W. Peterson will not deter the Army Corps of Engineers from conducting a final round of pub lic hearings on the question this week, a spokesman for the Philadelphia district of thecorps has said.

Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson told President Nix on today that unemployment among Vietnam war era vet erans "in effect no longer con stitutes a national problem." He credited the Administration's campaign to find jobs for thereturning servicemen.
The chilly air was filled with sounds of firecrackers, horns and chants of "We're No. 1!" as Miamians took to the streets tonight to celebrate the Dolphins' Super Bowlvictory.

Top echelon cellists are sometimes loath to schedule Bloch's "Schelomo" because it is shorter than a standard concerto, and "Don Quixote" by Strauss because so much of the spotlight is shared with other solo instrumentalists, not to mention the orchestra as awhole.

Ratification of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution no longer looks like a sure thing. Well organized and seeming ly well financed opposition groups have appeared, and they are making arguments against the amendment that many statelegislators find persuasive.

A source close to the Watergate case said today that four of the five defendants were under what he termed "great pres sure" to plead guilty to charges of eavesdropping on the Demo cratic National Committee head quarters in Washington lastJune.
Vice Adm. Wilfrid Neville Derby, former superintendent of the Coast Guard Academy, died yesterday at his home. Hewas 83 years old.
Americans for Democratic Action asked the Senate today to refuse to confirm President Nixon's cabinet appointees until the Administration re leases all funds enacted for social programs.

The New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra was formed last spring as a worthy project to train musi cians from the public housing community. Evidently the con certs in auditoriums and on the lawns, of the city's developmentslast summer were a success,
Two light airplanes ended up "piggy-back" today when one landed on top of the other while they wereattempting to land.
Only 2 per cent of those ar rested in New York City on serious narcotics charges are being sent to prison for a year or more, according to the headof the police narcotics division.

A jury of 10 men and two women will begin its fourth day of. deliberations tomorrow in the murder trial of Juan V. Corona, unaware that Mr. Cor ona apparently suffered his third heart attack Friday evening.
A 64-year-old retired police man was stabbed to death yes terday by a 16-year-old youth in an attempted robbery on the IND subway stairway at 44th Street and Eighth Avenue, the police reported.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J.-Father Flanigan of Boys Town is alleged to have said, "There is no such thing as a bad boy." Perhaps not. But reason able facsimiles exist: teen-aged boys who murder, rape, rob and assault fellow citizens, sometimes elderly people. When such boys or men are apprehended by the police, what issociety to do with them?
The post office at Allentown will continue to handle Sunday mail for the Scranton, Wilkes Barre, Hazelton, Pa., and Bing hamton, N.Y. areas, postal officials announced yesterday.
The Democratic party of Alaska to day nominated the first Alas kan native to run for Congress.

Egypt's international airline, Egyptair, will be re-equipped with American, rather than Russian passenger jets worth more than $50-million through financing arranged by an American investment banking firm.

The fire hydrants are open, even in this biting cold weather--town pumps that provide the sole water supply for drinking, washing and sanitation for thousands of tenants in 20 per cent of the housing in the area. When one hydrant freezes over, the residents pry openanother.

Australia's Attorney General said today that he would urge Britain to surrender her last vestiges of authority over his country and thus abolish "continuing relics of colonialism."
" Music of the Tudor Courts from Henry VIII to Elizzabeth I" is not the kind of concert title impresarios hold in particularly high esteem, but Saturday night at Tully Hall it looked likea winner.
The much-talked-about "en ergy crisis" became a reality last week in some other areas of the nation, and it could still happen in the Northeast if theweather turns sharply colder.

The Rev. Charles H. Van Tas sel, an Episcopal layman who was ordained in 1960 and had since served as an assistant at St. Ann's Church in Sayville, died yesterday in South SideHospital. He was 73 years old
The idea of divorce insur ance, to be taken out imme diately before or after mar riage, is gaining increasing interest among feminists,lawyers and legislators.
A Columbia University graduate student with a broken leg was lifted off the cold, windy peak of Anthony's Nose by a helicopter last night afterspending six hours on a ledge.
Sunday are generally quiet here-a siren or two each hour, church chimes spread ing in the dirty air and little more-but today brought a new low to the city's noiselevel.

Onny Parun of New Zealand rallied from a two-set deficit and won the men's singles title today in the New Zealand open tennis cham pionships. Evonne Goolagong of Australia swept to a straight set victory in the women'sfinal.
Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso asserted yester day that major responsibility for the continuation of the Long Island Rail Road strike rested with the 12 strikingunions.

Mamo Wolde, the 44-year-old Ethiopian palace guard, passed the goat merchants on Western Avenue and trotted victoriously into the Nigerian National Stadium today to win the marathon of the sec ond All-Africa Games. His time was 2 hours 27 minutes 32.02 seconds for the 26 miles385 yards.

A professional repertory theater in this smoky textile town in southern Serbia has achieved what many actors and directors can only dream about: Eager playgoers who have broken in the main door three times in the last two seasons, who occupy every seat at every performance and who crowdthe wall aisles.

Repre sentatives of European Jews meeting in London demanded today that East Germany in demnify Jewish victims of Naz ism, following the example setby West Germany.

The birthday of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., pro posed as a legal holiday in legislation still pending before Congress, will be observed here and in many other communities and major cities today.

A transit patrolman shot and captured an armed holdup suspect early yesterday after the man fled into an IND subway the 1 station at 125th Street and St. house Nicholas Avenue to escape from seven two pursuing city policemen, the police reported.

Mozart's sacred music has been snubbed as trivial, but that is a judgment needing a good deal of qualification. Mozart lived in an age and composed in an idiom that prized grace of feeling, and a later era's failure to per ceive the intensity beneath the elegance may only be exposing its own limitations.
Jerry West stole the ball from Pete Maravich in the final minutes today and led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 102-100 victory over the AtlantaHawks in a National Basketball Association game.

Harry W. Albright Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday that he had moved to close a "Loophole" in state law that has allowed two prominent in ternational financiers-Michele Sindona and Edmond J. Safra -to take control of banks in New York without regulatoryapproval.

A year ago, President Nixon wisely issued an executive order banning the use of cyanide, strychnine, and other systemic poisons to kill coyotes and other predators on the nation's public lands. Shortly thereafter, William Ruckelshaus, the Environmental Protection Administra tor, blocked their use on private lands as well, by pro hibiting the interstate shipment and sale of these deadlychemicals.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yester day the appointment of Richard A. Debs and Thomas M. Tim len, Jr. as senior vice presi dents of the bank. Both hadbeen vice presidents.

The big scoreboard in the Coliseum flashed the message over and over, "The Dolphins Are Su per," at the end of the Super Bowl contest today, and indeed the Miami team had played an almost perfect game in defeat ing the Washington Redskins, 14-7, for a perfect season andthe championship.

As the Soviet Government nego tiated a broad agreement for technical cooperation with the General Electric Company last week, Moscow television treated its viewers on three successive nights to a new feature film, "Washington Correspondent," seemingly dedicated to the theme that the United States is a land of violence that kills its public leaders.
A series of financial measures, including a proposal to allow savings institutions to make in stallment loans just-as banks do, is ready for consideration in the State Legislature tomorrow.
Stanley Teich, 36 years old, of 52 Greene Place, North Cald well, N.J., died today in a skiing accident at Hunter Mountain, the State Police said.
A military firing squad today executed a Chinese printer convicted of having refined and marketed millions of dollars worth of heroin in the Philippines during the last10 years.

In a bruising battle between two angry clubs, the St. Louis Blues finally won a game and the Islanders lost another their 11th straight.

Eight members of a City Council committee--a majority--have signed a Gay Activists Alliance petition for reconsid eration of a bill twice defeated in committee that would bar discrimination against homosex uals in employment and housing.
Fifteen burly policemen, carrying rifles and handguns, broke down two doors and poured into the home of the William Pine family lastTuesday.

PARTICIPANTS-The Long Island Rail Road and 12 unions representing 5,000 carmen, teamsters, clerks, elec trical workers, sheet metal workers and other nonoperatingemployes, as well as some supervisors.
President Nixon sent Gen. Al exander M. Haig Jr. to Saigon tonight to consult with Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu about the Paris negotiations on aVietnam cease-fire.

Last Oct. 1, Italy's giant automobile maker, Fiat, began a more flexible work schedule for close to 5,000 white-collar workers at the huge Mirafiori plant in Turin. This began the largest single European experiment with"flextime" thus far.

Lukas Foss did Bertolt Brecht proud yesterday after noon at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music, combining two short operas to Brecht texts by Weill. and Hindemith with some extraordinary renditions of Brecht songs by NinaSimone.
Bruce Crampton, an Australian, got a birdie on the 18th hole to win the $30,000 first prize today in the $150,000 PhoenixOpen.

At the request of Governor Rockefeller's legal counsel, who sought independent, outside, expert advice, the State Commission to Evaluate Drug Laws assessed the chief executive's narcotic proposals with their mandatory life term penalties. The commission found them to be both unworkable and unconstitutional. Mr. Rockefeller hasnonetheless presented his proposals for enactment.

What is it like to live in a poor country, one of the 25 poorest in the world? You're most likely to be an illiterate farmer working moun tainous, desert, grassland or salt-pan terrain at least 20 miles from a road, hundreds of miles from a seaport, and even far ther away from any type ofhealth service or school.

A little bit of luck and the kindness of two good Samari tans brought a total of $40 recently to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Nancy Troy told the fund that on Dec. 27-her birth day-she found a $10 bill onthe street.

VINH LONG, South Vietnam--Vu Thi Mai is a former heroin pusher. She and her family used to peddle narcotics to the servicemen at Saigon's Tan Son Nhut air base. An attractive, sleek haired 18-year-old, Mai lived with an American construction worker and has a 10-month-old daughter with fair hairand blue eves.

Miss Lois Farfel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron J. Farfel, was married here this afternoon to George Stark, son of Mr.and Mrs. Fred Stark of Paris.

This Westchester County village is nearing the end of a two-year court bat tle with the State Liquor Au thority that could funda mentally change the re lationship between the au thority and local governmentsthroughout the state.
A 20-year-old youth was ar rested yesterday in the Holland Tunnel after he had apparently stolen a Port Authority policecar from Newark Airport.

In the often overdramatic world of professional football, where coaches exhort their teams each week "to win one for the Gipper," and where locker- room truisms like "Winning Is Everything" are hailed as philosophy, DonShula usually cooled it.

The "Lyrics and Lyricists" series opened its third season Sunday evening at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue at 92d Street, with 'he youngest lyricist it has ver offered and the one with he shortest track record.
After six years during which his teams compiled a won-lost-tied record of 2238-3, Bill Pace resigned yesterday as football coach and athletic director at Vanderbilt University.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today named the Clinton Oil Company of Wichita, Kan., and 18 present and former officers and directors in a complaint alleging repeated willful violations of Federal securities laws.

The Defense Department's general counsel told a Senate subcommittee today that the Grumman Corporation had paid its "traditional" $8-million Christmas bonus to workers last month and that the money could have come from the $54million the Navy had advanced to the company.

An Australian journalist, Francis James, detained for more than three years in China on charges of spying, walked across the border into Hong Kong today after being deported by the Chinese Government.

Bishops of opposite color are the only pieces on the board that must follow totally separate tracks, never making contact with each other - which is what Boris Spassky meant when he said of his divorce that he and his first wife "were like bishops of opposite colors."
A three-way match to break the tie for the United States chess championship will be played Feb. 3 to Feb. 11 in Chicago, the United States Chess Federation announced yesterday.
Harmonizing the sunny, endearing side of Swanilda and her less appealing destructive inclinations is the task of great interpreters of the role in "Coppelia." On Sunday afternoon,

In an international match that almost went down to the last bout before a decision was reached, England's national amateur boxing team defeated the United States team, six bouts toa five before a crowd of about 1,000 in the Felt Forum last night.
Many Americans are risking their lives because of what they don't know about their own high blood pressure, experts said here today at a national conference on that health problem.
Stock prices broke sharply yesterday -- registering the fourth largest decline in more than two years--as fears of renewed inflation and uncertainty about Phase 3 stalked Wall Street.

The Nixon Administration spent about $95-million to administer Phase 2 wageprice controls, the Cost of Living Council estimated today. A council spokesman said the estimate included expenses of the Internal Revenue Service,

Arch A. Moore, a Republican, today became the first West Virginia Governor to succeed himself in more than 100 years. In his inaugural address he stressed "the utter failure of the Federal Government" to respond to states' needs.
Pat Boone is a survivor. Back in 1955 he was making "cover versions" (copies) of rhythm 'n' blues hit single records, softening them for mass - audience consumption and being very successful.
Academic disqualifications and a walkout by one player have reduced the troubled Cornell University basketball team to seven members, it was disclosed today.

Four of the six remaining defendants in the Watergate traial pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to spying on the Democrats during last year's campaign. They pleaded guilty to all seven counts of an indictment charging them with conspiracy, second-degree burglary and wiretapping. The action subjects them to a maximum of 55 years in prison.
A resolution that would give New Jersey voters a chance to reduce the six-month voter-residency requirement to 30 days passed the Assembly 65-0 today and was sent to the Senate.

The Freeport Minerals Company said yesterday that it had notified customers of a sulphur price increase of $3 a ton applicable in the Gulf Coast region, on the South and Middle Atlantic Coast and in the Mississippi River area north to St. Louis.
The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee introduced legislation today to reinstate a $225-million soil conservation program killed by the Nixon Administration last month. Representative W. R.
American growers lose $132-million each year because of air pollution damage to crops and plants, according to a new study by Stanford Research Institute.
Amid growing controversy over whether it should be played at sports events, the national anthem has been dropped from the Olympic Invitational track and field meet at Madison Sauare Garden.
Former Alderman Fred Hubbard surrendered today to Federal marshals to begin a twoyear prison sentence for embezzling $100,000 from a program to bring minority groups into the construction industry.

Celebration, sadness, nostalgia and even a touch of comedy were mingled as demolition of the historic Garden City Hotel under the pounding of a three-ton wreckers' ball began here today before a crowd of 200 people.

Rear Adm. Sidney W. Souers, U.S.N.R., retired, the first executive secretary of the National Security Council and the first director of a forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived here.
Switserland and East Germany will open embassies in each other's capital on Wednesday, the Swiss Foreign Ministry announced today.
The case of Earl Whittaker, a suspended correction officer accused of having encouraged inmates who rebelled at the Manhattan Men's House of Detention in October, 1970, goes to the jury today.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., one of the nation's largest investment houses, disclosed yesterday that it had experienced a sharp increase in revenues and earnings in the final quarter of calendar 1972.

The Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday settlement of Control Data's antitrust suit against the computer giant, and I.B.M.'s subsequent counterclaims.

Edward Brewer, a young harpsichordist who made his debut in 1966, appeared here Sunday night at CAMI Hall, His program included major harpsichord pieces by Bach and Handel, minor ones by Sweelinck and Byrd, and sonatas for oboe by Handel, Bach and Telemann, for which he was mosti capably joined by his wife, Virgina Brewer.

The Xerox Corporation realized its best three-month results in the final quarter last year along with record revenues and earnings for all of 1972, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday. The results reflect the highly profitable copier and duplicator operations.
There is nothing remarkable-looking about the Village Drugs store on Seventh Avenue South at Bleecker Street, which will close at the end of this month, after 35 years.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market dropped sharply yesterday after late selling pressure erased most of the earlier gains in active trading.

Walter A. Moos, a leading art dealer, died Friday at the age of 46. Mr. Moos, a New Yorker, came here in the early 1960's aid established the Galerie Moos, Inc., representing artists from Canada, the United States and Europe.

SENIOR CLASS The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, 120 Madison Avenue, between 30th and 31st Streets (MU 6-9244), is, it says, the oldest English speaking school for teaching acting (there's an older French one), going back to 1884.

The multimillion-dollar empire of the Rev. Rex Humbard, which in cludes a New York girdle factory and a Michigan college, is being threatened by security commissioners in Ohio and several other states.

Governor Rockefeller, who has often talked of the need to keep skilled professionals working in New York State, announced that he had hired former Gov. Russell Peterson of Delaware to head a new state commission.

Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the exchange would undertake a broad-based program to upgrade employment opportunities for women and minority groups at the Amex and in the securities industry in general.
Television station WNBC will drop four of its Sunday public affairs programs late next month and replace them with "Sunday," a live magazine-format series to be seen from 10 A.M. to noon.
Warren Wade, a retired actor and broadcasting executive, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 76 years old and had lived at the Actors Fund Home.

The Loews Corporation, a conglomerate with holdings in the tobacco, theater, hotel and real-estate fields, has acquired 848,700 shares of the common stock of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., or about 10 per cent of the retail company's outstanding stock.

Early this afternoon after four more defendants had pleaded guilty and the "Watergate seven" had diminished to the "Watergate two," one of the trial spectators turned to a companion and cracked: "This judge will have a trial even if there are no defendants left."

Dr. William Engel, a retired physician who was a benefactor of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Saturday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 84 years old and had been residing there and in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.

At 10 o'clock of a weekday morning fifteen men, armed to the teeth, break into the home of the William Pine family in Winthrop, Mass., by smashing the doors. Mrs. Pine and her teen-age daughter, in uncomprehend. ing terror, plead for mercy. Her husband, who holds night job, awakens in his upstairs bedroom to stare into the muzzle of a gun.
Retail grocery prices in the New York and northeastern New Jersey' area increased 0.6 per cent in November, a month in which they normally decline.

Shane Gould, the 16year-old swimming star, was named Australian of the year by a national committee today. The honor conferred on the blonde athlete has been given previously to Prime Ministers, among others.

Sixteen makers of popular cough and cold remedies reported under Government order today what is in their products that prompts them to advertise the way they do.

Federal District Judge George Rosling in Brooklyn declared a mistrial yesterday in the trial of Garrett B. Trapnell, who had admitted hijacking a Trans World Airlines jet last Jan. 29, but contended he was insane at the time.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Pope Paul VI met in the Vatican for an hour today and discussed peace efforts for the Middle East, the status of Jerusalem and the question of Palestinian refugees.
The process of selecting the six alternate jurors in the Pentagon papers case continued today, with the expectation that it will be completed by Wednesday. None were selected today.

To the Editor: The proposed solution of added controls, more review personnel and new agencies of the Congress [editorial Dec. 26] will not cure the problems of our national defense procurement system. It is based on a belief that the problem is rooted in the evils of a military-industrial "conspiracy," phony budgetary practices and "bought" contracts.

Municipal pension costs, which have nearly tripled in the last decade, are likely to triple' again in the next decade-to a staggering $2.9 billion ayear-even if the city puts a clamp on further, liberalization of the generous retirement programs now authorized.

Mayor Lindsay vetoed a bill ' yesterday that would have created six City Council districts to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council, contending that there had not been sufficient 1 notice, awareness and debate by the public on the bill.

Cyril B. Judge, of New York and Newport, R.I., where he taught at St. George's School from 1910 to 1927, died yesterday in Newport Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 807 Fifth Avenue and in Newport.

Canada is prepared to begin moving a peace-keeping force of as many as 1,450 military personnel into Vietnam within 10 days of a cease-fire agreement, officials in the Department of External affairs say.

A teachers' strike will keep Chicago's public schools closed today with both sides still divided on major issues, while the strike-bound Philadelphia school district opened special classrooms yesterday for seniors in eight high schools in that city.

ROME--"It is easier for a girl to have an abortion in Italy than in any other Western country where abortion is outlawed," commented an American who had helped find doctors for two fairly well-off foreign women.

Four of the six remaining defendants in the Watergate trial pleaded guilty today in Federal Court to spying on the Democrats during last year's campaign. They pleaded guilty to all seven counts of an indictment charging them with conspiracy,

The American Basketball Association yesterday held a secret draft by telephone here of collegiate basketball players. Two draft rounds were held, with both seniors and underclassmen selected, The Associated Press learned.

The Legislature authorized the State Department of Environmental Protection this evening to acquire control of a segment of the Appalachian Trail in New Jersey and protect it from impending commercial development.

George Romney, who is leaving President Nixon's Cabinet after four years as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has agreed to become the chairman and chief executive officer of the National Center for Voluntary Action.

Despite the Miami Dolphins' unbeaten record, Jim Kiick and Earl Morrall were uncertain today about remaining with the Super Bowl champions. Coach Don Shula hoped to persuade both of them to return next season.

President Nixon, citing "progress" made in the cease-fire negotiations in Paris, suspended bombing, mining, shelling and all other offensive action throughout North Vietnam yesterday. The White House press secretary announced the suspension after several hours of consultations between the President and Henry A. Kissinger.

The American Broadcasting Company recommended to the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that the F.C.C. retain its controversial prime times access rule for television for at least another two years.

Known through the last decade as the world leader in the manufacture of "super computers," the Control Data Corporation has moved recently to become a broadbased company, a kind of supermarket for computer service.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, joined a move today to provide Federal subsidies for urban mass transit systems that operate at a loss. Mr. Javits said that he had become a co-sponsor with Senator Harrison A. Williams

Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, will receive the Veterans of Foreign Wars 10th annual Congressional Award for outstanding service to the nation. The presentation will be made March 6 in Washington.

SYDNEY, Australia--Rudolf Nureyev's film of "Don Quixote," with the Australian Ballet, breaks new grond in both the cinema and the dance. The production, its filming recently completed, is expected to bring luster to the Australian image in the lively arts.

Stock prices registered their fourth largest decline yesterday in more than two years. Traders' fears were attributed to prospects of renewed inflation and uncertainty about President Nixon's Phase 3 economic plans.

The 18-yearold daughter of President Nguyen Van Thieu is to be wed Friday. Newspapers published a two-column announcement of the approaching marriage of Miss Nguyen Thi Tuan Anh and Nguyen Tan Trieu, son of the director of the national airline, Air Vietnam.
Two hundred American servicemen left Vietnam for home last week, dropping United States troop strength there to 23,800, the United States command said today.

A Public rvice Commission representive recommended today that a New York Telephone Comny be allowed to charge for cal information calls if the mber requested was in the cal directory. In return, he ggested, the company should luce the basic monthly arge.
The International Business Machines Corporation posted record worldwide consolidated net earnings last year of 1.28billion, equal to $11.03 a share, according to yesterday's preliminary report.
Responding to complaints of dwindling Congressional power, House Speaker Carl Albert called today for the first sweeping study of House committee structure in more than a quarter of a century.

A State Supreme Court jury last night acquitted Earl Whittaker, a city correction officer accused of encouraging inmates during a 1970 riot at the Tombs, of two counts of kidnapping and one of unlawful imprisonment.

Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies, the best pitcher in baseball last season but a member of the team with the second worst major league record, agreed to terms yesterday for the 1973 campaign.
The State Department, confirming a Greek Government announcement yesterday, said today that Athens would no longer receive direct United States military aid.
Joe DiMaggio and Johnny Unitas sat together at lunch here yesterday and the result was one vote for the designated pinch-hitter and one vote against the Baltimore Colts.
Mrs. Gertrude Albion Wright, widow of Dr. Richard L. Wright, who was editor in chief of House Garden, died yesterday at New England Baptist Hospital.

The Senate Democratic Policy Committee, in a fresh challenge to President Nixon's authority, decided today to try to limit the Administration's use of "executive privilege" to avoid giving testimony to Senate committees.

Forty-two persons were indicted yesterday in connection with a $50-million Brooklynbased policy gambling empire linked to Meyer Lansky. Half of the defendants had been arrested following a police roundup last Sept. 29, when District Attorney Eugene Gold announced the smashing of the operation.
The Senate Armed Services committeee approved today resident Nixon's nominees for op positions in intelligence nd defense.

A blow was struck by Dr. Bruno Bettelheim, the child psychologist and author, for what might be called boys' liberation. Dr. Bettelheim, in an article in the February issue of the Ladies' Home Journal, said studies revealed that grade school teachers reprimand boys more frequently than girls.

A Federal grand jury today returned fraud indictments against 10 persons who prepare incometax returns. The defendants were accused of inflating their clients' medical and dental expenses, charitable deductions and sales taxes. Some were said to have listed nonexistent exemptions

A Federal prosecutor charged today that seven past and present officials of Atlantic City ruled the resort "as if it were their private kingdon," enforcing "a total feudal system of corruption upon that society."
The Cyprus Mines Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Bagdad Copper Corporation through an exchange of stock.

The state and city clashed over welfare again yesterday when George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, charged that the city's new computerized system had failed to close a single case out of 5,896 referred by five centers since the system started Nov. 13.

Providing a positive counterpoint tq his earlier negative reaction to Governor Rockefeller's suggestion of life prison sentences for drug sellers, Mayor Lindsay yesterday outlined steps the city is taking to increase the number of drug abusers under treatment.

There always seems to be an undercurrent of humor in Jan Wodynski's work, whether she makes an explicit point of it or not. In the seven dances presented at the Cubiculo Monday evening, she went from the cartoon fantasies of "Superantics" to the quiet witticisms of "Changeover."
Clara Ward, the gospel singer, who performed her first solo at the age of 5 and grew up singing in churches with her mother and sister, died today. She was 48 years old.

A judge delayed yesterday any contempt of court action against union leaders of striking Philadelphia teachers. The strike of Chicago teachers rounded out its first week with negotiators at odds on several issues.

The Western Conference Teamsters announced significant improvements today in its contract with lettuce growers, an area where the teamsters are in competition with Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Union.
The Chief R4bi of Rome said today that the Vatican had committed a "grave discourtesy" by allowing a spokesman to play down yesterday's meeting between Pope Paul VI and Premier Golda Meir of Israel.

Wall Street has taken a careful look at President Nixon's Phase 3 wage-price system and has gone into a sinking spell, fearful of renewed inflation. But organized labor seems delighted with the looser and more voluntary Phase 3 program, worked out by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz, and George Meany,

A lawyer in the Watergate trial said today that one of the two remaining defendants would attempt to justify his actions on the ground that he had feared violence against President Nixon and other leading Republicans.

Yesterday Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith filed a "red herring," or preliminary prospectus, with the Securities and Exchange Commission as the manager of an underwriting group for a new mutual fund.
Final plans for an Inauguration Day anti-war protest march, from the Lincoln Memorial to the Washington Monument grounds, were announced here today by the two sponsoring peace groups.

Despite considerable hostile Public opposition, some states are quietly promoting sex education in public schools to curb increasing rates of illegitimate births, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare told Congress today.
A parade of speakers denounced the Board of Education last night for not being "accountable to the public" and urged the board to extend the contract of Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

The Long Island Rail Road and 19 unions were. ordered yesterday to show cause tomorrow in Brooklyn Federal Court why a temporary injunction should not be issued requiring them to end the strike while negotiations continue.
The nation's manufacturing industries operated at 79.7 per cent of capacity in the fourth quarter, the highest "capacity utilization" rate since early 1970, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Soviet Union's latest unmanned moon craft, Luna 21, made a successful soft landing today and delivered the Russian's second remotely controlled roving vehicle to the surface of the moon.

Less than two months before a legislative. election that threatens to shake a decade and a half of Gaullist rule, Government and opposition politicians are showing signs of hoarseness and ill temper from weeks of angry exchanges of accusations.
Elmer Anderson Carter, former chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, predecessor to the State Division of Human Rights, died yesterday.
Dr. Mindel Cherniack Sheps, a physician who became a biostatistician and an authority on biological factors affecting fertility and reproduction, died yesterday in Durham. She was 59 years old.
A 37 - year - old high school science teacher who had been under psychiatric care killed his wife and two young sons with an ax in their home here and then hanged himself, the police reported today.

Steel Pier, which has presented everything from diving horses to an embalmed whale, got some new owners today who would like to offer a new kind of entertainment. Three local businessmen bought the pier for about $2million and said it had "tremendous" potential for gambling. Milton Neustadter,

A slithering but friendly four-foot boa constrictor, a curious screech owl, a prickly hedgehog, a very nosey ferret and two cuddly young white rabbits visited the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Medical Center yesterday.

Calder Race Course, which has been open since last May 6, finally ended its eight-month stand today as Ogden Phipps's Daring Young Man won the $50,000 added Saul Silberman Memorial Handicap - and then pulled up lame.

After a year-long investigation, a Manhattan grand jury handed up an unusual report yesterday, charging the city administration with mismanagement for having allowed 127 union officials to remain on the city payroll in 1971 while they were receiving union salaries.
The Security Council decided today to hold a series of meetings in Panama City beginning March 15 on matters concerning Latin America.

was a very good year for wine taxes. The Governor's budget message reports that while the volume of liquor consumption had a 3-to-2 edge over wine a few years ago, the grape took a slight edge last year.

Chou Croute romped to a 14-length victory in the $64,800 Santa Monica Tandicap at Santa Anita today. Carrying the high weight of 128 pounds and ridden by John Rotz, the 5-year old mare went to the front of the seven-furlong test at the, quarter pole and drew away to finish in 1:23 3-5 on a sloppy track.
Arthur L. H. Rubin, a consultant in educational and academic fields, died yesterday at his home, 135 East 54th Street.

A United States Air Force private began serving two and a half years for attempted robbery here last night and a further term of four and a half months he had received for burglary was affirmed today.

C.B.S. News reported yesterday that it had gained access to portions of the draft agreement to end the war in Vietnam and gave details of provisions for release of prisoners, troop withdrawal, composition of a control commission and signing procedures.

Prices of live beef cattle futures played folow the 'leader with soybean prices yesterday as both climbed to new highs. Soybeans jumped the 10cents-a-bushel limit at the session's start and volume dwindled with virtually no sellers, and hundreds of eager bidders.

A jury of 10 men and two women reported today it was again deadlocked, this time 11 to 1, in its fifth day of deliberations on the fate of Juan V. Corona, the 38-year-old Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farm workers.

Twenty nervous people were sitting in a circle in the basement of an East Side church, directly beneath loops of glittery holiday tinsel. But there was no joy on anybody's face. No glad tidings. No good cheer. Then, at precisely 7:30 P.M., a rather heavy blond woman in an orange dress began to speak.

President Nguyen Van Thieu is expected to give his approval to the text of a cease-fire agreement brought to him yesterday by Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., and the Government is now going over the details of how it is to be carried out, according to Vietnamese officials close to the presidential palace.
The Metropolitan Opera has received sums of $194,500 for its student education projects and $200,000 for the Piccolo Met repertory to open next month at the Forum Theater.
The image of the "cop on the beat" painted by Governor Cahill in his annual message to the Legislature is proving popular with city residents and mayors-but not so popular with some police officials.

After a year-long Investigation, a Manhattan grand jury handed up an unusual report yesterday, charging the city administration with mismanagement for having allowed 127 union officials to remain on the city payroll in 1971 while they were receiving union salaries.
Doris Fielding Reid, a retired vice president of Loomis, Sayles Co., investment counselors, died yesterday at her home, 955 Lexington Avenue. She was 77 years old.

Susan von Reichenbach gave L her third-or first, depending on how you count-Tully Hall lieder recital Monday night and, a few hopefully correctable technical limitations aside, it was a most pleasing affair.

Wednesday, Jan. 17-In the final hours of the bombing of North Vietnam on Monday, 87 fighter-bomber strikes and four missions by three-plane formations of B-52's were flown against targets south of the 20th Parallel.
A television station says that a marked map found in the apartment of the slain hotel sniper, Mark Essex, indicates that he methodically planned four attacks.

Failure of motorists to include an extra dollar for the new reflectorized 1973 license plates is causing delays in mailing out the plates for thousands of car owners in the metropolitan area, according to Morris Gimpelson, regional director of motor vehicles.

A joint legislative conference of the United Auto Workers and the International Association of Machinists was announced today for March 5, 6 and 7. Discussions will cover union campaigns on such issues as national health insurance, consumer legislation, tax retion and environmental protection.

SovietAmerican trade nearly tripled in the first 11 months of 1972, even before large grain shipments began arriving here. The surge put the United States, for the first time, among the Soviet Union's major Western trading partners.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that even after the Vietnam war ends, the sources of growing tension between Congress and the Nixon Administration will remain.

Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a proposed $8.88-billion budget for the new state fiscal year beginning April 1. He said it represented a "sound balance between justifiable optimism and realistic caution" in assessing the state's fiscal condition.
The city's budget director said yesterday that the Gov ernor's proposed $8.88-billion budget contained "virtually no new money for the city."
There was a play last night at the Biltmore Theater called "Let Me Hear You Smile." One had a certain difficulty in even hearing a laugh.

Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, said today that he would challenge the re-election of Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, as chairman of the House Government Operations Committee.

After the steady flow of precise but bloodless studio re-creations that the big bands of the thirties and forties have been subjected to recently, it is both startling and refreshing to find a group of musicians recalling a band that nobody else has thought about, and doing it in such a way that the project becomes more than mere capitalization on nostalgic memories.

Joe Bugner, tuning up for nest month's fight with Muhammad Ali, retained his European heavyweight boxing title tonight by registering a unanimous 15-round decision over Rudy Lubbers of the Netherlands.

The Senate Democratic Policy Committee, in a fresh challenge to President Nixon's authority, decided today to try to limit the Administration's use of "executive privilege" to avoid giving testimony to Senate committees.

Like the couturier who annually moves the feminine hemline and calls it truth, Governor Rockefeller has basted together a state budget that sets a mid-calf mode for 1973-74. It's not the ankle-length, pay-as-you-go conservatism of Mr. Rockefeller's early period.
The death last month of former President Harry S. Truman moved many individuals to send memorial gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The 245-passenger TriStar jumbo jetliner was back in scheduled service today following two engine malfunctions that had led to a Government order for an immediate engine inspection.

Beginners are usually advised to search for safe leads against suit contracts, but in particular cases this easy generality may be difficult to apply. In the diagramed deal, West was in a position in which all leads were unattractive.

Jacqueline Du Pre and her husband, Daniel Barenboim, shared the billing at their recital Monday night in Philharmonic Hall, but it was very difficult not to focus all attention on Miss Du Pre's cello playing.
Derek Sanderson again received an offer he couldn't refuse and he will take $1-million not to play hockey for the Philadelphia Blazers.
Joseph M. Callahan, a former State Supreme Court Justice and Associate Justice of the Appellate Division, died yesterday at his home in Southampton, L. I. He was 87 years old.

Following are the major parts of Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget for fiscal 1974, which begins April 1: TOTAL-A total $8.88-billion asked--an increase in expenditures of $933-million over the present budget. The vast bulk of the increase would be go for existing state programs and for mandated increases, such as previously negotiated fringe benefits for state employes. No major new and costly programs are requested.
They're shooing the pigeons out of Washington because of Saturday's Presidential inauguration, but only as far as suburban Alexandria.

Annemarle Proell of Austria, unbeaten this season, vitrually clinched the 1973 World Cup title skiing today by racing to victory in the women's downhill race over the 3,200-meter Oberjoch course, slowed by more than a foot of wet snow.
John Cage, the veteran enfant terrible, will be on hand for a retrospective concert of his music at Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon in Lincoln Center's "New and Newer" series.
Eleven witches gathered around an altar in a darkened gallery of the Museum of American Folk Art earlier this week to consecrate wine and bless the occult show that opened there yesterday.

STRIKE HEAVEN ON THE FACE! a play by Richard Wesley. Directed by Israel Hicks; lighting by Kenn Billington; stage manager, Karen Hendel. Presented by The New Phoenix Repertory Company, Sideshow #2. At the Bllou Theater, 359 West 48th Street.

The Justice Department urged the Securities and Exchange Commission today to disapprove a rule proposed by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, Inc., that fixes minimum rates of commission on transactions. The Chicago board is seeking registration from the S.E.C. as a national securities exchange.

Musica Sacra departed from its avowed subject matter to include two secular works in its concert on Monday night.

Farmers of the Middle East from the Jordan Valley to the plains of Syria and Turkey and the limestone-walled fields of Cyprus looked today with thanks at their ancestral hills, all covered with snow.

Robert M. Webb, director of the division on youth and community services of the Federation of Protestant Weifare Agencies, died today of leukemia in Greenwich Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 5 Mill Pond, Cos Cob.
The week-long Federal court trial of two former servicemen charged in a 1970 bombing of an Army training camp ended abruptly here today when the defendants pleaded guilty to reduced counts.

Western Europeans indicated today their disagreement with initial American proposals to revamp the monetary system, heralding the first of what probably will be many clashes before greater stability is reached.
The reaction of the legislative leaders of both parties today to Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.88-billion budget was not unlike a political fever chart.

Earnings of six of the nation's largest banking concerns were higher during the full year of 1972 as well as in the fourth quarter, the companies reported yesterday. In some cases, the improvements were dramatic.
State Health Commissioner James R. Cowan said yesterday that only a small percentage of food establishments had failed inspection during the first month of the state's new program.
A tone of laconic, goodnatured crustiness makes "Female Artillery" middling diversion as the "Wednesday

The 16-year-old youth accused of stabbing a retired policeman to death in a subway station near Times Square on Sunday had been sent home from custody in a state narcotics center because officials there thought "he had been so good ... he had made marvelous progress."

Transport of New Jersey's operating losses, mostly because of route consolidations, service cutbacks and new state subsidies, should fall off sharply this year, the executive director of the Department of Public Utilities said today.
The Labor Department, charging the Bethlehem Steel Corporation with failure to overcome the effects of racial discrimination, ordered the company today to make sweeping
Another last-gasp victory fell into New York Knick hands tonight as they defeated the Phoenix Suns, 102-101, in a National Basketball Association game in which the officiating outraged both teams.

On its face the agreement between the Soviet Government and the General Electric Company for an extensive program of technological exchange and cooperation should help both Russia and the United States in coping with the growing energy crisis. That crisis creates a need for the most efficient utilization of fuels and for development of means to generate power with minimum damage to the environment.

John Havlicek's 16 points in the fourth quarter led the Boston Celtics to an uphill 106-102 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight before 10,274 in Memorial Auditorium.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday told Alex Rose, the leader of the Liberal party, that even if he did not run for re-election this year he would organize a political coalition to make sure that a candidate who had progressive leanings and was unbossed would be in the race.
Chou Croute romped to a 14-length victory in the $64, 800 Santa Monica Tandicap at Santa Anita today.

There was a time when Seton Hall University was synonymous with quality track and field. John Moon believes it can happen again, and soon. "With all the good talents around here," the new Seton Hall track coach said recently, "I don't see why Seton Hall can't be on top again."

Skillful sensibility of treatment and a fine pictorial sweep marked "The Forbidden City," an uncommonly worthwhile hour of television viewing last night over the National Broadcasting Company network.
Six Protestant church organizations are renewing a campaign for full disclosure and close scrutiny of American corporate investments and activities in southern Africa, it was announced yesterday.
While reports persisted abroad that a cease-fire in Vietnam was imminent, the Nixon Administration refused today to shed any light on that possibility.

Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a proposed $8.88-billion budget for the new state fiscal year beginning April 1. He said it represented a "sound balance between justifiable optimism and realistic caution" in assessing the state's fiscal condition.
The State Urban Development Corporation plans to proceed with its controversial nine-town housing plan in Westchester County, Edward J. Logue, president of the state agency, said today.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art says that one of its most popular paintings, "Odalisque," attributed to Ingres, is not by Ingres after all.
Sentries killed one Pakistani prisoner of war and wounded one when they tried to escape from a camp in Uttar Pradesh early today, the Defense Ministry said.

PATERSON. N. J.-My interest in the legal dispute that the Justice Department has with International Business Machines Corporation goes beyond the fact that I was raised in an "I.B.M. family" where several members of our family group received their sustenance and successfully raised their children, thanks in no little way to the admirable vision of Thomas J. Watson Sr.

Scarcely had Premier Golda Meir of Israel and her brigade of security guards departed from an historic encounter with the Pope of Rome than the various spokesmen began their unseemly quibbling over whether her visit had any meaning at all. Their nervousness reflected the remnants of. unreality which still hang over relations of church and state in modern Jerusalem, a city that is just too holy to too many people for its own good.
Senators from both parties, concerned over the nation's fuel shortage, proposed today that the Government allow price increases for oil, natural gas and coal.

Bill' France Jr., who succeeded his father last season as president of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, indulges the superstition of knocking on wood when things are going right - good advance ticket sales, no weather post ponements last year, everyone pulling together for 1973; and so on.

A 20-year-old woman who works or the Trenton Police Departnent was raped yesterday in ull view of about 25 employes of a nearby roofing company who watched intently but did lot answer her screams for elp.

Fairleigh Dickinson University received a million - dollar pledge today from a large North Jersey contractor to help it set up a Center of Building Construction Studies here on its campus overlooking the Hackensack River.

AVERY-Carleton S., of Bronxville, N. Y. on Jan. 15, 1973. Husband of Anne Welst Avery, father of Scott Avery, son of Helen Seymour Avery. Service at the Fred H. McGrath Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, N. Y. on Thursday, Jan 18 at 4 P.M. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y.

A 20-year-old woman who works for the Trenton Police Department was raped yesterday in full view of about 25 employes of a nearby roofing company who watched intently but did not answer her screams for help.

Following are questions compiled by The New York Times concerning the new rule on stock-exchange membership promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, a dispatch about which begins on Page 1. Tentative unofficial answers are based on numerous discussions with people in the Federal Government and in Wall Street.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered all stock exchanges to accept as members any brokerage firms doing "a predominantly public business."

People hold up banks all the time, but it's not every day that a bank holds up people. That's what happened on Sunrise Highway today for almost four hours, when a former branch of the Bowery Savings Bank was stalled in the three eastbound lanes.
States Government will provide insurance and financial services for private companies investing in Yugoslavia, the first time such Government services have gone to an Eastern European country.
Senator Richard S. Schweiker said today that the Federal sky marshal program, aimed at deterring airline hijacking, was "a complete flop" and urged Congress to stop providing money for the program.

John T. Connor, chairman of the Allied Chemical Corporation, reported yesterday that preliminary figures indicated "substantial" increases in earnings for the fourth quarter and full year of 1972, while sales reached record levels for both t periods.

Governor Rockefeller has proposed an $8.88-billion budget for New York State, up almost $1 billion from the current fiscal year's total. Despite that sizable jump, this is essentially a pre-election-year budget, one that clears away some old bills and holds the promise of a massive surplus for a time when Governor Rockefeller may be running for still another term. Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legislature today a bill that would restore a 10 per cent cut in welfare benefits to more than 1.5 million recipients in the state.

Joe Vavricka, a reserve forward, scored 15 points and led Princeton to a 43-37 victory over Temple in Jadwin gymnasium tonight. Vavricka scored 12 of his points in the second half as the Tigers erased a 20-17 half-time deficit and gained their seventh victory against six losses.

An undercover agent testified at a bribery trial in Federal Court here yesterday that he had used a concealed transmitter to tape-record conversations with two defendants accused of arranging for a Queens prosecutor to kill a criminal case.
For the first time in their short, unhappy National Hockey League career, the Islanders tonight held the opposition to one goal. Unfortunately, the New Yorkers didn't score any.

A group of block associations representing 250,000 Brooklyn residents filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court charging that the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage- foreclosure program "harms the general environment and hastens urban decay."

Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that the union would seek the right to reopen its next contract with the auto industry at any time to protect itself against Government interference under the third phase of wage and price controls.

The Labor Department, charging the Bethlehem Steel Corporation with failure to overcome the effects of racial discrimination, ordered the company today to make sweeping changes in the seniority system at its plant at Sparrows Point, Md., to assure blacks better job opportunities.

An offering of 1.35 million common shares of the Peoples Gas Company at $38.75 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation. The company's stock closed at 38% down 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Julio Martinez Castello, former fencing coach for New York University for 20 years and 1924 coach of the United States Olympic Fencing Team in Paris, died Monday at his home in Tampa, Fla. His age was 91.

Mike Wallace of the Columbia Broadcasting System is the winner in the category of outstanding reporting in the Alfred I. du Pont-Columbia University Awards in Broadcast Journalism. He was cited for his work on C.B.S.'s "60 Minutes."

Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by; BUSINESS SUPPLIES CORP. OF AMERICA, manufacturing and selling computer tab cards, 475 Fifth Ave. N.Y. Liabilities, $9,418,252; assets, $6,507,635. Plan of arrangement to be filed at subsequent date. Signed by William Callahan, vice president.
Canadian and United States energy negotiators are understood to have made quiet progress behind a curtain of secrecy toward an agreement for sharing continental oil supplies in an emergency.
Prices on the over-thecounter market and on the American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday for the third consecutive session in slower trading.
Under orders from the Public Employment Relations Board, the state today relented on a controversial parking fee for state employes and said it would refund payments to the workers.
Former Brig. Gen. Earl F. Cole and his secretary were convicted in United States District Court today on seven counts of making false statements to cheat the Army.

Mrs. Jacqueline Parsons James of New York, widow of Marquis James, twice a Pulitzer Prize-winner for biography, was married here yesterday afternoon to Francis Goodwin 2d of Wethersfield, Conn., founder of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra.
The State Urban Development Corporation plans to proceed with its controversial nine-town housing plan in Westchester County, Edward J. Logue, president of the state agency, said today.
Neil M. Gunn, an author and playwright, died last night in Inverness, Scotland. He was 81 years old.

The National Steel'Corporation of Pittsburgh confirmed yesterday that, along with the Southwire Company of Georgia, it had expanded a joint ven ture agreement with Earth Sciences. Inc.. of Golden, Colo.

For more than twenty years California authorities have known that the peculiar topographical and climatic conditions in Los Angeles and its five surrounding counties were making the automobile an increasing health hazard. Yet until a few years ago so little was done to head off an inevitable crisis that the California Medical Association, not given to hysteria, was moved to warn of "a state of chronic and increasing emergency."
The connection from Interstate Route 287 and the new Route 440 eastbound to the Garden State Parkway will be opened here for traffic tomorrow, state officials announced today.

The career of Andre Kertesz is one of the longest and most distinguished of living photographers. Among his professional peers, Mr. Kertesz-now 78 years old and a resident of New York since 1936 - has long been acknowledged as one of the master artists of the photographic medium.

A secretary in the Town Hall motioned toward the American flag and the Scituate town flag, trembling in a slight breeze, and said that the mourning period for former President Harry S. Truman may have helped mute a growing controversy here.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered all stock exchanges to accept as members any brokerage firms doing "a predominantly public business."

The credit markets continued to reflect yesterday the bullish implications of Vietnam peace and the bearish implications of too much domestic prosperity. Most interest rates, however, tended to advance as investors husbanded money in the expectation of still higher returns ahead.
