Two city prosecutors reported yesterday that they had "broken into" a Chinatown-based herointrafficking ring that they said apparently obtained heroin from China.
Anti-Government Basque guerrillas carried out another spectacular kidnapping last night and today, seizing one of Spain's leading industrialists and presumably hiding him in France.

MIAMI, Jan. 17 (UPI)--Fourth-seeded Cliff Richey had no trouble in downing Bob Maud of South Africa, 6-3, 6-0, but Bob Lutz, seeded eighth, struggled to a 3-6, 6-4, 6-3 victory over Colin Dibley of Australia in the first round of the $25,000 Saga Bay tennis tournament today.

Four members of a Bronx street gang were held without bail yesterday on charges that included attempted murder in connection with the mugging of a 43-year-old man who suffered stab wounds in the head and stomach.

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development moved yesterday to force the Jersey City Housing Authority to streamline its management and halt project deterioration. The department's area director,James P. Sweeney, said he would soon assign a full-time department staff member to "oversee the operations" of the Housing Authority.

The City Planning Commission has scheduled a hearing for Jan. 31 on a plan under which builders could make a cash contribution to a fund for the improvement of park areas in order to gain the right to construct larger buildings.

Herbert Ross's "The Maids," based on the play by Jean Genet, is an unusual ballet and it has had an unusual history. Mr. Ross, now more widely known as a Broadway and Hollywood director, created the work in 1957 in a special workshop organized by Ballet Theater.
Olga Korbut of the Soviet Union, who won three gold medals, a silver medal and the hearts of the world at the Munich Olympics, was named female athlete of the year yesterday by The Associated Press.
The Food and Drug Administration announced today sweeping changes in food labeling practices to give consumers a better idea of the nutritional value of about half of what they eat.

A special Federal agent who had posed as a Mafia mobster testified at a bribery trial yesterday that he had delivered "marked money" as a bribe to have a case fixed by Norman D Archer, an assistant district attorney in Queens.

The Treasury Department adopted final regulations today requiring banks to keep microfilm copies of all checks over $100 on hand in a move to make it easier to catch white-collar criminals. The regulations are the last of a series of rules adopted under the Bank Secrecy Act, passed by Congress in 1970 to help the Government in detecting crime carried on through secret foreign bank accounts as well as through domestic accounts.
Everybody has been talking about Japan as a major new source of investment demand for American securities, but nobody has done anything about it yet-except the Dreyfus Corporation.

President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam has raised several serious objections to aspects of a proposed peace settlement, an informed source said yesterday. But Mr. Thieu has reportedly accepted the broad outlines of the draft agreement.
Two alleged Mafia figures were indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury investigating the murder last year of Joseph Gallo in a Little Italy restaurant.

Keeneland broke a record of sorts today when it finished its sale of horses of all ages by drawing $3.8million for 657 horses. That total topped the 1970 record of $3.7-million, although 29 stallion shares that year added $663,100 for a total intake of $4.3-million for the entire sale.

The Food and Drug Administration announced today sweeping changes in food labeling practices to give consumers a better idea of the nutritional value of about half of what they eat. When these and a second group of food labeling rules that are to be announced soon go into effect over the next two years,

For a long time I used to walk five miles daily to work. Such was the power of doctors. Every day in the newspapers doctors said that walking was a smart thing to do. They still say it, although it is very rare to see a doctor walking.
The New England Whalers set up a solid defense in front of their goalie, Al Smith, and whipped the Chicago Cougars, 4-2, in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

Jurors in the Earl Whittaker case retired shortly before 11 o'clock last night, failing after two days' deliberations to reach a verdict in the case of the prison guard, who was charged with aiding rioting inmates in the October, 1970, Tombs revolt.

Housing starts reached the record level of 2,355,500 in 1972, up 15 per cent from the record achieved in 1971, the Commerce Department reported today. Starts in December maintained the high level that prevailed throughout the year, with an annual rate of 2,392,000.
Presiden Ferdinand E. Marcos consolidated his virtually unlimited power today, raising the pros pect of years of authoritarian rule for the Philippines.

Andrel D. Sakharov, the noted physicist and civil-rights campaigner, charged Soviet authorities today with violating generally accepted legal principles by lifting the citizenship of his former colleagues, Valery N. Chalidze, during a lecture tour in the United States last month.

WASHINGTON-The rate of inflation in the United States has declined substantially in the last two years. American progress in the struggle against inflation has been the envy and marvel of the rest of the world. But still inflation remains a problem here and the struggle is not over.
Garrett Brock Trapnell, whose five-week trial for skyjacking ended in a hungjury Monday, was born 34 years ago into a patrician world populated by famous war heroes.

Soviet scientists expressed confidence today that findings of their new noon rover, the Lunokhod 2, would supplement information gathered last month during the manned mission of Apollo 17 in an area only about 140 miles away.
Derek Sanderson was given a settlement believed to be $1-million and his unconditional release by the Philadelphia Blazers of the World Hockey Association yesterday.

The Long Island Rail Road, busiest commuter line in the country, has been rescued from the rust box by the intercession of Peter J. Brennan, the incoming Secretary of Labor. Borrowing a leaf from his predecessor in the Kennedy Administration, Arthur J. Goldberg, unionist Brennan has persuaded his old cronies in the striking nonoperating unions on the Long Island to go back to work at midnight tonight.
Governor Cahill said today that he would ask President Nixon to restore mandatory price controls if he found that landlords "rush to violate the principles" of the Federal anti-inflation program.
Twenty-five major American companies and banks with extensive experience overseas have banded together to help small and medium-sized companies get started in the export business.
A judge ordered 13,000 striking Philadelphia school teachers yesterday to obey his injunction and report back to their classrooms by this morning.

Libya is pressing her largest Western oil concessionaire to hand over 50 per cent ownership immediately under a formula that challenges the participation agreements reached by foreign producers in the Persian Gulf.

There were growing Indications today that the Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao have resigned themselves to the eventuality of a cease-fire negotiated without them by their respective backers, which could come soon after a settlement is reached for Vietnam.
Prime Minister Heath today announced Britain's most comprehensive program of anti-inflation measures since World War II, including curbs on prices, wages, rents and dividends.

Smoked Nova Scotia salmon can currently cost the Phase 3 epicure as much as $7 a pound. It is clearly time to look for cheaper ways to feed ourselves. And, as an artful hedge against zooming food prices, pasta is hard to beat.

Add one more new jazz club to the growing New York jazz scene. This one is in the East Village-the Jazzboat, on Avenue A between Sixth and Seventh Streets, a softly lit room with touches of nautical decor, including waitresses who wear round, white sailors' hats.

"Patriotism," said Samuel Johnson a couple of centuries ago, "is the last refuge of a scoundrel." Today, it is usually the first refuge of politicians like New York City Councilman Matthew J. Troy, who is among the sponsors of a bill to require the playing of the national anthem at sporting events, despite his own doubts about the bill's constitutionality.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers said tonight that a number of developments had combined to make 1973 "a favorable time" for negotiations between Israel and Arab countries.
Three members of the Super Bowl champion Miami Dolphins called in sick today and missed Pro Bowl workouts while a fourth was excused from playing in the game.

Food processors and packa gers yesterday generally supported the new nutritional labeling rules released in Washington by the Food and Drug Administration and particularly applauded the agency for making the guidelines voluntary.
Between Ideals and Reality: A Critique of Socialism and Its Future, by Svetozar Stojanovic, translated by Gerson S. Sher (Oxford University. $7.95).
The United States command announced yesterday that American war planes had attacked enemy positions throughout South Vietnam in the highest number of strikes in more than a month.

The American Broadcasting Company's telecast of this year's Tony Awards ceremonies on March 25 from 9 to 11 P.M. will have as its theme "The Wide World of Broadway" and will feature filmed scenes from Broadway hits in overseas productions.

"I am one of the most frustrated officers in the Police Department," Deputy Inspector William R. Bracey, commanding officer of the 32d Precinct, said last night. He was one of a panel of Harlem police officials meeting with the Harlem Task Force on Crime.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., announced yesterday its entrance into the real estate development field through the acquisition of George G. Mulligan Associates, Inc., a builder-developer of multi-family condominiums in suburban Washington.
Rejean Houle posted the first three-goal effort of his National Hockey League career tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

Governor Cahill said today that he opposed mandatory life sentences for convicted drug pushers, contending that anyone seeking stiffer prison terms for such offenders "must realize that the addicted pusher would do anything,

The stock market, which has been in a slump almost from the moment President Nixon's Phase 3 wage-price system was announced, staged an unenthusiastic recovery yesterday. Prices rose moderately while trading activity slowed to 17,680,000 shares from Tuesday's 19.170,000.

For the last three days, the walls of the staid old Syracuse Hotel here have looked like a Sunday comic strip. More than 2,500 posters have festooned the walls with such multicolored messages as "Boom Boom George Zambelli," "Hell Drivers - Wildest Show on Wheels" and "Everybody Loves a Clown."
A court yesterday recommended dismissal of a lawsuit seeking to declare unlawful and contrary to public policy President Nixon's decision last year to mine harbors in North Vietnam.

The worst storm to hit the west coast of the Iberian Peninsula in 25 years lashed the shores of Spain and Portugal today, sinking dozens of fishing boats, wrecking harbor installations and leaving at least 19 persons dead or missing.
Prof. Ivan G. Petrovsky, mathematician and Rector of Moscow University, died here Monday. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow.

Robert E. L. Strider, president of Colby College in Waterville, Ma., is the new chairman of the Asosciation of American Colleges. Mr. Strider was elected yesterday at the organization's 59th annual meeting here. He succeeds the Rev. Paul C. Reinert, president of St. Louis University.

Alfred Brendel, the Viennese pianist, has had the kind of career that would be possible only in this age of recordings. His recital and concert appearances have been relatively rare, at least in this country, but he is still an artist who commands a wide, and in some quarters even cultlike, following.
Television's absurdity can almost be charming-sometimes. Last night's example was "Cole Porter in Paris," a "Bell System Family Theater" hour shown on the National Broadcasting Company network.
In an emergency action intended to relieve the shortage of fuel oil in some parts of the United States, President Nixon today authorized increased imports of crude oil and heating oil.

Charity and ecology joined forces the other day for the benefit of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The catalysts were Juliette and Mike Levinton, who donated $6 to the fund, a sum that grew out of a year of saving

The American Jewish Congress has called on Navy Secretary John H. Chafee to repudiate an official memorandum urging chaplains to play a "strong role" in the yearlong evangelical campaign known as Key 73.
Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that Japan would extend emergency economic aid to Indochina as rapidly as possible after a cease-fire in the Vietnam war.

A jury of 10 men and two women adjourned at 5 P.M. today after 44 hours of deliberation in the case of Juan V. Corona, the 38-year-old Mexican national accused of murdering 25 migrant farm workers in 1971. It will resume at 9 A.M. tomorrow.

Some high Administration officials are reported deeply concerned over the increasing movement toward one-man rule in the Philippines by President Ferdinand E. Marcos. But well-placed officials said today that for the time being the United States would continue to refrain from commenting publicly about the political situation in the Philippines.
The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Chemical New York Corporation, which run neck and neck in the hotly competitive New York City banking market,

All the big events in fashion don't have to involve rarefied clothes at stratospheric prices. Pembroke Squires in his first collection for Main Street has shown that it's possible to chart new fashion directions in as prosaic an area as raincoats.

Dave Cowens scored 35 point and hauled down 20 rebound tonight as the Boston Celti?? extended their winning strea?? to seven games with a 117-9 National Basketball Associatio victory over the Portland Tra Blazers.

Ryder System Inc. directors have approved the purchase of 200,000 shares of the company's outstanding common stock on the open market and in private transactions. The purchases will be made over the next twelve months. The company's stock closed at 40 7/8, up 3/8, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland announced today plans to strengthen the state law protecting the confidentiality of reporters' sources. In an address to the state legislature, he said "the fourth branch of government - our
Thieves made off late Wednesday with three amplifiers that feed the main cable lines of Sterling Manhattan Cable Television, Inc., leaving 50,000 cable-TV subscribers with blank screens.

A BIRD IN THE HAND. By Donald Wetzel. 149 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $5.50. THE MORNING AFTER. By Jack B. Weiner. 263 pages. Delacorte. $6.95. It's funny how some novelists write well yet leave you cold, while others can take cliches, trite insights, and stock situations, and build powerful stories out of them.
The bond market, declining almost without interruption since early January, steadied yesterday, but interest rates in the money market kept on rising. In a major test of the tax-exempt sector.

Many people will regard The Times series on the South Bronx by Martin Tolchin as a horror story to be quickly put out of their minds-if they don't happen to live in the South Bronx or anywhere near it. But this social cancer is spreading; unless checked, it can destroy not just the rest of the Bronx but the city itself.

The block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues on West 36th Street is scarcely a Gran Via a la Madrid, come midnight. The garment center that clogs it during the day is resting, uneasily, and you can even find parking in the street.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos consolidated his virtually unlimited power today, raising the prospect of years of authoritarian rule for the Philippines.
Fittingly, William Matthew Byrne Jr. is a Hollywood version of a judge-young for a man in his position, ambitious, attractive and a bachelor.

Pakistan accused India today of "slaughtering" Pakistani prisoners held in India since the war between the two nations in December, 1971. The accusation followed a report from New Delhi that one Pakistani prisoner of war had been shot dead and another injured by a sentry as they tried to escape from a camp in Uttar Pradesh.

Twenty years. ago, Sidney Harth made his first appearance here as an orchestra soloist with the National Orchestral Association in Carnegie Hall. He was already on the way to a career, having won the Naumburg Award, but the engagement no doubt gave it an extra push.

A new face among the Aces when they defend their Bermuda Bowl world team title in Brazil in May will be Mark Blumenthal of Philadelphia. The 30-year-old expert will be the youngest member of the famous American champions,
Stock prices faltered on the American Stock Exchange yesterday and closed mixed in slow trading. They had been slightly higher during most of the session.
The men who manage the news media in the city were given a high-level glimpse of some high spots of the city's vast government yesterday.
The French Government began to remove English words from the nation's vocabulary today, banning such expressions as "hit parade," "tanker" and" zoning" from official use.
The International Basic Economy Corporation plans to curtail and sell certain of its operations and concentrate on the more profitable businesses.

Ralph T. Walker, who was hailed in 1957 by the American Institute of Architects as "the architect of the century," died yesterday at his home on Roaring Brook Road in Chappaqua, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

In a development that will provide significant help for the United States balance of international payments, the Japanese Government Export-Import Bank, instead of the United States Export-Import Bank, will finance the sale to Japan of 10 large United States commercial airliners valued at $237-million.
Crocuses may not have been budding in Central Park yesterday, but to many New Yorkers there was spring in the air. The thermometer rose to 60 degrees, equaling a 60-year record for the date.

The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India had been hit by the worst drought in a decade and was importing at least two million tons of food grains, mostly from the United States.
Monika Kaserer of Austria followed up yesterday's downhill victory by her teammate, Annemarie Proell, by winning the slalom race in the World Cup ski meet here today.

John Wayne Wilson of Shelbyville, Ind., was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday for the Jan. 2 murder of Roseann Quinn, but his arraignment was postponed for a week to allow a psychiatrist to examine him.

The military Government began criminal proceedings against former President Juan D. Peron today, charging that recent statements he made in Madrid were instigationss to violence." The court proceedings, opened on instructions from the Ministry of Justice, reflect the increasing antagonism between Mr. Peoron and the Government of Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, which allowed the former dictator to return to Argentina last November after 17 years of exile.
This is the last of four articles on the South Bronx. By MARTIN TOLCHIN Few devastated areas of the city show such outward, visible signs of progress as does the South Bronx.

The Government today described an elaborate system of alleged payments by a contractor to former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton and a second man, including a $25,000 cash payment made in a gasoline station and a "secret checking account" set up to receive $5,000 a month.

Nine years ago, Steve Savino was a pee-wee speed skating champion at the Willowbrook ice rink. So it comes as little surprise that, he's on his way to his third straight national championship. But that is the national figure skating championship.
Frank Shorter, the Olympic marathon champion, was presented the Amateur Athletic Union's Sullivan Award today as the 1972 amateur athlete of the year.
In a reversal of position, Community Planning Board 5 voted yesterday to reject a proposal to build a pedestrian bridge over 51st Street between two buildings on Park Avenue.

Three similarly violent murders in three weeks in lower Manhattan involving men the police said were part of the "leather bar" scene have sent waves of rumors and fear through the area's homosexual community.
Finland's Parliament passed legislation early today extending for four years without an election President Urho Kekkonen's current sixyear term, which was due to expire on March 1, 1974.
Opening statements in the Pentagon papers trial were delivered today, with the Government charging a simple case of theft of classified documents.

William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee to be Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, was accused in a Federal suit today of gross mismanagement and flagrant violation of his obligations to a corporation now involved in bankruptcy proceedings. Mr. Casey, currently the chairman of the Securities Exchange Commission, was named in a $2.1-million damage suit filed here, along with 16 other defendants.

History was made at the American Spaniel Club's national show on Jan. 7 at the Statler Hilton Hotel when Sedora Quettadene Damon became the first Sussex spaniel in the East to become a champion in more than four decades.

The killing by a policeman of a popular 21-year-old black youth who grew up in this affluent white community has left a feeling of anger, fear and frustration among many of the area's residents, particularly the young.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced today that he would introduce three bills to tap the Highway Trust Fund to finance urban mass transit projects, assist in controlling air pollution and conserve dwindling petroleum resources.
A 90-day cooling-off period in the Long Island Rail Road strike was announced today by Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee as the new Secretary of Labor.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 17 (Reuters)--Monika Kaserer of Austria followed up yesterday's downhill victory by her teammate, Annemarie Proell, by winning the slalom race in the World Cup ski meet here today.

Ben Jipcho of Kenya, co-owner of the world record in the 3,000-meter steeplechase, beat Merus Yifter of Ethiopia in the 5,000-meter race at the All-Africa Games today, Jipcho was clocked in 14 minutes 7.2 seconds. It was a games record but short of the world mark of 13:13 owned by Emile Puttemans of Belgium. Yifter was second in 14:07.52 and Kenya's Paul Mose third in 14: 08.38.

Large numbers or antiwar Congressmen will boycott President Nixon's second inaugural a California Democrat said today. Some may join protesters in the streets demanding that the United States get out of Vietnam.
A bill designed to outlaw the manufacture and assembly here of cheap handguns, commonly known as "Saturday night specials," was voted out yesterday by the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

One of the largest remaining tracts of natural wilderness in private hands on the Eastern Seaboard-an area comprising one-fifth of the Dismal Swamp that lies in Virginia and North Carolina-has been donated to

Anyone who wants to enjoy all the. hoopla and festivities surrounding President Nixon's inauguration. Saturday ought to bring plenty of money. The only event the average citizen can see free is the parade from Capitol Hill to the White House after the swearing-in ceremony.
Prime Minister Heath today announced Britain's most comprehensive program of anti-inflation measures since World War II, including curbs on prices, wages, rents and dividends.
There is strong evidence that pregnant women who smoke cigarettes are thereby increasing the risk of death of their babies, a Public Health Service report said today.

The name of the former Attorney General, John N. Mitchell, is finally back in the title of the old NixonMitchell Wall Street law firm.
Soybean prices, which jumped the daily 10-cents-a-bushel limit on Tuesday, made a similar leap yesterday, setting another record on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Directors of the New York Stock Exchange approved institutional membership yesterday for the first time under guidelines set forth by the Securities and Exchange Commission. They endorsed a series of constitutional and rules changes to comply basically with an order issued two days ago by the S.E.C.
A former Justice Department investigator says that James R. Hoffa's release from prison followed a chronology of bribery, threats and political intrigue that still reaches into the White House.

GRAND CAYMAN ISLAND, British West Indies-- Leaping high out of the dark waters of a jungle pool, a tarpon shook its head violently in an effort to break free, but my fly remained embedded in its jaw and 10 minutes later the fish was beached.

Herbert W. Kurzman, a consultant to the BVD Company, Inc., a licensing and manufacturing organization in the apparel field, died in his office at 350 Fifth Avenue yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 201 East 77th Street.

Chief Federal Judge John J. Sirica spoke for a host of incredulous observers at the Watergate trial when he told defendant Bernard Barker that he simply did not believe his story that $114,000 had arrived in unmarked envelopes from sources unknown. Since then the defense has moved from the incredible to the outrageous.

The killing by a policeman of a popular 21-year-old black youth who grew up in this affluent white community has left a feeling of anger, fear and frustration among many of the area's residents, particularly the young.

Although many signs point to an early cease-fire in Vietnam, reports from Saigon indicate that President Thieu is still dragging his feet on an agreement already extensively revised to try to meet his objections. The United States has paid a heavy price in men, material and moral standing for this delay on Mr. Thieu's behalf.

Acting on a recommendation from Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, the City Board of Education last night adopted new policies regarding pupil records that will, for the first time, give parents and youngsters the right to challenge "derogatory material" contained in official school files.
A 90-day cooling-off period in the Long Island Rail Road strike was announced today by Peter T. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee as the new Secretary of Labor.

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration today cautioned operators of the more than two million trucks equipped with special so-called RH5-degree wheels on dangers associated with reassembly after tire changes or other service.
A 3-year-old boy fell five stories from a window in a Brooklyn housing project last night, landed on a grassy plot and was reported in fair condition after he was taken to Cumberland Hospital.

The Sperry Rand Corporation, a broadly diversified industrial producer, achieved record revenues and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended with December, with all but the Remington Rand division in the black, according to results reported yesterday.
A bill designed to outlaw the manufacture and assembly here of cheap handguns, commonly known as "Saturday night specials," was voted out yesterday by the City Council's Public Safety Committee.

Following criticism in Yugoslavia and abroad, a twoyear prison sentence imposed last July 18 against a Belgrade University law professor has been reduced to nine months by the Supreme Court of Serbia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17--Three Democratic Senators said today that they would try to hold up Senate confirmation of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare until the middle of February.

At just about noon today a man identified as Willie Leonard signed the register at the Veterans Administration offices here, walked past the two guards at the door and up to the reception desk at which Bill Golding was sitting.

The statewide grand jury today indicted two Municipal Court judges from Atlantic County on charges of conspiring to quash a criminal-assault charge against a man who subsequently was sent to prison for trafficking in narcotics.
Vice Adm. Herbert D Riley, U.S.N., retired, command er in chief of naval forces ir the Pacific in the late 1950's died at his home here today He was 68 years old.
Australia pulled back today from an earlier commitment to bestow independence upon a reluctant Papua New Guinea next year, but reaffirmed that Canberra would still "work toward" that goal.
Prof. Leon Edel, the literary scholar and biographer, has been appointed editor of the diaries and journals of the late Edmund Wilson, the critic.
Black defendants in state criminal trials are entitled to have prospective jurors screened on the basis of possible racial prejudice, the Supreme Court ruled today.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today temporarily blocked the Berrigan brothers from going to Hanoi Acting at the request of the Justice Department, he stayed a ruling issued earlier in the day by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

With protests against the Administration's policy in Vietnam planned throughout the weekend -- ranging from vigils and religious services to marches and rallies -- local and Federal authorities are joining forces to insure that the inauguration and its surrounding ruffles and flourishes are not disrupted.
There is strong evidence that pregnant women who smoke cigarettes are thereby increasing the risk of death of their babies, a Public Health Service report said today.
A bank president, his wire and 16-year-old daughter were found trussed to trees and shot to death-the bank official with dynamite strapped to his chest--yesterday near a farmhouse in the Ozarks.
When Grace Institute opened its doors 75 years ago its purpose was to teach working-class wives how to take better care of their homes and children.
Prof. Ivan G. Petrovsky, mathematician and Rector of Moscow University, died here Monday. He would have been 73 years old tomorrow.

Strike-harried Long Island Rail Road commuters can expect partial service starting at 12:01 A.M. Saturday and full service Monday morning if striking workers return to their jobs as scheduled, a spokesman for the railroad promised yesterday.

WASHINGTON--Current conditions and the political setting now indicate that the Nixon Administration's welfare-reform plan should not be reintroduced in the first year of the 93d Congress. There are three reasons why the time is right now for going back to the drawing boards on welfare.

The mobility of pawns is slight in comparison with that of the other pieces. Slow-paced, unable to retreat, the pawn bogs down as soon as an enemy pawn blocks its path. In close openings such, as the French Defense or the King's Indian Defense, interlocking chains of pawns may create a pattern of frozen immobility across major areas of the chessboard.
Weather: Mostly sunny, mild today; fair and mild tonight, tomorrow. Temp. range: today 41-58; Wed. 39-60. Full U.S. report on Page 81.
President Pompidou of France flew here today from Djibouti, territory of Afars and Issas, and was cheered by some 20,000 persons on his ceremonial entry into the Ethiopian capital.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel ended her quick trip to Europe today by having lunch with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast.

Goals by Jim Neilson and Rod Selling within the last five minutes gave the New York Rangers a 4-4 tie with the Los Angeles Kings tonight, and averted what would have been New York's first loss to the Kings in three years.
A strong second half carried St. John's to an 87-59 basket-: bal victory over Clemson last night before 3,159 at Alumni Hall on the Redmen's Jamaica campus.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers said last night that a number of developments had combined to make 1973 "a favorable time" for negotiations between Israel and the Arab countries.
Joseph Papp, founder and director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, has repudiated a film about him and his work set for foreign distribution by the United States Information Agency.

Officials of the National Kidney Foundation disputed yesterday a recent article and editorial in The New York Times that cited Federal reports that had projected annual costs of $1-billion in the nineteen-eighties to treat 5,000 patients who would otherwise die of terminal kidney diseases.

Henry A. Schutz Jr. has been named special agent in charge of the criminal division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, its largest.

Mariner 9 scientists released today photographs of a dry, meandering channel on Mars that they said was "the clincher" to their theory that water must. have played a role in shaping the planet's surface.
An 18-year-old holdup man was shot to death last night in an exchange of gunfire with the 38-year-old operator of a grocery store in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, the police reported.

With his Theater at St. Clement's, Kevin O'Connor is reviving the grand tradition of the actor-manager. Since he took over last May as artistic director, he has turned St. Clement's (formerly the home of the American Place Theater) once again into a vigorous, active theater.

When Les Ballets Africains first appeared at Harlem's Apollo Theater in 1970, their reception was so triumphant that both they and local residents spoke fondly of their coming "home" to Harlem. Yesterday the Guinean dance troupe came "home" again to the Apollo,
An explosion shattered the $2-million Cherokee Nitrogen Company plant here tonight, igniting several neighboring industrial plants and threatening other buildings.
Thomas C. Wansley, 25 years old, a black twice convicted of raping a white woman, was freed on $10,000 bail by a Federal judge today after spending 10 years in prison.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against the General Host Corporation charging fraud and other illegal acts in its 1969 attempt to acquire control of Armour Co., the big Chicago meat packer. Nine other companies and individuals were also named in the suit.

The average housewife has been watching meat and egg prices rise sharply in the last few weeks with worried resignation. Meat and eggs account for more than 25 per cent of a typical food budget of $40 to $50 a week for a family of four.

Mike McCormack, a protege of Paul Brown, Vince Lombardi and George Allen, became head coach of the National Football League's Philadelphia Eagles today. The 42-year-old McCormack, who had been on the Washington Redskin staff, signed a three-year contract.
Three similar murders in three weeks in Greenwich Village involving men who might have been part of the "leather bar" scene have sent waves of rumors and fear through the area's homosexual community.

Yesterday was another dark day for freedom in Asia as President Ferdinand E. Marcos extended martial rule indefinitely while proclaiming a new Constitutionone which, even if it is eventually invoked, would give him sweeping new powers.
Honeywell, Inc., and the Univac division of the Sperry Rand Corporation, the major competitors for second place in the computer industry, announced major new systems yesterday.

Staten Island Democrats meet today to choose a new leader because of a judicial policy that bars a county leader from being a court clerk. Dante L. Ferrari, chief clerk of the Richmond County Surrogate's Court, has resigned as the county's Democratic leader because of the policy.

The owners of the Hudson Hotel at 1641-1659 Amsterdam Avenue, near 141st Street,were ordered by State Supreme Court Justice Birdie Amsterdam yesterday to eliminate the conditions and evict the tenants that have made the seven-story structure a "notorious" haven for crime and criminal activity.

Members of a new Government advisory committee reprimanded some of President Nixon's top advisers yesterday for what they said was the Administration's failure to understand the main economic problems facing women.

In a radio interview broadcast today, Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam said that his Government would refuse to sign an agreement that mentioned the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government.

Dorothy S. Baldwin, a psychiatric social worker who retired last November as a consultant to the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, died following emergency surgery on Monday in Suva, Fiji Islands, during a tour of the South Pacific. She was 67 years old.
Bob Guccione, the successful explorer of the outer limits of contemporary community standards, is now planning for women the kind of sexually-oriented magazine that he gave men in Penthouse.
Seventy-two pound Mark Levasseur questioned his father last Sunday before climbing the steps alongside the 50-meter ski jump here. "Did I do any better than last time?"

The Watergate trial went into secret session today when a key Government witness was asked to name people he said he had overheard talking on a wiretapped telephone in the offices of the Democratic National Committee.

Robert Barney Walker, chairman and chief executive officer of American Brands, Inc., died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at a hotel in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien. Conn.

The Watergate trial went into secret session today when a key Government witness was asked to name people he said he had overheard talking on a wiretapped telephone in the offices of the Democratic National Committee.
The Denver Rockets had a shooting game tonight coaches like to forget and the Nets shot with the accuracy Coach Lou Carnesecca would like to see done more often.

The Justice Department has charged that top executives of the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation held a series of secret meetings at which confidential cost information was exchanged.
Worrell Newspapers announced today that it had agreed to purchase two of Virginia's largest nondaily newspapers, The Manassas Journal Messenger and The Potomac News at Dumfries.

MERIDEN, Conn., Jan. 17--Connecticut's Treasurer, Robert I. Berdon, proposed today that the state's debt-ridden municipalities double their indebtedness in a complicated maneuver to provide new income to help pay for bonds they issued in the years when interest rates were very high.
Revenues of the Pacific Gas Electric Company in 1972 reached $1.35-billion, compared with $1.26-billion in the preceding year, Sherman L. Sibley, chairman of the board, reported yesterday.
In an emergency action intended to relieve the shortage of fuel oil in some parts of the United States, President Nixon today authorized increased imports of crude oil and heating oil.
The City Council yesterday overrode Mayor Lindsay's veto of a reapportionment bill designed to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council.

The Associates First Capital Corporation announced yesterday it had extended for 21 days its tender offer to holders of securities of the Talcott National Corporation at the request of the Justice Department.
The Government publicly suggested for the first time today that blackmail was a motive behind the alleged bugging of Democratic national headquarters last summer by Republican-financed agents.

Because of the current shortage, the Texas Railroad Commission will examine the natural-gas situation at its annual review hearing March 13 in Abilene, Jim C. Langdon, the new chairman of the commission, announced today.

Early in 1972, William D. Ruckelshaus was asked by leading motor manufacturers to postpone for a year the drastic automobile emissions standards ordered for 1975 models under the Clean Air Act. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency denied the request, and he had good reason to do so at the time-just as the auto companies had good reason to apply for the extension. Now they have appealed to the courts,
Higher income limits have been set for entry into public housing projects in the city in an effort to keep them from becoming economic and racial ghettos; Simeon Golar announced yesterday.

The Cromwell Advertising Agency and a former employee in the classified advertising department of The New York Times were indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of stealing $274,700 from the newspaper over the last four years.
The Air Force today selected Fairchild Industries, Inc., to produce at its Farmingdale, L. I., plant a new combat aircraft designed exclusively for providing close air support to front-line troops.
The Federal Government's chief witness in the trial of former State Senator Willard B. Knowl ton refused today to answer any questions until he was granted immunity from prosecution.

President Nixon has returned to Washington for the start of his second term, but instead of finding a spirit of rejoicing over this spectacular victory and elation over the impending cease-fire in Vietnam, he found many of his old supporters in a perplexed and critical mood over his recent conduct.

Don Coryell, head football coach at San Diego State University for 12 years after having replaced George Allen at Whittier College earlier in his career, was named head coach today of the St. Louis football Cardinals.

The personal income of American families and individuals rose by $74.4-billion last year, a figure much larger than the entire national income of most countries in the world. The Commerce Department reported today that the 1972 increase was 8.6 per cent, to a total income of $935.8-billion.

Last month, Corinna Marsh, retired and living at 12 East 31st Street on a small pension, sent the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund a check for $5, regretting at the time that it represented only half of her "usual" $10.

The winning number is: 992877 Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.
The City Council yesterday overrode Mayor Lindsay's veto of a reapportionment bill designed to increase black and Puerto Rican representation on the Council.

What some theatrical buffs might consider a million dollars worth of nostalgia will be sold here Saturday, possibly for less than $50,000, when most of the furnishings from the Alfred Lunts' town house are auctioned at Sotheby Parke Bernet.
Employees of the Long Island Rail Road began returning to work early today in line with a truce arranged Wednesday between,the carrier and striking unions representing 5,000 nonoperating employes.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos called upon all Filipinos today to close ranks and comply with the provisions of the authoritarian new Constitution he proclaimed ratified yesterday.

Japan's exports in 1972 rose 19.3 per cent to a record $30.2-billion, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today. The country's imports also hit a record at $23.7-billion, up 27.3 per cent from the previous year.
The weekly casualty report issued by the United States command today listed two Americans as having been killed in action in Indochina, both of them airmen lost over Laos.

A 35-year old inmate who had spent time in a state mental hospital committed suicide last night in his cell at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, where he had apparently been transferred after being deemed fit to stand trial.

A former inspector in the demolition division of the Department of Housing was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail for his part in what was described as "a systematic extortion plot" against demolition contractors in the city.

Africa's greatest sports extravaganza, the second AllAfrica Games, ended tonight with great jubilation but without answering the questions that were foremost in the minds of many of the young courtestants.
Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, yesterday announced the indictment of a 2 30-year-old former assistant district attorney in the Bronx on charges of bribery.

The State Division on Civil Rights announced today that one of New Jersey's largest real-estate companies-McNerney-Talmo Realty, Inc., of Bergen County - had been found guilty of racial discrimination in the sale of a $129,000 home in Englewood Cliffs in 1971.

In a farewell to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Elliot L. Richardson, the outgoing Secretary, said today that the nation was in a "crisis of confidence" that American social problems can indeed be resolved.

The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had awarded $57-million, the largest single water pollution-abatement grant in the agency's history, toward cleaning up Raritan Bay.

In pursuit of television's "new permissiveness," what you see is curiously but directly related to where you get it. The rule of venturous thumb seems to be: the smaller the audience, the greater the permissiveness.
Lance Rentzel of the Los Angeles Rams, was indicted today by the Los Angeles County Grand Jury on charges of possession of marijuana and codeine.
The council of this traditionally conservative city, which has a large concentration of military bases, unanimously passed a resolution today to help North Vietnam.

NOVEL FLICK Culture never flags at Japan House, the beautiful home of the Japan Society at 333 East 47th Street (832-1155), and starting today the very comfortable auditorium will be showing a series of 15 Japanese films adapted from the works of Japanese novelists.

In "The Wonderful Tar-Baby Story," Joel Chandler Harris described through his bygone Uncle Remus how Brer Fox laid a trap for his enemy, BrerRabbit, by creating a contraption of tar and turpentine which resembled a provocative doll.

Chronologically speaking, it was a tiny bit premature. Vittorio Rieti will not celebrate his 75th birthday until Jan. 28. But his anniversary concert on Wednesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was, of course, no less welcome.

Peru has resumed seizing foreign fishing vessels, with the impounding yesterday of eight United States tuna boats off the nation's northern coast. The eight ships, plus a ninth from Panama, were accused of violating Peru's disputed 200mile fishing limit.

The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that the present grain shortages in various parts of the world were being viewed with concern, "although there is no immediate cause for alarm."
Using a new method for the precise dating of old bones, California scientists have concluded that man first domesticated the cow and pig in Europe some 9,000 years ago.

The Civil Rights Commission has criticized the antidiscrimination sections of the revenuesharing act as too weak and has urged adoption of stronger provisions, including cutting off funds where rights are violated.

The other shoe has dropped in public broadcasting, not with a bang but a simper. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has decided to turn its Public Broadcasting Service into a wholly disowned subsidiary.
A midday temperature of 66 degrees yesterday--eight degrees above the record for the date--gave New Yorkers a touch of spring fever to go with their flu.
The United States and North Vietnam announced jointly today that their chief peace negotiators would meet again in Paris Tuesday to complete the text of an agreement to end the war.

The fouryear-old Paris peace conference on Vietnam was suspended today after its 174th weekly meeting, in anticipation of what participants hope will be the final private negotiating round between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho.
The Federal Government officially dropped charges today against five of the defendants in the Chicago-seven conspiracy case whose convictions were reversed.

Murder Remote, by Janet Caird (Doubleday, $4.95). A Crime Club suspense story. Rule Britannia, by Daphne du Maurier (Doubleday, $6.95). A novel dealing with U.S. - British relations in the near future.

D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, pleaded guilty today to one count of a 47-count Federal indictment charging him with conspiring to use interstate commerce facilities to commit bribery and extortion.
Pope Paul VI ruled today that any vegetable oil, not only olive oil, might be used from now on in the sacrament of the sacred anointing of the sick.

A somber picture of the problems facing the United States and its key commercial partners was drawn yesterday by a number of prominent executives who were, or still are, responsible for shaping the country's foreign economic policy.
Heavy United States air raids were flown throughout South Vietnam for a second day yesterday in support of South Vietnamese troops engaged in the in creasing ground fighting.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market finished mixed yesterday in moderate trading. Both markets virtually ignored the news that Henry A.
Mayor Paul T. Jordan urged legislators today to pry a rentleveling bill out of the Assembly's Municipal Government Committee for a prompt floor vote.
Gene Littler, who underwent an operation for cancer but is now back on the professional tour, has been named winner of the Ben Hogan trophy. The award is

C. W. Post won its 1lth consecutive game last night, beating City College, 65-57, in the loser's gym. City, playing without its leading scorer, Otis Loyd, built a 33-27 half-time lead. Lou Indiviglio of City scored 14 of his game-leading 22 points in the first half.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that although the comedians Dan Rowan and Dick Martin have been publicly announcing that their "Laugh In" television program will go off the air after this season, the network has made no such decision.
William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee as Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, denied today charges of mismanagement and flagrant violation of duties to a corporation he helped found.

Chancellor Willy Brandt went before Parliament today to deliver a gently worded declaration of policies for his second term that stressed what he described as the need for "citizen initiatives" to solve social problems.

An Army staff officer testified today that one of the documents released through the publication of the Pentagon papers could have helped the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong plan last year's Tet offensive.

Jack Montgomery grabbed the first-day lead in the $150,000 Tucson open golf tournament today with a five-underpar 67. The 31-year-old Texas pro needed only 29 putts. He had four birdies and an eagle for a one-stroke lead.

Al Horowitz, chess columnist for The New York Times from 1962 until last year, and three times winner of the United States Open championship, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 80 La Salle Street. He was 65 years old.

A proxy fight looms for control of Peter Paul, Inc., manufacturer of chocolate-covered candies with headquarters in Naugatuck, Conn. William J. Lunn, a Chicagc attorney and executor of the estate of Walter H. Johnson, filed yesterday the papers necessary to start the battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The order by outgoing Secretary of Labor Hodgson for sweeping changes in a discriminatory job-seniority system at the giant Bethlehem Steel mill in Sparrows Point, Md., provides a welcome indication that reports of the death of the Administration's anti-bias program may be premature.

The Telex Corporation yesterday filed a motion in the Federal District Court in St. Paul to set aside the settlement of the Control Data Corporation's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation.
The Army said today that it was investigating a charge, later diluted, that a drill sergeant had ordered trainees to kick a recruit who had suffered a fatal heart attack while on a march.

Soybean prices continued to soar yesterday, with the two nearby contracts moving up the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel, as they have every day this week, to close at new highs on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The General Accounting Office, in its third reply to charges of McGovern campaign finance irregularities raised by the former Republican national chairman, Senator Robert Dole, said today that it had found nothing new to refer to the Justice Department.

The Colony restaurant reopened, and Truman Capote and a number of other regular patrons of the restaurant at 30 East 61st Street in Manhattan braved the taunts of union pickets outside protesting the nonunion staff inside.

Soviet authorities have declared a state of emergency in northeast Siberia, opposite Alaska, after a winter storm covered tundra grazing grounds with a thick ice crust, depriving 370,000 reindeer of fodder.

Two American Sixth Fleet sailors today were sentenced by a Greek court to eight months imprisonment each for hooliganism and causing bodily damage. They were held at a United States air base in Athens pending an appeal of their cases.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's investigation of complaints against the Shubert theatrical and real estate organization began yesterday after the Attorney General obtained a court order authorizing him to make "a thorough audit." Although technically the audit would be of the estate of the late Jacob J. Shubert, who died in 1963, actually it will extend to the Shubert Foundation, which owns the Shubert operating companies.

Topseeded Rod Laver of Australia struggled to a 7-6 first-set victory over Nikki Pilic of Yugoslavia tonight, then dominated the second set, 6-3, to move to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Saga Bay tennis tournament.

The women's liberation movement came briefly to the Yonkers Rotary Club this afternoon, leaving most of the Rotarians "shaken up a bit," in the words of one, but decidedly unreconstructed.
Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of Labor, expressed today views on key labor issues that diverged sharply from past Administration policies.
The Federal Government is moving toward sharp reduction in amphetamine production quotas for the second straight year.

Those two prime jewels in the crown of Madison Square Garden Corporation, the Knicks and the Rangers, found themselves breakfasting in the same hotel coffee shop this morning, underlying the similarities between the two teams.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
Orlando Cepeda was signed by the Boston Red Sox today, ostensibly to fill the designated pinch-hitter role the club originally had opposed.

Edward Skloot, a 30-year-old assistant to Mayor Lindsay, and Herschel Post, a 33-year-old former executive director of the Parks Council, have been appointed chiefs of staff by the city's new parks administrator, Richard M. Clurman.

Three persons were arrested yesterday in the theft of jewels insured for $100,000 from a church in Brooklyn on Jan. 10. The jewels were not immediately recovered, but Chief of Detectives Louis Cottell said, "We're in the process of doing that now, we hope."

The lessons of the eleven-day bombing blitz against the Hanoi-Haiphong area are under intensive study in the Pentagon. The loss of fifteen B-52 bombers and thirteen other aircraft in the attacks against the industrial-economiccommunications heartland of North Vietnam surprised the American public.

The Congressional effort to protect newsmen from forced disclosure of their sources gained momentum on both sides of the. Capitol today with the introduction of new freedomof-information bills.
A jury of 10 men and two women today convicted Juan V. Corona, a 38-year-old Mexican national, of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers.

The-Southern California Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1972. Jack K. Horton, chairman and chief executive officer, placed net income at $137-million, or 8 per cent higher than the $127-million earned in 1971.
The Army said today that it was investigating a charge, later diluted, that a drill sergeant had ordered trainees to kick a recruit who had suffered a fatal heart attack while on a march.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation declined in its third fiscal quarter but at a lower rate than in the two previous quarters, according to a report issued yesterday by the producer of packaged foods.

Accompanied by Federal narcotics agents who took custody of him in Kabul, Afghanistan, Dr. Timothy Leary was flown to Los Angeles yesterday. Leary, once a leader of drug cultists, was detained by Afghan authorities and delivered to the American agents, although there is no extradition treaty between the United States and Afghanistan.

Sales, costs, prices and profits are likely to continue going up; according to the 14th annual economic survey conducted among the 13,500 member concerns of the New Jersey Manufacturers Association.

The Republicans kicked off their $4-million celebration of President Nixon's second inauguration today with a giant reception at the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology honoring Vice President Agnew.

A jury of 10 men and two women today convicted Juan V. Corona, a 38-year-old Mexican national, of murdering 25 itinerant farm workers. The jury deliberated almost one week before deciding that Corona, a labor contractor, was guilty.

An amicable settlement was achieved today before an official East German tribunal in an industrial dispute between an American importing company, the I.M.I. Machinery Corporation of New York, claiming delivery of deficient machines, and Unitechna, the East German state enterprise that sold them.

Butch Komives tossed in a pair of free throws tonight after the final horn had sounded, giving the Buffalo Braves a 127-125 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

The Western and Southern railroads said today they expect to file a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission on Monday for authority to Issue an emergency surcharge increasing freight rates by 2 per cent within the two territories with certain exceptions.

Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said tonight that African tribesmen in northeastern Rhodesia had been helping African nationalist guerrillas operating against Rhodesia from a sanctuary in neighboring Zambia.

Two adults and five children were slain late today in a house once owned by Kareem AbdulJabbar, the professional basketball player, and used as headquarters by a sect of the Muslim religion to which he belonged.

By precisely the same lopsided vote as before, members of the City Council have again approved an unconscionable reapportionment plan. This time their action was taken to override Mayor Lindsay's thoroughly warranted veto of a scheme that expands the number of Council seats from 37 to 43 without doing anything useful to overcome that body's glaring deficiencies.

The discovery of the bodies of two young men floating in the Hudson River off Greenwich Village added yesterday to the fears of the homosexual community, already stunned by three recent murders of homosexual in the area.

Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a $10.7-billion statewide bank holding company system based in Buffalo, reported yesterday a slim, nine-tenths of one percent, increase in its operating earnings in 1972 as compared with the preceding year.
Gerry Meehan scored two goals tonight and Hugh Harris netted one and picked up three assists as the Buffalo Sabres triumphed over the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-1, in a National Hockey League game.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to give $15-million in back pay and $23-million a year in raises to women and minority males against whom it had allegedly discriminated in job assignments, pay and promotions.

Gov. Ronald Reagan presented the California State Legislature today with a budget of $9.258billion, regaining for California the lead from New York as the state with the highest budget. Governor Rockefeller has proposed a spending program of $8.88-billion the next fiscal year.

Postmaster General Elmer T Klassen formally proposed to day six changes in the Postal Service's mail classification system including one that requires a surcharge for firstclass mailings that are not of standard size.

William J. O'Brien, a founding partner of Alexander Grant Co., an international company of certified public accountants, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital, Miami, of complications following heart surgery. He was 65 years old and lived at 2 Tudor City Place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Two of the Saigon Government's strongest supporters in the United States Senate--Barry Goldwater and John C. Stennis--urged the Government today not to create obstacles to a peace agreement between the United States and North Vietnam.
Mrs. Kitty Torch Chayes, a lawyer for the Office of Economic Opportunity, died in Doctor's Hospital early this morning. She was 74 years old.

A bribery-trial jury in Federal Court here listened yesterday to several hours of taperecorded conversations about fixing a criminal case in Queens. The case was allegedly fixed for $15,000 last spring by Norman D. Archer, a 52-year-old prosecutor who headed the indictment bureau in the office of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

The State Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal by John J. Kenny, former Hudson County freeholder, to have a state extortion charge dismissed. Kenny's lawyer, Donald Robinson, has been seeking to have the indictment quashed on the ground that Kenny had received complete immunity from prosecution in return for his testimony at a Federal trial of former Hudson County and Jersey City officials in 1971.

MOSCOW, Friday, Jan. 19--The Soviet Union and its East European allies have proposed an enlargement of the East-West talks on force reduction Scheduled to begin on Jan 31 to include "all interested European nations" plus the United States and Canada.

The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 14.5 billion ton-miles, 3.1 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 469,697, up 0.7 per cent from last year.

"Concertd for Piano and Winds" is a weak ballet, and its contribution to the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival last June, like that of other minor works in that event, was to help fill out an aural biography of the composer.

Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. left Saigon yesterday with President Nguyen Van Thieu's agreement to the general principles of a cease-fire accord but without resolving disagreements on several questions of carrying out the accord, a source close to the negotiations said today.

President Nixon's curtailment of funds provided by new Federal Clean Waters legislation, as well as restrictions in the new law, are delaying the appropriation of millions of dollars of state bond funds for dozens of new sewage treatment facilities in New York State.
Money and credit continue to increase at historically high rates, data released by the Federal Reserve System showed yesterday.

Two municipal agencies that review work conditions and minority employment in private industry have been consolidated into a new Bureau of Labor Services, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
Cecil W. Tate, an insurance adjuster here for more than 40 years, died Wednesday in Portla Valley, Calif., where he lived. His age was 88. Mr. Tate had been with Pitcher Tate here.
Encouraged by the result of his first race in 11 months, Marty Liquori will embark on an ambitious track and field assignment tonight and tomorrow afternoon.
Having been backed up by large orchestras in his two previous appearances here this season, Janos Starker chose to have the stage all to himself Wednesday night at Tully Hall.

John H. Shaffer has been up in the air for the last four years as Federal Aviation Administrator. Now the 53-year-old executive is leaving his $42,500-a-year government job to manage a moving company in the Washington area that he purchased five years ago.

The Senate Democratic Caucus resolved today to make "Cabinet officers and other officials" of the Nixon Administration subject to possible contempt-ofCongress citations if they should refuse to appear and testify before Senate committees.
The United States today signed an agreement with Yugoslavia to assist and encourage capitalist investment in joint ventures-the first such accord with a Communist country.

Oil and other energy issues, together with some leading glamours, were star performers in a generally flat stock market yesterday. The Dow-Jones industrial average, ahead by more than 5 points in the morning, finished unchanged at 1,029.12.

The Swedish Royal Opera marked its 200th anniversary tonight with a new opera about its ill-fated founder, King Gustav III. The work, "Tintomara," was composed by Lars Johan Werle and is based on the last days of the king who was shot in the back at a midnight masquerade in the Stockholm Opera House on March 16, 1792.

It is fashionable in southern Africa and elsewhere to dismiss with contempt the efforts of black Africans to sustain guerrilla movements against entrenched white minority governments. NEWARK, Jan. 18--The New Jersey college basketball coaches agreed at their weekly meeting here today that the relaxation of the 1.6 rule by the National Collegiate Athletic Association would hurt junior colleges more than anybody else. Most of the coaches said, however, that the new rule did not affect their schools because the schools had their own rules and regulations in recruiting and awarding scholarships.

Now, with something of the amazement of the early microscopists when they discovered undreamed-of "animalcules" in a gob of spit, scientists are exploring the surprising world of our own skins.

The "Odalisque," whose attribution the Metropolitan Museum has said will change from Ingres to a lesser-known artist, is only one of about 300 Old Master paintings that the institution has downgraded in a major re-evaluation of its collection.

The National Transportation Safety Board called today for stronger and more reliable braking systems for trucks. In a study of commercial motor vehicle braking, the board said that the longer stopping distances required by trucks, as contrasted with automobiles, "pose a serious threat to passenger cars and their occupants."

Amid exceptional security measures, Italy's neo-Fascist party opened a four-day national convention here today in a bid to be accepted by public opinion as a reputable and responsible political movement.

Bernie Williams pushed the Virginia Squires in front and Julius Erving held off the Denver Rockets by hitting seven of eight free throws in the final 46 seconds to give the Squires a 116-110 American Basketball Association victory tonight.

The Staten Island Democratic County Committee last night elected James A. Smith, as county leader. Mr. Smith is a 61-year-old retired municipal worker and served briefly last year as a City Councilman.

The United States and North Vietnam announced yesterday that they would resume their private peace talks in Paris next Tuesday "for the purpose of completing the text of an agreement." Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and scores of state and local policemen searched wooded Ozark hill country today for extortionists who bound a banker, his wife and their 17-year-old daughter to trees and shot them to death yesterday.

Speaking with the reflective and detached air of an elder statesman, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner told the City Charter Revision Commission yesterday that the city's basic problems would not be changed by rewriting its laws of government.

After six and one-half hours of deliberation, a Federal Court jury of six men and six women convicted Francis M. Goodell yesterday of hijacking a Pacific Southwest Airlines jet last July 6.

D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, pleaded guilty today to one count of a 47-count Federal indictment charging him with conspiring to use interstate commerce facilities to commit bribery and extortion.
The New York Raiders withstood three power-play goals by Quebec and rallied three times tonight to gain a 4-4 tie with the Nordiques in a World Hockey Association game that went overtime.

Lawrence Tierney, the film actor, was stabbed in the stomach yesterday afternoon in an altercation that began in a West Side bar and continued on the street. He was reported in satisfactory condition last night at St. Clare's Hospital.

All through the sunny day and into the twilight, buzzards wheel in watchful circles over National Stadium, but this is not construed as an omen having to do with Joe Frazier or George Foreman. Joe and George will be swatting each other in Kingston's tidy playpen Monday night, but in spite of press agents' efforts to rile them for the sake of the box office, neither has been shouting about leaving the other for dead.
Robert D. Huntington Jr., vice president of Trident Managers, insurance brokers in Manhasset, L. I., died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived on Mill Road in Oyster Bay.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi ordered the central Government to take control of Andhra Pradesh to day, following the collapse of the state government under pressure of violent separatist agitations.

The "Odalisque," whose attribution the Metropolitan Museum has said will change from Ingres to a lesser-known artist, is only one of about 300 Old Master paintings that the institution has downgraded in a major re-evaluation of its collection.

Ten restaurants and other food-handling establishments are on the latest list of violators of the city's Health Code. Each failed to correct violations between the time of first and second inspections,
North Korea today put forth five demands for United States actions toward the reunification of Korea, including the withdrawal' of all American troops from South Korea.

Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., said yesterday it would buy all of the 854,920 shares of its common stock tendered by stockholders. The offer, which expired Jan. 10, originally covered the purchase of up to 500,000 shares at $35.50 per share. The company's stock closed at 35, up 1 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mayor Lindsay plans to appoint a strong local task force to deal with the problems of crime and single-room-occupancy buildings on the West Side. In an interview, he said it would be similar to the one that tackled pornography and prostitution in the Times Square area.
Some 400 employes of the Norden division of the United Aircraft Corporation here have been notified that they will be laid off starting tomorrow and continuing through the end of January.

Federal authorities in Brooklyn announced narcotics conspiracy charges yesterday against eight men and two women in what they described as the largest heroin retailing operation in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, and possibly in the city.

Last month, Corinna Marsh, retired and living at 12 East 31st Street on a small pension, sent the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund a check for $5, regretting at the time that it represented only half of her "usual" $10.
Given the number of years Pilar Lorengar has been singing with the Metropolitan Opera, it is surprising that she did not get around to the role of Mimi in Puccini's "La Boheme" until Tuesday night.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed today to give $15-million in back pay and $23-million a year in raises to women and minority males against whom it had allegedly discriminated in job assignments, pay and promotions.

That creed helped carry a tough little kid named James Riddle Hoffa from the loading dock of a Detroit grocery warehouse to the presidency of the country's biggest and strongest union.
Higher income limits have been set for entry into public housing projects in the city in an effort to keep them from becoming economic and racial ghettos, Simeon Golar announced yesterday.

Tarsila do Amaral, a leading Brazilian painter, died yesterday in Sao Paulo. She was 82 years old. The artist studied in the Sacre Coeur De Marie school of Barcelona in 1920. She went to Paris and there met such artists as Fernand Leger.

MR. ZIEGLER: The President continues today to work at the office at the residence on his Inaugural Address and the. State of the Union Message and other messages that will be sent to Congress in the coming weeks.

Time magazine, with statistics gleaned from the 1970 census, is prepared to back its claim of circulation concentration in affluent neighborhoods and, in effect, is challenging other media to try to match it.

Alex Rose is probably the only politician who could meet with Governor Rockefeller and talk about a mayoral campaign coalition and then, six days later, meet with the Governor's bitter enemy, Mayor Lindsay, and talk about the same subject.
The rabbi who will pray for President Nixon at the inauguration tomorrow plans to pronounce the blessing that the Talmud prescribes when one sees a king and his court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18--Two adults and five children were slain late today in a house once owned by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the professional basketball player, and used as headquarters by a sect of the Muslim religion to which he belonged.
The Air Force today selected Fairchild Industries, Inc., to produce at its Farmingdale, L. I., plant a new combat aircraft designed exclusively for providing close air support to front-line troops.

Earl Whittaker, a correction officer, who had been accused of 27 counts of kidnapping, unlawful imprisonment, criminal solicitation and obstructing governmental administration, was acquitted of all charges yesterday.
The New York Times Company has acquired for cash the assets of the Marco Island Publishing Corporation from William R. Tamplin and Raymond Henle, it was announced yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today to ease restrictions on advertising by mutual funds and other investment companies. While retaining the "tombstone" or bare bones format of advertising as in the past,
Justin Miller, a law dean who had served from 1945 to 1951 as president of the National Association of Broadcasters, died yesterday, in a convalescent hospital in Santa Monica. He was 84 years old.

The Clock, a sleek, black gelding, will travel 700 miles to prance down some 20 blocks of Pennsylvania Avenue on Saturday. It will be his fifth consecutive inaugural parade, and he was brought out of retirement to do it.

John J. Furey, manager of the advertising acceptability department of The New York Times, died Wednesday evening of a heart attack in the Ely Avenue Queens, station of the IND subway line. He was 55 years old and lived in Lynbrook, L. I.

The United States Treasury today welcomed Tokyo's announced intention to repay earlier than required aid advanced to Japan in the immediate postwar years.
Eugene L. Wyman, a prominent fund raiser for the Democratic party, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his law office here today. He was 47 years old.
International Business Machines and selected energy issues moved higher yesterday, while the general stock market staged a mild retreat.
Peter Berdeshevsky, a sugar chemist and industrialist, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 39 East 12th Street. He was 78 years old.
The nation's total output, as measured by the Gross National Product, rose 6.5 per cent last year and inflation was at the lowest rate since 1966, the Commerce Department reported today.

The second installment of the new biennial exhibition of American art at the Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, opened to the public this week, and already shows ample evidence of being an exhibition of exceptional interest.
An agent's voice was heard counting out $14,500 for alleged fixers on a tape recording played yesterday at the bribery trial of a Queens prosecutor, a lawyer and a bail bondsman's associate.

Judge Joseph C. Hutcheson Jr. of United States District Court, first appointed to the Federal bench by President Wilson in 1918, died yesterday at the age of 93. He was chief judge of the Fifth United States Circuit of Appeals from 1948 to 1959, and although he retired in 1964, he sat on the bench here as late as 1968.
The morning, boat from Scotland docks at Larne a few minutes after dawn and the passengers switch to the tiny shore train to Belfast.

The Rev. Dr. Erich F. Voehringer, retired missionary, author and pastor of Grace and St. Paul's Lutheran Church at 123 West 71st Street in New York from 1940 to 1943, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Redding Hospital.

The Air Force disclosed today that a second pilot has been charged with refusing to fly a combat mission against North Vietnam during the heavy bombing campaign last month.
