Four robbers trapped in a Brooklyn sporting goods store with an arsenal of weapons and 11 terrified hostages shot and killed a patrolman and wounded two others last night in a raging gun battle with hundreds of encircling policemen.
The Belgian Government ordered all gasoline stations closed this weekend as the nation faced a worsening fuel crisis because of a week-long strike by oil-refinery workers.
Mrs. Dorothy Rogovin Renard, an associate of D.T.A. Publicity, a fashion and cosmetics public relations concern, died, apparently of a heart attack, at her home, 110 Riverside Drive, on Thursday.

LONDON-To most of us it now seems very strange, almost incomprehensible, that for centuries gross hereditary inequalities of wealth, status and power were universally accepted as a divinely ordained fact of life.

The country's most prestigious second-hand-goods bazaar, stocking wares from New England barns, imperial Chinese palaces and just about everything in between, opened yesterday for a 10day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street.
Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad voted today to omit the dividend on its series "A" preferred stock.
A handbook with 276 pages of New York City telephone numbers-ranging from emergency services to bus information - will be appearing in bookstores here beginning late next week.

The Government published new state of emergency regulations today that allow white provincial commissioners to impose collective fines on African communities without court hearings, or listening to arguments from those affected.
Freshman Republican Representatives from the New York metropolitan area generally fared well in the House committee assignment handed out this week.
The British Government ordered a fast ocean-going tug to head for Iceland today to protect British trawlers inside Iceland's disputed 50-mile fishing limit.

All natural gas supplied by the Long Island Lighting Company to 250 of its largest industrial customers has been turned off since last Nov. 1, the longest such period in the history of the company, sources there disclosed today.

Two and a half years after having left the chancellorship of Fordham University to work with educationally deprived students at a small black college in North Carolina, the Rev. Leo McLaughlin is off on a new academic adventure.
Bazaar de la Cuisine, at 1003 Second Avenue (53d Street), is one of those shops that leaves you convinced, after a few minutes of looking around, that your kitchen is ridiculously underequipped.

Soviet ground controllers maneuvered the Lunokhod 2 moon robot along the moon's sea of Serenity and made soil tests showing that it is a relatively young area of the lunar surface the news agency Tass said today.

The Internal Revenue Service filed a $145,657 tax lien today against John Armellino, former Mayor of West New York, who is serving a four-year jail term for bribery-conspiracy.

A handbook with 276 pages of telephone numbers for city agencies, consumer information, business advice and more than 600 other categories will be appearing in bookstores next week. It has been put out by radio station WMCA's Call for Action. based on its 10 years of directing people with problems to the. place where they can be taken care of.
Six Italian bridge experts who hold one world team title are suing the nonplaying captain of the Aces, an American group that holds the other world title, for $500,000.
The Bank of England reduced today its minimum-lending rate which had been Britain's highest since the outbreak of World War I in August, 1914.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a technical ingredient in the stock market outlook, declined sharply in the month ended Jan. 15, the Big Board reported yesterday.

Four robbers trapped in a Brooklyn sporting goods store with an arsenal of weapons and 11 terrified hostages shot and killed a patrolman and wounded two others last night in a raging gun battle with hundreds of encircling policemen.

Five present or former operators of sex-oriented bookstores and coin - operated "adult movies" in the Times Square area have filed a $4-million damage suit charging their landlords and the city with a conspiracy to put them out of business.

President Nguyen Van Thieu's only daughter married the son of a wealthy airline executive today in South Vietnam's most lavish social event of recent years.

A 16-year-old boy was indicted yesterday for murder and attempted robbery in connection with the fatal stabbing of a retired policeman in a subway station in the Times Square area. The boy, Kevin McDow, of 215 West 135th Street, is scheduled to be arraigned Monday, according to a spokesman for the District Attorney's office.
Gillis Villemure, in the Rangers' goal for the first time since Dec., 27, notched his first shutout of the National Hockey League season tonight as New York beat the California Golden Seals, 6-0.
Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird called today for the negotiation of an agreement between the Soviet Union, China and the United States to hold down future deliveries of weapons to Vietnam.

"Good Grief!" cried the headline in yesterday's Boston Globe. In years to come people probably will remember what they were doing on that Thursday night when they heard the news: New York Islanders 9, Boston 7.

John Jay Iselin will be named acting president of television Channel 13 to succeed James Day, who resigned as president Thursday, citing "irreconcilable differences" with the television station's board chairman, Ethen Allen Hitchcock.

City Councilman Edward Sadowsky actually described the position of the Council majority in dubbing as a "cynical political gesture" Mayor Lindsay's fully warranted veto of an outrageous councilmanic reapportionment scheme. The cynicism, the politics and the gesture were all far more on the Council's side than on the Mayor's; and the Council proved the point by passing it over Mr. Lindsay's veto.
The speaker of this nation's House of Representatives ruled today that a bill to control the press of Sri Lanka was unconstitutional.

Telephone company workers reacted with expressions of confusion, anger and considerable skepticism yesterday to news that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had agreed to give back pay and raises to minority-group and women employes against whom it allegedly discriminated..

Prices began to move up this week in a variety of industries following the loosening of economic controls nine days ago by the Nixon Administration. Probably the most significant increase was one of three-quarters of a cent a gallon in the wholesale price of No. 2 fuel oil, announced yesterday by the Mobil Oil Corporation.

President Nixon will be sworn into office for a second term tomorrow, emboldened by his sweeping electoral triumph of last November and a Vietnam peace settlement apparently within his grasp.

The chairman of the State Mediation Commission, acting as an arbitrator, awarded higher commissions for new taxi drivers yesterday in settling the final terms of a longdelayed contract between 70 fleet owners here and their 30,000 drivers.

The Wachovia Corporation, a one-bank holding company based in Winston-Salem, N.C., and parent of the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company, reported yesterday that its operating earnings in 1972 increased 6.4 per cent to $31.6-million, or $2.17 per share, from $29.8million, or $2.04 per share for 1971.

Two years in the Navy, where he experienced racial bullying and harassment such as he had never known back home in Emporia, Kan., produced in Mark James Robert Essex a deep and festering hatred of white society.

George E. McDonald, president of the New York Mailers Union, No. 6, said yesterday that a dispute over early terrmination of a three-year contract with the city's four major daily newspapers would be submitted to arbitration.
Sparky Lyle, the Yankees' most valuable player last season, has suffered a torn ligament in his right ankle while playing basketball, the team learned yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ford 2d did their best to add a little excitement to the inaugural celebration and, in their way, they succeeded. They managed to have Henry A. Kissinger and Martha Mitchell in the same room at the same time kissing each other.

The world heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, concluded training today and predicted he would knock out George Foreman in their title fight here Monday night "I don't think George can go 15 with what I'm gonna put on him," said Frazier. Clyde C. Ruffle, general manager of environmental affairs for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 52.

President Nixon's pre-inaugural announcement that Henry Kissinger will return to Paris Tuesday "for the purpose of completing the text of an agreement" once more raises hope that the end of the Indochina war-or at least the end of United States involvement-is imminent. Nothing could be more auspicious for the beginning of Mr. Nixon's second term.
An inquiry into the art swap between the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Marlborough galleries has uncovered curious legal and commercial problems.
A $2-million libel suit brought by the California scientist in charge of tests for the ill-fated space flight in 1969 of Bonny, a pigtailed monkey, goes to trial in Federal Court here Monday.
Farmers intend to plant 7 per cent more corn and 5 per cent more soybeans for harvest this year, the Agriculture Department said today.

Citizens here and throughout this Jersey Shore area are used to such things. Ever since its founding in 1965, the Shore Athletic Club has staged numerous track and field events, ranging from 50-yard dashes to 50-mile walking races.

South Vietnamese troops have begun a series of offensive thrusts on several fronts, apparently in an attempt to improve their positions before a cease-fire goes into effect, it was reported yesterday.
George Bush, a Connecticut aristocrat who became a Texas oil millionaire, took the reins of the Republican party organization today in an unchallenged but sometimes uncheerful transition.
Dr. S. Smith Stevens, an authority on the physics of sensory perception, died today at Vail, Colo., where he had gone to attend a conference on brain research. He was 66 years old.

GREENWICH, Conn.-When William T. Grant died last August, he blessed Greenwich Hospital with a gift-his mansion on Long Island Sound. But the hospital has discovered that the blessing is mixed. Zoning restrictions rule out the use of the property for a hospital, though that was not the purpose of the gift in any event. The hospital wants to sell the house and its 12.3 acres of land.

Two land developers convicted of selling a fake interview with a hijacker called "D. B. Cooper" for $30,000 were sentenced yesterday to Federal prison terms. The 12:10 A.M. to Jamaica, the first regular train to operate since the Long Island Rail Road was struck by 12 unions seven weeks ago, pulled out of Pennsylvania Station on time yesterday with a tired but happy threeman crew and some 30 uncertain passengers.

Easy conditions on the first stage of the Monte Carlo rally gave drivers few problems today. Prospecting and mining of minerals in Minnesota's Boundary Waters Canoe Area have been prohibited by a United States District Court decision that may offer a new protective shield for the nation's wilderness preserves. Those holding leases to mineral rights within the one-million-acre Canoe Area are permanently enjoined from direct or indirect exploration for the rich copper and nickel deposits that are known to lie there.

Any. safety program in the New York City school system must "emphasize human relations factors". rather than "punitive factors" if it is to have long-range benefits, according to a study released yesterday by the Board of Education.
Miss Rose-Marie Cavallo of New York and Robert Crace Ray of Weston, were married here this afternoon by Msgr Andrew Hajus in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

Woodrow G. (Woody) Gatehouse has been elected to his second successive term as president of the National Horse Show. The show's board of directors made the announcement the other day, adding that all other officers from last year had also been elected for another term.

Pete Rozelle, pro football commissioner, said today that sites for the 1975 Super Bowl and Pro Bowl would be selected next April at a National Football League meeting in Arizona.

A continuing decline in reller rolls across New York Statedown 39,546 persons, or 2 per cent, from last March's record--has led Abe Lavine, State Commissioner of Social Services, to describe the situation as a "trend toward stabilization."

The countdown is at four for Paul Smith, Rutgers Prep's basketball wizard. When Smith, a 6-foot-7-inch center, started his senior year last fall, there were 248 colleges recruiting him. Today, after long and tedious interviews with recruiters from all over the country, Smith has narrowed the field down to four-Rutgers, Fordham, Boston College and Notre Dame and not necessarily in that order.

Otto Tschudl, a former Denver University star by way of Norefjll, Norway, scored his first victory as a professional today by winning the slalom of the $20,000 Benson Hedges 100's Grand Prix at the Hunter Ski Bowl.
W. Rutherford Lane, who founded the Lane Paper Co. in Charlotte, died yesterday. He was 78 years old. Mr. Lane, who graduated from Colgate University, was a former resident of New York.
Zygmunt Nagorski, former president of the Warsaw Bar Association and of the Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences in America, died Saturday in Ossining, N.Y., where he had lived. He was 88 years old.

Three years ago, Stanford University students staged an antiwar sit-in at the university's administration building. Rear Adm. Kenmore McManes, former commandant of the Sixth Naval District and the Charleston (S. C.) Naval Base, died yesterday at his home here. He was 72 years old. Admiral McManes, who retired in 1962 after 44 years of service, became Sixth District commandant in 1959.

Lieut. Gen. Karl S. Day, Marine Corps Reserve, retired, a pioneer of Marine Corps aviation, died Friday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 76 years old and lived here. General Day was credited with pioneering advances and innovations in Navy and Marine Corps aviation in instrument flying and radio navigation.

Bernie Wells soared from the 50-meter ski-jumping slope today with the longest leap of the season. He covered 161 feet in the jumpoff to win the Mount Beacon Ski Club tournament. The 161-foot leap also equaled Wells's previous best jump made two years ago.

South Vietnamese forces made two attempts yesterday to recover wounded soldiers held prisoner by the Vietcong 40 miles northwest of Saigon but were attacked both times, senior officials disclosed today. The Southern Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1972. The preliminary annual report placed operating revenues at $983.2-million, up 18.7 per cent from the year-earlier $828.7-million.

Stock prices continued to drop yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in restrained trading. Prices in both markets have been mostly declining for more than a week.

Thich Thien Hoa, the leader of the once-militant An Quang faction of the United Buddhist Church, died today. The 55-year-old monk had been hospitalized for a month, reportedly with a heart ailment.
Donald C. Carroll, who was appointed in 1971 to reform the Hempstead, L. I. office of the Federal Housing Administration, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years' imprisonment for accenting bribes.
John Unitas, the quarterback who will be 40 years old on May 7, was traded yesterday by the Baltimore Colts to the San Diego Chargers for what both sides said were "future [considerations."

United States District Court Judge Frederick Bernard Lacey was reported today to be ready to resign from the bench, possibly when the current court session recesses for the summer at the end of June. People in a position to know said that Mr. Lacey was considering joining a New York City law firm.
Lyndon Baines Johnson, 36th President of the United States, died today of an apparent heart attack suffered at his ranch in Johnson City, Tex.

George Foreman, the new world heavyweight boxing champion, had to be carried bodily from the ring tonight at National Stadium. It was less than 100 yards back to his dressing room, but he never could have made it under his own power.
Steel production for the week ended Jan. 20 hit its highest level since the week that ended May 29, 1971, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported.

Nicholas Johnson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that the Nixon Administration's proposed broadcast legislation was "a very simple deal" designed to keep material unfavorable to the Administration off the air.

Unemployment among veterans of the Vietnam war era fell substantially in 1972, the Labor Department said today. The rate dropped from 8.1 per cent in December, 1971, to 5.5 per cent last month, which was lower than the rate for male nonveterans of the same age.

Indiana strengthened its bid for the Big Ten basketball title tonight by defeating Michigan State 97-89. The Hoosiers now own a 4-0 wonlost record in Big Ten play. The Spartans stand 2-3.

For the series "An American Family," currently being presented on the Public Broadcasting Service, the William C. Loud family permitted television crews to film its daily life from May, 1971, to the following New Year's Eve.

Two Swedish members of an international group invited by North Vietnam to inspect bomb damage said on their return here today that about 20 per cent of Hanoi was destroyed by American B-52 raids last month.

I didn't realize I whupped Joe Frazier so bad," said Muhammad Ali tonight after learning George Fore. man was the new titleholder. The former champion, who was interviewed at his training camp here, said he was asleep when an aide woke him with the news.

LANDGROVE, Vt.-The rate of suicide, both successful and unsuccessful, is on the increase, and being among the number of those who recently attempted it but failed, I assume for myself the right, or rather the duty, to speak on the subject, hazarding a guess at the same time for the reasons for this ominous trend.

State police investigators reported tonight that the alleged conspiracy to frame a Democratic New Jersey legislator by planting drugs in his home may be connected with a libel suit filed by the victim against three prominent Gloucester County Republicans.
The Norfolk western Railway reported yesterday a 17 per cent gain in operating earnings for 1972, but extraordinary charges sliced deeply into net profits.
Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight, and it was announced that his talks tomorrow with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam would be moved to the ceremonial setting of the International Conference Center.
Julian Moreno, an Argentine labor leader and Peronist candidate for Congress, was assassinated today less than 24 hours after his party had opened its campaign for the general elections in March.

The four men seized in the 47hour weekend siege and shootout at a Brooklyn Sportinggoods store were held without bail yesterday on charges of murdering a policeman-which could lead to a death penaltyand of kidnapping 10 hostages.

A judge was mentioned, but not by name, in a narcotics discussion on a tape recording played yesterday at the trial of a Queens prosecutor and two co-defendants accused of sharing a $15,000 bribe to fix a gun-possession case.

A pair of Wisconsin sailors walked off with the year's top yachting laurels given yesterday by Martini Rossi to the sport's outstanding male and female for 1972. Harry C. (Bud) Melges of Zenda, Wis., was named yachtsman of the year, and Mrs. Jane Pegel of Williams Bay, Wis., yachtswoman.

What do we make of a 27year-old soprano whose debut recital in New York comes under Lincoln Center's Great Performers banner? Or whose triumphant moments can range so widely in style and technical demands as to Include both the subtly witty songs of Satie and the heavy outpourings of Wagner?
The nation's largest mass appraisal company, which sets values for property tax purposes, described today as "irresponsible" charges that its work in Westmoreland -County, Pa., was "suspect."

The Assembly today approved a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would permit a defendant in a felony caseother than a case punishable by the death penalty or life imprisonment -- to waive indictment by a grand jury and to consent to be prosecuted on an information filed by the District Attorney.

Three bettors came to the rescue of a Boston race track Sunday after Wells Fargo was locked out of its safe and unable to deliver $600,000 to Suffolk Downs. The horseplayers loaned the track $1,000 each to help pay off the winners of the first three races.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company observed its 70th anniversary in 1972 with record annual and fourth-quarter sales and earnings, the broadly diversified manufacturer reported yesterday from St. Paul headquarters.
The Supreme Court overruled today all state laws that prohibit or restrict a woman's right to obtain an abortion luring her first three months of pregnancy. The vote was 7 to 2.
Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, called on the nation's bankers yesterday to exercise "restraint" in extending commitments to make loans in the future.

The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, the second largest bank in that city, reported yesterday sharp increases in its operating earnings for both the fourth quarter and the full year of 1972.
Last summer, George Foreman told Joe Frazier: "God blesses me with the ability to take away your title. It won't go to waste. I'll make good use of it."
Army lost a 20-yard runback after a kickoff by Duke in the second half of their football game in 1967 when Charlie Jarvis of Army shaded his eyes from the sun just before receiving the kicked ball.

The new Labor parts Prime Ministers of Australia and New Zealand, meeting for the first time as heads of governments, today hailed the ANZUS mutual-security treaty between their countries and the United States as a stabilizing and progressive force in Asia and the Pacific.

"I SHALL not seek, and I will not accept, the nomination of my party for another term as your President," Lyndon Baines Johnson told a startled nationwide television audience the night of March 31, 1968.

The home of the producer of an X-rated film has been searched by the Passaic County Prosecutor's office in an apparent attempt to find evidence of fornication, adultery or conspiracy to commit a crime.

Reaction to the Supreme Court decision on abortion fragmented yesterday along predictable lines, as leaders of the Roman Catholic Church assailed the ruling while birth control and women's rights activists praised it.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn overturned yesterday in a 4-to-1 decision a Westchester County State Supreme Court ruling that had enjoined the Dobbs Ferry Medical Pavilion, Inc., from performing abortions.

The Hamburg State Court lifted an injunction against the delivery of 3,500 tons of Chilean copper ore today in a ruling against the Kennecott Copper Corporation. The ore from the former Kennecott Mines nationalized by Chile's Socialist Government had arrived aboard a Soviet freighter at the wharf of the North German Refinery.
President Nixon's chief campaign fund-raiser, Maurice H. Stans, has denounced as "absolutely ridiculous" some provisions of the law requiring disclosure of political finances and contributions.

A public school in a high crime area of the East New York section of Brooklyn was renamed yesterday for Patrolman Robert Bolden, who was killed on Jan. 22, 1971. P.S. 345, at 111 Berriman Street, and formerly called the Liberty School, became the Patrolman Robert Bolden School.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Rick Barry, two of basketball's greatest stars, definitely won't play in tomorrow night's 23d Annual National Basketball Association All-Star game, to be televised nationally (Channel 7 in New York) at 9 P.M. New York time.
We had heard about the energy crisis, of course, but had not expected it to strike so close to home. You never do. It's always the other fellow's neighborhood that will get it, you tell yourself.
Ruled that states cannot prohibit voluntary abortions during the first three months of pregnancy when, the Court said, the decision should be left to the woman and her doctor.

The Minnesota Fighting Saints built a good lead in the opening period, . yielded in the second, then struck quickly in the final session to defeat the New York Raiders, 3-2, in a World Hockey Association game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Stuart M. Sperry, a retired investment broker who was a member of the New York Stock Exchange for 30 years, died today at Lawrence Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived here.
House Democrats made a hefty dent in the seniority system today, voting to make all committee chairmen subject to an automatic vote of the party caucus.

A West German Cabinet minister who is both a dedicated "European" and a staunch defender of the Atlantic Alliance has made a proposal that could help resolve differences on trade and other matters between the United States and the European Economic Community.
More than $100,000 was recorded yesterday by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in gifts, legacies and trust fund payments, bringing the total raised so far to nearly $970,000.
In a gloomy broadcast this evening, the Saigon radio said that the cease-fire agreement believed to be near completion "will not likely bring us a genuine and lasting peace."

23-Seven thousand people were being evacuated from an offshore Icelandid island early today as a volcano that had, been quiet for more than a thousand years erupted Police authorities on the tiny island of Heimaey, one of a group off the south coast of Iceland, said boats and planes were being used to get the in habitants of the town of Vestmannaeyjar to safety on the mainland.

Four members of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the new seven-man fulltime salaried body that will set the rules for corporate reports, were named yesterday as the auditing profession-somewhat more slowly than it had hoped--moved to set up new machinery.

South Vietnamese troops throughout the country have been put on full alert and security measures here and in the other major cities are being sharply intensified in anticipation of Communist attacks before the expected signing of a cease-fire agreement.

Governor Rockefeller held a news conference today on his controversial proposals on drug trafficking, and presented five Harlem leaders who, he said, supported his idea of mandated life prison sentences for illicit drug dealers. The bill was hailed by the group as a necessary means for protecting their community from "blood - thirsty, moneyhungry, death-dealing criminals."

"Hike!" the driver yelled and 14 growling dogs burst off the starting line in the fourth annual All-American Championship Sled Dog Races. Their breath made steamy little clouds in the frigid air as the teams raced the clock yesterday, lunging across 16.5 miles of brushlands, forests and frozen lakes.
A teen-ager working on a car in the driveway of a friend's house was shot in the leg late last night by his friend's

Shock, sorrow and the sense of a historic leader lost were the mourning themes of public officialss and private citizens across the nation last night as Ford spread that Lyndon Baines Johnson was dead.

"Hit the bag!" a photographeryelled at a stocky Russian yesterday in the New York Athletic Club, where the Soviet Union boxing team tuned up for its match against American amateurs next Saturday in Las Vegas.

Eugene G. Statter, former president of the New York Securities Dealers Association who managed the over-the-counter trading department of MabonNugent Co., stockbrokers, died yesterday at his home, 20 Korwel Circle in West Orange, N. J. He was 66 years old.
Henry A. Kissinger arrived here tonight, and it was announced that his talks tomorrow with Le Duc Tho of North Vietnam would be moved to the ceremonial setting of the International Conference Center.
Italy today inaugurated a new two-tier foreign-exchange system aimed at stemming the flow of capital to other countries and strengthening the lira.

The Chessplayer is a difficult creature to please. The club regular who has just landed his Sunday punch, flooring the club champion for the first time, might be expected to enjoy his elation for at least a week.
John Ben Snow, a founder and former chairman of the Speidel Newspaper chain died last night at Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs. He was 89 years old.

David Lidman, former make-up editor and stamp news editor of The New York Times, was named chairman of the Philatelic Advisory Panel of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission today. Fourteen-year-old Vicki Sibum of East Stroudsburg, Pa., was also named to the panel.

The Palestine Liberation Organization, the over-all guerrilla organization, has decided to request an audience with Pope Paul VI to thank him for raising the problem of Palestinian refugees with Premier Golda Meir of Israel.

Assistant Secretary of I Defense Barry J. Shillito said today that because of oil and gas imports, "interruption of the sea lanes now carries a far larger threat to this nation's security, economy and well-being than heretofore, when our own production base was a guarantee of continued secure energy supply."
North Vietnamese troops have reportedly inflicted heavy losses on, South Vietnamese forces in more than a week of fighting about 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

Shock, sorrow and the sense of a historic leader lost were the mourning themes of public officialss and private citizens across the nation last night as word spread that Lyndon Baines Johnson was dead.

A California scientist, suing for $2-million in libel damages after being accused of "savagery" in brain probes of live animals, testified in Federal Court yesterday that the brain was insensitive to pain.

Lectures on gourmet cooking and face-lifting are given at the Tulsa Club. 'Flowerprint smocks may be seen exiting the once 'all-male squash courts where Princeton University alumni play. And the elite Union League Club now gives tours to secretaries of its members.
Cast members of 17 Broadway and Off Broadway shows gave up their pay for last Saturday, Inauguration Day, as a contribution to rebuild Hanoi's bombed-out Bach Mai Hospital.

The Supreme Court agreed today to review a 1972 New York State law providing aid to parochial schools. Last October a three-judge Federal court held unconstitutional two provisions of the law, which would have provided $4-million a year for parochial school building maintenance and repairs and tuition grants to low-income parents with children in nonpublic schools.

The city's finance administrator, Richard Lewisohn, said yesterday that he had submitted to the New York Stock Exchange a plan for New York City to go into the stock brokerage business through the purchase of a seat on the exchange.
The ebullience vanished from the soybean futures market yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after one of the most spectacular advances in history.

A witness said today that $199,000 was paid to a defendant in the Watergate trial during last year's campaign with the approval of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.

Roy L.. Ash, former president of Litton Industries, Inc., sold more than 85,000 shares of Litton stock for about $2.5-million during a period when its prospects were apparently being enhanced by awards of $3billion in ship-building contracts, Representative Les Aspin said yesterday.

Abuses by physicians, denlists and other professionals in the Medicaid program have led to 370 disciplinary actions and $4,271,232 in reductions of claims and restitutions of wrong payments in the last three years, the City Health Department said yesterday.

The Housing and Development Administration will cancel its contract with the City Urban Renewal. Management Corporation, which has been managing city-owned buildings on 41 urban-renewal sites since 1962.

As soon as President Nixon ended his Vietnam peace announcement last night, Larry King, the organist at Trinity Church, went to an octaveand-a-half keyboard in the sanctuary and began pealing the 10 bells in the tower of the historic church at Broadway and Wall Street.

The Supreme Court dismissed 10 petitions last night that indirectly challenged President Ferdinand E. Marcos's right to proclaim a Constitution allowing him to rule indefinitely with full personal powers.
The Indiana Pacers stretched their winning streak to six games by staging a second-half rally to defeat the New York Nets, 110-103, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
WHITE EAGLE with Buck Jones (1932), and two serials, "Dick Tracy vs. Crime Incorporated," and "Flash Gordon's Trip to Mars," at 2 P.M. Saturday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, $1. JU 2-2424.

Returning to the home fans--13,669 of them--for the first time in a week, the New York Islanders displayed their lately acquired scoring form against the California Golden Seals in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

A witness said today that $199,000 was paid to a defendant in the Watergate trial during last year's campaign with the approval of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans.
Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran today told the Western oil consortium operating in his country that its present contract would not be renewed after it expires in 1979.

President Nixon said last night that Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho had initialed an agreement in Paris yesterday "to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia." He said in a televised report to the nation that a Vietnam ceasefire would go into effect on Saturday at 7 P.M., Eastern standard time.

A leading economist charged yesterday that the Federal Reserve System had allowed an "inordinate" growth in the nation's money supply during 1972, which he said would lead to a rekindling of inflation in 1973 and 1974.
The records by Billie Holiday that have been appearing concurrently with the release of "Lady Sings the Blues," the film about her, have mostly been reissues.
--Following, as released by military officials, is the schedule for services for former President Lyndon B. Johnson. All times are Eastern standard.

A volcanic eruption opened a fissure in an island off Iceland's southern coast early today and forced the evacuation of nearly all the 5,500 inhabitants. The volcano, dormant for 7,000 years, came to life virtually without warning and blasted a rift a mile and a half long in the island of Heimaey, spewing molten lava and lighting uP the sky for hundreds of miles around.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a proposal by one of its advisory committees that persons offering investment advisory services to small investors be exempted, if they meet certain tests, from the type of Government regulation applied to investment companies.

Japan Registered a trade surplus of $8,972,000,000 last year, an increase of $1,185,000,000 from 1971, the Finance Ministry announced today. Exports, based on customs clearance, totaled $28,025,000,000 in 1972, up 18.9 per cent from 1971.

America is moving out of Vietnam after the longest and most divisive conflict since the War Between the States. But Vietnam is not moving out of America, for News the impact of the Analysis war there is likely to influence Amercan life for many years to come.

President Nixon said last night that Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho had initialed an agreement in Paris yesterday "to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia." He said in a televised report to the nation that a Vietnam ceasefire would go into effect on Saturday at 7 P.M., Eastern standard time. The accord will be signed on Saturday.

The Episcopalian priest who officiated at the marriage of Jane Fonda, the actress, and Tom Hayden, the antiwar activist, has been indefinitely suspended from administration of the sacraments by his Bishop.
Ray Clearwater's second goal of the game with 29 seconds gone in sudden-death overtime tonight gave the Cleveland Crusaders a 5-4 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

A Candian member of Parliament, just' returned from North Vietnam, said today that officials there had told him that the projected international force that is to monitor a truce would be kept smaller than the United States had originally proposed.
An army of policemen poured into the narrow streets of Greenpoint yesterday to attend the funeral of Patrolman Stephen Robert Gilroy, who was killed in action last Friday.

The police disclosed yesterday that the gunmen who holed up for 47 hours with nine hostages in a Brooklyn sporting goods store had apparently arrived there in a commandeered "gypsy" cab after locking its driver in the trunk.
The game was definitely not the thing tonight as the East outscored the West, 104-84, in a nice, friendly exhibition called the 23rd annual National Basketball Association All-Star game.

Sargent Shriver, Democratic candidate for Vice President of the United States last November, was chatting with a dozen sports writers when George Foreman appeared on the far side of the swimming pool. In five seconds, Shriver was alone except for Barney Nagler of the Daily Racing Form.
James R. Schlesinger, outgoing chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, refused today to give Congress a flat assurance of total safety of nuclear electric power plants.

An increase in Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam was reported early 'today shortly before it was announced that agreement had been reached on a cease-fire and that it would go into effect this weekend.

Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address to the nation last night on the Vietnam war, as recorded by The New York Times: Good evening. I have asked for this radio and television time tonight for the purpose of announcing that we today have concluded an agreement to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.
United States-45,933 killed and 303,616 wounded (with 153,300 of these requiring hospitalization). South Vietnam--183,528 killed and 499,026 wounded (all requiring hospitalization).

SAILING TODAY Trans-Atlantic ATLANTIC CHAMPAGNE (Allantic Container), Rotterdam Feb. 4 and Southampton 5; sails from Port Newark, N. J. FERNLAND (Barber), Lagos Feb. 9; sails from Columbia St., Brooklyn MORMACPRIDE (Moore McCormack), Capetown Feb. 8; salts from 23d St., Brooklyn. ZVIR (Crossocean), Rijeka Feb. 14; sails from Columbia St., Brooklyn.

A late rally pared stockmarket losses yesterday. as volume increased on the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow-Jones industrial average, down nearly 6 points at mid-session, finished at 1,018.66 with a token decline of 0.15 point.
C. Merrill Chapin Jr., retired senior vice president and a director of the St. Joseph Lead Company, now the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, died at his home here today. He was 74 years old.

Following is a transcript of President Nixon's televised address to the nation last night on the Vietnam war, as recorded by The New York Times: Good evening. I have asked for this radio and television time tonight for the purpose of announcing that we today have concluded an agreement to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia.
Following are tributes to former President Lyndon B. Johnson that were expressed yesterday: QUEEN ELIZABETH II-He will be particularly remembered for his deep concern for those in need.

Governor Rockefeller said today that he had been informed of instances of "waste" and "inefficiency" in the educational system throughout the state sufficient enough to warrant the creation of an inspector general for education, with "power to invest gate, subpoena and recommend" changes to eliminate the flaws.

Federal narcotics agents, working closely with their French counterparts, have smashed a major operation that smuggled about 575 pounds of heroin from France into the United States in the last three years, the Government announced yesterday.

A few weeks ago, Smitty Zunker, a young commercial real estate and vitamin salesman in Houston, left his office in the Galleria Shopping Center for a cup of coffee and was accosted by what he describes as "an attractive young lady."

Senator Edmund S. Muskie charged today that the ways in which some wealthy persons could keep their Federal income tax rate below that paid by families of average income were increasing, not decreasing.

Historical eras are marked off by changes in concepts. The period of colonial expansion of the great European powers was a quest for "wealth"--defined as gold and treasure.
The game was definitely not the thing tonight as the East outscored the West, 104-84, in a nice, friendly exhibition called the 23rd annual National Basketball Association All-Star game.

The Senate confirmed two of President Nixon's appointments to top defense and intelligence agency posts today after one of them, the Deputy Defense Secretary, William P. Clements Jr.. agreed to sell stock in a Dallas bank to avoid a possible conflict of interest.
The new chairman of the Senat Judiciary Committee said to day that he would not b? "stampeded" into recommend ing passage of court-reforn legislation this year.

The selection of American Totalisator as winner of the offtrack computer sweepstakes here will mean faster, more reliable and varied service for the $2 horseplayer, the Offtrack Betting Corporation said yesterday.
An army of policemen poured into the narrow streets of Greenpoint yesterday to attend the funeral of Patrolman Stephen Robert Gilroy, who was killed in action last Friday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 23--Women police reservists went on duty in Northern Ireland for the first time today, the vanguard of what authorities hope will be a task force of "housewife cops."

Only one heavyweight champion ever has regained the title. Floyd Patterson won it back from Ingerman Johansson in 1960. But nearly all of them have tried, because their egos won't let them do anything else.

The American Electric Power Company yesterday announced plans to sell 6.5 million' shares of its authorized but unissued common stock in a rights offering to shareowners this spring. Directors will determine the subscription price and the date of the offering at a later date. Proceeds will be applied to repay short-term debt and for other corporate purposes. The company's stock was down 3/8 at 20 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The police disclosed yesterday that the gunmen who holed up for 47 hours with nine hostages in a Brooklyn sporting goods store had apparently arrived there in a commandeered "gypsy" cab after locking its driver in the trunk.

Parishes in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn have been asked to group into neighborhood clusters of four or five churches during the coming weeks to determine the future of the financially troubled system of parochial elementary schools.

Abraham Tulin, a lawyer and Zionist leader, died yesterday at his home, 330 West 72d Street. He was 94 years old. Mr. Tulin was honorary chairman of the board of directors of the American Society for Technion, the Israel Institute of Technology.

A New York engineering concern whose officials were accused by Federal grand juries of paying off New Jersey officials in return for contracts is still doing a handsome business with state agencies-including the New Jersey Sports Author ity, which awarded it a $10million contract.

L.B.J. Coverage, of the ceremonies and services for the late President Lyndon Baines Johnson, will be as follows: Channel 2, 4 and 11, at 1:00 P.M. to 3. Channel 7, at 1:30 P.M. to 3. Other channels will have special reports throughout the afternoon.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a 5-cent increase in its quarterly dividend and a 25 per cent stock split. The move will bring I.B.M.'s dividend to $1.40 a share from $1.35:

The results in this year's Hall of Fame balloting by the Baseball Writers Association will be announced today. The leading candidates to gain the required 75 per cent of the votes are considered to be three pitchersWarren Spahn, Robin Roberts and Whitey Ford-aN of whom became eligible for the first time. Others thought to have a chance were Ralph Kiner, Bob Lemon and the late Gil Hodges.

--Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., Republican of New JerSey, announced today that New Jersey would receive a $475,000 Federal grant to help fight water pollution. Mr. Sandman said the funds were to cover the first six months of 1973 and had been given to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Division of Water Resources last Friday.

A George Foreman defense of his new heavyweight championship against Muhammad Ali was the No. I topic on fight-fans' lips and in promoters' dreams yesterday, but that encounter isn't very likely td be the next attraction on your neighborhood closed-circuit television screen.

Harry J. Buncke, retired vice president for engineering of the Oxford Paper Company, died yesterday in a Stamford, Conn., convalescent home. He was 80 years old and had lived at 166 Altamont Avenue, Tarrytown, N. Y.

Higher rents and home-ownership prices were major' factors in a rise of three-tenths of 1 per cent in December of the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area, it was reported yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statiftics.

The chairman of a major construction company testified today that payoffs to public officials for their help in obtaining government contracts were a "way of life" in New Jersey. He said the practice had been prevalent for decades.

Representatives of 19 major petrochemical producers said today they had asked the White House to create a new category of oil-import quotas. The proposal was one of several intended to assure the industry maximum future supplies of natural gas with minimum increases in costs.

The St. Louis Board of Education ordered all public schools closed until further notice tonight after the second day of a teacher strike. The closings, the school board said, came on the recommendation of the Superintendent of Schools, Clyde Miller, who cited threats, harassment, damage to property and physical assaults by some teachers on strike.

The United States and Japan announced today a major consolidation of American military bases in Japan. United States officials said it would not significantly reduce American forces or impair American military operations here.

The moment of truth for the Pay Board in Phase 2 of the Administration's anti-inflation program came last March when it tackled an agreement that would have given West Coast longshoremen wage increases nearly five times the basic 5.5 per cent guidepost.

In diplomatic practice, the "initialing" of an agreement means that the chief negotiators have concurred on the language of the text. The agreement, however, does not go into effect until it has been formally signed by designated officials.
The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating to buy Vermouth Industries of America, Inc., a leading, privately owned vermouth producer based in Lodi, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (Reuters)--The Department of Agriculture issued an order today prohibiting Arthur N. Economou and the New York firm bearing his name from trading on regulated commodity exchanges for 90 days.
Members of Congress, after years of bitter debate over the war in Vietnam, united tonight in voicing relief and gratitude that the conflict appeared to be at an end.
Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho concluded their long negotiations on a Vietnam cease-fire today with glowing smiles and hearty handshakes.

David Behrman's concert of synthesized music Monday night at the Kitchen was perhaps more successful for sound than for form, but at its best the sounds were so nice that, just this once at least, one was willing simply to let them flow by.

The Communist delegation tothe Laos peace talks today issued its strongest condemnation so far of the United States role in Laos, charging that President Nixon intends to continue using neighboring Thailand as "a springboard for aggression" throughout Indochina.

Lyndon B. Johnson was a man of immense energy and vitality whose career was punctuated, but hardly slowed, by several serious medical problems. He had trouble with kidney stones, his gall bladder, his heart and -his digestive tract, but Mr. Johnson seemed to take all of these problems in his fast-paced Texas stride.

Arnold R. Weber, the first executive director of the Cost of Living Council, has been named dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration of Carnegie-Mellon University. The 43-year-old labor economist was also named a provost of the university.

The Southern Railway's directors yesterday increased the regular quarterly dividend from 40 cents to 43 cents a share, the maximum permissible under Phase 3 guidelines, after the road's president, W. Graham Claytor, reported record earnings and operating revenues for 19 72.

AMERICAN MISCHIEF. By Alan Lelchuk. 501 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux. $8.95. I think I can imagine two unambiguous responses to Alan Lelchuk's first novel, "American Mischief." Both of them depend on how one reacted to the recent American past-that is, the upheavals of the 1960's.
The 'dismissal of a murder charge against a man who had been accused' of kiling his-wife and tossing her body into a clambake pit is being appealed by the Wayne County district attorney.

A young man and woman were found shot to death last night on the edge of Marine Park in southern Brooklyn. The man, killed by a bullet that apparently passed through his body, was identified by the police as Kenneth Kaufman, 22 years old, of 2625 East 13th Street in Brooklyn.

Part-time antiques dealers are anything but rare these days. For most of them, it's the result of collecting enthusiasms that could not be curbed, manias for anything from thimbles to threshers that, in time, threatened to force them from their homes.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., a leading institutional investment house, reported yesterday that it had record revenues and net income, in 1972. At the same time, the concern's board raised the semiannual dividend from 5 cents a share to 6 cents.
A strike by airline pilots in Laos that would have severely impaired support of anti-Communist forces fighting there has apparently been averted.

Richard M. Clurman's "inaugural address" as the new Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs sent a chill up the spine of every thoughtful New Yorker. Mr. Clurman is correct when he refers to public frustration at unkempt and unsafe parks and on sound ground when he asks the Mayor and police commissioner for more help.
The Indiana Pacers stretched their winning streak to six games by staging a second-half rally to defeat the New York Nets, 110-103, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association dismissed Roy Rubin as coach tonight and replaced him with Kevin Loughery, who will be player-coach. The move was announced after the N.B.A. all-star game by Dan De Jardin, general manager, who said Loughery, 32 years' old, was given a contract for the remainder of this season and the next two seasons.

A Provo man was sentenced today to death by shooting for his first-degree murder conviction in the slaying of two teenage sisters-in-law last summer. District Court Judge George E. Ballif sentenced James Walter Winkle, 31 years old.

The Syrian Army has reportedly ordered Palestinian guerrilla groups to stay out of villages along the Golan heights ceasefire line that were severely bombed by Israel on Jan. 8, with what Syria said were heavy civilian casualties.

William F. Buckley Jr. won a crucial first round yesterday in his lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of collective bargaining agreements that force him to be a member of a union in order to express his views on television.

Presidents of the 29 colleges operated by the State University will be appointed to terms limited to five years and would face intensive evaluation of their performances, under a new policy expected to be adopted today.

America is moving out of Vietnam after the longest and most divisive conflict since the War Between the States. But Vietnam is not moving out of America, for the impact of the war there is likely to influence Amercan life for many years to come.
The World Council of Churches has decided to include banks in its boycott of concerns doing business with African countries ruled by white minorities.

Steve Smith, fresh from setting a world indoor record and confident that he can go considerably higher, will chase the first successful 18foot pole vault indoors in the Wanamaker Millrose Games Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting's recently announced intention of taking over programing decisions from its distribution arm, the Public Broadcasting Service, has led to efforts on both regional and national levels to create public TV hook-up financed without Federal funds.
The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association dismissed Roy Rubin as coach tonight and replaced him with Kevin Loughery, who will be player-coach.

The city's three major daily newspapers and their unions are facing a critical confrontation in coming labor negotiations that seems likely to determine whether these citywide dailies can make use of new and cost-saving print technologies and whether they can achieve settlements that will leave them economically viable.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York reported yesterday a sharp decline in net income for the quarter and full year of 1972. For the full year the utility showed a small increase in net operating profit that was more than offset by large extraordinary credits for tax refunds in 1971.
Its awesome aerial photography alone would have justified "The Incredible Flight of the Snow Geese," a rewarding 60-minute documentary shown last night on the National Broadcasting Company network.
Government sources reported today that 29 people survived the crash of a chartered jetliner in northern Nigeria yesterday as it was carrying Nigerian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca.
The sixth day of the H. Rap Brown trial ended yesterday with the addition of the eighth juror to the panel.

The latest entry in the network movie derby is the Columbia Broadcasting System's acquisition of rights to about 30 feature films from 20th Century-Fox and MetroGoldwyn - Mayer including Fox's "The French Connection," which won the 1971 Academy Award as best picture of the year.

Following is the text of a proclamation by President Nixon today on the death of former President Lyndon Baines Johnson: By the President of the United States of Americ: A Prorlamation To the people of the United States:

Governor Rockefeller and the Republican legislative leaders sought agreement today on a single "no fault" auto insurance bill that would present a consensus and avoid a repetition of last year's burial of the issue under a plethora of divisive bills and debate.

United States intelligence sources report that Hanoi has moved officials from its Ministries of Health and Education into South Vietnam's northernmost province in recent week's, possibly to establish a Communist capital there for the South.
Talks have broken off between the American Theater Wing and the League of New York Theaters over the future of the annual Tony awards-ceremony and show, which is nationally televised.

DELMAN-Plncus. Beloved husband of Carol adored father of Anne Stein, Nancy and Joan. Devoted grandfather of Lori. Dear brother of Phillip. Services today 9:30 A.M. Garlicks 1700 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn. DELMAN-Plncus, sorrowfully we record the untimely passing of this unique gentle man, respected for his knowledge, wisdom and helpfulness. He will be remembered.

Richard Ausley, a Portsmouth carpenter charged with abducting and sexually assaulting a 13-year-old boy who was found imprisoned in a buried wooden box, surrendered today to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Village Gate, for more than 15 years a popular Greenwich Village night spot at Thompson and Bleecker Streets, was among four restaurants cited yesterday by the Health Services Administration for failing to correct violations of the city's Health Code.

The general counsel of the Transit Authority began a $275,000 personal suit against City Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday, charging "false imprisonment" and other matters arising from an acrimonious disciplinary hearing the authority has been holding for the last two weeks.
The dollar moved down early today, depressed by a flow of money into Switzerland yesterday, then rose in the afternoon on rumors that a Vietnam peace agreement had just been signed in Paris.

Former Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet announced yesterday the formation of a nonpartisan committee to seek the bestqualified candidate for Mayor and to muster support for him. On the committee, which now numbers. 26 but will be enlarged, are businessmen, trade union and civic leaders and public officials, Democrats and Republicans.

As soon as President Nixon ended his Vietnam peace announcement last night, Larry King, the organist at Trinity Church, went to an octave-and-a-half keyboard in the sanctuary and began pealing the 10 bells in the tower of the historic church at Broadway and Wall Street.

Police ballistics experts are examining the automatic weapons of two men slain in an exchange of fire with the police in a Brooklyn bar early yesterday to determine if they could have been used in the assassinations of two patrolmen last January.

The Supreme Court has made a major contribution to the preservation of individual liberties and of free decision-making by its invalidation of state laws inhibiting a woman's right to obtain an abortion in the first three months of pregnancy.

Mrs. Charlotte Walrath Comfort, headmistress of the Hewitt School, 45 East 75th Street, from 1942 to her retirement in 1969, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla. She was 69 years old and was the wife of Lowell R. Comfort, retired controller of the Ward Baking Company.

More of the Long Island Rail Road's 90,000 prestrike commuters returned to the railroad yesterday, the second weekday of operation since the 90-day truce was arranged between the 12 nonoperating unions and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. On Monday, only 70 per cent of the commuters had resumed using the railroad, yesterday it was estimated that 80 per cent had returned.

The Vietnam agreement announced by President Nixon last night after more than four years of false starts and disappointed hopes could mark a momentous. turning point for the United States, for Southeast Asia and for the world. If it does not guarantee peace, this historic pact at least provides the framework and opportunity for a new era of compromise and conciliation in Vietnam and elsewhere.

Reflecting the marked improvement of the major steelmakers, the Armco Steel Corporation achieved a 75 per cent profit increase in the fourth quarter and 49 per cent rise for all of 1972, according to yesterday's unaudited preliminary report.

Edward (Kid) Ory, the Dixie land jazz great who wrote "Muskrat Ramble" and gave Louis Armstrong one of his first jobs, died of pneumonia and heart failure in a hospital here today. He was 86 years old.

A California space biologist contended in Federal Court here yesterday that a "maliciously false" report of his animal experiments caused professional associates to ask hostile questions reflecting on his integrity.

At least two gunmen burst into the residence of United States Ambassador Clinton E. Knox late last night and seized him as a hostage in what officials called an attempt to gain freedom for several Haitian political prisoners.

Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., frittered away a comfortable lead en route to defeat tonight against Alex Metreveli of the Soviet Union in the quarterfinals of the Rothmans $50,000 indoor tennis tournament.
A bill that would allow abortions at any stage of pregnancy was Introduced in the Legislature today by lawmakers who led the successful fight for a liberalized abortion statute in 1970.
Consumer prices rose in December by a little less than in most recent months and finished, the year 3.4 per cent above the level at the end of 1971, the Labor Department reported today.
Despite their newly won right to challenge the seniority system, House Democrats chose committee chairmen today exactly as they had in the pastby seniority.

A proposed bridge over 51st Street near Park Avenue has been abandoned because of public protest. The Uris Building Corporation and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said yesterday that their application for the pedestrian span would be withdrawn tomorrow when it comes before the Board of Estimate.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority yesterday retained as its ecological consultant on the Meadowlands Sports Complex the concern that did the original environmental impact study on the complex. Dr. Jack McCormick and Associates of Devon, Pa., was retained under a $207,000, two-year contract to advise the authority on construction of the complex, which will eventually be the home of the New York Giants football team.

The Prime Ministers or Australia and New Zealand said today that they would take measures, including possibly a break in diplomatic relations if necessary, against the French nuclear tests in the Pacific.

Whitney North Seymour Jr. plans to resign as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York within the next few months, according to Government sources.

Hermilo Novelo, a violinist, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night as the second performer in the "Concert Artists of Mexico" series presented by Carnegie Hall with the Cultural Counselor of Mexico in New York.

Irving A. Mass, who revived American film exports after World War II as vice president and general manager of the Motion picture Export Association, died Yesterday in Community Hospital. He was 76 years old and had lived at 104 Malvern Circle.

The shootout between police and gunmen trapped in the act of robbing a sporting goods store in Brooklyn evoked an exemplary display of courage, resolution and restraint by New York City police during two days of terrible tension..A tragic incident that had already cost the life of one young patrolman was prevented-by the police-from becoming an outright bloodbath that might have involved more patrolmen, the gunmen and innocent hostages as well.

President Nixon said tonight that Henry A. Kissinger and North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Le Duc Tho, had initialed an agreement in Paris today "to end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia."

New Jersey legislative reapportionment officials reported today that they were "reasonably optimistic" that they could avert a deadlock and adopt a compromise, bipartisan redistricting plan for this year's legislative elections.
In a dramatic homecoming and schedule-maker's dream, the Rangers will be back in Madison Square Garden tonight and face their long-time tormentors, the Boston Bruins.

By dint of intelligence, industry and luck, Amilcar Cabral became one of a handful of young Africans sent off to. Lisbon for university training by the white rulers of Portuguese Guinea. As a graduate agronomist he could have settled comfortably into the colonial service to be exhibited to outsiders by his superiors as a. successful "assimilado"--proof that color was no bar to advancement under "enlightened" Portuguese rule.

Lester, said today that as he "read the press reports," the Supreme Court decision striking down laws that restrict abortions during the first three months of pregnancy "could very well" dispoae of the case against Dr. Robert M. Livingston "and all others like it."

Returning to the home fans--13,669 of them--for the first time in a week, the New York Islanders displayed their lately acquired scoring form against the California Golden Seals in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

The band, which also includes three trumpets, two trombones, piano, bass and drums, made its first public appearance Monday night at the Jazz Club of the Overseas Press Club.

A program whose focus was the flute-harp combination made a decidedly pleasant evening at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday. Although there are only seven New Jersey skaters here at the national figure skating championship starting tomorrow, they form a quality group with a former Olympian and two Eastern sectional champions among them. Heading the group is Suna Murray of South Orange, N.J., as she tries to make the United States team for the third straight time.
A spurt of price increases that began soon after Phase 3 of the Nixon economic program was announced almost two weeks ago tapered off yesterday.

That's what makes LADO, the Yugoslav National Dance and Folk Ensemble, out of Belgrade, different from the Polish, Ukrainian, Czechoslovak, Russian and other Slavic troupes.

Robert Heller, a management engineer and efficiency expert who helped reorganize procedures for Congress, the Pentagon and some of the country's largest corporations, died Monday at Delray Beach, Fla.

After falling sharply most of the day, prices on the American Stock Exchange recovered somewhat yesterday after the White House reported shortly before 2 P.M. that President Nixon would announce at 10 P.M. developments in the Vietnam War.

Like a roomful of children with a new mechanical toy, the members of the House of Representatives used their new electronic voting system for the first time today. Alexander Onassis, the 24-year-old only son of Aristotle Onassis, the multimillionaire, died in a hospital here of a brain hemorrhage tonight, 27 hours after his plane crashed at the Athens airport.

Carloadings in the same week totaled 516,062, an increase of 11.5 per cent above last year.

Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

The Cleveland Museum has acquired a particularly fine and not previously exhibited Madonna and Child, an Italian Gothic sculpture of the 14th century, which museum officials have tentatively attributed to Andrea Pisano,
Walt Kocubinski scored 29 points to lead Lafayette to a 77-64 victory over Columbia in University Gym last night. The Leopards' victory was their fifth straight.
"Compared to what happened in 1937, this has been far from a bad season weatherwise," said Paul Bousquet, owner of the ski area in Pittsfield, Mass., his father founded 40 years ago.
Three new models of gasoline and diesel marine engines are being exhibited at the show by Greenwich Marine Engines, Palmer Point. Cos Cob, Conn.

Arthur N. Ecnomou, president of Arthur N. Economou Co., has charged that a 90-day suspension levied against his firm by the Department of Agriculture was a "fabrication" because he had not been registered with the Commodity Exchange Authority since 1970.

The Army rejected yesterday an appeal by Capt. Eugene Koouc, exonerated of charges in connection with the slaying of civilians at the Vietnamese ?amlet of My Lai, that he be flowed to remain on active uty as an officer.
John Begley, who served as acting warden of the Morris County Jail while it was being investigated by a grand jury has resigned as undersheriff effective Jan. 31.
A dispute between two ship officers unions over automatic engine-room controls was settled yesterday after it delayed the sailing of the Moore-McCormack Lines freighter Mormaclynx for two days.

Governor Cahill urged farmers yesterday to support efforts to keep valuable open spaces out of the hands of land speculators. While saying that the government respected the right of any farmer to sell his property, Mr. Cahill told the 58th annual state agriculture convention that "disincentives" were needed to discourage speculators.

A rare item of good news on the public housing front is the decision of the New York State Urban Development Corporation to resume work on planning low, and middle-income housing projects in Westchester County. The four-month moratorium on the plan ordered by Governor Rockefeller has come to an end,

A 9-point streak at the beginning of the game that. seemed more amusing than important, at the time, enabled the Knicks to score a 99-92 victory over the Buffalo Braves last night at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 19,553.
When Dr. Mildred W. Abramowitz, the new principal of Dwight Morrow High School here, suspended 20 students last September the school seemed polarized between blacks and whites.

The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, Inc., has announced that it had filed an action against PPG Industries Inc., its partner in a joint venture formed in 1967 to build and operate one of the world's largest olefin plants in Puerto Rico.

Arthur Ashe won a battle of tiebreakers and Marty Riessen overcame frustration caused by a disputed line call as both Americans advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament today.
OUT OF THE PAST There's nothing like a good run of somebody's something new to stir up interest in somebody's past. Ingmar Bergman, for instance.
Members of the State Bar Association toured the narcotics courts on the ninth floor of the Civil Court Building yesterday.

With rhetorical flourishes and casually recalled illustrations from his own decades in city and state government, Robert Moses told the State Charter Commission yesterday that all that was needed to run New York City better was better people.

Herbert Heaton, professor emeritus of history at the University of Minnesota, died yesterday. He was 82 years old. Professor Heaton was chairman of the history department from 1954 until his retirement in 1958.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered Spiegel, Inc., the big Chicago mail-order house, to stop offering customers what the commission said were deceptive "free trial" offers. The commission said the offers were not really available to everyone because Spiegel would not accept everyone who applied as a customer.

After a year of planning a five-year voyage around the world on a sailboat, refurbishing a schooner inside and out, quitting their jobs, selling their house, a boat and two cars and taking their three children out of school, two Northport, L. I., couples ran into a crisis they could not solve: money.

Annemarie Proell, the defending World Cup champion sped to her sixth straight down hill triumph of the season ii the Kandahar ski race today while the United States made its best showing this season with two skiers in the top 10.
In a surge of Communist ground attacks throughout South Vietnam, a barrage of rockets was fired early today into the Bien Hoa Base near Saigon, killing one American and wounding nine.

Arthur Ashe won a battle of tiebreakers and Marty Riessen overcame frustration caused by a disputed line call as both Americans advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament today.

American pop-rock music has always had a happy balance-of-payments situation: its exports far outweigh its imports. Only the British, spearheaded by the Beatles, have been able to withstand and fight back.

Sam Snead, trying for his sixth Professional Golfers' Association seniors championship , carded a sixunder-par 66 today and took the first-round lead over the East Course of the P.G.A. National Golf Club. Snead had 7 birdies and one bogey.

Dr. Edward T. Ladd, professor of education at Emory University, died yesterday in Atlanta of injuries suffered when struck by a tree limb that had apparently been weakened by an ice storm two weeks ago. He was 52 years old.

Throughout the long years of America's ill-fated involvement in the war in Indochina, the peace symbol remained a persistent expression of determination and hope. As time went on and the yearning for an end to the bloodshed grew in intensity, that symbol's message became emblazoned in the minds and hearts of millions. It formed a nonpartisan bond for many who agreed on little else.
The executive officer of the Kitty Hawk says fighting started aboard the aircraft carrier after marines, who had been ordered to break up groups of sailors, took action against only groups of blacks.
Bill D. Moyers, White House press secretary under President Lyndon B. Johnson and former publisher of Newsday, was in satisfactory condition in a Washington hospital after suffering chest pains.
