For the last three years, in a three-story building at 52 Herkimer Place in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the Ya Sin Mosque has been a gathering spot and place of worship for a growing number of predominantly black Brooklynites who have converted to orthodox Islam and become Sunni Muslims.

Preparatory work began here today on a large-scale international program to save Venice from decay and destruction. Delegates beginning a meeting at the headquarters of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization were told that the Italian Parliament was, at last, about to approve a $500-million plan that is the backbone of the international effort.

Something of a race seems to be shaping up on whether the Coast Guard, which must develop regulations on wastetreatment devices for boats, will do so in time for the boating season. If the Coast Guard acts in time, boatmen who do-not want to install holding tanks will be able to use other devices.
Utah's House of Representatives has defeated a resolution ratifying the Federal equal rights amendment while the legislature in neighboring Wyoming has become the 23d state to ratify the amendment.
The Houston Rockets snapped Milwaukee's eight-game winning streak tonight with a 129125 National Basketball Association victory despite Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's 48 points.
Bob Wheeler doesn't buy the business that a sub-4-minute Wanamaker Mile is impossible, even after 65 futile races. "If you get the right pace and the right runner,"

A high diplomatic source said today that Cambodia would announce a halt in her offensive military operations by Sunday. He said that the step was planned on the strength of American assurances that the United States and North Vietnam had reached an understanding during their Paris talks that the cease-fire in Vietnam would be extended to Laos and Cambodia as well.

President Nixon ordered today a renewed Federal effort to find jobs for returning veterans. Mr. Nixon signed an Executive order strengthening directions that Federal agencies and Federal contractors and subcontractors list job openings with employment service systems.

The Hunts Point Community Corporation in the South Bronx announced a drive yesterday to screen all 70,000 residents in Hunts Point for tuberculosis because the rate of active cases there runs about three times the national average.
Billy Casper carded a surprising 6-under-par 66 today in blustery weather and led the $205,000 Bing Crosby national pro-amateur golf tourney by two strokes after one round.

The appointment of two managing editors, effective Feb. 26, was announced today by Gene Roberts, executive editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer. They are Will Jarrett, now assistant to the executive editor, and Gene Foreman, executive news editor of Newsday, a Long Island paper.

The British Government proposed preferential treatment today for white immigrants from Canada, Australia and New Zealand over nonwhites seeking to enter Britain from other Commonwealth countries in Asia, Africa and the West Indies.

The television networks will provide videotaped and live coverage of the signing of the Vietnam agreements in Paris tomorrow. Since the four-power accord will be signed at an early hour New York time.

The southernmost part of south America, embracing while , Argentina and Uruguay, s an economic disaster area lick with inflation. Chile is in the worst shape. The cost of living rose 163 per cent in 1972. Next was Uruguay, with 94 per cent, and then Argentina, with 64 per cent. To buy groceries that were worth $1 a year ago, housewives in Chile have to bay more than $2.60.

Charging that the sale of ghost-written term papers for college and high-school students violates a new state law by "subverting the learning process and encouraging intellectual dishonesty and cheating,"
Beginning today, Roosevelt Son, Inc., will clear its securities transactions and customer accounts through Abraham Co., a spokesman for the Roosevelt announced last night.
Governor Rockefeller proposed a $55-million program today to expand the state's court system by giving him the power to appoint 100 State Supreme Court justices on a temporary basis.

While reporting that the conventional "quick treatment" graffiti-writing on the city's subways seems to be leveling off, Transit Authority officials say a more irksome defacement, the "grand design," or "masterpiece," is on the increase.

A 57-year-old man was stabbed to death by two assailants yesterday when he resisted a robbery on a Bronx street corner, the police said. A third man robbed the dead man's brother-in-law at knifepoint in a nearby schoolyard at the same time and the three robbers fled with a total of $238, according to the police.

The Board of Education told School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner yesterday to go on vacation April 1, three months before his contract expires. In a letter hand-delivered to the Chancellor shortly after 11 A.M. and made public by the board four hours later,

Lyndon Baines Johnson was buried today in a country graveyard on the northern bank of the Pedernales River. His coffin was lowered into the earth under an aged, twisted oak next to the graves of his mother and father on the former President's ranch.

Tenneco, Inc., a widely diversified company, attained in a 1972 the best results in its 29- t year history, according to yesterday's report of preliminary t inaudited results. Fourth-quarter results were little changed.

I'll never cease to be amazed at Holland's compatibility with water. Surrounded by it -- and occasionally overrun with it -- the Netherlands ("lowlands") have spent the six centuries Before Christ and much of modern times keeping the seas at bay.

The Newark Housing Authority announced tonight that the nation's longest public-housing rent strike had ended, but a group of tenants disputed the agreement and declared that the strike would continue.
The Republican state chairman and the five county leaders here discussed yesterday the possibility of nominating a Democrat as a bipartisan Mayoral candidate in this year's election.

There is a severe dichotomy in "National Lampoon's Lemmings," the musical revue that opened last night at the Village Gate. The first act, a headlong, supposedly comic assault on sex and politics, suffers from a serious case of the puerilities.
Next time you're flying the Atlantic and chomp into a good chunk of sourdough bread or a crunchy roll, think of Antonio Rodrigues and his speedboat records.
The University of California, Los Angeles equaled the college basketball record of 60 straight victories tonight when Bill Walton led the Bruins to an 87-73 triumph over Loyola of Chicago.
Dan Lodboa scored three goals and Rick Morris and Bob Whitlock two each tonight as the Chicago Cougars romped to a 9-2 victory over the New York Raiders in a World Hockey Association game.

The cease-fire agreement between Hanoi and Washington, which President Nixon has said will "end the war and bring peace with honor in Vietnam and Southeast Asia," will be signed in Paris Saturday and go into effect that evening.
Four Democrats who say they would like to be Mayor wooed middle-class support in Queens last night through organization politicians there.

Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan indicated today that his Government expected to be consulted fully by the United States and other major nations on any international plan for the postwar reconstruction of Indochina.

With rhetorical flourishes and casually recalled illustrations from his own decades near the top of city and state government, Robert Moses told the New York State Charter Commission yesterday that all that was needed to run New York City well was good people.
The Seven Wonders of the world I have seen And many are the places I have been; Take my advice, folks, and see Beale Street first.

Jack Trout, introduced as "Mr. Positioning himself," was the lead-off speaker yesterday as the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association devoted a day to exploring the current big buzzword.

Democracy is the way of life on the American bridge scene, and as a result certain types of contest do not exist. Selection is anathema, and if competition is not totally open then qualification is according to automatic guidelines of some sort.

The reason why the American League has taken the hat away from the pitcher is that the owners have no faith in baseball as entertainment. They haven't been selling tickets and they think the fault must lie with the game, for they know themselves to be sagacious, enterprising, farsighted, shrewd, dynamic, well-dressed and charming.
Rapid Sage, a 129-1 shot, paid $261.60, $55.20 and $13.80 for $2 across the board in posting a 11/2-length victory in the seven-furlong Rainly Lake Purse at Hialeah today.

Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, charged yesterday that half of the "gypsy" cabs on the city's streets had been improperly registered out of New York City for insurance purposes and had "insurance inadequate for public conveyance vehicles."

A survey conducted by Oliver Quayle for the State Urban Development Corporation shows that more than half of all Westchester County residents would favor the construction of 100 low- and moderateincome apartment units in their own towns.
Henry Boucha scored twice and his teammates displayed a rugged defense tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the struggling Boston Bruins, 4-2, in a National Hockey League game.

It didn't take long for Kevin Loughery, the Philadelphia 76ers' new coach, to begin revamping his team. Yesterday Loughrey sent the 76ers' only all-star, John Block, a forward, to the Kansas City-Omaha Kings for Tom Van Arsdale, a forwardguard, and a third-round draft choice.
The Fruehauf Corporation, a leading producer of truck trailers, announced yesterday that it was getting out of the modular homebuilding business since there was no mass market for such housing.
The peace agreement between North Vietnam and the United States has one provision that stood out as improbable when the Communists broadcast it in October.
Preparations were under way today for the final act in the five long years of Paris peace talksSaturday's signing of the agreements ending the Vietnam war.

The Chrysler Corporation announced today the recall of 10,362 Dodge trucks in two separate campaigns to overcome safety problems involving brake systems and engine hood latches in 1972 and 1973 models.
Racing against the time when a cease-fire goes into effect, the United States has swamped the South Vietnamese Air Force with hundreds of warplanes it can neither fly nor maintain.
Dr. Jean Tallman Beasley, pediatrician, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She Dr was 51 years old and lived at 272 Bayberry Lane.

Curtis F. McClane, a member of the Board of Mediators and Fact-Finders of the State Public Employment Relations Board, died Wednesday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Yonkers.
Dr. E. Stanley Jones, a United Methodist clergyman, who for more than 60 years had been a missionary, died yesterday in the Clara Swain Hospital in Bareilly, India. He was 89 years old.
"At home in Austria," Mrs. Elisabeth Waldheim remarked, "we would call this an 'einstands' party-a housewarming, you would say in this country."

With 1,613 miles to go in the Capetown-to-Rio de Janeiro yacht race, Matchless, the British sloop, had pulled up to fourth actual position and second over all today in the fleet of 37 ships. Matchless led in handicap position for the first week of the race that started here Jan. 13. She then dropped back, almost into obscurity, until yesterday when she pulled up to second over all and 13th on actual.
Four Arabs and two Jews suspected of key roles in what Israel says was an espionage and sabotage ring directed by Syrian intelligence were indicted today in Haifa District Court.
The trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. in the Pentagon papers case was in recess today because of the funeral of former President Lyndon B. Johnson.
An embargo imposed last August on imports of pet and "exotic" birds may soon be lifted, the Agriculture Department said today.
Premier Edmond Leburton announced today the formation of the first coalition Government of Belgium's three major parties since 1945. The coalition was formed after 64 days of political conflict,
Governor Rockefeller proposed a $55-million program today to expand the state's court system by giving him the power to appoint 100 State Supreme Court justices on a temporary basis.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
Mrs. Eloise Curtis and Richard D. Cioffi were married here this afternoon by Municipal Court Judge J. Branton Wallace in his chambers.
While some of his Oakland teammates have been shoveling food into their mouths and money into their pockets at winter sports dinners, Gene Tenace has been pushing ecology at whoever will listen.
State Department officials expect North Vietnam to release American prisoners of war in groups of about 100 men, starting about Feb. 10.
The Manhattan Jaycees last night named as man of the year for 1972 a young Hispanic city patrolman for his work in easing tensions among East Harlem street gangs.

Joseph Lowe, a pioneer in summer camping, died Wednesday at his home, 10 East End Avenue. He was 88 years old. Mr. Lowe, a 1904 graduate Of City College, held a master's degree from Columbia University and a law degree from Fordham.

All over the United States the structure of banking is ir ??lux. Old barriers to bank ex pansion, many of them with roots deep in the frontier poli cics of the 19th century, are falling as bankers struggle to meet the economic and tech biological challenges of the sev cies.
Ivar a. Foelling, who won the 1962 Kennedy Prize of the Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation, for pioneer studies in infant brain disease, died today. He was 84 years old.

The Paris agreement extricates the United States from the Indochina war and sets a pattern for possible peace between Vietnam's two halves. But, in itself, it insures neither peace nor unification of that country nor does it seem to guarantee a certain cease-fire in neighboring Laos and Cambodia.

The Irving Trust Company, acting under pressure from Washington and "with the greatest reluctance," suspended yesterday use of a formula that ties its prime lending rate directly to its open-market costs of funds. The effect is to delay an increase in the prime above the present 6 per cent level, a move that because of soaring money costs might have otherwise been announced as early as today.
The following article is the first of a series about the United States armed forces in the aftermath of the Vietnam war. Two additional articles, by Drew Middleton, will complete the series.
A military court today sentenced four Basques to prison terms of 12 to 17 years after finding them guilty of complicity in the kidnapping of a Bilbao industrialist a year ago.
Fire from a boiler room yesterday damaged the interior of the Mariner's Temple, a Baptist church that is an official landmark building.

Mrs. Kathleen Hassett McDonnell, the wife of James R. McDonnell, who retired Jan. I as vice president and actuary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, in Boca Raton, Fla., where the McDonnells had been vacationing.
The way was being rapidly cleared today for the first contingent of Canadian truce observers to leave for South Vietnam as soon as the Paris agreement is signed Saturday.

Pakistan today recognized the Cambodian government in exile headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk in Peking. The move follows Pakistan's recognition in recent months of North Vietnam, North Korea and East Germany.

Jon. T. Anderson, Cornell University's athletic director, said tonight that he had filed a complaint with the Eastern College Athletic Conference over the eligibility of a Boston University hockey player, to "give our players a fair shake."

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has opened an inquiry into the legality and prudence of recent sales of paintings by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Members of is staff have called this week on art houses and the museum itself,
The White House is expected to announce soon that it has chosen Donald S. Perkins, a Chicago food retailer, to head the new Federal Food Advisory Committee.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that he had asked for the reinstatement of a mathematics teacher who was transferred to a community district office in Brooklyn for having talked with a newsman without prior authorization from the district.

The two top law-enforcement officials in New Jersey disagree sharply over how business concerns that pay off public officials should be treated after they have turned state's evidence to help convict corrupt officials.
Dr. Eugene G. Lobert, a cardiologist who was associated with the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home, 585 West End Avenue. His age was 74.

Britons, just like Americans wrapped and chased by the glooms of January, await their Boat Show with eager anticipation. And just as the National in New York is No. 1 in the country. the London International Boat Show is THE show in the British Isles.

It's over. Or at least it is supposed to be tomorrow; completion and announcement of agreement between the United States and North Vietnam did not deter final, senseless acts of combat just before the cease-fire is to take effect.

Mayor Alfred B. DelBello said today that because of financial considerations he would not run for a third term this fall. His statement immediately increased speculation that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Westchester County Executive.

A high diplomatic source in Paris said yesterday that Cambodia will halt offensive military operations by Sunday. The source said that the fighting would be stopped on the strength of an "understanding" between Henry A. Kissinger and Le Duc Tho that the cease-fire they negotiated for Vietnam would be extended to Cambodia and Laos. [Page 1, Column 8.]

Joseph Paul, the chairman of the California Committee of Two Million, died last March, but his goal, to save the state's last free-flowing rivers from the dam-builders, was reached in late December when Gov. Ronald Reagan signed into law the California Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold substantial quantities of German marks in the foreign exchange market here yesterday, according to informed banking sources. The effect of the central bank's intervention - which, among other institutions, was conducted through the Marine Midland Bank - New York was to trigger a sharp technical rally in the dollar in relation to major European cur-rencies.

George Graff, who wrote the lyrics to "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling," died yesterday at a hospital in East Stroudsburg. He was 86 years old. Mr. Graff had written more than 400 songs, but "Irish Eyes" was by far the most successful and earned him about $10,000 a year in royalties until his death.
Bad weather in Texas prevented the three television networks from broadcasting the burial service for former President Lyndon B. Johnson in its entirety yesterday.
A student's film said to have offended President Tito "in an especially rude manner," has touched off an uproar in Yugoslavia's movie world.
Three-quarters of a century after his first significant works were written, Charles Ives continues to tickle the creative fancy of many composers.
East Germany's amnesty for criminals and political prisoners ended today, it was officially announced, with about 32,000 prisoners released since November.
Mayor Lindsay is seriously considering running for the United States Senate next year against the Republican incumbent, Jacob K. Javits.

The Republic Steel Corpora- rr tion reported yesterday 1972 sales of $1.6-billion, compared with $1.4-billion in 1971. Net income soared to $43.1-million, or $2.66 a share, from $136,452, or 1 cent a share, in 1971. The report said there was a $20.2-million provision for in come taxes in 1972 against a credit of $18.4-million a year earlier.

New Jersey Superior Court Judge Herman D. Michels in Newark ruled yesterday that the New Jersey-New York Waterfront Commission was entitled to look at airline cargo theft records. He denied a motion by American Airlines, Trans World Airlines, United Airlines, Eastern Airlines and Flying Tiger Line to bar access to the records to the commission.
The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that the object of the criminal justice system should be "the protection of society, not just the protection of the rights of the accused."
Mayor Lindsay is considering running for the United States Senate next year against the Republican incumbent, Jacob K. Javits. Although the Mayor has declined to comment on the matter publicly,

A panel of the National Advertising Review Board has found Kal Kan dog food advertising "permeated" with "false disparagement and unsubstantiated claims" against a competitor (Alpo), and although Kal Kan Foods disagrees with the findings it has agreed to "replace the specific advertisements and commercials."

A building that looks like a temple of efficient modernity-nine stories of glass walls enclosing a formidable computer and 4,000 masters and slaves to direct it and to do its bidding-has fallen victim to a modern illness that the French call "gigantisme."
Union and school board negotiators reached agreement today on terms for ending a strike that has closed the school system here since Jan. 10.

The hill country hospitality that marked Lyndon B. Johnson's political prominence was carried on by his widow today when she invited some of the mourners at the former President's funeral to join the Johnson family for sandwiches and conversation.

An employee shot and killed one of two holdup men who invaded a Harlem funeral parlor yesterday, the police reported. The incident occurred at 2 P.M., in Mickey's Funeral Home at 228 Lenox Avenue, near 122d Street.
Members of the State Bar Association toured the narcotics courts on the ninth floor of the Civil Court Building yesterday.

Senior Laotian Government officials said today that they understood there was a secret agreement between North Vietnam and the United States under which Hanoi would withdraw 60,000 of its troops from Laos and a lesser number from South Vietnam.
Spokesmen for Pan American World Airways and the British Aircraft Corporation denied yesterday a report that Pan American had decided against buying the Anglo-French supersonic Concorde airliner.
Two policemen--brothers assigned to the same radio car-were shot and wounded in a burst of automatic-weapon fire that tore into their vehicle in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn last night.

An Italian judge ruled today that a group of published pictures of Mrs. Jacqueline Onassis in the nude were not obscene. The judge ruled there was no case against the magazine Playmen, which published the 14 pictures in November, and reversed an order to confiscate the entire issue.

A Palestinian Arab was killed in an explosion in a Nicosia hotel room early today, apparently while handling a number of bombs, police sources said.

The oil industry turned in a mixed earnings pattern yesterday. The Phillips Petroleum and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported higher profits for both the final quarter and the year. Texaco, Inc., and the Marathon Oil Company announced higher last-quarter earnings but a decline in profit for the entire year.

Hatteras is exhibiting its all-new model, the 38 Flying Bridge Double Cabin. The new fiberglass luxury boat manufactured by A.M.F.-Hatteras Yachts, features a large flying bridge with seating for seven persons. J. B. Hargrave designed it.

George Pachano, a 49-yearold Cree Indian whose ancestors have roamed the wilderaess of northern Quebec for as long as anyone knows, is usually out in the bush at this time of year, trapping beavers and atters. But this winter he is spending much of his time in Monreal, 600 miles south of here,
Marvin D. Cristenfeld announced at Democratic headquarters here today his resignation as chairman of the Nassau Democratic County Committee.
The sniper fire that left six dead and 15 wounded in New Orleans early this month has again raised the question whether a national conspiracy exists among blacks to kill white policemen.

Communist military personnel will be flown to Saigon aboard American helicopters Sunday or Monday to join a cease-fire commission created by the Vietnam peace accord, a well-informed American source said yesterday.
The Charlotte, N. C., home of the father of a survivor of the slaying of seven Moslems here last week was robbed yesterday, the Charlotte. police have told policemen here.

Don McNeil opened a door and got shot the other day. Even for a policeman with a mystic belief in his own indestructibility, it was a close call. One minute he was investigating a reported fight between a father and son on the Upper West Side.

For probably the first time in its 63year history, the National Boat Show will have two openings, one tonight at 5 (sneakily called a "preview") and one tomorrow morning at 10 (with the Mayor cutting himself in). With a new managing director, it may be only the beginning of a host of new ideas.

Seniority is not yet a vanished custom in the House of Representatives, but the days are gone when a rebel Congressman like Morris Udall of Arizona could be charged with leading a "youth rebellion" at 47. The same myopic lineup of Arab and African nations that blocked forceful antiterrorist action at the United Nations last fall has re-formed at Montreal, together with the Russians and French, to obstruct efforts to put teeth into three existing antihijacking conventions.

Seton Hall and Fairleigh Dickinson, inexcusably, were beaten again in basketball this week. What was unexpected was that Rutgers lost to Lafayette in overtime, easily defeated Delaware and has been tagged the favorite over Columbia at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Seton Hall has also been picked to win over Georgetown.
A wage and benefit increase of 8.3 per cent for 33,000 employes of voluntary hospitals here has been reduced to 5.5 per cent, the Cost of Living Councill said in Washington yesterday.

COWPET BAY, St. Thomas --The sailing team had just returned from the Caribbean championships in St. Croix and was sitting around the patio of the St. Thomas Yacht Club here when the talk turned to the 1976 Olympics.

Elaine Comparone, a harpsichordist who made a brilliant debut here in 1970 and won further praise with a second New York recital in 1971, made her third local solo appearance on Tuesday night in the "Introductions" series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A Ford Foundation researcher said today that this winter's fuel shortages were a result of President Nixon's refusal to end oil import restrictions. He said that the shortages could be setting consumers up for higher prices.

Another hour of Burt Bacharach music, new and old, goes on television tonight over the American Broadcasting Company, with the effusive composer and his guests performing quite pleasantly while prancing around some leftover sets from a new movie,

A 76-ton ferry boat with more than 100 passengers aboard ran aground and sank in dense fog off the southwestern tip of Korea today. Rescue efforts suspended at nightfall after policemen had recovered 13 bodies.
Ethel Ennis was supposed to take her first sewing lesson last Wednesday night in her home town, Baltimore, but she had to miss it because she was in Philadelphia on the Mike Douglas television show.

With solemn words and music, this city paid a final tribute today to Lyndon Baines Johnson, the New Deal Congressman who became the 36th President of the United States. Lyndon Baines Johnson was buried today in a country graveyard on the northern bank of the Pedernales River. His coffin was lowered into the earth under an aged, twisted oak next to the graves of his mother and father on the former President's ranch.

The Long Island Lighting Company had earnings of $56.2.million, or $2.20 a share, last year compared with $50.2 million in 1971, the company reported yesterday. This represents the 20th year of increased earnings for the company.

Buying of holiday merchandise pushed chain-store sales in December to record levels, according to a survey by The New York Times. Twenty-nine leading chain organizations showed a sales gain of 16.3 1 per cent over December, 1971. The rise was the highest of the year, and the largest monthly gain on record.

Don McCafferty, who coached the Baltimore Colts to the Super Bowl championship two years ago, was named head coach of the Detroit Lions today. He received a three-year contract. Terms were not disclosed.
